summary: THIS BOOK WAS SO DEEP THAT I COULD NOT UNDERSTAND ANY OF IT.
reviewText: THIS BOOK BEING BY A NEUROSURGEON, IT WAS SO HARD TO UNDERSTAND. I WAS SO EXCITED ABOUT READING THIS BOOK. BUT WAS SO DEEP I COULD NOT UNDERSTAND IT. I GOT NOTHING OUT OF IT. WOULD NOT PASS IT ON.

I looked forward to reading this book as many reviewers gave it high marks. I don't see why.  The author spent about half the book providing details about his life and about half describing his NDE. While he described the visions he saw well  he answered virtually nothing regarding what questions of his were answered, why he was there, if he were judged and why or why not. There are a number of other books that are far better and more insightful. I'm not passing this book on to friends. I'll give it to the library instead.

Julia Bennett is the central character in this book.  She has lived with abuse all of her life with her alcoholic mother and her many boyfriends, and she is reliving it all over again with her fiancé Robert. Finally, one day after being abused she sees the light and decides to leave before her wedding and go to look for refuge with her Aunt Lydia, a woman who has tried to help her in the past.In living with Lydia, Julia also gets to know a group of women who will help her find herself and heal her soul and her body in the process. Unfortunately, for me, a lot of these characters were just too out there in regards to the psychic nights and the ability to find strength in their private body parts! I mean, who does that?! It's fun to be quirky but this was just a little too bizarre and kind of killed the story for me.Julia, of course manages to find love and her talent in the midst of some serious situations.While this book is indeed filled with warmth and love, I just could not get into the characters lives, thankfully so I guess since most of them are dealing with some very serious issues.  I wanted to like this book but in the end, I was just glad that it was over.

I was so excited when I heard about this book from a friend. I am fascinated with people that have had NDE's. I was especially interested since this man is a scientist and doctor and didn't believe it when his patients told him what they saw in their own NDE. I did read many of the reviews before I purchased the book so I was aware that the author did not detail a lot of his actual experience and what he saw in Heaven, but I was still very excited to read it. The author describes his experience in the Core, the Gateway and the realm of the earthworm's eye view. He did not explain what the Core or Gateway was. He used these words, but what exactly are they and where did he get those terms? He describes the first place he goes to as being in mud with blood and veins as if he were a worm in muck. That was confusing and strange. There was very little description or explanation of what he saw. I am glad to have read the book, happy that he is getting his message out, and I do believe him, but this book leaves the reader unsatisfied in my opinion. Anita Moorjani's "Dying To Be Me" was a better book for help from her heavenly visit. She gives more details and it is a better story all around.

I really applaud the author form his clever writing, but this book is just not what i wanted. If you are expecting a story about hiking the AT then its not that, you will have to skip to the story parts like i did. If you want a well written history about the AT and a description of the types of plants, trees and animals then that is what you have got! I prefer the juicy details about survival in these lone areas, otherwise i would just buy a geography book.

summary: Video VIXEN? Hmm, not the term I'd use :)
reviewText: Confessions of a Video Vixen is the story of Karrine Steffans a young woman who “struggles” to leave a life of abuse at the hands of her mother only to end up involved in a life of sex, drugs in the Hip Hop world.**Spoilers, sorry***I’ll lead in by saying that unlike some reviewers, I did not pay retail for the book I paid $3.00 at a garage sale, about what it was worth. I’ll also say that I’d heard little about the book when it came out because I’m truly not into videos or MTV, or television for that matter. I’m a writer, in fact, and I like to read different genres.Confessions of a Video Vixen is not a cautionary tale meant to deter women from the pitfalls of the entertainment industry. The book is simply a poorly written tell all’. The title of the book itself is a farce. Video Vixen? There were less than ten pages in entire book that referenced her video career and as far as the vixen part, well let’s just say that vixen would not be a word I’d use to describe Ms. Steffans.So many things disturbed me about Ms. Steffans’ story, everything from the abuse she sustained at the hands of her mother, to being raped, to running away, to exotic dancing at the age of seventeen; it sickened me. Then when she marries Kook G Rap her entire life became even more sordid and pitiable.There were also so many contradictions in this book, the main one being of course Ms. Steffans praying for a child so the child would make her better person and make her change her life. Right…Don’t let this story fool you into believing Ms. Steffans was a victim. This woman had every opportunity to make a career for herself, but instead she chose the easy life, have sex with famous people and get paid for it; the world’s oldest profession thrives!If I had to judge the first one third of the book, I’d say it was a 3.5 for her story of her childhood was compelling, as far as the rest of the book, it was a major letdown. I give Confessions of a Video Vixen two stars.

Though Bill Bryson has a very interesting and appealing writing style, I was disappointed with this book. He only hiked bits and pieces of the trail, mainly the southern end. The New Jersey and New York sections were neglected altogether, and he gave up on the section in Maine right after starting it. It is mainly a book about how he was unable or unwilling to hike the trail. I was hoping to get an experience of the entire trail  - and did not get that.  If I read another book about hiking the Appalachian Trail, I will make sure it is written by someone who actually hiked the entire trail.

Karrine Steffans tells the story of her abusive childhood, drug and alcohol addiction, and sexual relationships with various celebrities. All of this makes her story an entertaining read, but Steffans leaned on the explicit nature of her story to sell the book. The writing was mediocre at best, with chapters ending on awkward phrases and whole paragraphs in which the person she is talking to/about is unclear.I understand that Steffans felt that she had a specific message to get across to her readers and maybe stylistic writing was not her main focus. It seemed that she was more focused on simply telling the story rather than on the way the story is told. However, I felt that this decreased the impact of her story.I thought the last chapter and epilogue of the book were disappointing. The last chapter was contradictory, with Steffans saying how much she's changed but still regressing to her old ways with Usher. She justifies her behavior by saying she "felt free to be adventurous" with Usher because of their past relationship. She did walk out of Usher's hotel room, but it seemed like it was only after finding out he was with another woman next door. The ending of the last chapter made the epilogue weak.In the epilogue she says the difference in her lifestyle is that now she is her "own woman and looks for no one to complete her." There was nothing in the last chapter or the entire book that showed this change and frankly, I don't believe her.

Wow, didn't know I felt that way until I actually had to title my review.  For the life of me, I can't figure out how this book won a 2011 Reader's Favorite Award.  The main character, Molly, is beset with guilt over not stopping what she later found out was a kidnapping of a young girl.  Okay, so the premise is good.  From there it deteriorates, after a second kidnapping, into a kind of self-serving, poor-me kind of tale which as I said above is redundant, redundant.  I felt sorry for Molly's husband, as I was as sick of her and her activities as he seemed to be.  The characters were like people from a thirty minute Twilight Zone script, only not as well developed.  I'm laughing at this because it is such a great description.  At least I can entertain myself.  My recommendation is don't waste your time.  There are much better books available - thousands.

Just a bunch of rambling I felt like I was sitting in front of her while I was in the waiting room of the docters and she was one of those people who just had to tell you her life story... it would have taken 30 minutes for her to finish this rambling.

I purchased this book and begin reading, finding the first few chapters someone appealing, with some bit of laughable humor. After the first few chapters, I had to make myself finish this read. If your looking for the book to follow its title, then stop. If you want this book to be 10% title and 90% American History, then read it. Anyhow, how do you say that your walking the AT, and end up skipping over half of it and driving parts that you do say you are walking. I think that the author needs also to have a lesson in respect. Not everyone that he encounters can be stupid, ignorant, and should be made fun of.But then again, none of us will never understand his thinking of being much better, smarter, and wiser than the few people he did meet on his little walk. I found myself hoping through the last of the book that he would at least encounter his tremendous fear of " A bear in the woods". At least it would have maybe brought some delight to the reading, and who knows, with his apparent fear, he might have made it all the way across the AT......... running. The author could take a mighty lesson from Peter Jennings and his books.... A walk Across America.

summary: Glad I Got It on Sale!
reviewText: I had to force myself to read this novel to the end because I hate to start a book and not finish it.  Molly, the main character seemed to have no life and nothing to do all day long but run through the woods.  All of the characters were underdeveloped and I had no real sense of who these people really were. I found it impossible to feel any emotion for any of them or connect in any way. How the characters or story makes me feel, or how well I'm entertained is how I measure  whether or not a book is good.  The only chracter who had a tiny measure of personality was Molly's husband Cole and he came off as an absentee husband, a self centered whiner, and a jerk.  The plot was meandering, the characters all lacked depth, the suspense was low-level at best and at worst, completely non-existant. By the time I slogged through all of the side issues, I was bored and really didn't care any more 'who done it'.  I'm glad I got the book on sale for .99 cent.

summary: Chasing my wasted time back (SPOILER ALERT!)
reviewText: One would have to assume that if anyone gave this book, "Chasing Amanda," five stars they are not avid readers.  Foster committed the perfect crime by throwing a whole bunch of characters into a book, but not developing them fully, and by making the main character, Molly, a dysfunctional, "psychic" idiot who doesn't speak well for the world of clairvoyancy.  I have never disliked a main character so much in my life!  This book was selected for a book club; otherwise, I would have stopped reading it.  The entire book seems to have been written by someone with rampant ADHD who hasn't taken their medication--meaning the content was all over the place.  Our book club selected this book as a mystery, but it behooves me to say that Foster spills the beans on the guilty party pretty quickly, or I am used to reading thrillers and mysteries that leave me guessing.  Then you just follow along reading the insanity of all parties involved.  As a matter of fact, a pastor keeps a challenged child locked up in the house or cellar for twenty years because that's what the family wanted, and she finds two (2) other people ("friends") who are willing to assist her keep this child from society.  I can see why this book is print on demand and you have to pay for it first...

I could see when the author was trying to do character development, but it never quite felt genuine to me.  I never forgot that I was reading something someone wrote.  All the "danger" felt too contrived and was way too easily resolved.

The author claims that he traveled to the world of spirits and the worlds beyond our physical life in an NDE (near-death experience). He starts the book with scientific and logical/medical explanations of his medical case. Then delves deeper spiritually and attempts to convince us that he visited heaven - no evidence or support is presented. And the author never explains how he came back from this trip although he was about to die. So he contracted a weird illness (as he claims he dint know where it came from) then magically heals although medically it was impossible. Book is beautifully written but full of contradictions. Church goers will love this book. Not for people who believe in logic, science, and proven logical evidence.Yousef

This was a quick and interesting read, but the descriptions of him in 'heaven' were very short and the 'proof' was thin at best. Riding on a butterfly wing was more 'real' than reality? It sounds more like a bacteria-induced hallucination and, in fact, he also writes about long, drawn-out dream sequences that were also described as very 'real,' but then he says they were not quite as real as the heaven experiences.The closest proof or evidence: He recognized his long-deceased sister (whom he never saw in person since he was adopted) from a photo and then realized it was the person on the butterfly wing. This was persuasive, but not convincing. There just wasn't enough 'there' there.I expected more from a scientist.

summary: I don't like it...but these experiences are important to tell
reviewText: It was not what I expected and that is fine, but it does not resemble in any way other persons experiences.  There was a "rebuttal" written by a Christian minister and I'd recommend reading both to get a better perspective.  I guess we will not really know what heaven is like until we get there...and, hopefully, can stay.

I liked the first part of the book.  There were some very funny lines and I shared the excitement of setting out on the hike with the author.  But, as the author's committment to the hike faded, so did my committment to the  book. I leafed through the final half.The final line of the book is  "We didn't walk the 2,200 miles, it's true, but here's the thing: we  tried".  They didn't try very hard though.  In fact, they gave up  after looking at a map for the first time and seeing they weren't as far as  they had hoped.  Now I don't fault them for giving up - hiking 2,200 miles  is extremely difficult.  But don't come back and write a book about it.  I'd rather read about how someone made it.  The tone of the book is a sign  of the times - it doesn't matter what you actually accomplish, so long as  you have good intentions.Also, the author talked a lot about  environmental issues, but he just repeated all of the half-truisms espoused  by the popular press every day.  I don't feel that I learn anything by  reading one more layman's views on global warming, acid rain, etc.A big  disappointment, overall.

By now, most potential readers know the story. Two middle-aged guys, one of them (Katz!)completely out of shape in mind and body, decide to hike the Appalachian trail, from Georgia to Maine. The reader was suspect of the venture from the start, perhaps made so by the author's photo on the cover.  This is no athelete.  Full disclosure! They don't make it! They quit in Gatlinburg, TN. The author proceeds to make a series of negative comments about the area, which from this reader's personal experience are inappropriate, inaccurate and unfair.They try hiking the AT in sections, quitting again in VA, but only after Bryson takes several outrageous swipes at Confederate General Stonewall Jackson. The author is no Civil War historian (ie: Jackson and Robert E. Lee were in the Union Army at the time of the Harpers Ferry raid). The author sweeps dismissively through PA (it's a coal slag, you know), and skips NJ, NY and CT entirely. Bryson emerges in his native New England with smaller walks. Then the pathetic Katz resurfaces. They try to hike the Northern end of the AT in Maine, but surprise (!) they quit again. End of story.  I suspect strongly that Bryson backwardsly decided to write a book and then to hike the AT. Since he didn' make it, he had to use filler-lots of it. The result is a story that is satisfying in part but ultimately lacking. It would have been better if Bryson had completed a whole section of the AT, which he may have with the right partner, and stuck to writing about the outdoors. In so doing, he would have spared the good folks of Gatlinburg his "humor" and let Stonewall Jackson lay beneath the trees in peace.

summary: A Lot of Wasted Pages, even though I am so interested in the subject matter.
reviewText: Just finished this Book. . . I don't know what all of the hype was about on this book. It was almost like a scientific project for this neurologist to write.  The entire last 1/3 of the book was nothing but his index and thanking and acknowledgements to his friends, family and colleages. . . . page after page after page!!!  I would not recommend this book after reading it. . . I am so sorry I was so excited about it.  I am looking for really good books on NDE (near death experiences) and books about heaven.  I read one a few years ago by a Betty Eadie, which was much better than this one "Proof of Heaven".  It proves that Dr. Alexander can waste more pages in a book with his thank yous and index pages than of actual content of his "journey". I think the author missed a really good chance to give us all a better insight of details and what the hereafter was like for him.  Too much "big bang theory" and too little feeling for what lies ahead for us all.  A lot of scientific repetition and nothing for the reader to look forward to after the first half of the book.

Jack Coughlin may be a top-rnaked sniper but he lacks one of the main attributes usually associated with the trade... humility. He writes as though he is the only one that matters in a brutal war. He has none of the qualities of the top Marine shooters who are humble, self-effacing people like Ed Kugler, Eric England, and Carlos Hathcock. I've read all of these brave mens' biographies and they come across as thoughtful, talented men, who loved the Marine Corps and did their job, but weren't glory hounds and didn't enjoy killing. Coughlin should have spared us from his ego-centric bravado.

Too long...too repetitive...too much false suspence.  The book has potential but could have used a good editor.  In addition the Kindle formatting and digital errors were distracting.  i finished the book out of curiosity but cannot recommend.

This is only about 100 pages long, full of quotations, and leaps from point to point. It would have benefited very strongly from a good editor to help the author create a more coherent work, more worthy of the price. Some of the extreme suggestions and their justifications border on the absurd (e.g. don't have a bed and sleep in a sleeping bag on the floor because then you won't have the risk of falling out of bed). Unless you're a single ascetic this is probably not the book for you.

Yes bill bryson is a funny guy but always at somebody elses expense.  The guy seems to feel that the universe revolves around him and instead of showing reverence or at least respect for this american treasure that is the AT he finds most of his material from the people he encounters. Seems to me that this iowa born resident of new hampshire who has spent much of his adult life in england really doesn't care much for americans. Especially southerners. Much of the first half of this book involves his constant cracks about southern rednecks. Ok a few funny references to deliverence are acceptable but bryson doesn't stop there the cracks go on and on. Once he expressed his concern for running into "genetically challenged" people on the trail. Imagine if he wrote about hiking through harlem and used that term or wrote about hiking in an indian reservation and used that same term. Then bryson wouldn't be funny he would just be considered a bigot. Fact is mr bryson is an equal opportunity jerk because he doesn't like anybody. Almost everyone he encounters in this book has something wrong with them according to bryson. They are too stupid(everyone is stupid to him) too fat or speak the wrong way or drive the wrong vehicle.Now this isn't just a travel journal. Bryson tries to prove to us that he did his homework and really knows what he's talking about. Who cares. If you really want to know about hiking the appalachian trail there are hundreds of better books from people who have actually hiked the whole thing. If you want to know about the natural history of the appalachians you can also do much better. Bryson tries to tries to tie all these things together and for me it just doesn't work.
i was hoping to hear something new,  but it's the same old story. Naturally, if you want to go with that?
Too many times about his injuries and not nearly enough about heaven.Could have spent a LOT more time talking about what he saw and heard.

As a scientist, I actually have an open mind regarding the two oldest standing questions that have been asked since the dawn of humanity: is there a God and is there an afterlife?I am a physicist, and the one lesson that Relativity and Quantum Mechanics show is that the universe has a much richer structure than was assumed based on Newtonian physics.  I applaud Alexander for mentioning such in his book.  For example, in his description of heaven, he notes how time is different... in essence he was "everywhen".  This is consistent with the view of time as the 4th dimension and a being unconstrained by the 2nd Law of thermodynamics (entropy) which imposes a linearity of "before" and "after" in our experience of time.  Freed from this, one could experience time like space:  the "present" would be your location in time, but you could experience also all around you the past and future.Similarly, the possible role that consciousness plays in the physical world as indicated by quantum mechanics has been recognized for over 70 years now; and without a definite resolution.  See for example Schroedinger's book, "Mind and Matter", or the late John Wheeler's pronouncement that the is "is a participatory universe"Unfortunately, Alexander falls short in terms of how the book is presented as a "proof";  it does not add to the above literature on the deeper structure of reality.  Here are some my objections to his case:1) His heaven is remarkably anthropomorphic. Trees, waterfalls, butterflies, and puffy clouds??  Really? A bit cliched wouldn't you say. He mentions the vastness of the universe and other beings.  So my question is, to use a science fiction example, if you were from Vulcan or Klingon, would this be your idea of heaven?2) Who gets to experience this heaven?  The apes differ from us by only a few percent and certainly process information through their neocortex and are conscious beings.  Do they get to heaven?  Anyone who lives with a dog knows they are conscious and love; the coin of the realm in Alexander's heaven.  Do they get in?  Obviously trees get into heaven, but do mosquitoes?3) I read with great interest his Appendix B.  I understand when writing for a general audience the need to limit technical details, so I expected in the appendix to find the real meat of his argument of proof.  Sadly, there is none there.  He sets up a series of straw men and then knocks them down by only two arguments: "My experience was so rich that the physical trigger could not have worked." and if the trigger could have a possibility of working, then he resorts to "My neocortex was shut down".  He presents no hard medical evidence of his neocortex being totally non-functional.  He cites none of his actual medical tests in these arguments.  Also, the neocortex consists of billions of neurons.  None of these tests insure that every single one of these neurons were no longer firing.  I find it difficult to believe that there was absolutely zero activity yet somehow he makes a full recovery.4) There is one sentence where he mentions his past use of LSD.  LSD use results in flashbacks even years later.  Could the infections have simply caused such a flashback?  Of course, he would respond that his neocortex was shutdown, but as I mentioned before, he gives no hard evidence that this was measured in any definitive way.I was hoping for a much more technical, discussion of the NDE along with much more rigorous data.... after all that is how he is marketing the book.Finally, I would like nothing more than to believe his story.  NDE's could be another piece of data that contribute to our knowledge of the structure of reality.  This book does not do the case justice.

I hate writing this review, but I did not enjoy this book at all and I love Terri Osburn's other books. This was lacking...something. I found myself skimming the chapters. The cover made me giggle, it reminded me of a cookbook or orange juice commercial. I'm not a huge romance reader and it takes a lot to suck me in and this just didn't do it. I'm so bummed. But, I will always read Terri Osburn's books, this one just didn't do it for me.

I was hoping for so much more when I purchased this book. I should have read all the feedback before plunking $8 toward this book. It is really painful to get through as the author drones on about his experience. I know this type of book isn't meant for entertainment, but at least make it engaging to your audience. I'm gave up on the book; I'd rather enjoy my life than have to worry about what the afterlife will be like.  I ended up switching to fiction.

I was really looking forward to reading this book but just about gave up on it in the first chapters.  There was way too much about the writer's education in the beginning and boring technical jargon close to the end.  I wanted him to TRY to describe what he saw instead of saying it couldn't be described.  I enjoyed the parts about his biological family...especially his sister...but wouldn't recommend the book to anyone.  Sorry
I like this type of work, but this book just didn't seem to ring true.  To me, it was almost boring even though I believe in the afterlife very much

I would not recommend this book to a Christian without the Rebuttal to Eben Alexander's Proof of Heaven,by Robert Alan King.This is not a Christian book but probably was never intended to be.I think it could confuse weak faithed Christians.

An interesting report of his own near death experience which leads him to investigate the phenomenon.  His approach is narrow in that he assumes his unique experience is universal.  There are thousands of years of reported phenomena of our brains that support an experience that cannot be explained by neuro-science.

I read this book at our son's suggestion.  I talked with him last night and I told him that I really thought his view of the afterlife was unscriptural.  The three spheres that he mentioned:  the Realm of the Earthworm's Eye View, the Gateway, and the Core, I'm sure would be interpreted by some Christians as hell and heaven.  However, his comment of the Earthworm's Eye View as "a not entirely pleasant, but no doubt necessary, part of the cosmos" doesn't begin to describe the terrors of hell and its everlasting torment.  He said he received "the knowledge that  nothing can tear us from God, ever."  However, that's what hell is--an absolute separation from God.  I certainly loved that he met his "angel" who was his biological sister on earth ( a sister he had never met).  I understand that he was amazed at learning there is an afterlife and a God who loves him, and I rejoiced with him over that discovery.  I guess it didn't mean as much to me that he was reconciling his teaching as a neuroscientist with the reality of an afterlife.

Not recommended. There are just too many better books out there. The plot is convoluted and contrived. The characters are so poorly drawn that i thought two of them were the same person for most of the book and didn't care much when I realized my mistake.

Although it mostly kept my interest, it was not the "vampire saga", that I had expected it to be and for that I was disappointed. It really was a bit far-fetched, but then again I suppose that's what fantasy is all about...don't know if I care to read anymore from this author?

Bryson is a good quick study and we can well imagine he wrote great book reports in elementary school, BUT a naturalist and dedicated hiker he is not. Clearly, he saw an idea to write a book and took advantage of it by walking only one long stretch of the Appalachian Trail accompanied by an overweight, barely-in-recovery, boorish friend, Steve Katz.Bryson can snobbishly condescend when addressing how Americans transgress against nature, but does nothing when Katz TWICE empties the contents of his backpack along the trail. Middle age male self-deprecation has never held much interest to me, so I found little humor in the difficulties Bryson faces due to unpreparedness and sheer sloth.Something in Bryson's ego, and perhaps lack of determination, prevented him from inviting as a companion a true nature expert...the insights and observations of a birder or botanist would have made the book a lot more immediate and informative - but perhaps such a pairing would have forced Bryson to have walked the entire trail!
I found this book very vague.  As a Christian, a lot of it didn't really make much sense.  It sounds like more of a drug induced fantasy to me.

summary: One More Subjective NDE Story - Intriguing, Yes; Proof, No
reviewText: There is much to suggest NDEs are real, from experiencers "seeing" physical things they couldn't observe from where their bodies were lying, such as objects atop tall cabinets, to encounters with relations they didn't learn about until afterwards.None of those things are in this book.In fact, all the confounding aspects of the NDE phenomenon are here. Absence of science; uniquely subjective experiences that don't jibe with others' testimony; lack of detail about the structure, mechanics, and purpose of the "next world."Unlike most NDEers, Dr. Alexander gets no tunnel of light, nor life review, nor encounters with loved ones who have already crossed over. He perceives an extended flying journey over a richly colorful landscape -- something his subconscious dream factory might be likely to conjure, given his history of skydiving. Do all NDEers go to differently designed environments, or does each NDEer create his or her own?Dr. Alexander insists his physical brain could not have created his experience, but is maddeningly short of medical reasons why. He keeps saying his cerebral cortex was "offline," "shut down," etc. But that's pretty colloquial terminology, and at any rate most neurologists would tell you the brain delivers unexpected abilities and functions all the time.Dr. Alexander writes giddily about the huge stores of knowledge he acquired during his experience, but keeps most of it to himself. Only wisps and hints emerge. His post-recovery research is half a tour of old ground (as he discovers the 40-year-old research of Moody and Ring), half cribbed from pop summaries of quantum physics. Toward the end of the book, scientific method goes out the window. During his experience Dr. Alexander perceived a beautiful young woman flying alongside him, acting as a guide. He did not recognize her. Later he is given a photo of a deceased, previously unknown sibling, and decides that's who his guide had been -- an example of retroactive rationalization / evidence-tailoring that would shame any sophomore scientist.Despite the book's title, from a hard scientific perspective Dr. Alexander delivers no proof, any more than a UFO contactee with a vivid story to tell provides "proof" of UFOs. Ironically, in fact, Dr. Alexander's experience will bolster the skeptics' view that NDEs are locally manufactured hallucinations. There are many more convincing, hard-to-dismiss NDE stories to hear.

Dr. Alexander'sProof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlifemakes the claim that, as a trained neurosurgeon, he is uniquely qualified to judge the truth of his near death experience.  Alas, there is nothing in this book that supports this claim.  Oddly enough, the "place" that he travels to while in a coma does not seem to be heaven nor does he meet the classical Christian God.  Nevertheless, he somehow believes that his experiences support both the idea of heaven and of god.This uncritical approach to his dramatic experience is prevalent throughout the book.  For example, his one paragraph "solution" to the problem of free will is embarrassingly sophomoric and reflects the level of insight that he brings to the other topics in this book.I give much credit to Ptolemy Tompkins, the "ghost author" of this book, who turned the doctor's notes and verbal descriptions into a very readable book.

I think he spent 80% of the content of the book explaining who he was and his beliefs and just a small amount of time on the actual near deah experience story which was what I was interested in. You can read both apendixes of the book and thats it, that's the full summary, no need to go through the whole book.

This is another book that I deleted from my Kindle because of foul language.  I really hate that...especially when the story is just getting good. I actually enjoyed how this book started out right away and I was ready to keep on reading, until it began introducing some crude language. I can tolerate some typical swear-words, like "d..." and "h...", but when it becomes vulgar, it turns me off right away. This may have been a good read, otherwise. Unfortunately I can't give it a better rating, since I won't finish it. Some people, who aren't bothered by "bad" language, may love the book. Everyone is different and I'm not judging. It just didn't work for me.

The author is a practicing medical doctor, who contracted e-coli meningitis, which is said to be very rare for adults in the U. S.  As a result of the illness, he was comatose for a few days.  “Proof of Heaven” is a detailed account of the period while he was hospitalized.Did the author describe a journey to heaven or a dream induced by severe illness and effects of various medications on the human brain?  There is no doubt the author was extremely ill and not expected to survive.  While the existence of heaven is not embraced by all, some will find this writing indisputable proof that heaven exists.  Skeptics will view it as the fevered ramblings of a very ill and heavily sedated individual at death’s door.After publication the book was highly publicized. It is disappointing because it is essentially a medical case history of the author’s illness and descriptions of family and relationships.  The vision of heaven is mentioned and described only twice—once early in the book and at the end.  The medical aspects outweigh the proof of heaven.It has a bibliography on the subject of near-death experiences. It is speculative, though, how the bibliography in any way either elaborates or authenticates the author’s experience.

summary: Waste of time, Too much confusion,
reviewerName: Sadie Blake "Yankee, but really a Rebel"
reviewText: Actually, I did not care for it, but once I started, felt obligated to give the story a chance.  Where were the proof readers?

I wanted to like this book.  The description, the award, the positive reviews all helped me decide to read it. I think I got it as a free download, as I usually don't pay for Kindle books by authors who are new to me.  I certainly did not pay more than 99 cents.  For that, I am grateful.  I also am learning not to be fooled by the 4 and 5 star reviews, since there are marketing firms who will provide glowing reviews for books as part of a paid service.  I don't like to use negative reviews either because some people just are not happy...some of the negative reviews here are from people who clearly did not read the entire book and made assumptions about the ending that were untrue.  Sadly, reviews online are somewhat undependable.  That said:The first few paragraphs alerted me to the fact that I probably would not like the book, based on the style the author used to introduce the main character.  Regardless, the subject interested me enough; I wanted to finish what I started.  (Alert: some spoilers below)The Good:1.  The best part was being surprised by the ending.  I did not see it coming. I hate figuring out the "whodunnit" early on.2.  I was interested enough, in spite of the bad writing, to continue and read to the end.3.  The idea for the story was good.  Any book that keeps me till the end deserves 2 stars.\4.  It was NOT the worst book I ever read.  I don't even want a refund for my dollar or time spent reading it.  It was slightly less than OK, but  certainly not "awful."The Bad:1. All of the characters were indeed one-dimensional and none of them were particularly likable.2. The dialogue between Molly and her son Erik was weird and seemed phony.3. The marriage between Molly and Cole was shallow and lame.4. There were way too many subplots that did nothing to enhance the story and only served to confuse.The Ugly:1. There are way too many psychics in this story.2. References to Hannah's ex-husband Charlie are dead ends that go nowhere. Why in the world should she be afraid of him? He left her 20+ years ago.3. How can it be possible for the pastor to hide not one, but two mentally challenged adult men in this small town without being discovered?  Where did Rodney live? How could *anyone* think keeping a mentally challenged man locked all alone in an old cellar of an abandoned old house was the humane thing to do? Furthermore, what would compel Pastor Lett to stay in such a town after such cruelty was meted out on her disabled brother?4. Why were there ghosts seen by the pastor in the Perkinson house?  What did the dollhouse have to do with anything?  This was never fully developed and was a distraction rather than an addition to the story.5. Rodney's and the Korean couple's speech was extremely annoying.6. Attempts at humor failed miserably (i.e. Edie coming to meet Molly dressed in a trench coat and sunglasses...a completey worthless scene all in all.)7. There were several plot points that should have revealed something new but merely rehashed what was already suspected or discussed.8. Who took Kate? What happened to her? Where did she come from? When did she die?9. How did Kate manage to live in the same little town undetected for all those years? How did she get food and clothing?  It is unbelievable that she could be that close to home.  This would have been more believable had she been taken far from her home and held hostage....10. At the end there is a sudden mention of "two bodies" which were the wife and daughter of Walter Meeks....a character I had to find using Kindle search...briefly mentioned partway through the book almost as an aside.  There was no mention (that I remembered or could find using the search feature) of finding those two bodies earlier...and it was very suddenly revealed who beat up Rodney.  The old men were arrested, but on what evidence?  Were they also suspects in killing the Meeks family?11. There are too many unanswered and unexplained points to this story.I could pick apart the entire book but this is sufficient.
the first half moved too slow and was boring.  the last half got good and I enjoyed it.  too much wedding carp in theorist half.

I read this out of sheer curiosity with a very open mind. The book is nothing more than an attempt on the authors part to legitimize and validate the oldest profession in the world. It is inconceivable to me how a woman can "fall in love" with EVERY man that gives her some money for sexual favors. She plays the victim. How many women have been sexually assaulted, raped, and otherwise violated never resort to a "tell all book." She is in fact pimping us with her nonsense throwing around a few famous names. She got PLAYED AND PAID!!!Most men do not pay for sex, then support the prostitutes they frequent.  Don't waste your money. 5 Stars to her "editor" for making this indeed readable because it is doubtful all Karrine can do is what she is "famous" for. She is an  admitted drop-out and illiterate lady of the evening.

I'm all for a good tell all, but this book reads like an attempt to tattle tale.  The names are dropped without purpose and at the end of every mini story, she looks foolish and played.  I thought this book was about how she took the music world by storm as a video vixen and became caught up in sec, lies, and video.  But it isn't that at all.  This book should be called "How I Got Played Over and Over Again."  She mentioned giving advice to young girls in the end of the book.  I can't imagine my daughter coming to me and saying she's been receiving advice from "Superhead!"  In short, this was a weird read because much of the content felt as if she were writing to the wives of those who used her out of bitterness.  However , there were a couple of details I found interesting and laughable about some of the celebrities we know and love.  I gave two stars for those couple of details alone.

This story and Dr. Alexander's belief in the reality of his near death experience is interesting; but quite deceptive. Having read a great many accounts of the near death phenomenon, I was rather put off by his use of the title: "Proof of Heaven." He offered no such thing, and now I see he has tried to escape responsibility for it. I doubt he is trying to escape from the royalties this extra bit of puffing has provided him.Without a shred of empirical evidence to give credence to his account, the fact that he is a neurosurgeon provides us with no more basis to believe than if he were a carpenter. The most logical conclusion one can make from his account is that the infection that almost killed him also caused extensive brain damage. He admits as much, and that alone could account for his visit to heaven.I did not give this a rating of one because it was quite well written. I got my money's worth. Did he do that himself?

This book was disappointing in several aspects.  It is certainly not a spiritually enlightening story and, in my estimation, was written in a manner to impress the reader with the author's intelligence and background.  Not a book I would recommend to anyone seeking a reassurance of the existence of heaven.
Wasn't very impressed by this read. Just because he is a neurosurgeon doesn't prove this happened to him.  I have read several life after death books and this is not one of my favorites.

Not really believable, and author's logic in assessing his own condition falls short. This doc nails the physiological portion but that's all. Says his brain wasn't functional, therefore the experience he had while comatose could not possibly have been a caused by a chemical response due to traumatic brain injury or pending brain death.  But the mere fact that his brain wasn't fatally injured meant it still had some functionality remaining; therefor it could indeed have been a brain chemical released in the process of brain injury or impending death. It wasn't dead; it revived, which proves it wasn't dead.His experience sounded a lot different from the spiritual experiences of the majority of those having near-death-experiences. It sounded much like a delusion or hallucination. The spiritual aspect of his NDE seemed lacking, and he seemed perhaps not quite as sincere as one might expect after such a profound revelation and encounter.His life sounds lovely (all those creature comforts). Maybe he experienced that earthworm/amoeba state because he had yet to learn humility. Or maybe everyone's death process is unique, and his was just customized to fit his particular consciousness.Guess we'll all find out, someday...

The book started out interesting but it didn't move along very fast. It finally held my interest the last quarter. The middle half was boring for me. I haven't read this author before so maybe it was just not their best work.

I'm giving this book 2 stars because that's pretty close to the amount of the trail he actually hiked (and hated, if I remember correctly, because he only liked Virginia and the bulk of what he hiked was the southern part of the trail). And if the book isn't about hiking (and smoking and littering along a wilderness trail), but about rediscovering America, then he gets two stars as well. After reading this book, I would believe that Americans (especially those living in the South), are inbred, stupid and have incredibly ugly towns. He is at once arrogant and narrow-minded, somehow believing that he is the only intelligent being on the planet.I liked the first half and even laughed out loud, but it became increasingly tedious (much like hiking the trail according to him- I would have liked to drop out of his narrative like he dropped off the trail)... and it's not about hiking the AT, nor is it a fair representation of America.

I bought this book with high hopes. I groaned at the bravado of the opening sentence. I had thought that snipers were self-effacing, quiet, unassuming types, not chest beaters like these guys, but who knows? I had anticipated a rapid narrative but around page 80 boredom set in, and then I ran across this chapter-opening sentence: "There's nothing like a good war to get your adrenaline pumping." Or a good cigar. "And giant butterflies were bumping around in my stomach." Who edits these books at St. Martin's, a monkey? I read that last sentence while waiting in line at the DMV, and I stepped out of line and dumped the book in the trash. Nothing a sniper or a marine can say to my mind can overcome this kind of hacking at the language.

I couldn't wait to finish this book and it seemed as if it took me forever to do so!I'm not sure why but it was very confusing to follow - I would have loved to just put it down and go on to a better book,but I was compelled to find out who did it.  Of course it was who I had suspected all along.My best advise - don't waste your time.
Interesting read. I loved reading about a scientist finding God. The frequent scientific and medical terms proved more boring than informational though.

Not sure what I was expecting but this book was just a little too "out there" for me.  I realize he is documenting his experience as it occurred but it could not hold my interest.  I never finished the book which is rare for me.

The main character in this poorly written story is the type of person I try to avoid in my personal life.  She was all over the map, obsessive, unreasonable, self-centered, continuously ignoring advise from family and friends, contaminating crime scenes, and putting herself in danger without ever considering the consequences.  The premise of the story was good, but I couldn't overcome my dislike for the main character.  I won't buy from this author again.
gave me into an insight that I always thought existed that there is something out there that we know nothing about

Interesting story set in a tiny community where everyone knows each other gives a warm homey feeling. I read this book out of order (it is third in a series), but it was easy to jump right in. The author has a wonderful writing style that easily allows the mind to escape into her story.  I enjoyed this very much.

The author does not, in my view, provide enough information on his after-life or NDE experience. For every page about it there must be another 15 pages of autobiographical info, most of which is irrelevant to the theme of the book. Surely he could have described his NDE experiences, that did after all last almost a week, in more detail?

It was an ok book. It was a mystery and did have twists and turns. I just thought there was a lot of fluff to make it a longer book when it really could have been shorter and said the same thing. I liked it though. Was worth the read.
Interesting story and proof of faith and healing but too heavy on the techical and medical side and would like less.
Good, but compared to some of Bill's other books, it didn't excite. Perhaps if I lived along the trail ........

If you are into hiking OR the Appalachian Trail, this book might not be for you. Maybe the title should have been "my summer of 1997". The author offers some interesting historical facts, throws some personal opinion (quite uninformed in some cases), and that's about it. Do not expect a descriptive narrative of, well, nothing in particular. Hiking etiquette? No, thanks. How he managed to write 280 pages is pretty incredible. By page 180, I was counting down the pages like my kids do with their reading homework.As some others have mentioned; the first 40 pages are very funny; then he moves into the trail and for some pages he kept my interest; but suddenly he takes a summer break. That's when the book goes from a hiking narrative to some confusing story telling. The summer day hikes are a complete disappointment (not only for you, Mr. Bryson), and finally he returns with his companion Katz for the long 10 day Maine section; but quits after 2 days.Maybe reading the well organized, emotional, and coherent "Hiking Through" by Paul Stutzman a week earlier set my expectations at a different level.Conclusion: glad I got it from the library.
This is a book for a young woman, maybe on vacation, or maybe a beach read.  If that is your description, this is your book.
Light summer reading, plot fairly predictable but enjoyable nonetheless.  Not something I would have purchased, but glad I could check it out from the library.
Fast read and enjoyable. Very predictable though which is expected with a romance novel. Will probably read the other books by Terri Osburn. I enjoy this type of reading for relaxation.

I really thought this book was going to be good, but the editors certainly didn't assist the author as they should. Too many repeated paragraphs and missed ends of sentences. Just couldn't keep the story flowing.

This was the first book I read about the AT.  It did start off funny, since I am an older person and can relate to their pain, etc.  BUT I was very disapointed that they quit the trail.  I probably would not have bought the book if I had known that.  Bryson also made alot of rude remarks about Southerners and pretty much everyone he encountered, it's funny up to a point but became cruel. I get the impression he is your typical windbag elitist liberal who looks down on everyone unless they reach his intellectual or educational standards. NO THANKS! I wish I had bought this second hand so he didn't get any of my "blue collar" money.Since this, I have read books by AWOL, Skywalker and currently reading Becoming Odyessa-people who actually finish the AT, and I fond their stories much more entertaining and real.
This book was definitely interesting, but there were parts of t that were just too convoluted to make any sense out of.
Good but to much medical talk in book and explenations.This book is to detailed of the problem he had and it gets boring.

summary: Exciting and Boring at the Same Time!
reviewText: While I loved the overall messages contained within "Proof of Heaven," I found the author's voice to be rather dry and monotone throughout the book which made his bright light experience seem dim and dull to this reader.  I appreciated Alexander's candor in retelling his near death experience; however, I felt that his underdeveloped storytelling skills stopped this from reaching its full potential.  Overall, an below average to average book with an extraordinary experience attached.
Fast read... not quite so sure about his voyage -- guess I'll have to wait until I make the trip myself...
Interesting read. Reading is worthwhile. Will give you a lot to think about. I still wonder about Dr. Alexander's ability to remember his experiences.

I was immediately engaged in this book, the first of Mr. Bryson's that I read.  The first 50 or so pages are GREAT, and man, I was so looking forward to the Great Walk.  Then ... (sorry for the pun)... Mr. Bryson lost his way.  The book became increasingly monotone, boring, and almost lame.  What a let down!  I'd be up for "A Walk in the Woods II", if Mr. Bryson could see his way to keep on the path.

I have read several books about near death experiences. This book is written by a neurosurgeon and he writes like I would expect a scientist to write..somewhat dry but certainly believable. His experience is amazing and the condition he had is downright scary.  I am glad I read it. It supports the fact there is life after life. I purchased this book  using my Amazon acct. and read it on my kindle. Love that electronic tablet and love using Amazon!
Boring except the last 20 pages.  Written by an amateur.  Old topic and no much added.  Not worth saying anything more
This book was boring.  I'm a strong Christian but this was really slow reading.  I kept waiting for it to pick up, but found it very slow.

summary: There are no bears in this book!
reviewText: Don't be fooled by the bear peeking out from the bottom of the cover of this book, like I was, and think you're going to read about an adventurous bear encounter somewhere in this book. You never will! There are no bloody bears in this book! I found the book to be a fairly enjoyable read, but not really what I had hoped for (maybe something more action packed). I also thought it kind of lost steam in the second half and had somewhat of a let down of an ending. Plus, there was some harsh language I wasn't expecting. It wasn't a waste of time to read, but it wasn't the most satisfying experience.Most of all, I was mournful of the lack of a bear. Just look at the cover and make up a story in your head when you get to feeling that way.Edit: For all of the people who are dissing this review, you KNOW you wanted to see a bear in the novel too!

Lately, I've read quite a few modern YA updates of Shakespeare's work.  Usually, I enjoy them tremendously.  I like the way they bring the stories into modern times, without losing the basics of the original.I could have done without this one.Now, it's well written.  The author is gifted with words and can tell a beautiful tale, even when talking about not so beautiful things.My main issue - the main thing I didn't like about this - was Ophelia herself.  I don't like doormat characters.  I don't like characters who accept any sort of abuse - physical, mental, or sexual - as proof of love.  I can see why the author made the choices she did, but I have difficulty empathizing with her characters.This one won't be re-read.

summary: No doubt about it: She CONFESSED.
reviewText: Poorly written novels irritate me greatly.  Based on the life Karrine lived and the way she reacted to certain situations informs the reader that she isn't the most intelligent woman alive, but she did have Karen Hunter aid her with this book, so between the two of them, someone should have known how to write a decent book.  However, in this instance, the poor vernacular isn't the most imperative issue here.  What truly matters here is the fact that she was so unapologetically honest about many of today's hottest male celebrities.  She was sexually involved with superstars such as Ray-J, Kool G Rap, Ja Rule, DMX, Jay Z, Shaquille O'Neal, Ice-T and Diddy.  She was seemingly honest about her liaisons with these men, many of whom are married.Karrine was able to get doors opened for her because of her good looks and amazing sexual expertise.  In this book, she makes it clear that she has no love for her mother because her mother was not there for her.  This may or may not serve as a contributing factor to why Karrine was so free with her body.  She began her "career" as a dancer in hip-hop music videos.  This opened doors for her; she was able to get into concerts and VIP at clubs.  In the book, Karrine doesn't necessarily glorify the finer things in life, but one can easily imply that she enjoys them a great deal.  She is very candid about her abusive relationship with rapper Kool G Rap and the fact that she was homeless.  Before the book ends, she becomes a bit preachy and lets girls know that they should want more for themselves than to be a man's whore.I truly enjoyed reading the book.  It was difficult to put down once I became engrossed into it.  If you can look past the poor writing, this book should be at least a little enjoying and/or intriguing.

A lot of the book dwelt on the author's past growing up.  I had to get through that to get to the experiences mentioned in the title.  I understand the difficulty in explaining what he saw in terms we could understand.  But it took a lot of reading to get there.

summary: Sound like an experience I had with an anesthesia
reviewText: Many years ago, in 1976, I required a surgical procedure and because I was and still am allergic to most anesthesia, the doctor used a drug called ketalar ? or ketamine, which puts you out but also causes hallucinations as you are coming out of it - and these last for several hours, but it was considered a safer alternative to the anesthesia of the day. Fast Forward...When I read this book (bought it at Cosco while shopping with my sister who recommended I read it )what struck me was,"Where have I heard/seen/experienced these same sensations or realities that makes them so familiar?" Then I remembered my surgical experience of almost 40 years ago. After the surgery I asked my doctor about what I experienced (as it had all the components the author described) and he said they were not unusual for that drug. Does Dr. Eben's experience or my experience prove heaven exists - I don't think so - but it does prove how creative the brain is under the influence of chemicals.What I mostly noticed about this book was how well he could remember such details of everything, including what his friends, family, wife, and children all felt and experienced. Why aren't there more testimonials from physicians, nurses and others who attended to his near-death experience? I enjoy the topic so I gave it an O.K. rating, but as someone else said "Heaven sells" - so this was a slam dunk best seller from the gate - but how credible it is, only time will tell.

I have entitled this review "Colander" because, as a "Proof" of heaven, it is full of holes.  Even allowing for the American language in which it is written (It is not quite English) there was only a very short passage that was worth reading.  I have to confess that I gave up about three quarters of the way through.  Like your writer, I was brought up an Anglican, in a keenly active medical family - and spent my life as a clergyman. I prefer to say no more.

summary: Interesting recollections despite a non-functioning cerebral cortex
reviewText: A previously skeptical neurosurgeon is convinced of his journey into heaven after becoming decorticate  by a rareand devastating meningitis. Despite detailed recollections the premise remains somewhat unconvincing.

summary: Great Subject, Tough to Get Into
reviewText: I was hoping for more from this book, after listening to a wonderful TV interview with the author.  Parts of it were extremely intriguing, but the descriptions were difficult to understand - not the medical part but the spiritual part.  For me, it got kind of bogged down and a bit repetitious without increasing the understanding of the subject

I've read several books on NDEs. With the ambitious title *Proof* of Heaven and the quotes on Amazon from Ray Moody and Pim Van Lommel and the fact that it was written by a neurosurgeon, this book set very high expectations.  I've been around the block enough times to suspect that the use of the word "Proof" in the title was hyperbole, just like when I read Karen Armstrong's "Proof" of God.  Again, I was right.  There's no proof of anything in this book.  It it well written although short.  It's a very quick read and it drew me in right away.  There is quite a bit about Eben Alexander's life before the NDE and that is quite interesting.  Almost as fascinating as the NDE itself is the fact that he contracted the type of meningitis he did (a 1 in 10 million chance) and that he survived the type of brain trauma he experienced as a result. The fact that the guy is upright walking around and talking is a miracle. So, you could say there are three miracles that happened to him that week.As another reviewer noted, I was left wanting more of the NDE itself.  Dr. Alexander talks of great insights he received while unconscious in our world.  But, what he gives us in the book are generalities that most NDE experiencers seem to bring back. Those being that we are all greatly and unconditionally loved and there is a purpose to all of this madness.  One of the unusual things about his NDE is, while in that state, he has no recollection of Earth.  I had a friend a few years ago who had two Out of Body Experiences that sound very similar to Dr. Alexander's.  He talked of places like the Core and the Gateway (mentioned in the book) and of being in a state where he had no language, no real thoughts and was just experiencing things.  I haven't heard any other NDErs describe things that way.Overall, the book is good.  But, if you're looking for "proof" of heaven, I'm afraid you'll have to keep looking. I've read of other NDEs where the person experiencing them, who should have no knowledge of what is going on on Earth, has been able to describe things he could not possibly know.  There's no such proof in Dr. Alexander's experience.  Dr. Alexander tries to explain why his experience couldn't have been produced by his brain.  But, while I believe him, I don't think he proves beyond any doubt that it could not have been created as he was coming out of the coma.  We've all had dreams where seconds in that dream state seem like minutes or even days.
I enjoyed this book but found he repeated alot of the medical jargon which was not important to me. Loved his description of his visit to heaven. Takes a lot of the fear of death away.

summary: Some people can write about anything
reviewText: If this is a best seller, and it seems to be, I don't know why.  Sure it had its moments, but I thought I was going to read a book about a person who walked the whole Appalacian trail and his adventures and insights.  Instead it was about an out-of-shape writer, and his more out-of-shape  friend suffering for no apparent reason, except perhaps to use as material  for a book to bring in some money.  It's no wonder they are so out of  shape, with a diet of noodles and snickers, who wouldn't be!  The first  half of the book was amusing, and somewhat funny, thanks to the antics of  the side-kick, Stephen Katz.  But once they left the trail, returned home,  and Bryson comes out for a series of day hikes, I wanted the book to end as  badly as Bryson wanted the trail to end.  I mean, the only animals they  saw were two pairs of eyes, never identified, and a moose, which was worth  mentioning, but so much talk about what they could have seen!  Also, there  is much historical and statistical data, but oddly enough, no bibliography,  just a suggested reading list.  The statistics are sometimes interesting  and often too much, just fill to make the contents of a book to sell. I  also can't understand how Bryson's family tolerated his absence, as his  approach seemed very childish.  But such walks seem to bring in the bacon  for the author.

summary: Proof of heaven or proof of greed ...
reviewText: Very interesting experience with some unique differences than other NDE (Near Death Experience) narratives.  The author is certainly passionate about getting his message out and this is conveyed to the reader.  My beef is that the narrative is surprisingly short for a "book" (165 pages) and followed closely by a sequel, "Map of Heaven" which I have yet to investigate.  I can only assume by the title that it is a further exploration/milking of the same experience.  I resented it and felt short-changed even though my copy was borrowed.  The commercialization of his "message" detracts it big time.

This is a very controversial subject. One has to read it for themselves and decide. The medical diagnoses are well conveyed and therefore, help you to understand what occurred and ultimately led Eben Alexander on his journey. There were accounts of Dr. Alexander's family life and other non-pertinent experiences in the reading, which I sometimes felt he talked about too much, rather than keeping with his journey to Heaven. That was my only particular criticism of the book. I otherwise found it well done.
Although I understood the medical terminology and physiology of his experience, his explanation was too scientific and did not leave room for faith.
well for me it was just a review of everything I already know, but it was a good reminder.  it would be great for someone newer to metaphysical studies.

My parents raved about this book for years, and so I finally decided to pick it up to see what all the fuss was about. A Walk in the Woods chronicles the misadventures of the author, Bill Bryson and his trusty sidekick, Katz (who apparently appears in other novels of Bryson's, as well), as they embark on an epic quest to hike the entire length of the Appalachian Trail.This book has its charm, and the writing is very smart. I had a few laugh out loud moments. However, when it becomes apparent well before book's end that the author will not even attempt to reach the end of the AT, my interest started to wane. This should have been foreshadowed well before this point, but I digress.The interactions between the characters and some of those they encounter along the way were enough to get me started, but not enough to keep that fire lit. Where the book goes wrong, is it's incessant need to teach the reader copious amounts of history on points Bryson finds to be fascinating, but the reader may not. Additionally, I was disheartened to learn that both Bryson and Katz made frequent side trips by car, hitch hiked, and partook of many other modern conveniences that cheapened the reading experience.I was looking for a hilarious and interesting, possibly enlightening journey, sprinkled with adventure and comedy, and what I got was a classic bore. I would pass on this book if you're not a history buff, or if you have a short attention span.

summary: Some parts are stronger than others - understandably.
reviewText: I am heartened, encouraged and a whole bunch of other positive feelings because he wrote this down. Faith is, for me, indescribable.  I'm a believer, but I've never been able to tell anyone how I just KNOW there's a God.  But hope, that's something we can all relate to, when we have it and when there's an absence of it.  For me, having a scientist agree with both faith and hope was more than uplifting.His descriptions of the medical parts resonated for me more strongly than his descriptions of his actual out-of-body experiences.  I realize that he was brave for even trying to put down in words feelings and intangibles. I'm glad he wrote this, but, as with most stories I've read about people going toward the light and the calm and the serenity that comes as the spirit departs the body, I think it's almost too specific to that one person for me to enter into it with him.What I take away is assurance that such states exist, that this scientist cared enough, believed enough to tell us about it. The book is strong and memorable for me in the layering of both faith and hope on top of his intellect and training.

This is written so that each character gets there own section unlike the other books where the narrative weaves back and forth between characters. Hanna's story is definitely the worst, it gets super boring after a while, I think it might be the longest too. The stories don't exactly fit in to book 5 either. In book 5 Aria was supposedly cooped up all winter break and in this book...well she definitely wasn't at home the whole time. It's a pretty good book though.

summary: romance I like but don't need every detail
reviewText: Not my favorite story, the romance encounters were a little to grafic for my taste.  I sometimes "fire the author" if it's something I'm not enjoying at all but kept reading to find out what the mystery of her running away was, though that wasn't a such a surprise.

I believe that Dr. Alexander believes his account of his NDE to be accurate and real. I believe he feels a very strong compulsion to share his experiences and that he put hurculean effort into recording his experiences after the fact.Whether or not he has unravelled an ancient mystery remains to be seen. Of course, when we finally discover the truth our time will have run out for sharing the news with others.My guess is that devout Christians will embrace this book and the agnostic crowd will be swayed very little if at all. The writing style and organization of the book--while admittedly not within Dr Alexander's extensive training--leaves a bit to be desired. All that said, I commend him for trying to make a difference in the lives of others.

summary: Everyone in the industry has had this girl omg
reviewText: This book is a good tale of what young women should not be. I dont know why she would decide to write a book about all of the high profile men she has slept with especially since most of them were married. Shes been with everyone from fred durst to usher..shaq to diddy..She had a young son who she basically ditched with a nanny so that she could sleep around with these men. She expected all of these men to take care of her and when they didnt expected people to feel bad for her.  This woman seems like nothing but a gold digger. The book is ok if you are into hip hop.  Its basically tryst after tryst with a whole slew  of rappers...irv gotti,ja rule,ice t,vin  diesel,diddy,jay  z,usher,ray j,shaq, and the list  goes on.

This book is probably the most popular book about hiking the AT, but make no mistake about it, this is a pretender's tale.For one thing the author did not hike (either thru-hike or section hike) the entire AT; he hiked about a quarter of it. To be fair, the book title did not suggest he did, and certainly you don't have to hike the entire AT to earn the right to write a book, but this leads to my second point which is: He did not even make a sincere effort to hike it. In the beginning of the book he tried to make us believe that he would thru-hike it, but it later became apparent that he did not actually intend to do so (he and his friend had other things planned out already). I think this is very misleading to say the least.Now let's forget about all this and judge the book by its own merit. The first half of the book is quite entertaining, as this was at least a pretension of trying to complete the whole trail, and there is a continuity in it. However, it also becomes apparent that the author and his friend do not actually appreciate the wilderness, they constantly curse at the daily trudging, and the author even suggests at one point that the AT should be constructed with "hamlets" along the way. It is also clear that the author can be quite mean-spirited at times the way he describes other hikers. But, let me be fair: if the book keeps up the consistency as in the first half, I would give it 4 stars.But then in the second half the book "falls off the cliff" so to speak. The author drove to various points of the AT and made some half-hearted effort to hike a few sections. This part of the book is fragmented and full of fillers (e.g. his made-up brush with hypothermia, etc.). It is actually rather pathetic. Thus, judging the book as a whole, I would give it 2.5 stars (and I am being generous to round it up to 3).

I like reading books on NDEs. I loved the idea of reading a book that would describe it from the inside from a medical standpoint. And I liked the idea that the doctor was a pure scientist who didn't believe in an afterlife.The middle was great. It was detailed and the author explained things well. I was disappointed that I had to force myself to read the last chapter. Also if you're not familiar with any medical terminology, you might get lost.
The book actually would be a 4 but Molly was too selfcentered and unable "to give it up and go on". I cannot enjoy a book and dislike the main character.
This book was too superficial for me.  I read it months ago and just remember that I was somewhat displeased with it.

summary: The book didnt really connect with me
reviewText: I finally finished this book after 6 months. I love books like these with the experience of the persons NDE but this one I had a hard time with. Maybe because it kept switching back and forth from the dream world to real world? Not sure but I did lose interest and it took me awhile to finish this book. The best book so far I have read that is similar is "Many Lives, Many Masters" by Dr Brian Weiss. It is about past life regression but sort of the same message. I'm not doubting his journey did occur I just wasn't able to fully connect. I did like his recommendation of hemi-sync by robert monroe though for use with meditation and so on. I would still recommend reading this book to anyone who asks.

I have no reason to doubt Dr. Alexander had an afterlife experience.  His terms for the "areas" he visited sound story-like rather than real.  I am wondering why he never mentions seeing Jesus.  I wouldn't recommend this book.

This book recounts Dr. Alexander's near death experience.  It initially seemed more autobiographical than anything else, and I wished the author would have dedicated more pages to what he saw and felt when out of body. But it is conceivable that those impressions, feelings and memories are irreducible into ordinary language.  In the final chapters, Dr Alexander attempts to hang a scientific moniker on his NDE but really can't.  I WANT TO BELIEVE THIS
Nice treatment of subject from author's very personal perspective but lacks depth. More information could have been included.

summary: "Proof Of Heaven" I'll be reading it again, and I'll be thinking about it more, that much is certain.
reviewText: "Proof Of Heaven" is a book I've read that I'm not sure how I feel about it, but it stays on my mind. Life after death is a compelling question for all human beings. I personally believe in an afterlife. I am a spiritual person. I may not be the reader this book was intended for. I'll be reading it again, and I'll be thinking about it more, that much is certain.

I thought the book was just okay. The author is very very smart, so when he got into the medical jargon the book became a little boring. I was expecting a huge revelation about the after life, but thought everything he saw we heard before from other nde. I guess I was hoping to find out how we find our relatives and what God might look like. The book was interesting but not a page flipper.

Although I believe she had a very real heavenly experience, she said that she was offered two doors to walk through, meaning after one dies he gets a choice as to where he will spend eternity. The Bible confirms that our decision for eternity is made while still living on the earth. Also she was shown that all spirits were previously created and lived in Heaven. Then God sent them to be born in the flesh on the earth. This concept is often confirmed by what God told Jeremiah, "I knew you before you were born." If God did send already existing spirits to live on the earth, then He has sent millions to be condemned to Hell, because of the poor choices they make. Why would they leave a safe place in Heaven, to wind up in Hell?Of course, God knows His plan for every person that a man and woman would create, confirmed by Psalm 139, just as he knew and conceived in His mind the world before it was created. But that newly created spirit by a man and a woman is offered a choice on the earth to follow Jesus Christ, or Satan. An otherworldly experience must be verified by the Bible.

A Walk In The Woods is a personal account of the author's adventures on the Appalachian Trail, or AT.  The author, Bill Bryson, humorously recounts his mishaps, triumphs, and encounters on over 500 miles of this 2000+ mile trail.  Not an experienced backpacker, the author and his friend, Katz, heroically adjust to trail life, and in very little time fall into the backpacking routine:  walk, walk, walk, rest, eat, walk, walk, walk, eat, sleep, lather, rinse, and repeat.The author peppers his tale with interesting facts about the U.S. Forest Service, the history of the trail itself, mankind's abuses of nature, and information on various areas that he passes through.While I would have enjoyed a bit more detail at times, I was very happy with the overall content of the  book.  It is a very quick and enjoyable read, not to mention funny, and has a broad enough appeal for a very general audience.  I can easily recommend this book to anyone who would enjoy an easy, relatively funny read.

I wasn't blown away by this book, nor was I totally put off like some reviewers. I just thought it was okay. There's some humor, a lot of sarcasm, and a bit of profanity - it's true. I enjoyed the details about the Appalachian Trail, but probably not enough to read it again.
A .ice be a challenge book. A bit different.t than the usual romance novels. The lady in the story is gutsy and mysterious.

This book is very thought provoking.  I liked some parts, others I thought were too technical.  The unusual interpretation of heaven is different from any I've read.  Toward the end, it seemed repetitive.

A Disobedient Girl is a tiring novel.  It is a good story, but I didn't mesh with the characters, and the dates and politics confused me since I am not familiar with Sri Lankan history at all.  The characters, especially Latha, upset me.  I know I can never understand true servitude and what it would take to wipe away years of service, but I felt like she kept to her servitude ways because she was afraid to do anything else.The reason Latha upset me so much was right away when the story opens, Latha is stealing rose colored soap because she believes she deserves it, she knew she was supposed to be in a higher position then she was born in to.  Yet when she is free (to a certain extent) she still reverts back to her role with her childhood friend/mistress Thara.  This includes sacrificing her own child and responsibilities to raise Thara's.Biso's character also grated on me because she was so cookie cutter beaten wife character.  In many books authors tend to revert to a stereotype and this is what has been done with Biso. She also makes bad decision after bad decision and was completely predictable.  I felt like I had read about Biso in numerous books under numerous names.But the book was still well written especially for a debut author and not many writers can transition from third person to first person and still pull it off.
