Ru Freeman's work and stories might not be to my own liking, but for those who love betrayal, desire, Sri Lankan politics and caste systems you should like this book.  Just research the dates before you read this novel, I knew Princess Diana got married in the early 80's, but the switch back and forth caused me to loose track of the time.
My mother in law got me this book for my birthday she said she loved it but Ilm not so sure I do!!It was good but not all that especially for Super head lol

summary: Good read for a medical student
reviewText: I bought this book with great anticipation and it didn't disappoint, but I got bogged down in reading all the technical jargon.  I'm sure if you are a doctor or medical student you would get quite a lot out of this book. I was hoping for a broader description of the afterlife.  I have no doubt the doctor did visit heaven, I just wish he had written more about it than about his condition.

I used to camp all the time when I was growing up, with my folks and later on involved in Scouting. I hiked, day hikes mostly and usually as often as the weather would allow with little concern for the season.  I therefore tend to read books on AT (Appalachian Trail) and it's hikers as it's a dream I'll never realize. 'Walk' is about a man discovering there's a trail, unbroken (more or less) from Georgia to Maine. Some 2,100 miles long up the Appalachian corridor. Bryson sets off, completely unprepared mentally or physically to walk the AT and soon discovers that it's a daunting task. Bill's got a good grasp of humor and never fails to convey the humor in the situations he and his hiking companion, Katz, who's even more ill prepared for the journey than the author. There's a few moments, mostly littering by throwing gear away and not policing his cigarette butts by Katz that I find rather annoying. We also, as we sadly do in so many 'Trail' books, get preached at about just how crappy we're doing as caretakers of this planet. Bryson's not the worst by a long shot but I'd really love to read a story about hiking the AT without the need to break out into how we're killing the amphibians off or how many species of trees have gone extinct due to our careless nature. I know it's a problem but if I wanted to read about it I'd go looking for books on THAT topic and not hiking. Don't get me wrong, this is well worth reading (thanks Lisa!). I found myself laughing out loud in many places. I could just do without the preaching from the soapbox.

summary: I'm a Christian, but this doesn't feel right
reviewText: I believe that the human soul is immortal and that everyone will carry on after our bodies pass away, either in eternal happiness in the presence of the Lord, or in eternal suffering depending on whether you were able to struggle through all the worldly "traps" and believe and trust in the Savior of our souls Jesus Christ. Eben claims to have seen Heaven, but I don't recall the name Jesus even mentioned in the book once, (pretty significant omission). He has named God "om". He speaks of being in what he calls an "earthworms eye view" with faces appearing in a brown ooze. I'm sorry, but the bible says to be absent from the body is to be in the presence or the Lord. If something doesn't seem right .... it probably isn't. I started this book wanting to believe it, but this is just too much.

not compelling reading, but interesting.  The issue of near death experiences shows that humans are above the animal kingdom, because we can contemplate spirituality and the lower animals cannot.  Take that PETA!
Fairly credible account of an NDE but it, like many, degenerates from a spiritual to a religious conclusion. This challenges the authenticity of the experience.

"I, Elizabeth" did not meet my expectations. I am a fan of historical fiction, but I much prefer the work of Margaret George and Philippa Gregory to that of Rosalind Miles. This novel is interesting because it covers Elizabeth I's entire life and goes into a lot of detail about Tudor history. However, I thought the writing was very dull at times and I never really connected to Elizabeth's character the way I should have. I suggest reading "The Virgin's Lover" instead.

It's just a mindset that I am trying to understand and grasp. Darwinism. Survival of the Fittest. Just read the same mindset-type in "Confessions of a Homewrecker- 100 Tales...".To each her own I guess....

I have no religious beliefs, but I am always happy when someone "finds" their God for  themselves and their  heaven.I tend to lean towards, he is a doctor, and he has found out for sure what he has been taught as a belief.  Doctorshold alot of power.  Many who have read this found it wonderful.The language he uses, is used by alot of "spiritual" people to describe their Universe.  I am all about whatever helpsyou feel connected to goodness and developing an awareness to oneness and helping our earth and humanity.  Iam not at all concerned how or where you get "it" as long as you are feeling great and good about "it".I live more in an "energy" concept.  YOu can't make more of it, but you can release what energy you have stuckinside you with techniques that change  how you think about energy, yourself, and how we use and don't  use itto empower outselves.

Well written, but I didn't find that he proved that heaven exists.  I guess because the author is a neurosurgeon, the reader is supposed to swallow his views because he "so credible."  It's an interesting book though, and I've heard and read similar near death experiences from others.

summary: Wanted More Length to the book.
reviewText: Dr. Alexander writes well and the book was enjoyable, but it was just so short.  The time he spent in Heaven is a brief account and the rest is his explanations as to how, as a man of science, he knows his journey was real.  I wanted to spend more time in Heaven with him.
This is the perfect book if you are looking for a light-hearted summer romance type of book with a predictable outcome.

summary: lovely experience, but a bit dull to read
reviewText: I have always been open to such ideas, and deep down inside, want to believe.  However I am also very science-minded and realistic, so I often find myself back and forth trying to figure out what I believe.  Although this book was a bit slow to read, the message was reassuring.

I love the topic.  Who doesn't.  That fact didn't aid my enjoyment of this book.  After finishing it, I read a lot about Dr. Eben Alexander and his telling of his near-death experience and how this book evolved.  All of it called into question his assertions and other people involved in his care, and who knew him at the time, contradicted what he says was happening to him while he was 'unconscious'.  Left me feeling a little bit used.
I thought that the book had a very interesting hypothesis, but the author became too wordy and long winded. In short, the author could have made his point with fewer words.
Although it was interesting to read, this book did not convince me that it spoke of heaven in a biblical sense.  Others seem more impressed than I was (written for my wife).

I felt that there was a lot of New Age imagery in this book. I had also never heard God referred to as "Om". I think if God ever wanted us to know Him by this name, He would have mentioned it in the Bible. He has several titles but this was a new one on me. I think possibly this author was talking to a different spirit altogether. The information in this book did not line up with what I have read in all the other books about people who have gone to Heaven. I never doubted that Heaven exists, But I can't accept the account of this author's experience.
My husband really liked it, but my opinion is that it is just Okay.  I felt that there was too much medical jargon that I really did not like or understand.
I saw Dr. Alexander on the Katie TV show and bought this book on kindle to read his story.  I appreciated what he had to say

A story of a near death experience as seen through the eyes and related by the mind of a neurologist. I enjoyed the story but was overwhelmed when the writer ventured off into verbiage meant for other people in his field.
I found there to be points of interest  I had seen the author on TV. Way too much background on the Surgeon's life.
It was okay......There are other books on this subject that I have enjoyed a lot more.  I'm sure he was writing this for his scientist  friends and doctors who are not believers of heaven.

This was the first book I'd read by Bryson.  I read it on the plane and laughed out loud a few times.  The chapters written about hiking the trail with his friend are great, really funny.  I really wish the book had been pared down to just that part of the adventure--about 3/4 of the book.  His friend is seriously hilarious.He gets a little didactic when writing about the history of the trail, and I got a little impatient with that and scanned through it.

summary: ... scientifically speaking - I thought he put forward a great case. Where I struggled with the boom was ...
reviewText: The book was well written and scientifically speaking - I thought he put forward a great case. Where I struggled with the boom was the lack of reference to the Trinity, to Christ's great work of mercy and grace and no mention of His Lordship.

i picked this up cause I was in the mood for a funny read. This book is funny - for about 2/3rds of it. The rest of the book is padded with lots of data about national parks. If I had known it would be so scholarly on that front, I probably would have skipped it alltogether. The first 2/3rds is really funny though.

The storyline was cute. Funny and fast paced. I personally just think the ending fell kind of flat. All the momentum was built and then it just fell flat. Didn't really make sense then why all the secrecy was necessary. Could have had a better storyline without all the extra drama that was wrapped up too quickly to even matter to the plot.
I LOVED the beginning of this book.It slows to a glowing amber...then it seems to just fizzle.But it parallels his own enthusiasm for the trail... so maybe that is intentional?

summary: Either you will love it or hate it
reviewText: There is no middle ground with this narrative. You may like and believe the story or you may dislike and doubt it. No matter what you do, one can't with absolute surety say that this was not bound to happen. Not a bad read!

How do we respond to evil acts in our community?  Melissa Foster using the characters in her book to make us look at our relationships and to make us question how we care for one another as family or friends or neighbors.
I would have given this book 4 stars but as the story went on, I started to despise Willow - she's a little snotty & wont give Randy a break or a chance and became very unlikeable, very quickly.
Not that great, was not that spiritual like a lot of others I have read about NDE 's.  Would not recommend, can't believe it was a bestseller.
the book was okay. I managed to finish it but never felt connected to the characters nor was I ever really engrossed in the story.
the book is too techinal for me.  It is written for doctors using terms I do not recognize. However, it does have a good message..

I like this book, it was suspenseful and made me want to keep reading it. I was a little disappointed in the end. Some stuff at the end came out of nowhere, I dont want to give it away in case you are going to read the book. With all of that said I would recommend the book. It was good I finished it in two days. You will be turning the page and wanting more. Worth the .99..... Enjoy

If near-death experiences (NDEs) interest you or if you are skeptical about the veracity of NDEs, Dr. Eben Alexander's Proof of Heaven may be your book-- although an investigative report in Esquire has raised doubts about the accuracy of Alexander's account.Proof of Heaven is of special interest in this genre because the NDE is reported by a Duke University-trained neurosurgeon, who taught neurosurgery at Harvard Medical School; has written and published numerous peer-reviewed papers on neurosurgical techniques and outcomes; and has practiced neurosurgery at Boston's acclaimed Brigham and Women's Hospital, a Harvard teaching facility, as well as at Lynchburg, Viginia's Lynchburg General Hospital.Dr. Alexander's NDE occurred during a seven-day medically-induced coma induced by an extremely rare case of E. coli meningitis.  The detail and authority of Alexander's medical account is at the core of Proof of Heaven, and adds immeasurably to the impact of the book.  According to Alexander, his neocortex (the area of the brain that mediates consciousness), was rendered inactive during his coma and was incapable of producing or assimilating the rich, variegated experiences that he encountered during his NDE.  Of keen interest as well is that Dr. Alexander was hooked up to monitoring equipment during his coma, and that the reported data are presumably inconsistent with the NDE that he reports.Equally of interest is Alexander's ability to evaluate the scientific theories of NDEs against his own experience.  The doctor believes that current medical theories of NDEs are inadequate to explain his experience.  Briefly, according to Alexander, current theory would explain brief, disorganized or confused  memories or thought patterns during an NDE.  Alexander reports, however, that his own NDE was lengthy, coherent and richly detailed-- a seemingly impossible medical outcome in the absence of a functioning neocortex.In an afterword to Proof of Heaven, Dr. Alexander notes that he has co-founded an organization, Eternea, to collect data on NDEs and other spiritually transformative experiences (STEs), to conduct scientific research in these areas, and to bridge the gap between scientific theory and spirituality.  This is a hopeful, constructive and immensely important endeavor.For the above reasons, I recommend Dr. Alexander's book with caveats, as discussed below.  As for the actual NDE, I found it relatively flat and impersonal, especially when contrasted to other books in this genre.  (Dr. Alexander notes that he experienced the NDE largely from a perspective of disembodied consciousness, rather than as Eben Alexander.) During his NDE, Dr. Alexander moved repeatedly between three areas:(1)An "underworld", characterized by a feeling of imprisonment in a primordial sludge;(2)A "gateway area", that would roughly conform to most human conceptions of heaven; and(3)A "core", an area of simultaneous darkness and illumination, which embodied a sense of advanced consciousness, all-encompassing knowledge, and a presence that many might identify as God.While Dr. Alexander's NDE is conceptually interesting (to me, it relates to the ongoing human struggle to transcend limitations, and the account roughly corresponds to religious accounts of purgatory and heaven), it was this aspect of his book that I found the weakest, owing to its somewhat impersonal flavor.CAVEATs:  Alexander's account has been investigated extensively by Esquire magazine. Esquire reports that there are a number of concerns related to Alexander's personal history and the events depicted in Proof of Heaven:1. Alexander fails to disclose multiple malpractice suits against him.  Of these, the most serious was an operation in which Alexander allegedly operated on the wrong surgical site and attempted to falsify related records to cover up his error.2. The ER doctor who treated Alexander during the coma described in Proof of Heaven denied to Esquire that Alexander lost the underlying ability to reason consciously during his coma.  The ER doctor also notes that the coma was medically induced, not spontaneous-- an important detail that is omitted from Proof of Heaven.3.  The National Weather Service, according to Esquire, partially refutes Alexander's account of the local weather conditions prevailing during and immediately after Alexander's coma.The caveats reported by Esquire do indeed diminish the credibility of Alexander's  NDE account.

summary: Interesting history of the trail, second half less compelling than the first.
reviewText: As both a Bill Bryson fan and a long distance hiker myself (although I have not done the Appalachian Trail yet) I really expected to love A Walk in the Woods. I was a little bit concerned, since when my partner handed it to me (he finished the book first) he said, "I don't think you're going to like it..." But still, I was really looking forward to reading it.For the first half of the book, I also really did enjoy the book. I wasn't bothered by the fact that they were unprepared or out of shape. Nobody is really prepared for their first long distance hiking trip until they are a few weeks into the trail. I remember my own experience of staggering along under my overly ambitious pack. I also enjoyed that he talked honestly about the experience of hiking, and I liked the way that he interspersed history and facts about the trail with the travel writing.The second half, however, got much less interesting. The day trips and the abortive Maine portion were actually kind of disheartening. The whole feel of the prose got sort of mean spirited. He didn't have to walk the whole trail to feel like he walked it, but I honestly would have preferred to see him expand the first half and leave the second half out completely.There is still quite a bit of good stuff in here, particularly if you are interested in the southern part of the trail. There is also quite a bit of truth about the culture of the long distance hikers. I laughed quite a bit  while I read. I guess that the complaints boiled down to not quite being as good as it could have been.

summary: Moe and Curley Take a Hike
reviewText: After I read "A Brief History of Nearly Everything" I decided that Mr. Bryson was one of those rare writers that could teach and entertain at the same time. Unfortunately he fell a little short in both areas with this effort. The humor was clever but just too caustic for a southern boy like myself. He would readily admit the shortcomings of both he and his goofy companion but just as readily go into "Deliverance" jokes about every person he met on and off the trail, even taking a cheap shot at the Boyscouts! He did a fairly good job explaining the challenges of hiking the AT but had too many wanderings into political musings about the environment, the government, etc, etc, etc. Interesting read, just not great

Bill Bryson did not "rediscover America on the Appalachian Trail."  It is disheartening to read about someone who has the opportunity to take 6 months or so out of their lives to complete the AT but apparently takes so little from the experience.Obviously, there are people that you run into in this world who are aggravating or rude, but it's amazing that every person that the author encounters is in some way a caricature of a human being. For example, they are either too annoying, stupid, southern, cheap, or fat to be in the good graces of Bill. Mr. Bryson comes off as arrogant, and downright rude through the book.Bill Bryson gives the illusion that he is concerned by the Forest Service and their serial road building, but doesn't take care of the woods he is walking through himself. At one point, his partner chucks a cream soda can out of his tent and it rolls into the underbrush (not to mention the food products and coffee filters that were thrown off the side of a cliff). What happened to leave no trace?I was really looking forward to reading this book, but it's not what I expected. Sure, Mr. Bryson has a few cute/comical stories, quips, and comments through the book, but it's not enough to redeem it for all other offenses. If you want to read it, check it out from the library. I will not purchase another book from this author.Note: I did purchase this item from Amazon and as always, no problems with Amazon.

The story is okay, written in a flowing, entertaining manner, but is the age-old tale of a woman selling her body and soul for a chance at stardom and a shot at money and jewels. It would be likely boring to read but I would like Karrine to get her act together, grow-up, and take care of her son.  He is watching her every move and there may well be another generation that belays hard work and study, and tries for the shallow life of fancy cars and expensive watches, and hip-hop music and gold chains. I sincerely hope she can escape the sordid life without AIDS and a life-threatening drug habit.  After reading her book, I would hate to see a small piece in an entertainment magazine about an unidentified, unknown adult female found dead in an alley after being thrown out like garbage from a Mercedes limo. I trust that she will stay true to herself and her son.

Dr. Alexander III told a very interesting story but I found that he seemed to be more involved with the medical and physiological aspects of his experience that his emotional experience.  Rather than giving an emotional description I felt like I got a clinical description of his journey.  It was still an interesting read.  I have a medical background and that information was fine but that was not what I expected to find.
I haven't quite finished it.  Found it interesting but found some of the medical and technical terms hard for me to understand

summary: Paranormal romance with a twist, or two.
reviewText: Gail Crawford sneaks off in the middle of the night to pay a visit to Moulton Bay's most reclusive resident, Alexander Claybourne.  She, and several other local children, believe that Claybourne is really a vampire in hiding.  Gail hopes that Alexander will use his dark magic on her sister Kara, who has been injured in a car accident, to save her life.  Alexander explains to the girl that he is not a vampire and turns her away.  But he cannot stop thinking about the injured woman and visits her in the hospital.  While there he succombs to the urge to give her some of his blood.  Claybourne may not be a vampire, but he acts like one and is not human.  I enjoyed this paranormal romance, despite it having a ludicrous suspense plot.  Not great, but it held me in its spell until the end, which is all I ask from a book.

summary: Too Little Information on the Experiance
reviewText: I waited with much anticipation for the release of Dr. Alexander's book `Proof of Heaven'.  Of course I cannot comment on the validity of his experience since I have not had any such experience but I am always interested in what others who have had near-death experiences report. I do think, as others have commented, that too much space was used in reporting family interaction and medical detail.  I would like to have read more of his near-death experience but on the other hand it is possible that as time passes after coming out of the comma the memory details begins to fade.  On my part it is interesting to compare Dr. Alexander's vision of what happened to my studies in A Course in Miracles. Some things agree but a lot do not (which does not invalidate his experiences).

summary: This was good, but I didn't need all the scientific details...
reviewText: This was a well written and fascinating account of the out of body experience by the author while he was clinically dead for 8 days. I couldn't put it down for the short time it took to read it.Once the story was told, a great deal of scientific data was presented (which one would expect from a neurosurgeon defending and analyzing his case).Although I did read theses appendices, they did not have the compelling interest of the story.I would recommend.

Everyone told me how "hilarious" this book was.  I decided to read it.  The first half of the book is SO funny that you will probably have a hard time not laughing out loud.  Note:  Do not read it alone, in public! :o)Then you get to the second half of the book.  What starts out as a comedic "average joe" adventure turns into a political statement. Blah, blah, blah.  As if someone else wrote the first part of the book, Mr. Bryson decides to venture into coma-inducing historical facts, all the while giving his dry opinion of the government and park service.  ZZZZZ ... oh, sorry.  I dozed off just thinking about it.If you read this book, I recommend doing what Bryson and Katz did (warning: SPOILER).  Only complete half and then give up.

summary: Does not deliver on the title!
reviewText: I pre-purchased this book based on the publishers hype, being a physic's and math guy I was excited to read proof from a learned specialist. I was passionately hoping for some crumb of evidence to support what I have long believed, that there is a heaven. The hope of course being to help heal the world, but alas if you want proof of heaven you will have to look elsewhere.Oddly I found that the good doctor's experience of what Heaven is like aligned very closely with what I hope (and have logically deduced to the best of my ability) heaven will be like, and that part was quite exciting but in the end there was no proof. He does go into great detail about all the things that could have caused these experiences and walks down a checklist of why each of them do not apply but there is one glaring item he does not address "Is it possible you were dreaming (or something closely related to dreaming) the experience either just before/after slipping into/out of the coma?" The timeline of these experiences and how it related to real time are absent and no attempt is made to detail this aspect of his experience yet the books description leads one to believe it will do just that if only you read it's content. (This very may well be the publishers doing.)The Good Doctor even mentions the lack of a sense of time during his experiences (and we all know how skewed time can be in dreams) so I was surprised he didn't deal with this aspect. I am certain the Good Doctor believes these experiences were real but he presents no "hard scientific proof" and because of that I am compelled to agree with other reviewers and say that I feel more than a little bit taken advantage of by the pre-release hype the publishers spun concerning this book, I suggest changing the title.A good read but he falls short of the mark.
This book was interesting and I can recommend it to others.  I especially like that it was written from the perspective of a neurosurgeon.

summary: Still waiting for the heavenly experience . . .
reviewText: This book was okay. I was kind of disappointed by the time I finished the book. I was still waiting for the author to fully express the idea of heaven. Too much data relating to life and not enough spiritual explanations.
Dr Alexander's "Proof of Heaven" was interesting, even entertaining, but wordy.  Took a while to get through.  His book did further confirm my belief in NDE's.

summary: A comforting and provocative argument for the afterlife
reviewText: This author's credentials weigh heavily in favor of the view that we all possess an immortal soul, separate and independent from our bodies.  Since this view is shared by most of the great religions and was also present in antiquity, we can take comfort in its persistence, interpreting it as a clue dropped by the Creator to alert us to its tantalizing possibilities.
My husband was dying and I wanted to read this. It arrived , I read it and have loaned itto a friend now.  The book is challenging to nonbelievers - comforting to the terminally ill I wouldthink.

summary: The real tragedy was not her....
reviewText: I like alot of other reviewers here felt sorry for this woman in the beginning, but after she continued to get herself in all of this b.s. I cared less and less for her, there was only 1 story that messed me up and that involved the last few days of Merlin Santana(Romeo of the Steve Harvey show), if her words are truthful then we get a first hand account into the way hollywood throws away it's young talent, I will admit that I did sympathize with Karrine as she remembered how broken down in appearance and spirit Merlin became in his last days, everything from how he was treated at clubs by the security to how he needed to spend the night with her cause he had no where else to go to. That is the real tragedy in this book, I will admit that this book would make a damn good movie!

This New York Times #1 bestseller is an unusual true story about life after death. It's fairly short and to the point (208 pages). I admit it seemed like a reasonable account of a near death experience (NDE) as the author comes across as very believable considering his training as a neurosurgeon. However, don't expect much in the way of exposition, theorizing, explanations, or insight about what the experience really was or what it meant. It was a personal experience that goes beyond words. It's basically a story about "what" happened not "why" it happened. Don't expect much info on "The Other Side". Chapters 29 (A Common Experience), 30 (Back from the Dead) and 31 (Three Camps) is the most interesting part of the book. The author dismisses the more common explanations such as REM intrusion, DMT dump, and the reboot phenomenon as "spectacularly short" as a workable hypothesis.There are plenty of academic, medical, scientific and other technical terms used here that seem to get in the way of a good read. That style demands to be taken seriously but can make the story plod along because the author lacks the flourish of a natural writer. Very interesting glimpse into heaven but no word of hell. I was disappointed in the title because little actual proof is offered and Heaven remains as mysterious as ever when you finish reading this book. Few answers are really provided so it is up to the reader to decide for themselves what these experiences mean. The author has a website discussing NDEs and reincarnation.
I did not find the book as convincing as its author deems it to be.  It was very similar to other NDEs that I've read about.  The medical preamble was somewhat tedious to get through.

summary: Review from One Book At A Time  onebooktime.blogspot.com
reviewerName: P. Eberhardt "One Book At A Time"
reviewText: I picked this book up because Queen Elizabeth I fascinates me.  I've read many different historical fictions about her.  I really liked the first part of the book.  Most things I've read start were her half-sister Queen Mary has her in the Tower of London.  So, I haven't read much concerning her childhood and when her father was still alive (at least were she was the focus of the story anyway).  I felt that reading about that time period helped me better understand some of her actions as an adult.  I also liked reading about her relationship with her half-brother, Edward.  But, sadly the later part of the story started to really drag down.  I found myself skimming parts.  But, I don't blame it on the book really.  As stated above, I've read a lot about her.  This book really just did not have anything new to add.  It focused on the facts and more on Elizabeth the Queen, not Elizabeth the person.  So, if you haven't already read some historical fiction about Queen Elizabeth, you might like this one.  But, if you already have a lot of information concerning Queen Elizabeth I, you might want to find something else.

summary: Victim to Saved, with darkness throughout
reviewText: Like some other reviewers, I wanted to like this, too, especially since "The Last Time I was Me" (another of Lamb's) is, by far, my favorite novel, well, EVER.Those who have stayed through an abusive relationship may either bond with this right away or have flashbacks. Not having gone down an abusive road, I found parts of this book unreal in a 'why on earth would anyone be such a victim of her own life' kind of way.Some characters are likable, but I didn't fall in love here...

summary: Fun and Fact Filled Account of a walk on the AT
reviewText: Bryson writes a winsome account of his walk on the AT. Along with a less than able, although, willing 'friend', he recounts the variety of people, places and wonder of the eco diversity found along the trail.The most off putting of the story is his self identified political rants. Yes, the Forest Service and National Park Service have been run by idiots over time. Yes, both are still under-funded (and will continue to be). His rants detracted from the overall pleasure of his account.If you want a good account of someone's personal journey along with some great insights into the history of the development of the AT AND some of the boneheaded management decisions made in running the parks, this is a good book for it.

Nine years ago, Molly witnessed a kidnapping, and the child was later killed. She couldn’t deal with the pain and guilt, so she and her family uprooted out to the country. Now, a 7 year old girl, Tracey, has gone missing. Meanwhile, Molly, who has psychic abilities, which she calls The Knowing, continues to have visions and feelings about the missing girl. Molly believes if she can find Tracey, she will alleviate her guilt and pain. She gets heavily involved in the case, and into some danger. The real question is, will she find her before it’s too late?In alternating chapters, we also see from Tracey’s viewpoint, who is hidden underground, with her captor, a character we know. Just as desperate as Molly is to find her, we are desperate to find out why she was stolen and why her captor believes it was justifiable.I really love reading books about missing people, kidnappings, and disappearances. One of my favorites in this category is The Year of Fog by Michelle Richmond. Although it is a very sad topic, it is fascinating too and I find myself captivated by these kinds of stories. Chasing Amanda was an interesting story about kidnapping, made even more interesting by the fact that we see Tracey, the abducted child, and hear her point of view while she is missing. I’ve rarely come across missing persons stories like this, and really thought this was a cool concept, rather than having the abduction shrouded in complete mystery… but don’t be mistaken! There still is plenty of mystery surrounding it, in that we know who kidnapped her, but are left wondering why they did it. The kidnapper states repeatedly that they saved Tracey, and were doing what they had to do. Since we knew where Tracey was, I wasn’t on the edge of my seat with the suspense, but I still really enjoyed it. I also liked the psychic visions that Molly had, giving the book a touch of the supernatural but in a very realistic setting.The story is quite interesting and I think it could be even better with some excellent editing. On numerous occasions, I would come across a sentence that really should have been two, as there were two different statements separated only by a comma (Example: “Molly put on her jogging clothes, the familiarity of them felt like an old friend…” p. 201). Because I am a stickler for grammar, this detracted slightly from my reading experience, but I don’t think it would bother everyone.
The author demonstrates his knowledge of medical terms and poly-syllabic words. A bit hard to follow but, I suppose that is the nature of the topic.

summary: Good medical book, spiritual - not so much
reviewText: As all reviews should start, I read this book as a Christian and with 37 years of working in a medical related field.  So, I'll review it first as a Christian. This NDE (near death experience) that Alexander had is indeed hard to quantify. I would never say he made it up or that he didn't somehow experience the things he writes about. But, did he go to heaven - absolutely not. For one thing, there is no accounting for the atonement of Christ on which every Christian's faith rests. Instead, he seems to imply (or perhaps I only inferred)that there is sufficient "love" to get everyone to heaven. Had Alexander not been clinically brain dead for seven days and if I had only read his out-of-body experiences I would have sworn he was on an LSD trip as the phenomena is sounds very similar. I found his "proof" in the back of the book that it was not a medical cause curious as he continually stresses that the cause of his "death" is one in a million that 90%+ die from it. Therefore, I would think that the premise of the book falls short in that he has no valid or solid conclusion about the NDE.From a medical standpoint, the book is very entertaining although you need a modicum of medical and scientific knowledge to understand all that he writes. One of the strongest areas of learning in the book is the value of having family sit at your bedside constantly if you are in an ICU/CCU. This is important to the patient as it is well-known that holding the patient's hand and talking to them regularly increases survival rate. It also helps prevent negative talk in front of the patient (which they hear even in coma) and screwups by the doctors and nurses.  I think his strongest statement in the book concerns scientific and medical studies, which complains about the success of placebo's healing rate at 30% because it screws up the study conclusions instead of studying the placebo effect to see if they can increase it. Good advice, but I don't know if the government will finance these kinds of study?

It was interesting but way too clinical for the average reader.  I was waiting for more description of what was seen and his actual journey.  I think his writing is like medical journal writing and I am sure he is a brilliant neurosurgeon but has problems putting his experience in layman's terms.  I actually lost interest half way through the book.
This was a decently written  novel. Too details sex scenes for my taste so that is why 3 stars.  The plot was good and characters interesting.  I liked the setting of an island.
Good book. It was an interesting view from one man's experience.  I am more of a suspense reader but this was a nice change of pace and as a Christian, I enjoyed it from a religious point of view.
I like the philosophy but not being a medical professional, the terms were a little too technical.  Kinda took me away from the flow of the story.

The first half of this book was very engaging... and second half felt like it was all about his trying to convince us that it was real.  I would never argue with anyone who is convinced of his experience, but I do believe Alexander believes he was in Heaven.

summary: Should have stuck to the facts
reviewText: Eben Alexander is a neurosurgeon. In 2008 he contracted a rare illness that struck with unusual rapidity and put him into a coma hours after it struck. He remained in that coma, unable to even breathe for himself, for seven days. His doctors considered him brain dead and unable to wake up; or, if by some miracle he did wake up, he would be severely brain damaged. But he did wake up, and within a short time regained all his abilities. How did this happen?While the pathogen causing Dr. Alexander’s illness was discovered- it was the common E. coli- they never did figure out how it managed to get into his brain and spinal cord fluid. Nor did they figure out how he survived it when his neocortex was shut down for days- or how he felt himself to be conscious through out the seven days and had memories of being in heaven during that time. He is convinced that his survival and his memories of heaven are proof that God exists, that the soul exists after death, and that his survival was a miracle. There is also the fact that he knew a couple of things that went on while he was in a coma that he shouldn’t have been able to know. He states that God loves us all, and his illness was for a reason.I’m not automatically against the possible reality of near death experiences – NDEs- but I don’t automatically believe them, either. Alexander’s recovery from his illness was unlikely but there are other cases of people recovering from illness that should have killed them. And we certainly don’t know everything about the brain; neuroscience learns surprising things every day. What happened to the author was remarkable and some aspects are unexplainable at this time, but there is a chance his interpretation is colored by his religious training.Then there is the problem that some of the things in his book just aren’t true; he took some liberties with the truth here and there. Alexander did not lapse into a coma on his own; because he was delirious and thrashing around to the point he couldn’t be treated, the emergency room doctor put him into a medically induced coma which necessitated putting him on a ventilator. He was kept in that coma, and the doctors periodically tried to bring him out of it, only to find him still delirious; he was never ‘brain dead’. He states that as he was about to be transferred from the emergency room to the ICU, the rallied for a moment and shouted “God help me!”, but the emergency room doctor, a friend and co-worker of the author, says that is impossible because he was already intubated, and with that hose down your throat, you can’t speak. There are a few other examples of dramatic license here and there, but most of them aren’t serious. Do these lapses of verity invalidate the author’s message? I don’t know.Was the author’s recovery near miraculous? Pretty much. Does his NDE prove life after death? No. Does the fact that he apparently had mental contact with other people, learning things he couldn’t have known prove that *something* science can’t explain yet happened? Possibly; but because I now cannot trust his version of events, I don’t know. I wish he’d put forth the true version of events rather than try and make them more dramatic; his story would have been a lot more convincing then.

The basic storyline is good, but the book is in much need of editing. In an effort to keep the reader off-guard, the author includes too may red herrings, risking confusion even after the mystery has been solved.It also includes too much "thinking"... as we have to listen to Molly worry about the effects of her gift (and obsession) on her family life, and her own lack of confidence.  Some gray area, uncertainty would make the struggle with her visions realistic, but it takes way too long for anything to happen.This could have been a very good book, but it's overwritten and often confusing (and not in the good way).

summary: Good content; not the best writing in the world
reviewText: I liked the book because I enjoy NDE and related topics in general. I think anyone interested in afterlife studies would benefit from reading it, as would some skeptics and scientific types. But if you're distracted by poor structure and things like run-on sentences, you may have a hard time getting through this book. Dr. A, understandably, is much more fascinated by the complex workings of the neurocortex than the typical reader would be. Long passages about brain function are interwoven with tales of his other-wordly and family experiences in a way that's a bit awkward. I hope he'll consider using a ghost writer in subsequent editions. Still, the story is fascinating enough and the price low enough to give it a read.

I appreciate that the author, who is a neurosurgeon, stays with the facts instead of letting his emotions get carried away with him. The book has a rather abrupt ending, and I never felt a connection to the author. I recommend this book if you are interested in the afterlife.

reviewerName: Sarah "I'm a Canadian book blogger who loves ...
reviewText: Molly's life was turned upside down when she witnessed the abduction of Amanda, but didn't recognize it as an abduction. In an effort to try to save her life and marriage, she moved her family to the small town of Boyds. Everything seems to be getting better until a little girl goes missing. Molly feels compelled to help find her, even if it means destroying the peace she has finally found. Can she find Tracey before she loses everything she loves?I enjoyed the storyline, but didn't like Molly. I found her selfish, unrealistic and just plain annoying. I have tried to figure out why I disliked her so much, but I can't pinpoint any one thing. In the first few chapters, I found myself sympathizing and siding with her husband more than her, and I just never got over that.Since Molly's character is such a big focus in the book, I found it hard to get into the rest of the story. I did find myself interested in how the kidnapper was. There were hints here and there, and I did figure it out about halfway through the book. This didn't detract from the story as I was still trying to figure out more of the back story.Overall, this was an interesting storyline with lots of secrets to be revealed. I really wanted to love the book, but I couldn't connect with, or even like, the main character, which definitely affected my opinion. This is a book I would recommend as I am sure I am in the minority regarding Molly.

summary: Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeons Journey into the Afterlife.
reviewText: I liked the book, he was preaching to the choir with me, but there were long passages, where he went into some rather boring medical detail, that were hard to get through.

I've read several near death experience books, and expected more from this author since he is a surgeon.  The good news is that the experienced proved to him that there is life after death, unlike the medical profession who thinks those experiences are brain / dream reactions to stress.

I really loved the characters in this book.  You feel like you get to know all of them and wish you could hang out, except maybe not naked! There were some cringe moments where the brutality of her former fiancée became all too real. But still, it was a great rom com book.

summary: Good read, though a bit deep in technological termnology making it a challenging read after a while
reviewText: It's great to have a scientist finally support the existance of NDE, but on the flip side...due to the fact that the author is a neurosurgeon the writing is understandable, but somewhat straining on the 'average joe.'  I guess that's to be expected.  But thank you, DR Alexander, for standing up for NDE and not clamming up due to the pressure you must receive from others in the medical field.
Home to Stay was a very easy reading book.  It was the first Anchor Island novel that I have read and I will likely read others.

I was not very impressed with the first Laymon book I read, The Midnight Tour. Now that I've read a couple of his books, though, I seem to enjoy them more. Laymon, more than any other horror author, has sort of a 'learning curve' to get through to be enjoyed. I think that Blood Games is a much better introductory novel of his to read than the Beast House stuff.The characters are believable archetypes and serve the novel very well even if they're not particularly original. There's a zany filmmaker, a model, a regular girl, and so on. With five main people in the novel of the same sex, sometimes it's hard to distinguish, and Blood Games suffers from that at times. Overall, though, it seems to work. The sense of foreboding that dominates the bookBlood Games is a fairly well-written horror novel and, though it moves along particularly slowly in parts, definitely is worth a shot. Laymon has a unique style - very 80s pop horror, a la King and Koontz - and the formulas he uses work sometimes and don't work in others.As with Midnight Tour, though, there are definitely some problems with the novel. The flashbacks are almost wholly unnecessary and serve only to characterize all of the women. But, by the time you get through the second flashback, you have a good idea of who's who and ultimately feel yourself skimming them. I certainly did.

summary: Good story of distance hiking on the Appalachian Trail
reviewText: A fun read. Well written story of hiking the trail. Not great as a guide book, as I had hoped. Somewhat difficult to find te trail segment I wanted to read about which was Skyline Drive in western Virginia in Shenadoah National Park.

I really enjoyed this book.. This author does a very good job of explaining medical terms... in layman's language and makes it easy to follow.. It's a moving book.. incredibly touching and believable.. I found this book profoundly moving and it just confirms what I already believed.. however if I didn't.. I certainly would after reading Dr. Alexander's account of his time in heaven.

summary: Must read it with an open mind.
reviewText: Interesting in light of other such books because his experience was quite different.  I think maybe because he was not a believer.  But as my son said, " it is only proof to him because he experienced it but is not proof to any reader" so maybe the title should be changed a bit.

I wouldn't buy this book because it has nothing to do with anything relating to what's going on in the Pretty Little Liars series now. But it's still good because of course, it's fast pace and addictive.

A surprising knowledge of medicine, quantum physics and spirituality, all presented in plain and seriously genuine, humble prose. As an engineer and scientist who minored in quantum physics, I have been puzzling over the spiritual implications of the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle for decades......not to mention the whole question of what happens after we die.....this book gives us a much clearer insight into these questions. A must read if you have the slightest interest in these topics! Thank you, Eben, for sharing this experience with us.......

While I have to disagree with the title Proof of Heaven that this book was actually not proof of heaven, I found the premise and the experience shared in this book quite fascinating. Dr. Alexander talks about his experiences while in a coma from a serious bacterial meningitis attack that is quite rare and shuts down the neo-cortex of the brain, the part that makes us, basically, human, and puts him in a coma he was not expected to live through or return from. He shares his vivid memories of experiences he had in a place outside of this realm of existence, memories of acceptance, love, inclusiveness, connectedness, peace, calm and so many good things. The main point that of love, unconditional and overwhelming, in a way that isn't even able to be expressed on this world.Dr. Alexander considers this absolute proof of God and Heaven, where I see it as proof that there is something after this life, but not necessarily the religious versions of God and Heaven as we have been told in the Bible or through other religious upbringings. I find the concept of unconditional love fascinating, and somewhat comforting, and I definitely like the perspective of life of some sort, existence and consciousness of some sort, after this body fades away, especially now that I have been diagnosed with a terminal illness, and thinking about death and dying is something that has come to my mind sooner than it would for most people.I enjoyed his personal stories about his journey. I appreciated his honesty about how he was not really a believer prior to this experience, that he was a staunch man of science, to a point, and how this changed that. I like the way he now weaves these two things--the science and the faith--together to be a better doctor and a better person.I like that he provides other resources and information for the reader to read, to consider, and to decide for themselves what they think happened. I went to many of his other resources and read them and even saw him in some video where he was interviewed about his experiences. It's all very compelling... and again, somewhat comforting, especially to me. See, I have a terminal illness, and I know my death is more imminent than I had original expected it to be... life and death, this life and the afterlife, have both been big on my mind. This book did provide me some comfort, some feeling that there might be something else out there beyond this. I think I needed that. At the same time, there was some compelling stories that tied some things in his life together in a way that seems only able to happen outside of this realm. You'll have to read his story to learn more about it. If you're interested, but not sure about buying the book, look him up online and read some of the places where he talks about near death experiences with others who have had them too. Fascinating stuff, and it might help you make up your mind if this is something you want to consider buying or not. I consider it money well spent, if for nothing but the fascination factor.If you're not a believer, this book might make you think about an afterlife differently. If you are a believer, I think this book can really reenforce your faith. If you're a skeptic, you might still find this book fascinating in what it shares about how to live your life now. I think it's well worth considering and picking this one up to read, and he tells the story in a compelling way. There is enough technical and medical/scientific information to make you feel informed, but not so much it's bogged down. And there is enough personal anecdote and experience to feel you're reading a story too. Good balance.

summary: I, Elizabeth - more history, less suspense than Gregory
reviewText: Fans of Philippa Gregory's novels about Elizabeth will like - but not love - Rosalind Miles' version.I, Elizabeth is worth reading. Miles has a gift for convincing language that never strays out of its period, and she packs the book full of historical events that fans of the Elizabethan era will no doubt relish. I enjoyed some of her assumptions and conclusions about the rationale for Elizabeth's actions, although I'd have to say that the very best of these wasn't revealed until the epilogue and was almost an afterthought, while it could have been the thesis for the story. Perhaps it WAS the thesis and I just didn't catch the hints along the way - regardless, it was terribly clever.There were times when this book was difficult to put down, but the pace ebbed and flowed, unlike Gregory's books, which drive forward with relentless page-turning fury. Still, you can't put your life on hold to read all the time, and this is an excellent and enjoyable choice for picking away at in stolen moments here and there.
inspiring sharing of a near death experience and possible afterlife.

I enjoyed Gunnery Sgt. Jack Coughlin's account of being a marine sniper.  The publication is a very easy read and military lingo and thought is explained well.  Most of all I like hearing about Lt. Col McCoy who seems like a brave commanding officer who deeply cares about his marines.  The book is extremely informative about the inner workings and tactics of marine snipers in today's Marine Corps.  In many ways the book is a fast paced read because the demand for the snipers to move quickly on the battlefield.I wish the author would have delved more into his family situation, but he decided not to tell that part of the story.  I hate when women say "we need to talk," those words are a real drag.  I guess one drawback would be there is no real dramatic ending or climax but I imagine that helps display some of the mundane of conflict and the accuracy of the account.  Officer Bob sounds like a tool, and even if that aspect is embilished a little bit, it helpfully points to some of the frustrations of combat.  The author should have added a little more concerning his entire career as a U.S. Marine.  The book is overall an easy and interesting read however.  And while this is not one of the best accounts from the conflict in Iraq it is a valuable account and worthy of reading.  God Bless the U.S. Marines and keep up the good and heroic work in Iraq.

A gripping novel that will keep you in your seat reading until the whee hours because you MUST find out how it will all unfold. A story of 3 lost girls and the woman who has visions as to their whereabouts and how they ended up stolen from their families. A suspenseful book with just a hint of some paranormal twists. I definitely had a hard time putting this one down when it was beyond my bed time! There were a few slow spots that I would have speed up a bit and a lot of searching in the woods for the little girl, but as a whole this book sped along like a train.I think the one thing that I absolutely loved was the description of the characters and places. I could really picture each character and feel their personalities - they became lifelike. The setting - Boyds, MD was unqiue and described with such detail that I felt as though I could picture it right in front of me. A distinct city with a rural setting that allowed for certain events to occur that could never have happened anywhere else.As with every suspense, I rate a book as to how far in advance I find out who dun it or if they are in the story at all. I think I realized the captor at the best moment, because I spent the rest of the book trying to confirm my hunches. A perfect amount of hints were given along the way, but nothing too blatant.A suspenseful book that is definitely worth the grab. A book for both genders and most ages to read whether it be in the middle of summer or curled up in the winter.

summary: Bryson is funny and has a green heart
reviewText: This is the second Bill Bryson book I have read ("Notes From a Small Island" was the other) so I knew I was guaranteed much wry and spot-on humour, together with eccentric experiences and out-of-the-usual travel reminiscing. He did not fail to live up to these expectations. He is so adept at making you feel like you live in the moment with him as he encounters both the banal and the sublime. This book truly treasures the Appalachian Trail, while not hiding its frustrations and mundaneness. There is also much in the way of interesting factual information which serves as a compelling case for environmental advocacy. I am certain most who treasure the environment will find much to cheer about, and much to rue, in this book, as I did.Early on, Bryson forgoes any perfectionistic desire to complete his hike of the whole trail and instead is content to hike part of it, and in so doing, shows us both its mysteries and challenges together with its beauty. It also takes some of the pressure off him and us, as he is content to enjoy the walk rather than try and accomplish something for its own sake.He has written a very entertaining story which does service to both the environment in America and the gift of human companionship, walking the shrinking Appalachian woods with his hilarious hiking buddy, Katz. American culture is always an easy target for a skilled humourist and Bryson is good at poking fun where it is due, and pointing out the sad lack of appreciation for natural beauty among much of the American public.The end result of reading this book, as I am sure it has been for many others, is that it fed my desire to explore more of the outdoors, appreciate what we have and fight to keep it.

Bill Bryson is a funny guy.  I'd love to have his job, which apparently is, as a "travel journalist", to take vacations and write about them.  He does do a fair amount of research too, and he shares that throughout the book.  But while this book will share some interesting tidbits about the Appalachian Trail, it is not primarily about the AT, but more about his and his buddy's trip on it.  They have some comical adventures.  They obviously aren't experienced hikers, but did seem to fare better than some people on the trail.  In any event, I would recommend this book.  It is a short read - about 225 pages, and reads very quickly.  I gained an appreciation for the AT, which I knew very little about.  I also had some laugh-out-loud moments reading this book.  In short, it is a pleasant, none-too-serious true life tale that will garner a few laughs along the way.I think Bill Bryson's book, "A Short History of Nearly Everything" is better than this one - as there is quite a bit more meaty information in it.  However, the two books are quite different styles.  This one is kind of a diary/travelogue, while "A Short History of Nearly Everything" is a short history of science and its characters.  Bryson doesn't play nearly as prominent a role in "A Short History".  Different books, but both quite good.

summary: Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife
reviewText: I like the ease of use on my iPad, the fact that with Audible.com I can listen to this on my car radio.The price was right.

summary: Laugh Out Loud Fun for the Armchair Hiker
reviewText: A WALK IN THE WOODS is the first of Bill Bryson's travelogues that I've read, and if this one's any indication of his work, it won't be the last one that I'll pick up.  It isn't without its flaws, but still it's a delightful book.It might be paradoxical to say so, but maybe because it's so honest that one feels at first slightly disappointed in the book.  This isn't a story about hiking the Appalachian Trail (AT) end-to-end.  Bryson and his hiking companion, Katz, early on think that maybe they'd try to complete the AT, and the reader gears up for it, too, but it becomes clear by halfway through the book that that's not going to happen--if only because the reader sees the pages dwindling away and miles of trail still stretching out far ahead.  The book loses its footing a bit when Bryson and Katz split up.  Up to that point, the reader has been following the preparations for the trip, tagging along on Bryson and Katz's hike on the AT from Georgia to Virginia, and occasionally taking a break to listen to Bryson's ruminations on the history of the AT and the changing environment through which it passes.  Much of the narrative is laugh-out-loud fun.  Bryson's writing honors the tradition of Mark Twain's humorous commentary on the American scene.After Bryson and Katz part ways, Bryson just samples the Trail from Pennsylvania through New Hampshire.  Here Bryson's narrative is soberer, and focuses less on his experience than on anecdotal history.  The fire and ice vignettes--from the burning ghost town of Centralia, Pennsylvania to the freezing winds of Mount Washington--are not without interest.  When Bryson himself enters the scene, though, he's cranky (except when he revels in not carrying his pack), judgmental, and has a tendency towards easy generalizations (this is seen in passages about the South, too).  You get a flash of Bryson's humor now and then, like the anecdote about the directionally challenged Chicken John, but it's not the same as before.  You just want Katz to come back.And he does.  Katz rejoins Bryson to hike the uber-challenging Hundred Mile Wilderness in Maine.  Katz and Bryson, in very different ways, save each other's life in these pages, and you realize, perhaps belatedly, that this book, which only rarely looks up to appreciate the natural surroundings through which it passes, isn't really about the Appalachian Trail, it's about being and staying alive.The book didn't inspire me to be a "through-hiker" on the AT, but it did get me to think about doing some day hiking.  And it also made me think that I'd like to read another Bryson book.
Not very well written because it's jerky and the sequencing leaves a lot to be desired but worth a read nonetheless. It will strengthen the belief of many but I douibt it will make any converts.
The doctor's sincerity and succinct language made the book quite readable.As always, I appreciate the sharing of oone's personal story, speaking from the heart.

I really enjoyed this human interest story about a "normal" person's journey on the Appalachian Trail.  He is funny and compassionate and he made my husband and I want to try our hand on part of the trail.  For historical reasons and for posterity in our lives.

summary: A Good Book: Funny and Interesting
reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this book, although I did not expect to.  Almost every non-fiction/travel/adventure book I've read that was supposed to be good, wasn't.  For example, I didn't like The Perfect Storm because it was boring and read like a textbook.  Fortunately, A Walk in the Woods doesn't.The main attraction to this book is the humor: Billy Bryson is a pretty funny guy.  He can make everyday situations hilarious and catches humorous things most people would miss.  I love it when he makes fun of people.  He does it so well!Bryson also does a good job of mixing history with his hiking story without getting too boring.  Actually, the facts weren't boring at all: it's just that the story was so funny and entertaining you wanted to get back to it.Overall, I really enjoyed A Walk in the Woods.  I hope to read more of Bill Bryson's work in the future.

An amazing story of this Neurosurgeon's journey to Heaven.  With every page I turned I was hoping for more details of Heaven, but there was more about the coma and the process.  Understanding the story and scenario had to be set, just wanted to hear more about Heaven. However I do commend this Doctor for telling his story and thankful for his recovery and all the lives he touches.

I enjoyed reading about his experience with the after world. That it is written by a neurosurgeon who was basically an atheist, and couldn't believe science and religion could ever coincide was the best part.

summary: Makes a Great Point, But Leaves One Out
reviewText: A beautiful and fascinating book. The author makes the very important point that we are all loved, we are never alone, and there is far better waiting for us. However, he does not mention HOW we get to Heaven, which is by accepting Jesus as our savior and into our hearts.

summary: Artfully Crafted Tale, Full of Surprises
reviewText: Reading this story is like peeling an onion, layer by layer.  The author manages to hint at the resolution of a character's thread while keeping the reader guessing, as no character's story is as straightforward as it seems to be. I did not give it 5 stars simply because it, at times, lacked momentum. In fact, the best part of the story was the last 30% or so where all of the action came to the forefront, and the character's secrets were revealed, one by one. I enjoyed the mysticism woven throughout the tale, and found the plotline engaging. In all, a great read and a great value for .99 cents!

I enjoy reading about this topic - life after death.There are no answers just "plenty food for thought" for those who ask themselves what is beyond.  It is written in an informal, engaging style, in a tone typical of someone who has gone through a very traumatic experience.
This was a good read. The reporter could have had a little more strength. However, if you likeromance then you will like this book.  I have read  numerous  authors,I like this  one.

The only reason I gave it a 4 instead of a 5 is that the writing itself is okay but not worthy of a 5. Now the information about his personal experience of an NDE from someone with as much medical knowledge as he has and the "miraculous" recovery of one who should be either dead or brain dead is powerful and should be at least considered as validation of the NDE experience. But as one who has "been there/done that", I am a believer. Try it, you might like it!

summary: A Medical View of Life After Death
reviewText: This account by a physician of his post-death experience differs from most other accounts in several meaningful ways. First, and most important in my view, is that the author presents detailed medical facts about his condition prior to what he asserts was his physical death. He presents convincing evidence that his brain was completely dead and displayed no electrical activity whatsoever. Second, he is absolutely certain that he was indeed dead and his account of his experience includes a great deal of detail that I have never seen in the memoirs of others -- and I have read scores of books on this topic. Finally, unlike many other people who have undergone post- or near-death experiences, Dr. Alexander's medical training and understanding of the human brain makes him a highly credible judge of what actually happened to him. I am not implying that others are not credible; only that this particular author has a degree of knowledge that most others lack and therefore he has more information on which to base his analysis.Whatever you choose to believe, it is quite clear that this doctor experienced some highly unusual phenomena, not just because he claims to have seen 'heaven' but because he was brain dead and then, rather suddenly, revived *with all of his mental functions intact.* Several physicians who attended him are quoted in the book as saying they have no idea how someone in his condition could regain 100% function, but he definitely did. And he has been subjected to entire batteries of medical tests in an effort to ascertain just how his body was able to do this -- all to no avail. Some might call it a miracle. Overall, Dr. Alexander's story is absorbing and a worthwhile read.One more thing to the credit of this book is that it has an excellent bibliography from which interested readers can identify other books on this and similar topics. For me, the question of life after death was not resolved by reading this book, but it did go a good way toward opening up new avenues of inquiry and presenting some ideas that I had not previously considered.
Enjoyed the book and it was a fast easy read.  Great to slip away into the romance of the story.Scurtiss.net

summary: An NDE-story of his own by a modern neurosurgeon
reviewText: (1) This book clearly shows the obvious that only when you yourself have an "extraordinary experience," you, even if you have been a diehard materialist, become a believer of "extraordinary facts" which almost always lack "extraordinary evidences."(2) There are numerous examples of NDE (near death experience), as the author has studied previous examples after his own NDE experience. Unfortunately, these experiences are intrinsically of "Subjective" nature, and hence, as we have seen, are always rejected by "Objective" science, despite the author's explanation based on the "Objective" recordings of his brain activity during his coma of almost one week.(3) If, however, NDE were accepted as a scientific fact, then it would mean that science accepts some version of the so-called notorious "Dualism" initiated by Descartes. John R. Searle, Professor of philosophy at the UCB, writes in his book The Mystery of Consciousness (1997) as follows to reject any versions of "dualism":... But dualism seems out of the question. To accept dualism is to deny the scientific worldview that we have painfully achieved over the past several centuries. To accept dualism is to conclude that we really live in two quite different worlds, a mental and a physical world, or at the very least that there are two different kinds of properties, mental and physical. ... (pp. 194-195).(4) Recently I read the book "Quantum Enigma - Physics encounters consciousness" by the physicists Bruce Rosenblum & Fred Kuttner (2012/ 2nd Ed.). I posted my critical review of the book, in which I wrote (& also copied the following in my review of Searle's book):"In my view I am very much sure that a form of dualism would be verified sooner or later in some "physical experiments." I speculated it in a paper published in the Journal of Scientific Exploration, Vol. 24, No.1, pp. 5 - 39, 2010: Rebuttal to claimed refutations of Duncan MacDougall's experiment on human weight change at the moment of death," (which is available from amazon.com).(5) In my view, some "Objective" physics experiments should be conducted to show that our physical dimension is not a closed system but open to some non-physical dimensions, regardless of their being called a "Heaven" or a world for Afterlife &c.; And this is what I speculated in the paper mentioned in (4). And this kind of physics experiments definitely helps in judging whether or not the author's claim is correct.

I enjoyed this book.  I thought it was a little too technical in some areas, but the author was describing his experience fromhis viewpoint and medical experience.  I hope to read another out-of-body experience in the near future.
