This is an extremely funny travel narrative.  Although the book does fall off in the second half with boring exposition about the politics of the nation's forest service, most of the book is very funny and well worth the time.  Bryson's ascerbic wit is the perfect companion on the AT, which provides a wonderful canvas for dozens of bizarre escapades involving Bryson and his hysterical hiking buddy, Katz.  Don't miss this one folks, it's great.
I found this experience spellbinding and very interesting.  I found some things I questioned but on the whole I  liked it and would recommend  it to anyone.

The amount of research that went into this narrative is simply amazing, and it shows in the level of detail of the story. The author gives a solid sense of place and atmostphere as the queen's story unfolds, giving the reader an insightful window into what life very well could have been like for the monarchs and courtiers of 16th-century England. The writing truly gets into the mind -- and heart -- of Elizabeth on the amazingly difficult and triumphant journey of her life.

Bryson is good fun.  I had never thought about hiking the trail, but after reading this... I'm happy to appreciate the adventure through Bryson's eyes.  While the adventure is daunting, Bysron makes it seem certainly possible for anyone to try.

summary: I Can't Get Enough of Bryson
reviewText: It didn't surprise me at all how much I enjoyed this book about Bill Bryson's adventures on the Appalachian Trail.  If you are already a fan of his, you too will thoroughly enjoy this book.  For me the one reason why I didn't give it as much praise as his other books, is simply that I am not a hiker and would never in a million years undertake such a trip.  I loved his book on Australia because I am Australian, his books on small-town America because I have lived in small-town America, and his books on England and Europe because I have travelled extensively throughout both.  But hiking and camping? - not going to happen except from my armchair - my idea of roughing it is to stay at a Days Inn instead of a Marriott!

summary: Very good  Good reading another one to recommend ........
reviewText: it was a gift to my Boyfriend he said it is good and that he likes it ......he cant seem to put it down when he starts reading ......

Bryson's book is entertaining as well as full of interesting facts and opinions. He rails against the Park Service for not protecting the wilderness areas and its animal and plant inhabitants. He spends a lot of time discussing the dangers of long distance hiking through Appalachia; bears, wild cats, murderers, hypothermia, starvation....Yet he never really has any serious problems and the only large wild animal he encounters is a moose.He paints a funny yet disturbing picture of Americans in general, their addiction to cars, their lack of curiosity, and lack of education. He encounters and critiques drunk hillbillies, ditzy yuppie hikers, technology and equipment obsessed bores, and an occasional well prepared hiker who he appreciates. Bryson has a somewhat sarcastic attitude, is a bit of a snob, with an aquired English writing style; he uses words like "arresting" instead of attractive and says "flush for food" instead of well stocked. But this is also his charm and wit, so I can ride with it.  Meanwhile, Bryson and especially his friend Katz have a complete lack of culinary abilities, surviving for much of the trip on noodles (Ramen?) Snicker bars and Slim Jims.  Oatmeal would have been a perfect trail food and a much better alternative to Snicker bars and Slim Jims.  Bryson failed to bring the oatmeal that Katz had purchased because he didn't like it.  I am really surprised at least one of them didn't die from appendicitis along the trial. Or, dead or dilimbed from a bear attack.  Bryson states in the beginning that bears are attracted to Snicker bars, yet he carries a hugh load of them.Bryson nostalgically refers back to his times in Europe on a number of occasions. He obviously prefers the well groomed and tavern/hotel lined hiking routes of Europe over the crude outback of America. However, at one point he states that if the AT were lined with nice facilities, the expense would make walking the AT prohibitively expensive, so he concedes that it isn't practical.I was disturbed by Katz's proclivity for tossing good food and expensive clothes out of pack in an attempt to reduce the weight.  At one point he even tossed his water bottle.  This seemed purely moronic.  And a waste of money, even as Bryson complained about the cost of food and motels along the way.  Why they couldn't share a room was another odd thing I didn't understand.At the end, I felt at once concerned about the fate Katz and not too concerned about Bryson's fate. Katz was slipping into alcoholism at the end of the book and  Bryson was arguably not doing much to halt that slide.  Katz is a needy yet sensitive guy and Bryson is satirical and a bit of a hardass. Bryson's habit of walking way ahead of Katz was disturbing and I thought a dangerous practice in those wild areas and probably added to Katz's feelings of alienation and abandonment.  I hope Katz finds his way. Bryson no doubt is living in some well manacured English town hanging out at pubs and spinning yarns about his travels.Dispite all my complaints about his attitudes and contradictions, I think Bryson is a great writer, funny, informing, and perceptive.  As a west-coaster with little knowledge of the area, I learned a lot about the Trail and its history.  If I ever go hiking on the AT, I'll know what to expect (this statement is to all those hikers who, as related in the book, after four hours quit the trail because "It wasn't what I expected.")

summary: Brings to mind the Folk Hymn "Wayfaring Stranger"
reviewText: http://wayfaringstranger.com/vid4.htmDusty Springfield sings Wayfaring Stranger, her tv show in 1 September 1966I'm a retired Soldier and Combat Veteran and my College transcript includes "Atomic Physics."The good Doctor has done a commendable job of communicating his vision at the "earth worm level."Still,I'm just a poor wayfaring strangerI'm traveling through this world of woeYet there's no sickness, toil nor dangerIn that bright land to which I goI'm going there to see my mother/fatherI'm going there no more to roamI'm only going over JordanI'm only going over homeI know dark clouds will gather 'round meI know my way is rough and steepYet golden fields lie just before meWhere God's redeemed shall ever sleepI'm going there to see my father/motherS/he said he'd/she'd meet me when I comeI'm only going over JordanI'm only going over homeI want to wear a crown of gloryWhen I get home to that good landI want to shout salvation's storyIn concert with the blood-washed bandI'm going there to meet my SaviourTo sing his praise forever moreI'm just a-going over JordanI'm just a-going over home

summary: "I had never encountered anything so hard, for which I was so ill prepared."
reviewText: Returning to the US after living in England for twenty years, Bill Bryson becomes intrigued with the idea of the hiking the Appalachian Trail, a portion of which is in his New Hampshire backyard.  The 2100-mile trail from Georgia to Mt. Katahdin in Maine winds through virgin forest and scenes of incredible natural beauty and provide an unparalleled opportunity to be alone and reflective.Bryson's sense of adventure and his enthusiasm hold him in good stead as he sets off in Georgia, though he has little idea of how difficult it will be to hike 15 or more miles a day, up and down mountains with forty pounds of gear, including a tent, on his back.  He is accompanied by Stephen Katz, an acquaintance from Iowa with whom he once traveled in Europe, who is even more out of shape than he is.  The contrast between the attitudes of the two men--Bryson, enthusiastic, and Katz, grimly concerned (and complaining) about the difficulties--reflect, between them, the attitudes of virtually any reader of this amusing and thoughtful travelogue.  Additional kooky characters appear throughout this account to add humor and complexity to the hike.Bryson is a fine observer of nature, and as he and Katz travel for six weeks from Georgia through the Carolinas into the Shenandoah National Park, he includes much background about the trail and its history, and about the record of the National Forest Service and the National Parks Service, both of which he finds shocking.  The National Forest Service is the largest builder of highways in the country, providing access for logging operations in the forests.  The National Parks Service has a hands-off policy regarding the protection of endangered species of trees, which are dying due to global warming, diseases, and pollution.At the end of six weeks, Bryson and Katz end the first phase of the hike and return to their homes.  The book loses some of its narrative momentum and its humor when Bryson returns months later to continue part of the trail alone--the reader misses Katz and his complaints--and Bryson becomes more philosophical and more critical of governmental policy in the latter part of the book.  Overall, however, this is a fascinating account of a trail that traverses a major part of the eastern landscape, and Bryson beautifully conveys his awe for its magnificent scenery.  To the extent that its species are vanishing and its forests are dying, it is also a wake-up call to all concerned Americans.  n  Mary Whipple

The book was quite thought provoking and at times got a little hard to understand due to medical terms.  The bottom line is he really feels he has been threre and the story has a surprise twist on the end.

This is quite a humurous book, I was often laughing out loud at the dialogue between Katz and Bryson. Couldn't have been a better unmatched pair to hike parts of the AT.  Informative and provided some information about the hx of the trail and the places it goes through. I would have given it five stars, but he chose to plug some rants in the book that we could have done without. Things like how he feels about the environment, mining, hunting and so forth that took away from the book, but only a little. This book falls into the category of cotton candy for the mind. Fun, but still enough mystery to keep you reading.

This book recounts the adventures of Bill Bryson as he attempts to hike the Appalachian Trail.  Not long after returning from a twenty-year stint as a journalist in England, Bryson became fascinated with the idea of hiking the Appalachian Trail, portions of which practically ran run through his backyard in Hanover, New Hampshire.  After announcing to his friends and publisher that he was planning to hike the trail, Bryson then had to go through with it and actually do some hiking.  As it turned out, he didn't have to hike alone, since one of his friends, on learning that Bryson was going to tackle the trail, volunteered to accompany him.  This friend, Stephen Katz, had hiked with Bryson before, but was in even worse physical condition than Bryson himself, being still in recovery from drug and alcohol rehab.It was a chilly day in March when Bryson and Katz set out on the trail-head in Georgia.  Over the next few months, they encounter hikers and wildlife, see breathtaking vistas and countless trees, and trudge several million steps together.  They learn the vagaries of their equipment and the etiquette of the Trail, and make peace with the past.  Along the way, Bryson takes time out to describe some of the scientific thrills observable from the Trail, and he occasionally rails against the hazards that are degrading the environment.What is odd for a book of this kind is that Bryson seems to have a distinct dislike for wilderness, despite his enthusiasm for hiking.  It's hard to tell if he is exaggerating for the sake of humor or if he is truly as terrified of wild critters as he makes out to be.  Thinking back, he remarks that hiking in Luxembourg, where he could stay in inns each night and was never far from civilization, was much more fun.  And when he and Katz head for the part of the AT that is most deep in the wilderness, that's when things nearly far apart for them.  This distaste for the very wilderness that is at the heart of the AT experience may set some readers off,  but other than that, the book is a very entertaining account of a spring and summer well-spent.

I enjoyed the book very much but was left wondering why Newton was buying girls clothes at the garage sale. I thought he must have something to do with the abduction. But then it never explained and left it at that. Did I miss something?

I am a fan of coming-of-age tales (The Kite Runner) and family sagas (The House of the Spirits) as well as stories that are told with multiple voices (The Poisonwood Bible).  I am especially fond of stories that take me to other places, places I've never been but have always been curious about (Memoirs of a Geisha, Snow Flower and the Secret Fan).  So when I came upon "A Disobedient Girl" through the Vine program, I found a story that really fit the bill.Author and political journalist Ru Freeman tells two stories at once in her debut novel, one of a girl named Latha who is a servant in a prosperous Colombo home and the other of a woman named Biso who is running away from a sullied reputation as well as an abusive alcoholic husband.  Though Latha outwardly adheres to the Sri Lankan caste system, she rebels in small ways by pilfering luxurious soap from the Vithanage's lavatory and developing a sisterly bond with Thara, the daughter of the household who is of the same age.  A little too willful for her own good, Latha's rebellion ends up getting her into trouble early on; when she is denied her wages to buy a new pair of sandals, she exacts revenge on the surly mistress of the house through Thara's girlhood crush Ajith and winds up pregnant at 16.  Sent to a convent to have the baby, she returns to Colombo for Thara's wedding and is shocked to learn that not only is she marrying their other childhood friend Gehan (a boy for whom Latha had affection) but has also been commissioned by Thara to be a servant in her new home, an ironic and cruel penance for her past sins.  Between Latha's tribulations is Biso's great escape from a miserable life, she and her three young children stealing away in the early morning hours from the seaside town of Matara to her aunt's house in Ohiya, a journey they take by train.  Biso encounters setbacks, prejudice, tragedy and terrorism along the way and reminisces on her brief but bold affair with a man named Siri, a rebel rouser who fathered her youngest child.  Though the journey is long and their resources limited, Biso keeps a brave face for her children, knowing all too well that though the gods seem to be smiling on them at every turn, their good fortune will only last so long.Freeman alternates viewpoints chapter by chapter, Biso's tale told in first-person and spanning only a few days, Latha's in third and spanning several years (an interesting juxtaposition of narratives). The novel is so saturated in Sri Lankan culture and Sinhalese terminology (phonetically spelled, making it impossible to translate for someone who does not know how to speak or write Sinhala) that it can often distract from the story and becomes a detriment to its readability.  She uses one too many Sinhalese words in her character's dialogue, leaving a reader wondering what someone has said (Have they used an expletive? An endearment? A proper noun to denote class? No one knows half the time).  She also frequently mentions obscure brand names (Baygon, Panatol, Disprin, etc.) and forget about interpreting any slang - it's a lost cause.It appears Freeman was a little ignorant in estimating the worldliness of her readership, unmindful that the majority of people who pick this up will more than likely NOT be of South Asian descent and/or origin and won't know much about it as a result.  Or perhaps she thought she was educating her readers, only to end up confusing them instead.  This is where the editor and/or publisher should've made some smart cuts and amendments to help simplify, clarify and balance the book's contents before it hit the shelves (it did so only two weeks ago).  Though these details may encourage some (such as myself) to scour the internet and other resources to find out more about Sri Lankan culture, it may vex others beyond repair and nearly 400 pages of it is a lot to digest.Other than this most glaring of flaws, Freeman writes with a passion and intensity that propels the emotional viewpoint of her characters, seamlessly blending past with present.  She deftly interlaces her characters' fates with small and subtle threads to weave a brilliant tapestry of fate, perseverance, love, betrayal, integrity, the bonds of family and sisterhood and the suffering that results from the choices we make.Bottom line: Emotional, tragic and beautiful, "A Disobedient Girl" will open a reader's eyes to another world, another culture, another way of life, providing a sumptuous and heavyhearted tale amidst the exotic backdrop of a country isolated from its neighbors by the yawning depths of the Indian Ocean.  If you're a fan of Khaled Hosseini's "A Thousand Splendid Suns", this one comes highly recommended.
This book shows how a Doctor who didn't believe in heaven, first hand witnessed that there is a heaven.  It was good but Randy Alcorn's book Heaven is even better.
Home to Stay was a good book.  It read fast, and keep me interested until the ending. I'm definitely going to get more of the anchor island books.

This is a slightly different Laymon book.  While it has many of the standard elements they are weighted differently in this one.Five young women met as freshmen in college.  Although all quite different, circumstances of their initial meeting bonded them together.  One thing they all had in common was they did not like injustice and wrong-doing (particularly when aimed at one of themselves).  During college they have a number of wild adventures where they dole out their own brand of justice.  These stories are portrayed as flashbacks throughout the book.Just after graduation they decide to get together once a year for new adventures.  Each year a different one chooses where they will go and what they will do.  This time Helen, a fan of horror movies, has chosen an abandoned hunting lodge where a slaughter took place many year earlier.  But things quickly turn serious when they realize that the place is not completely abandoned.  But it is when they decide to cut their visit short and leave the first day that things begin to go wrong. Now the ladies must pull together and use their skills in their most serious adventure.Unlike many other Laymon books, we do not see characters become uncontrolled when the bonds of civilization are broken.  This book really focuses on characters standing up for themselves and taking the law into their own hands.  Also unlike many others, this one offers better explanations as to why the characters make the decisions they do and why the police are not an option.  Definitely chilling in parts with great atmosphere.  Things really do proceed right to the final page.  A must for Laymon fans.PS.  Look for the author's cameo.

summary: First half much more entertaining than second
reviewText: I listened to this book as an audio book, so my experience of it may be different than that of other readers.The actor, not Bill Bryson, who read this book did an excellent job. His voice was interesting and pronunciation of words sounded good. I give him 5/5 stars.I really enjoyed listening to this book, but the first half of the book was much more interesting and engaging than the second half. I am not a hiker by any means, but recently my husband and my parents talked about trying a few days on the Appalachian Trail just to see what it's like. Therefore, I went to the library and got all of the books I could find about the trail and thought this might be a fun book to listen to.As others have pointed out in reviews, the first half of the book is great. Bryson and his friend Katz are on the trail, living and learning about themselves and the great outdoors. When they left the trail and subsequently decided to skip some sections, I thought, "Alright, that's fine, I'm sure there's only so many interesting things one can say about walking through this section of trail. We'll see what happens in the next state." Then, after they had been on the trail for (I can't remember how long) a couple of months, they left because they had to get back to their lives. Again, I understand. This was taking longer than expected, I'm not sure that they were fully prepared (or as prepared as one can be) for such an expedition, ok, the end. However, that was not the end of the book; I still had 4-5 more CDs to go!After they left the trail, Bryson still felt the urge to hike. He took day trips closer to his home in Connecticut and climbed some of the more mountainous areas. But, of those excursions, none of them had the same feel, for him or in his writing, as when he was solidly on the AT. Also, he seemed to be becoming more and more frustrated with the National Parks system and people along the way.Throughout the book, Bryson is quite amusing with his side stories from the hike about himself, Katz, and some of the people they met along the way. Also, the information he gives about the trail and how it came to be, in the first half of the book was quite interesting.I still want to try to hike some of the trail. I don't think the entire AT is for me, but listening to his experience makes me want to try parts of it for a few days or weeks at a time.

Dr. Alexander's experience is a true one and I enjoyed reading about it.  However, the book was a little more medically technical then I would prefer.  Again, however, I felt it was important to include the medical information for skeptics to read and consider.
Did not contradict the general views ofothers' NDEs.  His perspective was uniqueas depicted in scientific terms and wasvery convincing..

summary: All quiet on the Appalachian Trail
reviewText: This audio book was written and read by the author is in the style of John McPhee and even quoting him once in a while. It includes facts and people like "The Perfect Storm."  Then Bill Bryson adds first hand personal experiences. You can identify with his comments that do not have to be funny to be familiar.This book recounts Bill Bryson's experiences on the Appalachian Trail. The dry facts can be picked up through other material. However the personal experiences are just that, personal. If you have never been hiking then you still get a feel for what you have missed. However if you have hiked then you can really appreciate the people he met, and circumstances that he went through. There are hikers and then there are hikers. In the Boy Scouts you are usually in a well-organized group, in the military you have to be more cautious of objects and terrain, Sierra Club and Outward Bound have their unique points of view. So if his experience is different, it still makes for fun reading.I even liked the sections on selecting and using the equipment. I am afraid if I had met Bill Bryson on the trail; I would have been one of those "equipment comparing" people.Anyway do not expect an epic and you will enjoy the time you spend reading this book. Oh, and it does make me want to go hiking.The Mother Tongue

summary: A very unique NDE story from a prominent neurosurgeon.
reviewText: I've read many accounts of Near Death Experiences and this one was very different.  I appreciate the authors candor and courage in telling his story.

Bryson has a perceptive account of two middle-aged men setting out with minimal preparation to hike the AT.  He is a good narrative writer, although you will not mistake his prose for Ian McEwan.  But he is consistently amusing, with 8-10 'laugh out loud' lines in the book.About 20% of his book is ideological cant of the 'modified Luddite' variety.  One is always thankful to avoid the full-out Luddite variety in a hiking book ("Wouldn't we all be better off living the simple life in huts and nice bonfires for heat?").  Bryson's is of the 'modified Luddite' form in that he argues for turning the clock back only 100 years or so instead of 1000.  For example, he yearns (ad nauseam) for the restoration of farming to the Delaware Valley and tries to position himself 'in the middle' between the hard left 'back to nature' crowd and the world of progress as we know it.It would have been a better (albeit shorter) book without all the diversions into his mild-leftist, political ideology.  For example, he argues that because "some naturalists think" the moose population of New England is 20% less than the State Park system does, under the very limited state-sanctioned hunting program, "the moose aren't so much culled as slaughtered."  (Pg. 242) Such non-sequiturs bred of leftist ideology abound, but can be overlooked bythe thoughtful reader.  Moreover, one can always be thankful it wasn't worse.On the other hand, it may not be Bryson's fault.  It may well be that the publisher presumes leftist ideological cant is part of its target audience for hiking books.  We shall never know.  But the book would have been five stars without it.All in all, a pleasing (though sometimes tendentous) way to gain an appreciation for the terrain and context of the AT.

Bill Bryson's engaging narrative of hiking the Appalachian Trail makes excellent and oft-hillarious reading.  Taking on the trail with his friend Stephen Katz, the two struggle with 40-pound packs as they head north from the mountains of northern Georgia.  Their destination is the upper woodlands of Maine some 2,100 miles away.  Readers feel as if they are moving alongside the pair as they struggle with terrain that ranges from moderate to difficult to downright frightening.  One moment they are struggling up a steep mountainside, later they swiftly descent into a foggy-shrouded forest.  Along the way they encounter danger, serenity, fear, insects, animals, loneliness, laughter, and a few other hikers - and they sleep on the oft-cold ground in tents or crude shelters.  Readers comprehend the joy the two experience at finding a cheap motel and a McDonald's after many days on the trail.  Bryson and Katz didn't quite traverse all 2,100 miles, skipping sections in Tennessee, Pennsylvania and elsewhere.  Still, they hiked a distance longer than New York to Chicago in those spring and summer months.  All is told by Bryson in his easy-reading style.  Having hiked a small portion of the trail (in Tennessee) this witty narrative was like deja vu all over again.
Iv'e read quite a few "proof of God" or "proof of heaven" books.  This one appeals to my scientific nature.  It's a good read. Still don't know if I'd call it "proof" though.

Considering the author is a man of science and not an active Christian, I had to reconcile that with his not declaring seeing God or Jesus Christ in Heaven.  He mentions a loving force, but didn't name it.  Otherwise, it was a lovely portrayal of what we can expect when we die if we are believers.  The ending, regarding he deceased sister, was captivating.
This story kept me wanting to read more.  Just when you think you have it figured out there is another twist.  I would have liked more details to Kate's disappearance and ending.

Set in Sri Lanka, A Disobedient Girl follows Latha, a young servant girl in the Vithanages' home, and, separately, Biso, a woman who takes her three young children and flees a drunken abusive husband and a fishing community where people whisper when she walks by.This book is about the role and place of women; about how we are too often defined by our role, our job. About motherhood and loss.The writing is vivid, mindful of all the senses, at one point commenting on the mouth feel of a word. Freeman does a good job of using Sri Lankan words (I'm guessing they're words in the country's official language of Sinhalese, but I'm not sure) and translating them, in context, without it being awkward and without the book being twice as long as it otherwise could be.While I don't understand the choices these women made, I can begin to understand the helpless, stuck feeling their choices sometimes stemmed from. And the regret they felt over some past actions. I may not go so far as to call them sympathetic characters, but I think they are realistically drawn.A Disobedient Girl is haunting, tragic. It has stayed with me. I could see what was coming and hoped I was wrong, but I wasn't.I'm tempted to call this women's fiction, a class of books I don't think I like. This book rises a bit above that crowd, though, as it draws attention to societal issues and failures.Freeman was born into a family of writers in Colombo, Sri Lanka. After a year of informal study at Murdoch University in Australia, she arrived in the United States to attend Bates College in Maine. She completed her master's in labor relations at the University of Colombo and worked in the field of American and international humanitarian assistance and workers' rights. She calls both Sri Lanka and America home.

summary: Looking for Love in All the Wrong Places
reviewText: Confessions of a Video Vixen by Karrine Steffans was surprisingly an interesting story. It was more than just about your classic groupie wanting the spotlight. It did more then call out some of the men in the industry, such as Diddy, Ice T, and JaRule...to name a few. Karrine was searching for love that she never received at home. While it did reveal the horrible way women are treated in the music industry, it also displayed the mindset of most of the women that are considered groupies. They are insecure and looking for someone to validate their existence.Looking past all of the glamour, she did have quite a childhood. Karrine had a mom who never loved her and was practically jealous of her.  She was abused by her mother and raped, not only by a neighbor but also by her own husband. Her father was an absent figure in her life. She had no one to turn to. So she turned to the one thing that most women with that background turn to: SEX! Of course she still had a choice, and she definitely made some wrong choices. She allowed her self to be used at times, because she thought she had no choice.I believe this book is a great tool to use as an example for young women who may be in similar situations. Hopefully they can glean from Karrine's mistakes and see that they can make better choices. Being a groupie or video girl is NOT all it seems to be.Reviewer Donnica CopelandAPOOO BookClub

As a doctor, I appreciate his scientific background and explanations to solidify the reality of his near-death experience. Maybe those who believe like he did before this event can open their minds to the amazing world that awaits after our spirits leave our bodies. It's too bad it took such a drastic illness for him to realize what he should have seen in others' NDEs. I don't quite agree with a couple of points he made about the afterlife; hence, the four stars. Otherwise, I loved how he wove everything together to tell his story.

Having fell in love with the audio version of Bryson's The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid, I decided to give A Walk in the Woods a try. This audio is also read by the author.Bill Bryson moved to Hanover, New Hampshire, and soon after realizes the the Appalachian Trail, at least part of it, is close by. After doing some reading about the trail, he thought it would be pretty cool to hike the trail which runs from Georgia to Maine. He solicits friends and family to join him, and even puts notes in his holiday cards inviting people to hike "the trail".The only person to respond to his invitation was an old college buddy, that he never got along with too well...Steven Katz. The two of them are like the "odd couple". Bryson is very prepared, having shopped for all the essentials for the trip, and packed very well. Katz, is like Oscar with his duffle bag well packed with Snickers Bars and Little Debbie cakes, all the essentials he felt he'd need. When Katz' bag gets a little too heavy, he tosses the water bottle...who needs water on a hike in the South right?. Their hike began in Georgia, and last about 6 weeks or 500 miles.The book was very amusing. In addition there is a bit of history about the Appalachian Trail, as well as environmental and ecological issues neatly laced into the story. Great travel Memoir.

summary: Hard to dispute this doctors journey into Heaven
reviewText: An interesting book written by a neurosurgeon who claims that he made a journey to Heaven after a serious illness.  From what he expresses it is difficult to dispute his claims.  Believers in Jesus Christ, according to Dr. Alexander, have a lot to look forward to after we leave this earth and all of its problems.  Even if you are a believer in God this book causes you to give thoughts to what the afterlife will hold.  Very good reading.

The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because I thought he would talk more about his experiences on the other side. That's the whole reason I bought the book. In the end what I learned from his total experience and how the medical world perceives such experiences proved to be just as valuable for me.
Very interesting book - it delves into our mind more and the descriptions of pre-heaven and heaven are quite unusual - I enjoyed reading it.
This is the kind of book that draws you in to keep reading until you unravel the mystery. It felt like a ripped from the news kind of story.

This book was a very interesting account of a doctor's experience with near death experience.  While this is not actual prood of the existence of heaven, it certainly provides one with a lot to think about.

reviewerName: Randa "I'm a huge geek girl whose now also an...
reviewText: The cover:This is my favorite cover in the series. I like that the four girls are on one cover :).The storyline:It might include minor spoilers for the book itself and not the other books in the series.Unlike the other books in the series, which have each chapter with a different point of view from each of the girls, in this book we have four parts for the four girls and each part has chapters from that girl's point of view. It is more organized in a way.So for this review, I'll do ratings for each part separately and then I'll make the big conclusion.1st: Hanna: 2.5/5 stars:To me, Hanna's story was the worst one. I couldn't sympathize with her or feel sorry for her.In this book, Hanna's father, his wife Isabel and her daughter Kate are staying with Hanna' in her house.And as usual, Hanna struggles to be on good terms with her Dad and with herself. She feels weak, alone and not loved after what Mona did and how her father treats her now that he has a new family including a new daughter. Also Lucas goes on vacation with an old family friend which, to her, make things only worse.So, she decides to join a fitness club afraid to get chubby again and to get her mind off "A", and while she's not sure whether she has to or not, the fitness trainer definitely gets her attention and she decides to join in for him. And that's when the disasters start.She suddenly decides that what she wants is a new romance with an older guy and she does everything  to get him, only she's pushing him away.All this is happening while she's still with Lucas, her boyfriend.You can imagine the end yourself and you might not get it right, that's why I'm not spoiling the book for you anymore.2nd: Emily: 5/5 stars!Emily's story was the best in the book. It is about friendship, family, loyalty and kindness.In her part of the book, Emily is still mourning Ali's death and she's trying so hard to be brave for herself and her family now that they're all gathered and trying to make her feel welcomed and loved.Just in time for Christmas, while everyone is getting ready, things start to disappear getting stolen by a group of girls who call themselves the Merry Elves, and Emily's mother gets a thing of hers stolen too, so what happens is that she asks for Emily for help (catching the girls in the act).Emily gets into a lot of different situations with different aspects and begins to question what she's really doing while trying to please her mom and yet still true to herself.The end is epic!3rd: Aria: 3/5 stars:I usually hate Aria (not Lucy Hale!) the most out of the four girls. She's too sensitive, too emotional, always trying to find love and most importantly, sometimes she's just too stupid to endure.In her story, the family reunion she's been waiting for for so long is ruined by the coming of Meredith. Yes, she just gets angry and acts with nonsense but I somehow understand her anger. Anyways, she's back in Rosewood and an old crush from Iceland is there looking for her!She feels like it's finally getting better and maybe she's finally going to be happy again. Until that crush of hers crushes her down along with the law...The end? Just ok. Could've been worse.4th: Spencer: 4/5 stars:Spencer's story was actually intriguing. With the family drama, her being the one who told on Ian and her sister hating her, her life couldn't get any worse. Well, think again!The Hastings are staying at Nana's house for their vacation and Spencer decides she needs to relax and have a relationship (she says: "a ling") to get her mind off of things. Thinks start to look very promising, the guy notices her then he's into her, her sister is talking to her and even her mom seems to be noticing her again. Oh well, things are about to flip upside down!Spencer gets stabbed in the back, betrayed and discovers a really bad and nasty truth. Just when things start to look very bad (even I thought she's going to get the bad end again), she gets help from the last person she thought would help her ever. And then what an end, the second best one in this book after Emily's (although it could easily be the opposite ;)).In general:What I loved:- Emily's character.- The writing is as always really good.- The family drama, the relationships and how real they were.- "A" `s point of view at the end of each part. I just love it!What I hated:- The girls desperate tries to fall in love.- How all the girls' vacations (except for Emily's) are about finding a guy. I find this completely nonsense.- There motives, behaviors and decisions were mostly made at an angry moment without giving it second thought.Favorite quotes:The four girls continued to glare. Emily was sure they could hear her galloping heart. She was about to apologize again, but then Cassie burst out laughing, lunged forward, and wrapped Emily in a huge hug. Heather circled her arms around Emily, and then Lola and Sophie joined in, too. Emily remained stiff for a few moments, and then tentatively squeezed back. --- Emily's Pretty Little Secret: Chapter 16: The Whole World was at Peace.Just after they'd professed their affection for one another, A had exposed their relationship. Ezra had resigned from his teaching position immediately and taken off to Rhode Island. Since he'd been gone, Aria felt like she had PTED--Post-Traumatic Ezra Disorder. She couldn't stop thinking about him. --- Aria's Pretty Little Secret: Chapter 1: The More the Merrier at Solstice Time.Colin took a few steps toward her. "Are you a new member of my cheering section?" Spencer cocked her head. "I don't really do cheering sections--unless I'm the athlete being cheered on. But maybe I could make an exception." --- Spencer's Pretty Little Secret: Chapter 2: Cute Boys Make Everything Better.Conclusion:One advice first: read this book in its order! After you read Unbelievable. If you don't read it in the order and leave it for later, you might get confused and things start to get messed up in your mind.This book was a fun quick read (although I took almost 2 months to get it done thanks to my reading slump...). To me, it wasn't a necessary read, you can read the rest of the books without it, you're not missing anything important. It is just nice to know while the new "A" was getting ready, what were the girls doing.

summary: It makes you ponder the question of an after-life
reviewText: Alexander writes a very credible and sincere account of his near-death experience.  The details are riveting.  In the last couple chapters, however, some of the medical/scientific terminology was difficult for a "layperson" to understand.The ending itself was rather disappointing.  I felt it would have been more powerful if the author had included an epilog, bringing the loose ends of his story together by describing how his experience has impacted his life going forward and influenced his wife, sons, sisters and perhaps even colleagues and friends.

summary: A Super Read!  This book is good fun.
reviewText: I loved reading "A Walk in the Woods."  It is laugh out loud  funny--and it holds up when you read excerpts to the person sitting next to  you when you cracked up.  Now I want to get out and walk the Appalachian  Trail...but not all at once!Many folks have taken the time to write a  careful synopsis of this book, so you really don't need me to write another  one.  Bryson successfully blends narrative and fact into a truly  entertaining book.  Unfortunately, a recent trip to one of the areas  described in the book has revealed that at least one of his facts is  already out of date: more than 95% of the Frasier firs in Smokey Mountains  National Park have succumbed now to disease.  It makes me wonder how the  underground fire in Pennsylvania has progressed.But up to the minute  accuracy isn't truly important for this book--just read it and enjoy the  story.

This book is worth a read. Dr Alexander is a professional specializing in the human brain, its diseases and its function. Here , you have the testimony of someone who cannot be accused of being a wishful hysteric in his description of his post life experiences. When Alexander says, that after he recovered from his death experience, he reviewed his medical charts and confirmed that he was ABSOLUTELY brain dead, we can believe him. He is the authority.However, there is an aspect of his account that leaves me sorry for him. His relating of his experience seems to have failed to cause him to submit to the 'Light'. He , yet, maintains much of the intellectual impudence that raises barriers to full submission to the actuality of God; at least, that is my take on what he relates to us.
Fascinating account of a near death experience from a credible source. I'm not sure I buy it, but not sure I don't!
This was an easy read just wish I would of known their were two before it. I would recommend it to anyone.

I totally believe that what Dr Alexander reports was his experience when in his coma. it is not possible that a man of high standing in the medical community would make up a story like this. knowing, as he would, that his reputation risked destruction as result.Even if you are not predisposed to believe in an afterlife, his description of feeling total love has to be reassuring.I do not think his title is good, as he does not actually prove there is an afterlife. I think this is impossible to prove, and certainly not with science!Certainly worth a read.

Dr Alexander's experience stands out in that he was a scientific skeptic of the NDE phenomenon and dismissed NDEs as purely biologic in origin. The word "Proof" in the title however is proof to Dr Alexander, he being the one who had the experience; for the reader it is a strong "testament" to maintaining individual identity and continuity of mortal relationships in the great beyond, and that the evils of the present world are swallowed up in an enormity of goodness beyond mortal description. However for the reader, it is not likely that reading about NDEs will translate into a truly moving, soul- changing, "born-again" type of spiritual experience, as it typically is with those who live the experience. It is clear from this and other writings that experiencing Divinity is a spiritual experience and not just a mental exercise or study, and can only be understood by spiritual means. I would recommend the reader become immersed in God's established Word and LIVE the Word sincerely to approach a mortal spiritual experience; then Dr Alexander's experience and that of many others can be comprehended much more intimately than words on a page.

summary: Enjoyable to the end of the last piece of pie.
reviewText: whatever I can say about this book will undoubtedly be said about her other books.  short,good, sweet, not sickening sweet.they are probably just as good, so I probably won't read them.  all readers can choose to or not to.
I enjoyed Dr. Alexander's sharing of his coma experience.  It does make a case forit having been a "real" event.

summary: My least favorite in the series
reviewText: I really enjoyed the first 2 books in this series and I was looking forward to reading this one. However I found this book lacking. I wasn't emotionally connected to Will.

reviewerName: Denise "I love reading books. I love and read...
reviewText: This story went too fast for me. I want to see more of Julia and Dean together.That is my only complaint. This is the first book I have ever read by Cathy Lamb it won't be the last one. The main character Julia has been dealt a really rotten hand of a life. It seems at each point she strives to grow no matter where she is planted. Until her wedding day to her abusive boyfriend/fiance and she can't marry him. Thus begins the best runaway bride and really find herself story I have read in a while. Mixed in with crazy lovable family members loyal female friends are also truly good men with good hearts and of course a few not so good men. So of the story is predictable but so well told it just made the story more sweet for me.
I really appreciated Dr. Alexander's clinical approach to the subject.It's certainly a view of what comes next that many people can comprehend.
"Proof of Heaven" is very inspiring and informative.  Well written. It is quite believable since the author is a renowned surgeon.

What drew me to this text more so than any other about NDE's, was that it was scribed by a neurosurgeon, renowned for their mechanical/rational view of consciousness. For those scientists whose feet are firmly planted in this particular camp, the notion of the spirit as something separate from the workings of the brain brinks on the absurd. Before Alexander's coma due to E-coli, an illness for adults that occurs in around one in ten million people, and to fully recover is nothing less than miraculous. The doctor's `conscious experiences' while in this coma for seven days, is the books purpose: to report to fellow medical colleagues and the layman that consciousness does in fact go beyond our current understanding of the brain.What is so different in Alexander's account to other such experiences is that he was not `aware' of his earthly identity which, according to the author, enabled him to `travel' further into realms of consciousness or dimensions.There is a quote from a well- known physicist that if the concepts of Quantum Mechanics have not scared you in anyway, you've not understood the discoveries. Doctor Alexander touches on Quantum theory in this book and interlinks the notions of NDE's and his experiences while in a coma, adeptly.It is well known to some that science has moved so far that spirituality/philosophy is now being explored by scientists to help explain the unexplainable. Alexander has made a valuable contribution to this project.If you have any interest in NDE's, this is the text to read as it, in one way, helps us understand the phenomenon, but also raises more questions, than it does, answers...
A little technical but thought provoking - I enjoyed the bookand would recommend it to anyone seeking  information on thisexperience
A wonderful description of after-life.  It strengthened my faith, and perked my interest in heaven.  I have recommended it to friends

The first half of this book was really funny and I even laughed out loud at a few parts. The only problem was that it did get  a bit tedious at sevral parts of the book. I am only twelve, but I read the the complete sherlock holmes when i was 8 and almost every  main classic that you can think of ,so i think that ive had a fair exposure to literature. Because of that, I think that it is fair to say that some parts a re a bit stretched out.STILL WORTH THE READ!!!

Seriousness spiked with the humor of every day observations made by Bryson.  One of the best books I have read this summer.  The book does slow down in Part 2 but it was a great read that I didn't want to put down.

Having never read travel writing in my life, I did not know what to expect.  I selected this title for my book club to read and I kept my fingers crossed that I hadn't picked a bomb that my clubmates would dread finishing.  Quite the contrary!We met last night to discuss "A Walk in the Woods".  Everybody loved it!  I lead the discussion and we found ourselves laughing hysterically over Bryson's many little anicdotes about life on the trail.  His colorful but strange hiking partner, Katz, was a favorite in my group.  We never thought that this overweight, non-ambitious, middle aged man would make it past the first day, but he did.  Although, my group concluded that he must not have had anything else to do in his life and this way he got free food from Bryson and rent was free on the trail.This book is filled with funny stories and commentary.  There are some historical sections on the AT and the Eastern Seaboard.  Bryson did his fare share of research and it shows in his writing.  The book just makes me want to go to the AT and do some hiking.  It sounds beautiful!This is a must read and I give it 4 stars...

I enjoyed this near death experience tremendously. The descriptions were very good and I was able to imagine myself in the place this man found himself. The most interesting fact about the book: The man was a neurologist and pretty much thought death was the end. He had no deep beliefs but does now. To the author: Sincerely, thanks for sharing.

Elizabeth is probably, without argument, the greatest queen of all time.  She had the most cunning mind of her time.  What we know of her is that she was the best ruler of England (king or queen) that the country has seen.  Even Queen Victoria doesn't seem to really compare.  But in Miles's book Elizabeth is portrayed, not as a stern queen, but as a woman with emotions and desires.  Her scandalous relationship with Robert Dudley is shown as a genuine affection between them.  Even Elizabeth's attitude towards her troublesome cousin, Mary of Scots didn't seem to be very harsh.  When asked to sign her death notice, Elizabeth hesitated for many months and even years before she went through with it.  She had compassion towards family; she restored all the titles her Boleyn side of the family lost when her mother was executed.  In general she seemed like an actually human being.  But I rated this book four stars instead of five because, despite of the excellent reviews, the book was just not very interesting.  I was surprised, since Miles has written excellent books about Guenevere.  A much better book, written by Margaret George would have done Elizabeth justice.
This book was recommended to me to read and it was a very intersting read. It was alittle technical for the average person.  luckly I am a nurse so I could understand better than the lay person.
Very well written. Interesting and believable from spiritual and scientific perspective. We all want to know what happens "on the other side."
Wanted to give 5 stars but it started out a little slow, kept putting it down but once it picked up I couldn't put it down. So in the end I'm glad I finished.

summary: Don't go into the woods at night
reviewText: Bill Bryson's A WALK IN THE WOODS:  REDISCOVERING AMERICA ON THE APPALACHIAN TRAIL takes reader up the most revered and legendary walking trails in American history.  The story is somewhat laid-back and may be preferred reading on trip because it reads like a long magazine article or essay, and lends itself to fun reading.  Some critics compare Bill Bryson's writing to Mark Twain's with all its satire and humor and plenty of popular culture references within his narrative.The book begins in Georgia and covers 870 miles north towards the concluding trail that ends in Maine.  Bryson provides an immense amount of information of the history of the trails from its natural state to the dangers that have occurred in the past.  Aside from the humor and dialogue between Bryson and friend, Stephen Katz, the most informative part of the book is how Bryson spotlights the ecological and geological rich history of the trails as well as reference to a little historical trivia pertaining to one well-known Civil War site on the Shenandoah side of the trail, Harpers Ferry where abolitionist John Brown attempted to liberate the slaves.The Appalachian Trail is a part of Americana and American history.  Although there is a hint of a little romanticism of the past on Bryson's part, he interweaves the past with the present, and shows readers that despite progress, industrial and corporate development that surrounds the trails, the trails are still intact with its natural splendor and its big brown bears.

There are lots of LOL moments in this book.  I have read all or almost all of his books.  And this one is typical.  I love the first 3/4 of the book, and then I get kind of tired of him.  But overall, this one was historically and comedically better than most.

He had me laughing and wanting to get my 62 year old fat ass on the Appalachain Trail. Then I read more and thought "No way am I gonna do that!". I seem myself more like his friend Katz, willing but no where NEAR being prepared to do this hike! At times  he drifted into political and conservation type rants, all of them deserving of the rants but somewhat detracting from the Trail story. (my opinion) That's why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. His description of the different sections as the trail courses thru the states makes me want to choose Virginia as the section I'd like to try. It sounds beautiful! And I have NO desire to do the north end, up thru Maine and the Hundred Mile Wilderness!! You young guys can deal with that...[...], I should have done this trail 30 years ago!!What's funny is just a couple weeks back we did a small day hike in north Georgia on the High Shoals trail, down to a beautiful water fall, just a 1.2 mile hike. On the hike back up to the car I was huffing and puffing, my hip was hurting, I was sweating heavily in GOOD weather... and I think I want to do this with a 40 pound pack on my back??!! LOL, I must laugh at myself. Driving up a rough mountain fire road on our way to that hike we crossed over the AT. There was room to pull over, so we stopped to get our bearing (yes, we were lost). As we're trying to figure out where we were and where the High Shoals trailhead is, a guy comes hiking down the AT and pauses to eat his lunch. About 3 minutes later another hiker appears. During our 20 minutes there we saw 6 guys come down that trail! We spoke with the first two guys, one who wanted to celebrate his 65 birthday on the trail, the other guy, much younger, hiking the trail for several days on his own. They both had a slightly dazed but determined look as they spoke of the crowded shelter from the previous night, almost 20 hikers in there! I topped off their water bottles and thanked them, thinking I should do this hike!Who knows, maybe when the weather turns cooler (it's turning hot now) I can get a friend to hike a few days out there with me... the book has me dreaming about it! Good book, I really enjoyed it and want to find more about hiking the trail. Plus, I'm having fun researching gear on the web!Hope you enjoy the book as much as I did!!Back to browsing for gear...

Hearing such a clear and definitive description of the afterlife from a scientist who has a lot to lose from his own skeptical  medical community, gives real credence to this book.  It gives me a sense of hope and peace for my loved ones who have passed on.

I really enjoyed this book. It was easy to get into, but kept me just off balance with assuming that I knew what was going on.  I did guess correctly on a few things right up front, but because of the twists in the story, I was kept uncertain until the end. The story was well written and I found myself often wondering about what was going to happen when next I had a chance to read! Highly recommended.

One can only imagine what this sincere and dedicated author experienced as he struggled with the concepts of Heaven;  Do you suppose he is right;  Oh, wouldn't that be wonderful;  It took great courage to set this book to the printed page; a great and much appreciated risk!  Everyone should read this book!

The story of Alexander's experience after being in a coma was an interesting account on his part.  Did it offer "proof" of Heaven is something the reader will have to ascertain. I thought his story was something we could all read and wonder about in life and my thoughts of the proof of Heaven coincide with my own story and that is what I liked about his book.

I wanted to be assured heaven was real, and felt encouraged by the prologue where the author says the book is for people like me; people who haven't totally believed other NDE (near death experience) accounts. However, I wasn't completely convinced, obviously, since that was a ridiculous idea! He does give a nice account of his experience and a lot of science about why it was an NDE, not a dream or hallucination. For me, the one thing I need to know is that I will be with my sons when my time does come, and he says otherwise.Overall his experience was amazing and his recovery was nothing short of miraculous. I was more moved by the odds being stacked against him and he and his family overcoming and pulling through than with his account of heaven.

summary: Try to read this one and still doubt that there is an 'afterlife'
reviewText: Great read, it would be hard to discount the story as anything else other than what it is... He truly seems to have experienced Heaven while dead.  I would recommend this book highly above any others that I have read in this genre.  His medical explanations leave little room for argument, and are very authoritative.  If you know a sceptic, this is the book to give them.
I don't need the proof but this book did reinforce my belief of something far greater. What an experience indeed.

To think that we were given an inside look at what happens to us in a trauma by a nuerosurgeon was amazing.  I thought his description of heaven a bit much! But who's to argue with what someone saw as heaven when you won't be able to tell people when you get there...  Very interesting and a good read.

I highly recommend this book to anyone who is interested in the outdoors  or in vicariously taking a little adventure.I live within a three hour  drive of the AT and have only been to Mt Washington.  Perhaps, unknowingly,  a few other segments in New Hampshire.  This book has made me a lot more  curious about the AT though.  More than that, it has made me want to set  foot on it.  Even if its just for a day hike.Bill Bryson is a great  story teller and a lucid writer.  After the first page it feels like the  book is being read to you.  My  thanks to Bill Bryson for putting his  journey to print.

summary: Awe inspiring, light, witty .... definitly a must have in your travel books collection.
reviewText: Narrated against the backdrop of America's oldest and most extensively preserved natural forrests, Bryson re-tells the story of how he and his friend, Steven Katz, braved 500 miles over a span of many, many weeks hiking along "the longest continuous footpath in the world, the Appalachian Trail", beginning from one Amicalola Falls Lodge in Atlanta to Front Royal, Virginia; and then meeting up again a few months later to continue on along the same trail towards Mt. Katahdin through the famous Hundred Mile Wilderness.Personally i liked it in the beginning  because i thought it was simply hilarious, the way Bryson spiritedly and rather presumptously decided to hike the AT one day simply because he got excited with all that fancy camping and outdoor gear in the store. However as the story progressed i found myself drawn to how he proceeded to describe the AT, it's humble beginnings and the general surrounding forrest environment, from both flora and fauna, with facts that denote extensive research and a great understanding of the subject. Even more appealing was how easy to read the content was despite having quite a generous few pages filled with historical facts & geographical statistics.He has an almost uncanny sense of humour and what has been written on paper is almost as clear as being there first hand. I laughed out loud several times while on the public train. It was something i could not help doing. I enjoyed the way he described the various people he met and interacted with along the way from the annoying & patronizing Mary Ellen to "Chicken John", the guy on Stratton Mountain with the Enviro Meter to the four noisy, boistrous, safari attired high-and-mighties he encountered at one of the AT shelters.A deep sense of sadness overcame me tho when he proceeded to describe how unchecked logging, state approved killing of certain predatory animals in the late 1800s, diseases introduced from foreign lands, the over zealous collection of rare and endangered spieces of plants have forever changed the face of the forrests along the AT from what it used to be just 50 or so yrs ago.When i finished the book I came away feeling a great respect and even greater humility for MOTHER NATURE by all her beauty, majesty, her great expanse of power and seemingly never ending ability to shock and amaze even the most seasoned hiker. Bryson's acute observation and ability to paint that very picture with stunning clearity by combining such in-depth factual information with bursts of wittisisms make this book worth the read anytime anywhere.Having said that it was rather a downer to discover somewhere along the middle, just when things were getting exciting, that the story would not cover his adventures in the woods for the entire 2,200 miles of the AT cause he never did hike the entire length of it. Rather, he hiked the trail in several segments...finishing off with the 100 Mile Wilderness reunited with Katz again some months later.
I am not much for foul language and this book had its share of that.  I loved the story line and would recommend reading this as well as the first two in the series.

The strength of this book is that it is written by a neurologist with atheistic tendencies until having a very incredible Near Death Experience.  It is an excellent counter argument to the scientific, fact based belief that spirituality and God are just functions of an imaginative brain.

I have worked in the medical field for most of my careers and met many physicians. I am so pleased Dr. Alexander has written about his spiritual experience. His profession adds credibility, although there will continue to be the naysayers, I for one am thrilled to see what I and many others believe in writing from a Neurosurgeon. We are spiritual beings! My only criticism is religions do not play a part of the spiritual experience, they are man made, fear based and controlling. True spirituality is true freedom and love. Highly recommend!

summary: Plenty of Humor but Also an Important Message
reviewText: I am giving this book 4 stars instead of 5 only because I found the beginning part of the book (before they actually start hiking) to be slow and boring.  Once they started the Trail, though, it was anything but boring.  Not only were there constant laughs to be had and great stories of their adventures on the trail, but I am really thankful to Mr. Bryson for including so much of the environmental information that he did.  It was really eye opening and incredibly sad what we are doing to our natural resources, and I think Mr. Bryson has found a brilliant way to use humor to share this information in a way that is not only accessible but enjoyable.  Bravo, Bill!

summary: very interesting recounting of his experience
reviewText: The interesting part about this account is that this is from a very well educated man of science, who had not been a believer before.  He tells very well how this experience could not have been something which just happened due to the attack on his brain.  It is remarkable that he recovered fully and has been able to continue his life work.
Not the usual white light tunnel; this gentlemen from the educational stand point seemed to know what he was talking about and experiencing.

Although already a believer in "Heaven", I was interested in learning about Dr. Alexander's shift in perspective based upon his unique experiences. Overall a good book. I hope as a medical doctor, he does help shift the world in belief and understanding of life beyond life.

Selected by my book club.  Fun to read and share stories as we live near the trail.  Someone who has hiked most of the trail, attended the club meeting and shared his experiences.  Now talking about hiking a small portion of the trail.

I really appreciated this alternative perspective of potential life after death particularly after all the hubbub around the book and movie about the little boy who met Jesus when he had an afterlife experience.  I think there is an afterlife and it's for everyone not just those that are "Christians" so I appreciate this perspective.

I enjoyed the book but there wasn't really anything in there that I had not read from other NDE writers.  Too much of the book was indexes and appendixes...I would have liked more description of the journey.

I'm going to address the abuse Ophelia suffered, which I see many other reviewers have objected to. First of all - I do understand why other reviewers are upset. It was tolerated if not outright accepted and maybe this is not a book for younger girls who may misunderstand that this is not a good example of what they should do in a similar situation. HOWEVER, what the other reviewers are maybe not seeing is that, very unfortunately - it was portrayed accurately. Many victims of abuse will act similarly to how Ophelia did. It's not right and I wish it was different, but that's how it is. I've worked with victims of domestic abuse for the past three years - some are tolerant and even accepting of what was done to them for a variety of reasons. In this story, Ophelia was trying to help Hamlet - was trying to be his outlet and give him what he needed. Is it right? No. But it does happen. This book was not ADVOCATING abuse and saying hey, it's okay as long as you're upset, just like it is not saying that murder is okay. It was simply portraying a situation in which abuse was happening. And I'm not sure why people are surprised by the abuse. Did no one read the original play?Onto the book itself - I thought this was a rather excellent retelling of Hamlet, grim and harsh, from the point of view of someone who was an ally but who was also very wronged by that complex character and just a hint of magic and the supernatural.  I really enjoyed this exploration of Hamlet and Ophelia's relationship. Dark, sweet, complex, and no, not always pleasant which made it all the more realistic. I loved how the author gave the characters a bit of her own interpretation - especially Horatio. All in all, I couldn't put it down. I thought it was very well done. This author has a lot of talent and I will be seeking out more of her work.

This is a pretty fascinating story. Especially because the author is a highly trained neurosurgeon. It is another example, if more were needed of the incredible mystery of consciousness and the relationship between brain & mind.
Loved this book - the end totally threw me ... suspensful ... interesting ... at points a book that could not be put down.  Highly recommended!
This book details the more intellectual side of the life after death experience and answers more scientific questions.very good
I wondered what this book said.  It is quite an interesting read and although I don't buy all of it, it is a good thing to get you started thinking.

summary: Very good story of one persons experience to heaven, especially having come from a science background
reviewText: I am a volunteer for hospice. I have suggested this book to patients who are struggling with what happens after death. I remind them this is a story from a person who was a non believer of after death experiences. I think it is good to feel the soul and spirit of a person goes to a wonderful place, far from our understanding.
I really enjoyed reading this book, I think we all want to know what happens after Death.It makes it seem not bad at all.His way of telling the story is very interesting.
Great summer read, love and romance we what we all need. Lie in the sun and just drift away enjoy
Not sure if I think he really experienced this or whether it was something to do with his medical condition.  Make up your own mind on this story.

summary: Not sure that proof is the correct word.
reviewText: This was an interesting book, but required some leaps of faith that not everyone may be willing to make.  Certainly he expects us to view his experience from his point of view but I still have my doubts.

I thought it was worth the read and it appeared well the read until I started to read the rebuttal. The 2 together show what our faith is all about and how easily Satan can deceive us. It explains, in the Rebuttal how Eve and then Adam were deceived. both books complement each other.

Many authors can put a smile on your face as you read. Bill Bryson does more than that. He  makes  the reader laugh out loud as you read. You may try and prepare to prevent yourself from laughing out loud, so as not to disturb others in the room, but your attempts will be futile! Just like in his book "The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid", it is an enjoyable read.And, in this particular book, you not only laugh, you learn a lot of geography, history, etc.Even 16 years after its initial publishing, I recommend this book.Dr. Stanley E. Toompas, Optometrist& Author of , "I'm the One the Other Isn't, Books 1 & 2"

summary: Felt like I got blisters; what has happened to Nature?
reviewText: So much has been written in these reviews about Bryson's book I'll limit myself to a few major observations. A Walk in the Woods is humorous, but falls somewhere in the middle along the continuum of Bryson's funny to serious books. His hard-core, realistic descriptions of what he and his friend endured made me ache sympathetically for him.I have a friend who hiked the Trail and learning that parts of the Trail are in barely hikeable condition or undecipherable (or unmapped) was sad. This is one of our National Treasures, people. (But thanks to the volunteers who do tend to their portions!)Lastly, I was glad that Bryson included tales of the areas where man has harmed Nature - perhaps forever, such as in the town that had had to be abandoned because of underground coal mine fires that could not be extinquished. It's a sad day when a heralded nature trail can't be enjoyed without also witnessing some of the 20th century's disasters, but I'm glad Bryson called them to our attention.

summary: Proof of heaven is thought provoking
reviewText: A very interesting journey that you won't forget so easily.  It was alittle different a journey than the tipical nde.

This was not a excellent book, but I would recommend it to someone. She really gives you an insight to that lifestyle. Girls can learn through her experience. Not exactly a "tell all" but it is definitely good! You will get your money's worth though.

summary: Made me an enthusiastic Bryson fan
reviewText: The longest hike I have done, in terms of distance, is the Chilkoot Trail in Alaska. As a tour guide, I have time to spare between my jaunts across the state and took three days in the summer of 2012 to hike with a buddy along the length of this tremendously historic trail. It is 33 miles. Not even a fingernail scratch on a map of the Appalachian Trail, and because of this I have enormous respect for the out-of-shape Bryson and Katz who managed hundreds of miles of the AT, even if they didn't complete it.'A Walk in the Woods' is a fun book, and a good travelogue. In terms of personal description of their experience, Bryson is tremendously journalistic, and equally humorous. He takes himself not at all too seriously, and his jokes and his thoughts on the trail and hiking generally, were a joy to read. As a Washingtonian, i've grown up hiking and camping and can attest to many of his observations, such as the zen mode achieved when walking great distances and the increasing lack of attention paid to hygiene and your stomach, the longer you are in the woods. His imagined reaction to what would happen if he ran across a bear, (it involved the ruining of his underwear and likelihood of death through a 'blown sphincter') were laugh out loud funny.As any good travelogue should, he included anecdotal history throughout the work and opined on some of the more poignant aspects of American attitudes towards nature. His history of the trail I found altogether uninteresting (it would likely be more exciting, if I was in the midst of hiking the AT), but his notations on the Forest Service and Park Service were excellent. The Forest Service's primary function being the construction of roads through the nations wilderness, in order to better allow timber companies to access the 49 million acres of harvestable land. The Park Service, with a history of hurting the land when attempting to assist it, has gone to the other extreme and now will not interfere with diminishing grass lands, even if their assistance would be 'demonstrably beneficial'.His most wonderful observation though is worth quoting. In regards to Americas attitude towards nature, he says,"...alas, beauty has become something you drive to, and nature an either/or proposition--either you ruthlessly subjugate it, or you deify it, treat it as something holy and remote, a thing apart, as along the Appalachian Trail." This was the most impacting line of the book for me.Lastly, his relationship with Katz is heartfelt. You can sense the companionship and humor of their interactions. And, at the end of the book, when Katz has had a brief relapse into drinking, the monologue he gives is just genuine and intimate. A look at the lonely life a former alcoholic could easily occupy once he has said goodbye to the sauce.Overall, this is a great book that made me a huge fan of Bryson. Recommended, so long as you can trudge through his odd justification for only completing a portion of the trail and then returning to particular sections in day hikes and drives. It felt piece-meal, and easily could have been excluded from the book. As other reviewers have said, the work lost momentum in the second half, but it is still more than worth the read.

The book was recommended by a friend who said it was really good.  I agree.  For those who doubt the existence of an afterlife, the account by Eben Alexander of his experience is riveting.  He is a scientist, dedicated to the scientific method, and he doubted spirituality and what it means.  His illness and subsequent experience transformed him.
Really enjoyed this book. Very interesting especially coming from a scientist's point of view. Fast read. Thought provoking and inspiring.

summary: Parts made me laugh out loud!
reviewText: Part one of this book is sooo funny!  Had me in tears.  The second part is a lot of history and facts and not quite as funny, but still a very good read!

I enjoyed the book. It left me wanting more, so either that's a good sign because if peaked my curiosity, or it's a bad sign because it did not satisfy my curiosity. I definitely recommend reading the book as it is very interesting and well written.

Too bad it takes a highly respected neurosurgeon's testimony to open the eyes of the non believers as to there's more to life than what meets the eyes. Good book that stretches past the normal yada yada medical explanations of consciousness into the nuts and bolts of logical common sense. This book will open the eyes of the reader to pursue other authors versions of the mysterious ways of the conscious and subconscious mind. Sometimes the author gets a little wordy try to explain something he doesn't understand either.
He certainly has a solid scientific background.  I struggle with this belief and he has brought me closer to yea rather than nay.  Very interesting,

A thought provoking book about a subject that men have questioned for centuries. Having seen the lengths ancient peoples went to to not be alone at death, this book may actually answer that question, Is there a heaven?And what about hell?

I can see where this would bring comfort to the sick, and dying or even the bereaved. Having read other NDE literature, it's difficult to grapple with the way the story was given. The spiritual and scientific dichotomy just didn't resonate well. I think I would have preferred from purely scientific angle, even understanding how he tried to show their interconnectivity. In spite of which probably sounds like a negative review I did enjoy the book, my issue was aesthetics purely.
Enjoy the book  but it got too technical for a lay person ( meaning not a doctor or scientist). but once you get beyond that part is is terrific

This is a great book even though it doesn't fit easily into a single category.  It isn't a technical guide to the trail or hiking in general.  Much of the book doesn't even deal with hiking at all.  The book is funny, full of insight, has tragedy and triumph, and in the end is well worth reading.  The author seems to have problems with everyone along the trail that doesn't share his goal or opinions (most notably the Park and Forestry services).  Luckily the author cuts many of his criticisms on the loss of nature short and quickly moves on to a more upbeat topic.I've read this book twice and would recommend it to anyone that has ever seen a trailhead and felt a pull beyond words to see what was beyond the next hill.

Eben Alexander does a wonderful job of letting us know what is beyond and how (beyond) incredible it is and at the same time how to create that same love here in our physical bodies back on earth. My family experienced 2 tragic deaths withing the last 1 1/2 years and this was so helpful for me.Thanks for sharing your experience with the world.

summary: It was a well written book and told a believable story.
reviewText: I thought the book was well timed for the world we live in and told from a scientist point of view.  The scientific language was difficult for me as a lay person, so to be honest, i skipped through a lot of it, but  focused  on the personal side of the story.  It was very moving.

This is not a simple story at all...the author writes with a strong emphasis on his medical training and ponders physical and psychic issues.  That said, I found his story to be very reassuring on the reality I have accepted that heaven is real.  So many who rely on science to,dispel notions of God will doubtless mock this, but the blessings in my life go far beyond "the big bang" and I appreciate a scientific effort that reinforces spiritual sense.
