Interesting bimodal distribution of reader comments. It is clear that if you have a sense of humor and interest in, but not slavish love of nature, you will love this book. It has many hilarious passages. I liked Bryson's  criticism of the AT as well; that it might have some more places where  there was an interface between rural areas, and wilderness. I have always  found these interfaces the most magical and inspiring. (Although some are  unfortunately ugly as well.) As one who has hiked sections of the AT, I  thought it was an excellent depiction of the people and trial itself.
You can feel the passion of Dr. Alexander's experience in his words. A great link between science and religion. It is interesting to note what he DIDN'T experience during his coma.
The book moves, is enlightening, funny, and educational.  If you have ever walked in the woods, it might not look the same again!

This book relates the experiences of a highly acclaimed neurosurgeon when he lay near death.  His medical training serves him well when he documents his physical condition, and his scientific background enhances the details of his journey.  The only negative I experienced was perhaps his unwillingness or inability to curb the analytical details and just fly with the amazing journey.  It is clear, however, that he emphasized the professorial details to lend credence to the experience.
This was a quick read and was very well written.  I would have liked a little more information on the near death experience and less on how the family was handling the experience.

We haven't finished the book yet, but so far it is very interesting.  We are Christians, and are looking for ways to encourage people to accept Christ and the life beyond.  This book may be a good tool to use in this goal.  Faye Wilkerson

While I have read several books on "out-of-body," experiences, this book added additional insights not covered in other books. I recommend it to anyone looking for answers. Skeptics will always be skeptics, until they, themselves go through the process. For me, I'm a believer.

I have read about 10 of Richard Laymon's books and I have liked them all. This is also an entertaining story. Richard has a knack for combining suspense, horror, funny dialogue and sexual overtones that keep you turning pages. I have actually come to enjoy his books more than Stephen Kings'. The two best books Laymon has written is "The Traveling Vampire Show" and "Island". Since his death I am slowly working my way through all of his novels savoring each of them. If you enjoyed this novel I also recommend David Morrel's novel "Creepers". They have similar story lines. For now Richard Laymon is still my favorite Horror writer.
Nice summertime read.Take it to the beach. Sit down and read for a couple hours. Fast easy read.  Enjoyed it.
This is a great way to spend free time and get a good dose of romance. The story keeps you wanting to know about the past of the characters and rooting for love to heal the wounds.

summary: Doesn't everyone want to know about this subject?
reviewText: It was interesting to hear what he had to say since he is a doctor and it would appear that it was based on actual facts.
Thought his story was very interesting.Definitely makes you think (which I like about books).If it's not true,he has one heckuva imagination.

Sniper is not a profession that readily comes to mind when naming jobs.  Now I know why - it's really not an easy thing to do.  This is the story of Gunnery Sgt. Jack Coughlin, a veteran sniper for the Marines, and Capt. Casey Kuhlman, also a marine.  Think about what a sniper does.  Apart from being an expert marksman, this job cannot be easy, for many reasons, and this book explains why.  Coughlin tells a touching story of his father's work ethic, which he in turn learned, his own passion for baseball, how he was nearly blinded by a sharp stone thrown by neighborhood kids, and how he joined the Marines at nineteen where he discovered he was a great marksman despite never having used a gun before.  There's more to being a sniper and his comment, "...there is no such thing as a stupid sniper," resonates well throughout the book.

I think the most interesting part of this book is that Eben Alexander knows the "doubting Thomas" found in most doctors concerning the life beyond the physical realm as he was one himself but in spite of that he firmly believes and represents what he experienced. He also reminds the reader that we are here to learn and become more advanced in our understanding ofknowledge and love and finally realize we are all not separate but one.

I love to hear the stories of people who do not believe in God, but God has a way of pulling them in to His fold.  This was a supreme example of just that.  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was that it got a bit technical for me in certain sections, as it was written by a doctor and described his medical situation.  Other doctors, nurses, etc., will have a greater understanding of those parts than I did, as I'm an accountant.  However, I loved, loved his story of finding the Greatest Love of God during his unexpected illness.  Could see that it was important for the author to describe his condition in detail, for it was a miracle that he lived through it.  That was clear...

summary: Another source of "insight" into heaven and what we might ...
reviewText: Another source of "insight" into heaven and what we might expect.  Each writing on this subject comes with a different perspective and this one is interesting because of the author's background, education, and years of work as a neurosurgeon.

Unlike most people that have reviewed this book, I had not read any of the other books in the series. With that being said, I didn't feel as if I was missing out on anything just because I hadn't read the books prior to this book. To me that says a great deal about how the writer answers all the necessary questions without boring the reader. Willow and Randy's love story could have easily had an epilogue to finalize where they ended up down the road but otherwise, I believe the book had a heartfelt story line.

summary: Good Story of faith and science
reviewText: I loved the story and how graphically the visions are described. I am in healthcare and have heard so much of the denial of afterlife too. This was a great story told in a very interesting manner. I wonder if I enjoyed it so much because of my profession or my faith...
It was a quick easy read with a deep enough plot to keep me interested. Likable characters that have left me wanting to know them more through the other books of the series!

summary: A Doctor's View of the Afterlife
reviewText: I have been studying near death experiences since 1976 when my dad had cancer. I have a friend who refers to the NDE-ers as the "Dead Saints", who bring back their experiences of heaven to us. I had heard about Dr. Alexander, and thought he would be able togive a new reference point for it. I was hoping that he would inspire other scientists/doctors to see things differently. I would have liked more detail about what he learned and felt while over there.

summary: Proof or not, a fascinating book
reviewText: "Heaven" aside: this is a fascinating story about the medical trauma endured by Dr. Eben Alexander, a prominent neurological surgeon who suffered life-threatening bacterial meningitis.  Dr. Alexander has written a heartrending book about his sudden, excruciatingly painful illness. His wife and sisters keep vigil at his bedside.  His young son struggles to cope; his hospital colleagues struggle to help.  Each person in this story is a genuine character who we come to care about as they move through grief and hope and ultimately to joy when he recovers. In particular, the back story of his own adoption (and search to connect with his birth family) is poignant, with mixed emotions all around.  As a doctor, Alexander includes background on neurology. How does the tissue of the human brain give rise to an intelligent "self?" Is there something beyond the cellular matter inside our head that makes us "us?" As he describes his own illness, he explains brain science clearly but with a sound technical basis, including the different schools of thought about how the brain gives rise to consciousness.Of course, the point of the book is Dr. Alexander's own near-death experience. He tells this story as authentically as possible, making clear when words are inadequate and when his metaphors are limited. Given these limitations, he does well evoking a reality where there is no physical sensation, no time as we know it, and no memory of earthly identity. There are only a few chapters that describe the "afterlife," with much more of the book dedicated to his medical experience and the biology of the brain. But I was satisfied to see that quite a few things were included that had not been in the Newsweek article (a precursor to the book's release) and news stories about it. This includes his experience of a dark, claustrophobically fleshy realm and a much different realm of vast brightness that he experiences as being in the presence of God (although he is cautious about naming God and does not dwell on Christ or other organized religion - which will disappoint some as much as it appeals to others).  I'll also admit I was a little thrilled at the story of the "girl on the butterfly wing," especially when he finally recognized her.I know it is a stretch to call this "proof." It is one person's experience and it cannot be observed or repeated by others, as science requires. But death will always be that way. It is fascinating that, with all we can know about human biology, the mystery of consciousness and death remain just out of our grasp. Those who want to disbelieve Dr. Alexander's story will do so.  That is human nature, and we're all skeptics about something -- it takes doubt as well as faith to keep humanity's quest for knowledge driving ever forward.  For those who are inclined to believe, or who are not sure, Dr. Alexander's story is certainly food for thought. Personally I cannot say I'm 100% convinced. But I will say that in my own soul, the images and experience he described resonated with a feeling not unlike familiarity.  IF this is true - if Heaven is out there- it might well be like this.

summary: Entertaining, Not really about AT much
reviewText: Listened to the audio book and I was laughing hysterically at the beginning .  I did get his humor and at least he was entertaining.  Some books I've read about the AT are so dry, like "I walked 8.2 miles and stayed in Hilbilly shelter, then I got up and walked 11.1 miles...."  He does go off on tangents about alot of things, so what I got from it was it wasn't really that much about the AT.  I didn't think he complained alot like some people said.  He did describe  better than most  the parts of the AT that he did see.  Also, I believe the fantatical thru-hikers seem to think the AT belongs to them and there is no merit in doing short hikes.  I'm glad the book wasn't really about a thru-hike.  I liked his descriptions  and humor but I could also see where some people who lack a sense of humor wouldn't get him.  It's an enjoyable read, but if you are a serious, fantatical hiker, just accept this book for what it is. I give him credit for walking any of the trail and even started to like Katz before it was all said and done. If you are really serious about hiking the trail, I would suggest getting a variety of authors and their perspectives.  Normally I don't like authors reading their own books, but in this case if anyone else had read it, I don't think it would have had as much impact.

This was an enjoyable and uplifting book, detailing one man and his family journey through an illness that rightly should have killed him.  It can be considered a true miracle of science and spiratuality.
What an awesome book to add on the two that already exist. Several women have been in violent relationships and has found real love after wards. I love how this is not the "typical" love story.

I've always been fascinated by tales of Near Death Experiences (NDE).  I suppose this and a natural curiosity is what drew me to `Proof of Heaven' by Dr. Eben Alexander.The author is a neurosurgeon and also the victim of an extraordinarily rare spontaneous e. coli infection that nearly killed him.  `Proof of Heaven' is his cathartic missive that chronicles what he encountered as he lay comatose and near death for a week.This is an interesting story particularly because of the scientific background of the author.  Who, by his own admission, had a very difficult time in the belief of a God or life after death.  His NDE was transformational.First, there is the fact that Dr. Alexander is regarded in the scientific literature as a medical miracle. Given the severity of his illness the chances of his simple survival were slim to none.  Were he to survive the anticipated outcome was life in a persistent vegetative state. However, he not only survived but against all odds made a seemingly full recovery.While in coma, the author was present in body only. One that remained unresponsive as the e. coli ate away at his neo-cortex.  However, outside of the spacial-temporal world that defines material consciousness, Dr. Alexander was on the journey of his life.  By his account he traveled beyond an earthly existence to a place better defined by levels of increasing spiritual awareness and enlightenment. Unconditional love was at the core of this state-of-being.This physician, against years of academic and clinic training and application of scientific method now believes that true health can only be achieved when one realizes that God and the soul are real.  Too, death is not an end of personal existence, but rather a transition.This is a story that is difficult to ignore and a book I would highly recommend for those with even a cursory interest in the subject matter.
I always like to hear about NDE from different sources.  It stimulates my curiosity.  I know folks who have had this experience.

I started out really loving this book, but the longer I read, the less I was drawn in. I believe Eben Alexander. I've even had experiences similar to his.What I came away with was two-fold. One, seeing some of my own experiences validated in print, unexpectedly, ended up doing nothing for me. Two, no matter how transcended an experience is, nothing makes up for the educating and change-causing effect of a long journey "there," as opposed to a leap, such as is caused by a near death experience. I very much hope to read more from Mr Alexander once his ordinary life experience has caught up to his transcended experience.
A book that is both tragic and humorous, with an uplifting ending for all the characters in their various struggles.
Read this book very quickly.... was a good plot and Author kept me sitting up straight.  I love suspense and she kept me there.

Bill Bryson can sometimes be too cute for my liking, but his style works well in this book.  With his sometimes trusty sidekick Katz, who is totally out of his element here, the two decide to hike the Adirondack Trail from Georgia to Maine.  Bryson keeps things light and breezy, but at the same time, the difficulties of such an undertaking are shown; the cold, the rain and snow, and the anxieties about getting lost and running into wild animals.  There are many interesting and humorous moments here, getting a wild ride from a young couple in Georgia, having a woman tag along with them and drive them crazy, staying with many others in a slummy bunkhouse, Katz disappearing in the middle of nowhere and so on.  After a long time hiking and checking the map to see that they had not travelled far at all, one could really appreciate the vast distance they had to walk.  Bryson more than once says that the walk was monotonous and pointless in many ways, which is why he eventually had to skip many sections.  His walk in the coal mining country of Pennsylvania was among the most interesting, especially the town with fault cracks throughout.  Living in a New England college town Bryson goes a bit overboard with his uneasiness about "rednecks" but his comments are made in fun and it's more about being a fish out of water than anything else.  This book is just a fun read, and if approached in this way it is enjoyable.

summary: Most, if not All Women Have A "Promiscuous Freak" Side Waiting To Come Out
reviewText: First, my criticisms:This book was not as entertaining as the 1996 bestseller, "You'll Never Make Love in This Town Again."  I remember reading that book when I resided in Los Angeles, but I really hadn't read another "erotic memoir" and/or "Hollywood Kiss & Tell" type book until Ms. Karrine Steffans arrived on the scene (Ms. Steffans has been one of my MySpace 'Friends' for a while now).  Actually, I really wish a book about former Entertainment Industry attorney Angela Wallace would come out.  I think that book would potentially blow "Confessions" out of the water.Sadly, being a person who has pursued a career in the Entertainment Industry myself, very little in this book truly "shocked" me or even surprised me.  I think women will find this book much more interesting than the average male would.  Men (both in the Entertainment Industry and outside of it) already know what's up.  All you have to do is watch HBO's "Entourage" to get a glimpse of the Hollywood lifestyle from the male perspective.Over half of the reason why most men want to be rich and/or famous is so they score more women.  It's really that simple.  Most guys who are singers, musicians, TV stars, Movie stars, Hip-Hop/Rap stars, stand-up comics, or any other Entertainment Industry VIP type would never be able to attract and seduce the quantity and/or quality of women that they now do if it weren't for their wealth and fame.  Even a knucklehead like Pauly Shore scores chicks in Hollywood.  C'mon people.  Pauly Shore??Did anyone ever read "Pimp: The Story of My Life??"  If not, you should.  Robert Beck a.k.a. "Iceberg Slim" breaks it down in that book.  In that book, he essentially says that the vast majority of women have an ultra-kinky, masochistic, submissive, and promiscuous side of them just begging for the right opportunity to reveal itself (take note men! Read "PIMP" and "Mode One").  Ms. Steffans is a prime example of that.  Her story has very little to do with her adverse upbringing.  Even if Ms. Steffans had been raised by a college-educated, church-going mother with a few morals and ethics, I truly believe Karrine's story would still be essentially the same.  Why?  Because Ms. Steffans was DYING to become famous.  She's star-struck.  When you're star-struck, especially if you're a woman, you'll do just about anything to achieve wealth, fame, and the glamorous life.  I used to live in Hollywood, CA (right on Hollywood Blvd, in between Fairfax and LaBrea).  I met plenty of aspiring actresses, singers, models, and music video girls.  I know their story.My comments and/or compliments:A lot of people criticize Ms. Steffans for writing and publishing this book, but I don't.  It's smart business.  Women love to read gossip (men do too, but not quite as much as the average woman).  Why do you think tabloids like "The Star" and "The Nationals Enquirer" are so popular??  The Wall Street Journal would go out of business before tabloid magazines ever will.  Ms. Steffans gave her audience just what her nosy, gossipy demographic wanted to read:  "juicy" behind-the-scenes details of all of her erotic trysts with well-known male celebrities.  "Is so-and-so packin' (i.e., well endowed)??  Does that one rapper have stamina?  Is that one studly movie star sensuous and kinky in bed??"  These are questions that most women 18-35 want answered.  And Ms. Steffans doesn't disappoint.I congratulate Karrine on her new career as an author.  Being a book author can be a very rewarding and satisfying career.  If this book is her entry into the world of books and publishing, more power to her.  To the guys who were "called out" in this book:  Can you really be upset??  You make your bed, you lie in it.  Ever heard of a "confidentiality agreement??"  Prince, the singer and musicians, knows all about those (hint, hint, wink, wink).  I think the aspect of this book being a true "cautionary tale" is over-hyped.  This book is good entertainment ... nothing more, nothing less.  This book will not dissuade any aspiring actress from making the same mistakes Ms. Steffans made.  They will have to gain wisdom as they experience their climb on the Hollywood ladder.

There are a few really illuminating chapters within several biographical chapters.  I like the scientific explanations that the author found did not discredit the spiritual revelations.  The only disappointment was that when my Kindle indicated there was still 20% left, that 20% was devoted to footnotes and thank you's.

I'm not going to write a lengthy review summarizing the book, but just wanted to add my 2 cents-so to speak.  This is the first book I have read by the author and I truly enjoyed every word.  I was drawn to the book because a co-worker of mine had a daughter that hiked the trail one summer.  I couldn't even imagine what her experience had been like and this book gave me some understanding of the experience.  Do I think the AT hikers are crazy?  Absolutely!  Am I a little envious of their experiences?  A resounding Yes!  Conflicting emotions about the whole thing?  Totally!Thank you to the author, for letting me live vicariously through his experience, if only for a brief period of time.
I found it most interesting as the unknown is difficult for most to understand especially a scientific mind and the fact that he experienced this through almost dying is amazing.
Humorous tale of Bill and what I picture his out of shape buddy Katz, quick read. What brought me to read this was after enjoying A Walk Across America by Peter Jenkins

reviewerName: Dr. Wilson Trivino "Success- living the life ...
reviewText: We are all on a journey from the womb to the tomb, but none of use know what is after that?  No one has really come back from death. There are individuals who have experience near death experiences but you often wonder they really experience a trip or imagined the whole thing.In Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife, Dr. Eben Alexander claims to have made the passage, or at least get to the outer rings of the transition. What makes this book fascinating is that it is written by a scientist who before his experience did not have much of a spiritual belief system.  However, once he got back, he became a believer and now is on a quest to share his story.The book also delves into Eben's own insecurities and the internal struggles that have consumed so much of his life.  It is a quick read and gives the reader one man's odyssey as he literally came back from the dead.

summary: Amazing perpective on near death experiences
reviewText: If you are questioning what happens after death, read Dr. Alexander's book. The fact that he is alive is an amazing story in its self. Parts of the book are technical and told to get the attention of scientists, but that is not the majority of the book. I read the book in preparation for his visit to my town and I am glad that I did. I find his story comforting and quite similar to other accounts of near death experiences. The book and his appearance leave lots of questions, but he is still writing and has a website. We will always have questions, but that is part of our journey on this earth. Proof of Heaven serves as a prompt/guidepost for my journey.
I was hesitant at first, but drawn in to the true story as most people would be because of the subject matter, Very good book and very well written
A slow read, simply because you stop and think about the evil Forest Service, Centralia, hypothermia and American chestnut trees.  Maybe more serious than other Bryson works.

I really love near death experiences.  It makes me feel closer to my "true" home, and gives me hope for a better world.  It was a great story of faith and answers to remarkable prayers.  The back story was a bit choppy, but you realize it was written by a Dad, not a professional author.  Their own journey to knowing and understanding Christ is wonderful.  I realize this experience is sacred, and many things may not be able to be told to all of us, but the one topic I wish would have been answered in the book by their son is: What was your homework?  What did you have to work on?  Why was it your favorite thing?

I have lost a lot of close people lately so I wanted to open my mind to this. I would love to believe this is truly how it works. But only time will tell I guess. I have recommended this to others.When someone takes pictures of me at home, I have the same number of orbs surrounding me as the people close to me that have recently departed. I get comfort from that.
Terry Osborne has a good sense of suspense and realistic, believable penchant for romance. I recommend Osborn for rromance readers.

Kind of a scientific view of his Near Death Experience even though he tries to write in lay mans terms. He describes a beautiful place after moving thru the dark tunnel which he called a worm hole.  I once had an out of body experience as a kid, flying ala Peter Pan above the Edens Expressway towards downtown Chicago.  He experienced flying with an angel or guide through the air above a wondrous world full of joy and instant knowledge of any question he thought of.  The ending is poignant when he realizes that his guide was his sister who had died before he was born.  Food for spiritual thought.

While the title suggests it is an autobiography the majority of the book is concerned with the authors time in Iraq during the campaign to overthrow Saddam Hussein.The author was an experienced sniper with previous combat experience before going to Iraq. What comes through clearly is the very aggressive attitude of the Marine Corp and the author's desire to participate in the fighting. This is counter-pointed by an incident late in the campaign which obviously left a deep impression on the author and highlights the difficulties of modern fighting and trying to prevent civilian casualties.What also comes through clearly are the problems of trying to maintain a family life and being in an elite military unit. These problems led to the author's marriage breaking down and to his decision to leave the Marine Corp. He also details some of the frustrations he found serving with some people who are less than professional and his disgust at one person in particular being rewarded for his service was another reason for leaving the Corps.All in all, an intersting book with insight at what motivates a sniper but I would have liked to see more about the author's life other than in Iraq.
An interesting read with a medical perspective and a view into the afterlife. This book was certainly more comprehensive thanother books dealing with this subject matter.

It was difficult to put this book down once I started reading...and to realize this even happened in my state makes it even more interesting.  Really enjoyed this and hope to see a movie of it if one is ever made.

summary: Combination Mystery and Love Story Rolled Into One
reviewText: The author did a masterful job keeping the mystery a mystery until near the end of the story.  Well done Terri!  Also, the author built the strength of the love story to a surprising peak that will keep your interest.  Thanks Terri!

This is a book I normally would not have read, but I was on a trip and had run out of reading material and someone had left this behind at the lodge I where I was staying.The book is an easy quick read about Julia who has had an abusive childhood and is getting ready to marry an abuser. She has an epiphany on the day of her wedding and leaves her dress on a tree as she high tails out of North Dakota and into Oregon to live with a crazy Aunt. There she develops friendships with some quirky women, all of whom have their own tales of abuse.Some of the abusive scenes and descriptions are hard to read. Some of the characters and situations are rather trite or cliched, but in the end you do care about each woman and her journey towards healing. The ending of the book was a little disappointing to me in that Julia's lover showed little understanding of what an abused person goes through and without that understanding, it was hard for me to accept the sequencing of events (trying to avoid spoilers).I liked the book enough that I'm going to readThe Last Time I Was MeandHenry's Sisters.

summary: So good I read it twice.
reviewText: A very funny story even though he wrote this now 15 years (or so) ago.  The need to wander gives it all a bit of a romantic notion.  However, you also see that he and his friend were entirely over their heads.

We let my wife go after 10 days in coma as we feared that she will be left in vegetative state if she comes back. There are aspects in the book which make me think if I took a wrong decision. However there are aspects which make me think that she must have got her angle and one with infinite love and compassion. It also strengthens my belief that I will meet her one day.
This book made a believer out of me. It confirmed what I already believed. Praise God almighty. He loves us inspite of our faults.
This is a fast moving tale with likable characters.  They are eccentric, but very likable, and I enjoyed it very much..

I loved this book even though I knew what the outcome was going to be.  I couldn't put it done.  You find yourself rooting for Beth and Joe.  And, you want to hate Lucas, but he's not a bad guy either.  And, I can't wait to read the 2nd book that follows.  It's a fun mindless summer read.

Willow is a woman with secrets. Randy doesn't mind the secrets, he's intrigued with woman. There are two other books but this one is an easy stand alone. If you can get over the desire to lock up the self-serving reporter you'll be fine. The friendship between Willow, Beth and Sid is refreshing as they don't indulge in the backstabbing that some girlfriends do. Anchor Island is a place you would love to visit, too bad it's not in my backyard! Randy is drool material without being roidded out. He and the guys are welcome in my house. There's likable lawyer and a photographer that made me applaud.

summary: Intricately woven story with significant details throughout.
reviewText: I enjoyed this book and how every detail had significance. Questions were answered and left you guessing throughout the book as you read along.
This and other books like it were recommended to me by a person who opinion I value.  At times it was a little "involved" for me and I kind of got lost while reading it, but I did enjoy it.

Great book.  Author surprised me with his intelligent and creative flow leaving it hard to put down.  Very detailed and leaves you with a sense of what to truly expect while attempting this thru-hike.

summary: "The resort isn't quite as deserted as they think" (surprise?)
reviewText: What the blurb on the back doesn't tell you, however, is that "Blood Games" is really two different stories interlaced into one somewhat uneven novel.The primary story is your standard horror fare, as five women get together and camp out at a supposedly abandoned backwoods resort with a bloody history... Yeah, if you didn't know what genre this book was, you could probably make an educated guess.The second story consists of flashbacks, most of which revolve around the women's escapades in college, apparently to whet our appetites and give us several little precursors to their imminent ordeal at the Totem Pole Lodge. These chapters could be compared to the flashbacks on "Lost," which didn't necessarily have anything to do with the present-day story but told us more about where the characters came from and what made them tick. I'm giving "Blood Games" the benefit here, because otherwise it looks like Richard Laymon just rewrote and slapped together two originally unrelated manuscripts to fill his page quota.The book's first half is more concerned with character than with that pesky thing called "plot." Not only does nothing major happen in the present, but the flashback chapters take up a LOT of these first 200 pages. So you'll really have to make an effort to like the five heroines if you want to be invested in the second half. Not the easiest thing in the world. The only one I consistently cared about was Abilene, the level-headed POV protagonist. Everyone else--the headstrong Cora, the feisty Finley, the spoiled beauty Vivian, and the physically unattractive sympathy magnet Helen--fluctuates at best. Yes, even Helen suffers because the book doesn't really focus on her image problems until quite a ways in.But I got used to them all. And y'know what? The rest of "Blood Games" was enjoyable and suspenseful enough. Plus, on their own, the flashback chapters are pretty entertaining, maybe even preferable during the book's first half. They get less interesting towards the end, but that's when hell breaks loose at the lodge and delivers a finale typical of Richard Laymon. It's not the best finale he's ever written, but I don't regret the ride there.7/10

Wonderful story of this man's experience in to the next world.  I am always amazed by people who scoff at someone else's experiences.  Here we have medical personnel who had a hard time believing one of their own.  I am a firm believer in near death experience.

Too many juicy details..I did not put it down for more than a few hours until i was finished reading it. Needless to say, there is a message in this book about the unseen ills of the industry and the lengths women would go to be accepted in this particular industry. It also depicts in detail the exploits these women are subject to at the hands of famous and successful individuals.
The description says this book will change your life.  Not even close.  It was an interesting book and remarkable that this dr had this experience.

What I especially like about this book is the authors honesty about how he was before the experience and how he was after. It is always good to read the perspective of someone who did not believe in an afterlife.

This caught my interest early and kept it all the way through.  It is the story of an abducted girl and a woman's attempts to save her. The woman searching (Molly) lost her daughter in a similar kind of crime and refuses to let it happen to another little girl.I found the characters believable and the details beautifully described.  I don't often read books this long and involved, but this did hold my attention.  I do feel it would've worked as well if it were shorter, but that is a matter of personal preference.  I would recommend this book to anyone who would enjoy a thrilling, paranormal mystery that is very well written!
I enjoyed this book but perhaps those without a medical background will find some of the technical information a bit hard to follow.
Thoroughly thought provoking. I believe him and pray he is right. Quite something for a physician to be willing to share such a personal story. I think this makes it all the more believable.

summary: Well written case for proof of heaven.
reviewText: It was very well written, but I skipped over some of the technical information, because I'm not in the medical field.  I got the feeling that he was presenting a case to people in the medical field, which I completely understand.  I thought it interesting that his experience was much more than the light at the end of the tunnel.
Love all her books, can't wait to  find more new ones...  Thank  you so much Amanda for all the entertainment you provide to me, I've read you for years.

4 stars because it is too medical in parts for the general reader, but I guess Eben needed to convince his medical peers.i have read 100's of books on that topic. This one is especially convincing, since it comes from a man who knows how the brain operates.
Proof of Heaven, I loved the book - written so well -information we all love to hear and I recommended the book to family and friends

My friend Chris read this, and then passed it on to me, stating, "We need to do this."  I will now pass it on to my friend Alana, saying, "Wouldn't it be cool if we could go on some day hikes on the AT?  I don't think I could make the whole thing."  The best thing about this book is that while you're reading it you feel as if you're right there, walking the Appalachian Trail with Bryson.  He describes, in vivid detail, the people he meets on and off the trail, the conditions of the trail, and his experiences, to the point where when I do some day hikes on the AT I just may recognize something he's talked about.  Another great attribute of this book is that this is not solely the story of Bryson and his friend Katz hiking the AT; Bryson also describes the history of the trail, the environmental concerns surrounding the trail, and so much other information about the trail and the people who have been affected by it.  Bryson's wit and sarcasm make even the driest history of the trail interesting, and reading the book definitely makes the reader want to get up and hike the trail, or at least part of it.
Some of us are blessed with special abilities, although not everyone believes that those that are able to see, really do.  This book is showing what could happen.
The first third of the novel was slow, the second third went a little faster and the final third was a page turner.

I enjoyed the plot of Home to Stay very much. It was original and inventive. I think the resolution was a bit hurried but ultimately a good ending.  An excellent happy ever after for easily relatable characters we can all imagine being friends with.

summary: Interesting and plausible but a bit padded
reviewText: I bought this book after reading an excerpt online. It was well written and compelling, but I felt as if there wasn't quite enough material for a full book, even one as slim as this, so there were places where it seemed padded, as if the author (or his editor) was looking for ways to make it longer. In particular, I felt this way about the chapter, late in the book, where he went into how "scientific" the notion of consciousness is.I've seen the 20/20 and Nightline segments on Dr. Alexander, and I think you can get most of the gist of his experience from that, though the book goes into more detail about his medical condition and certainly his background and his near-death experience as well.Still, it's a good addition to the literature on life after death if you're interested in the subject and a fast read.

summary: The most convincing account of heaven I've ever read
reviewText: Dr. Eben Alexander's Proof of Heaven is by far the most convincing account of heaven that I've ever read, and I've read at least five accounts, including the bestselling Heaven is For Real, Flight to Heaven, and 90 Minutes in Heaven.  As of date, Proof of Heaven still remains #1 on the New York Times Best Sellers List.I am fascinated by the fact that many of these accounts are strikingly similar.  However, I became somewhat of a skeptic myself when I noticed that most of the books I had read on the afterlife were written by ministers, missionaries, or someone affiliated with a church.  To hear an account from someone who didn't believe in God, didn't go to church, and who had no interest in religious matters, made that account far more believable.  In fact Dr. Alexander is a neurosurgeon who relied on scientific proof to explain the workings of the world.Unexpectedly infected with bacterial meningitis, Dr. Alexander remained in a coma for seven days. By the end of the week, doctors were convinced that he had no chance of waking, and even if he woke, he would never recover.  But one day he wakes up and eventually completely recovers to the astonishment of the medical community.  During the time he is unconscious, he gives a heartfelt account of what happens to him.  Though Dr. Alexander's voice is thoroughly engaging, his time in heaven is described quite generally.  There are no incredible details of heaven.  The most descriptive he gets is when he talks about puffy, pink-white clouds, flocks of transparent orbs, shimmering beings racing across the sky, and people singing and dancing among trees, fields and waterfalls.  God is referred to as Om, and the most vivid character is a girl on a butterfly wing who accompanies him.However, his descriptions of hell are compelling and disturbing.  Here, Dr. Alexander is almost graphic in his details and his report stays with you for some time.  As a reader, you are so sold on his story that you begin to think that hell really does exist, and that maybe it's a good idea to review the Ten Commandments.  He also spends many pages informing the reader on near-death experiences and where his experience fits in that research.  His insights on spirituality and God are alone well worth the read.

An enjoyable read.  It was quite amusing how he chose his hiking partner, whose main qualifications seemed to be that he had a pulse, was an acquaintance of Bryson, had nothing else to do at the time, and most importantly, was the only person willing to go.  That he was a bona fide neurotic was a bonus.It's hard to imagine two guys less prepared for a long hike.  As someone for whom being fit is a normal part of life, it's just amazing, even hilarious, to see how people prepare for highly vigorous physical activities.  Bryson's method consisted of asking no one for advice, and taking 2 long walks.  His partner did even less.  Then when they're out on the trail, obviously having a very difficult time, Bryson bitterly resents the fit people racing by him, having no problems lifting their packs overhead when crossing the river.  Nothing about "maybe I should have actually prepared for the hike" or anything like that.  I had to chuckle and remind myself that intelligence and writing ability are no guarantee of having the slightest clue about physical activities.To their credit, they did walk a significant length of the trail - not like these high-rollers who pop in, walk a few miles on the trail, and hog the whole campsite because, ew, you other people smell!I enjoyed Bryson's observations about the regions he was walking through, and the historical background of the trail and its environs.  It was somewhat disappointing that they didn't finish the trail, but that's the way life goes sometimes, and despite a complete lack of preparation, by the end he clearly had learned a lot about hiking and the trail.

summary: MOMENTS OF SHEER BRILLIANCE - IN A FOREST OF  FAIR PROSE
reviewText: The author has an amazing command of the english language, which he uses, intermittently, to describe his sometimes poignant, sometimes hilarious experience of hiking along the Appalachian Trail. I greatly enjoyed about 40% of the book (that alone makes it worthwhile) enjoyed about another 40%, and labored through the other 20. Mr Bryson honestly reports the experiences he had while hiking some 900 miles of the trail with a quirky, earthy, friend. The honesty and personal vulnerability of his writing was touching on a very human level. For the most part, this book was an intriguing read. I am looking forward to reading another.

One of the noteworthy things about Bill Bryson is that he is funny and that clearly shows through in his book A Walk in the Woods.  So much of what he has to say about hiking rings true as anyone who has been on a hike or a camp out for that matter.  The joy of a motel, with a shower are as heavenly he describes it.When Bill Bryson moved back to the US, after living years in Great Britain, he came up with the idea of hiking the length of the Appalachian Trail.  He tried to talk anyone and everyone into accompanying him and finally an old and very out of shape friend named Stephen Katz agreed.  Their adventure begins by Katz tossing out many necessities to lighten the load and from that point the reader is happy to tag along on their lengthy excursion.But Bryson is not all humor, the reader learns many interesting and entertaining facts about bears, the trail, hiking equipment, history, earth science, the changing face of the woods in America, environmental issues, endangered and extinct animals and natural disasters.I'd happily recommend the book to anyone interested in travel or humor.

summary: My Literary Trek Through the AT
reviewText: I had heard of Bill Bryson, but had never read any of his books. I picked this up at a discount store, and thus began MY adventure. From the moment I started, I was enthralled. In between Bill's recollection of his adventure is littered all kinds of interesting stories and histories of the places visited and the wildlife that lives (or lived) there, and best of all is the humor (my favorite part is his account of reading the book about bear attacks). I was a bit disappointed, as someone already pointed out, he did not hike the entire trail, but I was never the less intrigued by every bit of what he did see.Though I do disagree with some of his science and politics, it doesn't hurt the book one bit. I was glad, I guess you could say, that he does point out that often times conservationists and the Park Service do more harm than good for these National Parks and nature in general.The only reason I gave it 4 stars was the F word and a few other bits of dialogue could have been done without. I realized that it was mostly, if not always, part of a conversation, but still.

A walk in the woods is a non-fiction humorous novel to read. It starts off with two hilarious characters Bryson and Katz, these two main characters in the story have decided to hike the Appalachian Trail. But what lies ahead, is way out of their league. Raining, snow, hail, all of these things comes right into their face on their crazy journey.The book itself is full of many parts of humor, adventure, and wilderness. Even though this book does have that very beautiful nature feeling the overwhelming amount of high school level facts they throw in, in chapter full can become overwhelmingly boring. But even though those facts were included I found this book a very good read, and hope you will decide to read it as well.
Home to Stay was a good romance.  The characters are the type you can picture being real.  You will embrace the main characters, Willow and Randy.  If you want love and friendship,read this  book.

summary: A Good Luck at the NDE Experience
reviewText: This book is better than most near death experience books as it is written by a neurologist who experiences as both a doctor and a participant.  Easy to read, but the take away is still who knows?
The coma ideas I have read several times and still get confused.  However, while I enjoyed the book, I wanted more details about the images and the experience.

You might think, perhaps, that a book that tells the tale of two neophyte hikers tackling an overly ambitious project (hiking the entire length of the Appalachian Trail) and not succeeding, but having virtually no truly dramatic moments, a book that doesn't hide the fact that hiking such a long distance quickly becomes boring even to the people involved, an interminable slog through woods that you're too tired to appreciate the beauty of, able to think only of your next break from it in some small town or rest stop, would be intensely boring to someone just READING about somebody else's boring, interminable slog.You'd be wrong. Bryson manages to tell the story with sufficient dry wit and self-deprecation that there are actually several laugh-aloud moments. Add to this his marvellous detailed research into the flora, fauna, history, and politics of the Trail, and his fine descriptions of those moments when he actually came out of his exhaustion-induced stupor long enough to notice the stunning scenery, and you have a fine read. And as he says toward the end of the book, they may not have conquered the trail, but they (or at least, HE) DID hike 870 miles over the course of a spring, summer, and fall (his partner accompanied him for somewhat less than that.) Not bad for a rank amateur who started off out of shape and utterly unwise in the ways of the wilderness. I have to admit, I'm impressed.

Does consciousness cease when the brain dies? "No" says Dr. Alexander.His book is based on his personal experience of brain death. Provocative and a helpful contribution to a body of literature that suggests that consciousness continues after death.
The book was good, but sometimes hard to follow.  Another person's journey to the hereafter.  I would recommend this book.
This book kept my interest and I was enjoying reading it.  Loved the ending. Enjoyed all the characters in this book.

[...]My rating: 4 of 5 ⭐️Working in Dempsey's Bar & Grill is not exactly what Willow Parsons went to school for, but it's what she has enjoyed doing for the last year since she landed on Anchor Island. Not eager to share the fact she has chosen the small community to hide out in, she has nonetheless been able to make some really good friends here. Only one person unsettles her, partly because his massive size reminds her of someone she never wants to see again, and partly because of the conflictling feelings he brings out in her.Gentle giant, that is how everyone sees Randy Navarro, adventurer and owner of the local gym, but he can't seem to catch a break with Willow. Awkward, since Will and his sister Sid are the best of friends, and they all hang out together on a regular basis. When he notices there isn't simply dislike, but real fear in her eyes, he is determined to make her feel as safe as possible. The preparations for the wedding of their friends offers opportunities to slowly win her trust.Recognizing Randy for the kind man he is, Willow finally is letting down her guard with him, and soon finds herself drawn into a romantic entanglement she did not want to have. But when her worst fears came true, instead of turning to the ones she had come to love, she reacted as she always had.......she ran.*****Warm and Lush!!This is not my first book in the Anchor Island series by Terri Osburn, a series that centres around a small island on the outer banks, and each have left me feeling utterly satisfied.The characters from previous books reappear as supporting cast in HOME TO STAY, but the book is a story by itself, a solid standalone. There is no ongoing backstory that snakes through the series you have to be afraid of missing out on if you don't read the books in sequence or even miss one here or there. A colourful collection of friends are at the core of each story, in their late twenties to mid thirties, each finding their own, sometimes unexpected, happy ever afters.This time it is Randy's turn, a quiet and unassuming giant of a man who is protective of his friends and sister, loves challenging himself by seeking adventure and puts a high value on living healthy. A good man, who is bothered by the fact that the woman he has more than a passing interest in seems to be afraid of him, when he poses absolutely no threat to her at all.The object of his focus, Willow, has come to the island a year ago, eager to escape into anonymity, for fear of being recognized and found, with good reason. She has kept to herself for the most part, but still has managed to make a few friends without having to share too much background information. She is simply seen as someone very private. Randy brings out feelings in her that slowly start making her feel safe enough to open up.Well-written and dripping with atmosphere, Terri Osburn creates a close-knit community where people still look out for each other. Where the entire town is invested in the happiness of one of its members. And where, once you have been adopted, you always have a home. As Willow finds out.✨A captivating, spicy and heart-warming home-coming.✨**Copy provided in return for an honest review.**
easy read nothing educational but surely somthing to take on a plane ride or to the beach it fun and crazy evrything you expect from the cover a couple of "what the hell " moments cool book over all

summary: Maybe My Expectations Were Too High
reviewText: Would have liked to have heard more details of his experience in the next sphere, instead of the urgency he felt to have the scientific community believe this was a true experience in him and in others. To those of us that believe in NDE's, that would have been more relative to us. Still a good book with many thought- provoking concepts presented.
This book is great. It has given me some peace of mind. I believed there was something after this life, but since my husband's passing 7 months ago I had some doubts.
Non-fiction at its best. I highly recommend this book to everyone! It is an amazing story and extremely thought-provoking. Don't judge the writer until you've read his story.
With the recent death of my Husband this book helped give me the peace I had gained more meaning. Especially with his view of persons singing and so happy.

summary: An Important Step On The Path to Enlightenment
reviewText: Having read many books on this subject over many years, I found this accounting particularly credible because of the author's scientific background vis-a-vis the "non-scientific" extraordinariness of his experience and how he came to grips with it. It was a deeply moving account of his life and how this NDE affected him and changed his life perspective. Unless one goes into this reading as a skeptic with a closed mind, one would be hard-pressed to discount the supporting evidence in the form of the many doctors and family and friends who were so intimately involved, not to mention the many other documented accounts with so much commonality of experience.

summary: A Beautiful Story of Courage and Friendship
reviewText: In the character of Julia, Cathy Lamb has created a woman who is warm, funny, unique...and quite literally on the road to self-discovery. After leaving her abusive fiance at the altar in Boston (and her wedding veil on a gnarled tree in North Dakota), Julia keeps driving West until she gets to her aunt's house in Oregon. When she gets there, she meets a community full of quirky, offbeat characters, who show her what it means to support each other, value themselves and honor their passions. For Julia, that passion is expressed by the making of her chocolates. It's through her ability to be creative again, and to be in a place where she's surrounded by such fierce love, that Julia is finally able to deal with the dysfunction of her past and see that a very new kind of life is possible for her.One of the many things I loved about this story was the way the author built such distinct and heartbreakingly real characters. These were people who had experienced traumas both simple and complex and, yet, so often their way of dealing with the world was through their humor and through the power of their bonds with each other. As diverse as they are, the reader soon feels she *knows* these people--that they're so three-dimensional they just might walk off the page to greet us--and, to me, that's the mark of an incredibly talented author.Written beautifully with scenes that are, by turns, poignant, dramatic and hilarious, Julia's Chocolates is a novel I would highly recommend.
I love this book so much I have sent one out to two close friends.  Its a heartbeating experience,  which one must really decide for one self after reading.

We recently had a "camp" in Maine right on the Appalacian Trail. Having met and befriended many hikers we had a special fondness for this book. Bill Bryson injected his story with laugh out loud humor and some of the reality of hiking in the wilds from Springer Mountain to Katahdin.  Every through hiker, every hiker has a story and this one is well told. Do yourself a favor and read it.  And if you ever hear a story about the "Trail Angel" at Surplus Pond in Andover, Maine, that would have been my husband Roland in the years before he died in 2011.

summary: A talk with a good friend
reviewText: Bill Bryson is one of those writer's who can tell you a story, as if he's sitting there talking to you over a cup of coffee.My wife gave me "A Walk In The Woods" right before our trip to the Great Smokey Mountains and the  Appalachian Trail. We had no intention of walking the AT, and this book humorously points out why.When Bill and his friend, Stephen Katz, decide to undertake this task, they know they're not in prime shape--but it's just walking. The laughs start early, well before they are out of Georgia.This isn't just a humorous account of their journey, but has snippets of historical and travel elements, all of which are enjoyable.This is a book you can read again and again.

summary: What a scientist and skeptic said was hard to disbelieve.
reviewText: It was really amazing the way he described heaven.  Also, the scientific bases he used were very believable. Towards the end, it got a little too "scientific" for the average reader.

summary: A neurosurgeon talks about his NDE
reviewText: As a fellow traveler or Dr Alexander, having had an NDE when I was 17, I appreciate both the story he tells and his struggles to tell it.  This is a beautiful, heartwarming book I recommend to all.

Shooter is an excellent book, filled with plenty of real world action, but that is not the strength of it. Shooter puts you into the mind of the sniper, as you attempt to understand the conflict of emotion a sniper endures. When reading through the book, you often have to stop, and remind yourself, that this book is written by real people describing actual events, not some fiction tale typed up by someone who hasn't "been there". If you want to truly understand the combat environment, and not read a list of chronological events, or the distorted views of sideline observers, read Shooter.

To be honest, I picked up this book at a library sale but never had any intention of reading it. I love Bill Bryson and have read some of his other work but a book about his hiking the Appalachian Trail is something I would NEVER read! Strangely enough, I was bored one hot summer day and cracked it open only to find myself completely enthralled and racing through it as if it was a thriller. In other words, I loved it. So I supposed I have to say, Bryson may know my reading tastes better than myself!The book starts with Bryson getting the idea that he should walk the Appalachian Trail as a way to reacquaint himself with his homeland. For twenty years, he had lived with his wife and four children in England. In 1995, they all moved back to the states and settled in New Hampshire (Bryson and his family have since moved BACK to the UK). Always an avid lover of nature but never much of a hiker, Bryson decides he'll hike from the southern most spot on the AT (Appalachian Trail) to Mount Katahdin in Maine. As is usual with Bryson, he reads all about the subject and focuses a great deal on bear stories, deaths out on the trail, and the sordid history of the trail itself. He spends copious amounts of money on his gear and plans out an extremely optimistic hiking schedule. As the date gets closer, he worries about doing the journey on his own until his old childhood friend from Des Moines, Iowa calls and asks if he can come along. The two were hiking buddies years before and the experience had almost ruined their friendship, however, Bryson jumps at the thought of having company. Bryson chronicles their hiking and adds in chapters on the history of the trail, the history of the National Parks Service, even the history of some of the towns that they stop in. He really does a thorough job and in under 300 pages (for the paperback), it flies by!I have to say that I learned much more in this book than I ever thought possible. When the historic chapters came up, I often thought about skipping them but found myself just as engrossed as I was in the chapters detailing Katz and Bryson's odd couple-esque hiking trip. Bryson's reflections on the importance and significance of the AT in his life as well as in that of America is extremely well articulated. I have to say that it's the complete package! Bryson's humor always makes me chuckle but this book proves that he can also handle serious matters with great insight and understanding. It's excellent as far as I am concerned and certainly a read that anyone can enjoy (and how often can you say that about a book?!)
Fantastic Book!! This book is one of a kind! It made me belly laugh one moment, and the next moment the hair on the back of my neck was standing up.

I just finished reading this book and I absolutely loved it! The author does an amazing job writing about two separate women whose lives are completely intertwined. As I read further and further into the book, I slowly begin to see those connections. I was constnatly amazed at the intracicies in the story, and the twists and turns that came with those intracicies.I'll avoid summarizing the plot because you can see that in other reviews and the book review. However, I will say that each chapter switches between narrators--Biso and Latha. Sometimes while reading, I would decide that I found one girl's story more intriguing than the other and I just wanted to skip to the next chapter to continue her story. Every time I had to fight that desire and just read the whole book in order. In doing so, I would become so intrugied with the next girl's story that I then didn't want *her* story to end...it was hard to read each chapter sequentially because I was so hungry to know what happened without so much suspense!If you like clever connections, twists and turns, and a bit of culture (the book is set in Sri Lanka), I would highly recommend this book. It's one that's easy to put down and come back to later, but it's so intriguing when you get far enough into it that you really don't want to do that at all :).
Couldn't put this book down until the end.

I read this and bought several issues for libraries.  The author is an expert in his medical field, and worthy of attention.  Scientific explanation of his experience sets it apart from similar recounts.

summary: A thinking person's guide to the afterlife.
reviewText: This book gives much food for thought. I personally believe in heaven, and an afterlife. The thing that really brings it home as opposed to other out of body death comments, is that, as a neurosurgeon, Dr Alexander later knew that his brain was not able to dream or be conscious after he came out of his coma. In other words, while he experienced his out of body death images, there was no way his brain could have produced them. His brain was shut down. It was an uplifting and scientific explanation for the ideas of an afterlife. It is a truly moving spiritual comment. I would recommend it to anyone; believer and non-believer.

summary: As a scientific minded person I find it challenging but interesting
reviewText: I find it serendipitous that a neurosurgeon was able to deeply understand the realm of consciousness--for the benefit of all of his patients, if for no other reason. I enjoyed the book and his narration. An alternate and novel (to me) method of meditation is presented in Mr. Monroe's work. It seems there is much more to be learned on the subject, to say the least :)

similar to other books on those who have been privileged to glimpse the wonders of Heaven.  Validates those who claim to have visited the Heavenly realm, and encourages believers to introduce others to the faith, that they too might be saved.

summary: "Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife" review
reviewText: If you love to read Near Death stories, this one is interesting because the author is a brain surgeon and he did not believe the ND experiences his patients told him about until he himself experienced a ND.  Afterwards he uses his knowledge to support his story.  I was impressed.

I've been reading this book at the same time as I'm reading Ray Kurzweil's book on how to create a mind. What is so interesting about Eben's book is his insistence, based on his experiences while he was in a coma, that the mind and consciousness is not dependent on the brain. Skeptics will still argue that his experiences arose from a recovering brain as he emerged from his coma. However, the vividness and profundity of these experiences do not correlate with a brain that has been badly damaged by meningitis. Further, the experiences suggest an afterlife that is even more real than the one we experience in this life. So, while humanity may build a non-biological intelligence that exceeds the abilities of the physical brain, it may still be missing that special ingredient that allows humans to go beyond life in a physical body.

summary: An amazing account of a neuorgurgeons NDE
reviewText: It was very interesting read and just a miracle of survival against all odds.  Most human beings in a coma for a week would have a very compromised life from this kind of brain infection.

summary: If you are a doubthfull religous individual, you may find a lot of answers.....
reviewText: This is a story of a doctor going through an out of body experience when suffering a stroke...without giving this story away...he becomes more aware and better equiped in helping future patiences.J F. Bigras

summary: Steven Katz is a comic genius
reviewText: Bill Bryson is a great writer. His real genius in this book was choosing Steven Katz to go along. Together, they walked the Appalachian Trail. Well, actually, together they walked the southern portion then Katz vanished for a while and he joins back up with Bryson for the final leg of the trip in Maine. Funny thing, when Bryson is alone and Katz isn't around it isn't very funny. Bryson draws a portrait of his companion that is utterly charming.Katz can't keep up with Bryson and Bill has to keep waiting for him. Katz gets tired of carrying a heavy pack so he throws away all the food (except the junk food) and so on. This book made Bill Bryson a multi-millionaire. Everything he writes from here on out is solid gold. I hope he is taking good care of his friend Katz. He deserves it.

Years ago, when neurologists and other doctors and scientists began explaining away the NDE as a confabulation of the brain, I said to my spouse "I cannot wait until a neurologist has an NDE."  At last, this has happened.I commend Dr. Alexander's bravery in telling his story in all its detail, a very difficult thing to do with an experience that is fundamentally ineffable, and while knowing that many of his colleagues would be dismissive.  I hope that Dr. Alexander's current focus will bring the synthesis of science and spirituality that he so ardently desires.This book is informative and uplifting, and should be in every hospice library.  Carry on, Dr. Alexander.

Usually chosing books on reviews, I was a bit apprehensive that I chose this book from the cover and inside blurb.  Twenty pages in I was relieved to know I made a wise choice as Cathy Lamb's book is rich in character, plot and resolution.Julia, abused her entire childhood, sickly chooses a cruel finance who continues the pattern with great zeal.  The day of the wedding, in a moment of clarity, Julia realizes she is making a huge mistake.  She escapes in her beat-up car from New England to Golden, Oregon to the comfort of her Aunt Lydia's farm, leaving her wedding dress dangling from a tree in North Dakota. At Aunt Lily's, Julia befriends 4 women who attend "Aunt Lydia's Psychic Nights" where each lady exposes her own set of disturbances.  The friendships open Julia's injured mind to understanding no one deserves constant berating, constant hitting, constant chaos.  But as she heals, her crazed fiance plots vicious revenge, and Julia knows a reckoning is coming.I found this beautifully written because in the face of disturbing subject matter there was still uproarious humor, gentle moments, quirky, loveable characters and redemption.  Written with a homespun prose, the book keeps you on a fragile edge, but doesn't leave you dangling for too long.  A perfect balance makes this a must read for all that hide from truth or are in search of it.Great first effort; I look forward to more books from this gifted author.
Free is good! I loved this quick read! It is easy to download with just one click! My bookshelf is stocked with good free books!
This book is full of wonderful details and certainly gives much food for thought.  Anyone who fears dying may find this comforting.

Read this book because it was chosen by a member of a book club I am in.  I think the authors experience was a powerful testament that there is a God. I would recommend it to anyone that has doubts.  This life is not the end of the road.

I had watched an interview of Dr. Alexander on TV, this is when I decided to purchase his book.  Reading it I was totally absorbed in the entire story.  Beautifully written, an easy read which provides answers to those ready to believe in a beautiful eternal life and the loving magic of the Universe. A must read for all those who want proof that heaven does exist.
Another very good book that reinforces that Heaven does exist!!!  I highly recommend this book to others, especially anyone who is questioning Heaven's existence!!!

This is a moving account of one man's near death experience.  The writing style is captivating from the very first page and it moves along quickly with no slow spots.  Written by a medical doctor who clearly knows how to communicate with the layman, it tells a story that is both uplifting and reassuring about Dr. Alexander's visit to heaven -- the great beyond.  Proof of Heaven is a great read and a reassuring experience.

Molly Tanner's is cursed/gifted with clairvoyance, which she call Knowing. For the most part, she's kept it hidden for fear of rejection. But her life fell apart nine years ago when she witnessed a child, Amanda, being abducted from a parking lot and didn't question the man who said the girl was screaming because he wouldn't buy her a doll. Molly saw in her visions what happened to Amanda, and has lived with debilitating guilt since then--to the point of almost losing her sanity. To help her, Dr. Cole Tanner moved his wife and son from Philadelphia to a small town in Maryland.For ten years, the Tanners have been happy in their new home. Eric, the Tanner's son is in his first year of university, and Molly is active in the new community. She feels safe and accepted until Tracey Porter disappears from a playground. Guilt from the first abduction overwhelms Molly, but she is determined that this time she will speak out in time to save the child.As her visions surface, so does Cole's insistence that she let the police handle the crime. Molly knows Tracey is alive because visions reveal Tracey's fear and that she is being kept in a dark place. Molly's search uncovers old and new crimes and old and new secrets. Does she dare risk all? And can Molly help Tracey in time to save her?I don't give spoilers in my review, so I can't reveal the plot's intricacies. This book engaged me right away and kept me turning the pages. Ms Foster kept me guessing to the end of the book, then presented several surprise twists that united all the story's threads. I love a book that ties up all the loose ends nicely, don't you?CHASING AMANDA is available in print or e-book from Amazon. Please check back on Wednesday, when Melissa Foster will be a guest interviewee. In the meantime, you can learn more about her at her website, [...]

The book is one powerful trip to Heaven as told by Eben Alexander Admitting he was skepticalabout such an event before he was thrust into a coma from which it was doubtful he wouldcome out of it and have such a tale to tell. His message is that much more powerful byhis experience that he returned to share.

I have read various articles about near death experiences and a couple of books ("90 Minutes in Heaven," "Heaven is for Real," and find it fascinating that they have commonalities with each other.I am a non-denominational Christian and find comfort in reading the Bible and talking about Christ to others.  Much of my faith has been derived from experiences like the author's story, but not on a "near death experience" level.  I know that God is always with me and relish in his spirit when I feel him "speaking" to me on a level that I don't quite understand.It is obvious that Dr. Alexander is a very intelligent, accomplished neurosurgeon and I found the medical terminology somewhat difficult to grasp.  But that did not prevent me from understanding his story.He begins by describing the bacteria that attacked his body and the experiences while meeting God in heaven.  He describes it in as much detail as he can muster but finds that our language prevents him from describing it in full.  Next, he goes into details about what heaven and God are like - where love is a dominating force - and describes his physical, emotional and mental experiences.  Finally, he writes about his return to earth and how he ended up sharing his story with others.I would recommend this book for both believers and non-believers who are "on the fence" about whether there is a higher power.  It is a quick and fascinating read.

I LOVE THIS BOOK!  It is the most compelling read.  It's my little "go to" book when I really want to feel good.  It's my special little gift to myself that I look forward to.  It's like having a little treat treasure that's all mine when I want to have something sweet.  Its the best!I keep learning more and more about the private life of a very brilliant man that I actually find interesting.

summary: Mana in the dessert of materialism.
reviewText: This books potential readership falls into three categories:1. Those who are convinced there is an afterlife.2. Those who are convinced that life ends with the death of our body.3. Those who think there must be something beyond our material existence but have no experience on which to base this belief.Eben Alexd claims he wrote this book for those in category 3, in which I am included.Proof of Heaven confirms much of what William Bray discloses in Quantum Physics, Near Death Experiences, Eternal Consciousness, Religion, and the Human Soul, but there the resemblance ends. Bray's unfocused memoir is virtually impenetrable to anyone who isn't a physics scholar. If not for the monumentality of the subject matter I would have given up on it. In spite of the Bray's scientific credentials, the sloppiness of his writing casts a shadow on his credibility.Eben Alexander, on the other hand, has gone to the time and trouble of writing a book that is a pleasure, rather than a chore, to read. Proof of Heaven is clean, clear, precise, and credible. The author neatly balances the facts of his personal history and family background, with his "adventure" in the non-material world. For this reader, Proof of Heaven was a life altering experience. At 78 years of age, death has morphed from hypothetical to an imminent inevitability. It was therefore a comfort to be reassured by someone who has plunged into the abyss and survived to tell the tale. The message Eben Alexander delivers is a familiar one: 'Good News, God is Love.'True, his (admittedly inadequate) description of the afterlife (i.e. "heaven") is not entirely a pretty picture but anything is preferable to oblivion. Right?Right?

I read this book a few years ago a decided to reread it.  I enjoyed it just as much the second time.  The journey was very interesting and entertaining.  In addition the information about the national parks and the trail were very thought provoking.
Parts will make one laugh out loud - VERY LOUDLY.  One reads to anyone walking by.  An interesting book - must read the rest of his offerings.
This book was well written, very believable as it is written by the physician who experienced it.  Easy to read, easy to understand.
This is a truly inspirational book written by a neurosurgeon who died and came back.  Very interesting and an easy read.

summary: Review by James L. Hatch, author of "The Substitute"
reviewText: I usually like to let a story simmer a bit before writing a review, but this time I am making an exception because Chasing Amanda by Melissa Foster is exceptional. What a marvelous and uplifting story. The writing is superior to nearly all novels I have read, and the editing left few issues to trip over as I traversed the story.Molly is the Chasing Amanda heroine, a woman plagued by complacency guilt. Her "gut" told her to intervene in a potential child abduction eight years past, but she lacked faith in her own feelings and hard facts on which to act. After the child, Amanda, is murdered, Molly blames herself. Consumed by guilt, she becomes so depressed and dysfunctional that she nearly destroys her marriage and family. In an attempt to rebuild her life, she and her family re-locate to Boyds, MD. Over several years, she manages an incomplete and a shaky recovery, but is then confronted with a similar situation when another little girl, Tracy, is kidnapped. Once again, Moly is confronted with "The Knowing", paranormal visions that enable her to feel and "see" the terror experienced by the missing child. She vows not to fail Tracy, as she had Amanda, and is determined to follow the powerful seizure-like visions that grip her body when The Knowing overtakes her. The police and her husband believe she's losing her mind, but her son has faith in her ... and visions of his own.The writing is superb; the novel is spellbinding. I especially enjoyed the dialog between Moly and her son because Melissa Foster nailed it. The vernacular is current--the exact phrases and expressions one would expect from a young man. I also enjoyed the third person presentation that enabled me to know what each character was thinking. I could literally feel Tracy's terror as she was dropped into the "bad spot", a deep hole that her abductor covered with plywood and dirt as part of a behavior re-shaping program. That scene still makes me shudder.I will not give the plot away, but I will say two things about it. First, I had no idea who the perpetrator was until near the end of the story. I thought I did, a couple of times, but I was wrong. Somehow Melissa Foster managed to cast a cloak of suspicion over lots of innocent people. I did not feel intentionally misled, but I wouldn't want to play chess with Melissa Foster either. Second, the story is an emotional roller-coaster. If tears don't slip down your cheeks several times as you read Chasing Amanda, especially near the end, then you probably need professional help.Chasing Amanda has an intricate and well-developed plot, and the characters are so vivid they could be real. I give this book a strong five-star rating; I'm delighted to have read it.James L. HatchAuthor ofThe Substitute

Loved the book--couldn't put it down.  A very quick read, with lots of great narrative and description of the AT.  His scenes with Katz had me laughing so hard I cried.  I could just picture those two--especially Katz  pitching camping items!  The author does tend to go on quite a bit about  environmental issues, but from his description, I guess it's about time  someone did.
THIS SUBJECT HAS FASCINATED ME FOR SEVERAL YEARS AND THIS WAS WONDERFULLY WRITTEN BY A SCIENTIST WHO CAN'T ACCOUNT FOR IT OTHER THAN IT HAPPENS.
