Very interesting take on the metaphysical by this Harvard surgeon.  His experience was similiar to other near-death experiences, but his description was a little different.  Enjoyable read.

summary: Someone who understands and speaks out about NDE
reviewText: Having had my own experience in a different way, I could relate to this experience. I appreciate that this author has a scientific approach in one aspect and a spiritual approach in another. Obviously he cared enough to talk to the people who experienced this with him and found out what they were doing, thinking and feeling while dealing with his experience. His family is very blessed to have each other in this lifetime.I appreciate the medical knowledge shared as well and I hope he continues to serve our realm in his heartfelt way. We could all benefit from a doctor who has been enlightened as he is.

summary: Extraordinary NDE report and amazing recovery from bacterial meningitis.
reviewText: I finished this book yesterday and found it enjoyable. Dr. Eben Alexander, III recounts the story of his bout with bacterial meningitis, which put him into a coma for a week, during which time he had amazing NDEs. I was just as impressed by his full recovery as by what he reports from his NDEs. From what my son, an M.D., tells me (and Dr. Eben notes this as well), such an extended comatose experience ensuing from bacteria feeding on the brain usually results in a permanent vegetative state, or death. Yet just at the moment when they were about to terminate extraordinary life support, he popped back into consciousness. Amazing!The NDE is unusual in that he doesn't have much of a personal identity and is actually aware of such. He meets no family members nor anyone else he recognizes (at least at first; surprise ending about this part), but is nontheless "dualistically" engaged with "others" -- angelic orbs playing beautiful music, other humans, a beautiful female guide, and, of course, God, Whom he calls Om (from the sound surrounding the "Core" of all things). He absorbs deep truths non-conceptually and immediately, feels connected to all things, travels about by projecting himself via thoughts, and feels completely loved and accepted. It's not all pleasant, however, as he also comes into a dimension of "muck" that he calls Earthworm-eye view, an absorption into earthiness, but in a suffocating way. The gates of heaven open again and again to draw him out of this muck, which is "alive," but somewhat eerie. Eventually, he is told he must return to his body and his life on earth, but has no idea what this means in the absence of personal identity. Once returned, however, he re-integrates with his life as a husband, father and neuro-surgeon.Dr. Eben's young adult son (in med school) is one of the first who is told about the NDE experiences, shortly after his dad returns, and he wisely suggests that his dad write out everything he could remember while it's still fresh and before he begins reading about NDEs and other spiritual literature. I think this lends even more credibility to what Dr. Eben reports.Much of the book is spent ranting about how close-minded the medical profession is concerning these kinds of experiences. Dr. Eben notes that he himself was once a reductionistic, scientific materialist, who believed that the brain generated consciousness -- that consciousness was an epiphenomenon which basically evaporated with brain death. Yet his own comatose experience, during which time his cerebral cortex was inactive, has convinced him now that consciousness is primary, with the body a means of expressing and developing it. This view is close to what most Christians would affirm.I had a couple of negative responses to the book, however. Dr. Eben seems so intent on "proving" that consciousness exists independently of the brain that he recommends James Monroe's Hemi-sync technology, which induces out-of-body experiences for many. He also likes it because it's not linked to any particular religious doctrine. Let the reader note, however, that OBEs do not always take one to heaven. Monroe himself fell among some pretty rough characters during some of his OBE forays. Heaven is filled with love and joy, but not all dimensions of reality outside the body are heavnely.Another "problem," and one that most NDE people demonstrate, is that Dr. Eben seems to be convinced that his experience put him in touch with *THE TRUTH* about all sorts of metaphysical and theological issues. He doesn't critique religions much, and in fact seems to have found his way back to his own Christian roots, but the tendency to evaluate theology, philosophy and science in the light of his experience runs throughout the book. The problem is, here, that NDEs, taken as a whole, do not disclose a consistent message about the afterlife, if that's even what the phenomenon puts one in touch with at all.Still, his NDE, as so many others, turned out to be a spiritually transformative experience, encouraging him to examine literature that he had previously ignored. He seems to be a better man for it, though he'd best be careful about his crusading spirit against scientific materialism. The doctrinaire obstinacy he will find among such people will wear him out if he's not careful.
Recommend to anyone to read. Very well written and thought provoking at all levels.Of all the books on this subject this is filled with facts that cannot dispute the end result
Great book written on a controversial subuct, proof of heaven. Although the author didn't demonstrate actual proof, he did open many doors to think about.
I found this book to be very informative and comforting.  It just goes to show that you should never give up hope, no matter what the situation is.

This is one of the best book written about some one getting to view Heaven and getting to return and reintegrate theexperience. I would strongly recommend this book to the non believer as well as the believer. well told

As always, the service from the vendor was marvelous!  I heard Dr. Alexander speak on NPR and immediately went online to order the book.  He is very convincing and his experience has a lot in common with others who have had a near death experience.  He even included a few experiences that I haven't heard of.  I'm very glad I bought this book.
Love and forgiveness.in this life  and after that  is the message..this book renews faith or will guide a person without it to  at least ponder it.

This was a beautiful, engaging, and moving book.  Many of the reviews offer plot summaries, so I won't attempt the same, but I will say that, for me, the core of this novel is the imperfection and consequent heart-breaking misjudgments of the two protagonists.  Both Latha and Biso are complex, proud, and strong women, and their flaws are precisely what makes them real and compelling characters.  Human weakness--in all its manifestations--is a key theme in this story, and Freeman's novel is powerful precisely due to her unrelenting willingness to engage that universal trait and not shy away from it.  It is not a pretty book, though there is much beauty here, and these are not pretty characters.And if you're at all concerned that understanding Sri Lankan politics is necessary for understanding or enjoying this book, be assured that it is not.

summary: Dr. Alexander is giving his honest, forthright account of what he experienced in a coma. Yes, it is controversial, that's Okay
reviewText: I bought his book because I too remember the void he speaks about. Only my experience with it was prior to my birth.  I was about 12 years of age before I could finally express what I remembered because of the abstract quality of my memory. I am glad he wrote the book, perhaps it will be more convincing than other NDE's becuase he was in a coma. When I have shared my memory with "experts", I have been told my memory was from when I was in my Mother's womb. I doubt that. I still do not look forward to dying, but I believe that it is not the end of my soul's existence.

summary: Simply wonderful and inspiring; it made one think about what comes after.
reviewText: A wonderful soul searching book that made my heart beat a bit faster; it was written from the heart. How wonderful to have a doctor whose life was based on facts and results show that God is always there; even though at times we do not feel His presence.
Read it, it is a great book! I recommend it to anyone and it is very thought provoking. Makes you look at life differently.

bill bryson really knows how to write. This book is a great read for anyone. It is very funny but full of information from a novice to the back country. Defiantly worth picking up and reading cover to cover.
I have a neuropsych background.  This man experienced what he said he did, how he said he did it.  There is no other explanation.

I have read several books of this nature.  It is amazing that they mostly describe an after journey of a similar nature.  In this case, the person who relates the experience is uniquely qualified to relate in a more scientific fashion, what she experienced in her death like coma.

summary: Finally! something that actually deserves the adjective "Awesome!"
reviewText: Just moments ago, I finished reading this book and knew I HAD to review it. I was not really surprised to find that 1,048 others felt exactly the same way. Quite a remarkable thing considering it was released such a short time ago. Dr. Alexander seems to a have touched upon an open wound in our collective consciousness. It's created quite a stir, and for good reason. The book is an outstanding achievement. It is at once, a thoroughly engaging memoir; an entertaining scientific exposition of NDE's; and a deeply moving account of one man's journey in unraveling one of Life's great mysteries ~ Consciouness itself.After all the 'Sound and Fury' surrounding this book settles down, it will inevitably endure as a timeless classic in its field. The sheer mastery of the literary form by Dr. Alexander to convey his experience in such a sincere, engaging, and emotionally powerful way, places his book head and shoulders above others of its kind. Moody himself, an icon in the field of NDEs, said it was the best book on the subject he'd ever read. After reading it yourself, I'm sure you'll understand why.As many have said, this book rings true on SO many levels that one feels as if Dr. Alexander has somehow stirred the embers of our own remembering. If you feel that you and I have similar interests; that we are perhaps even kindred spirits, and you find yourself on my 'Read All My Reviews' page, I can only say, from the deepest part of me ~ READ THIS BOOK!

I was hospitalized this year and twice felt like I was slipping away.  The second incident was scary because I stood at a door and looked out, and it was a black void.  I just couldn't step out because I was afraid that I wouldn't be in heaven since so many near-death accounts talk about walking toward the light.  This book, however, described the author's experience, and he, too, went through a dark place before arriving in Heaven.  The writer is believable because he is a neurologist, and he maintains his belief about dying and going to Heaven even though many of his friends and other neurologists are slow to accept his experience.  I was not disappointed and plan to review it in my study group in January.

Gobbled this book right down because the author's near-death experience isn't the most amazing part---it was his perfect credentials for influencing everyone's opinion about that experience!I've visited places such as this neurosurgeon visited during his 7-day coma, and my nearly forty years of studying the *interdimensional* science of Consciousness made it all seem normal and to be expected of someone in his dying situation. What impressed and astonished and delighted me was how PERFECTLY his situation was designed to gain the attention of everyone who has NOT yet come to the awareness that consciousness does not begin or end with the physical brain!I highly, highly recommend this book. It's quick to read, because the story is so compelling, and the doctor/author has gone to great lengths to explain why this was NOT hallucination (that part of his brain was classified as completely nonfunctional at the time), or any other among a long list of conventional science's debunking explanations for NDEs. His unique experience refutes all of these arguments.The only flaw in the book isn't really a flaw: he can't yet explain how or why these things happened to him. Not to worry, Dr. Alexander! Others have and will. For instance, "The Infinite Concept of Cosmic Creation" by Ernest L. Norman offers complete, diagrammed, scientific explanations for the aspects of consciousness that bridge dimensions. This science fully explains how and why he experienced the visions and connections of his NDE, where he went, and perhaps even why he did so.As for why his deceased father didn't come to greet him during his other-side visit--that, too, can be explained. It's in my books, it's in E.L. Norman's books, and one day I'm sure the author will understand, as well.Because of my already-established beliefs, I'd stopped reading about near-death experiences, but I will be recommending this book to everyone who'll listen!
This is an amazing book and as one who has cancer, I read this book very closely...it is Heaven sent and this is the second time I have read it. I do look to the after life and to be with our Lord.

summary: Search in to the unknown...interesting, emotional and touching
reviewText: A positive approach to spiritual wisdom, unending family support and love.  I highly recommend this warm, uplifting memoir sharing how to find true contentment and happiness  after experiencing tragedy and grave sickness.

I just got done reading all 3 books  in the series and couldn't put them down. It is my first time reading Terri Osburn but won't be my last, I've already preordered the 4th book I can't wait fir November. I hope we hear more about Kenzie and Manny as well.
Cathy Lamb is a favorite author. This is another interesting and thought-provoking book, dotted throughout with her usual witty humor. Great writer.
A truly thought provoking, and possibly life changing book.  Very worthy of anyone's time, regardless of how busy they are in other aspects of their lives.
I was a little disappointed that it didn't give me a lot of answers but I suppose that's all up to my interpretation.  A very quick read and a very interesting story.
Well written by a doctor giving some medical aspects of death along with an easy to understand view of heaven.
It's pretty convincing in it's proof that Heaven exists.  It's amazing that this man lived through this experience with so little lingering problems.  Sharing the book with family and friends.
I usually read Debbie Macomber - so this was a nice change of pace.  I hope to read other books in this series.

summary: Riveting Suspense Creates Winner for Melissa Foster!
reviewText: "No! I want to go home!" She clawed at the dirt, kicking fiercely at her captor's face, "I'm not going back in there!" Tracey felt her arm being pulled and twisted behind her back. Her terrified screams were absorbed by the dirt walls of the tunnel.Chasing AmandaBy Melissa FosterMelissa Foster hooked me from the first page and I stayed there reading until I finished it that evening! If you have the time, I'd recommend you plan to do the same...because Foster's second book is full of suspense, intrigue and a story that grabs you and holds on tight until you've read the final words! The subject matter is horrendous, of course, but I find that well-written novels with a tremendous impact, also serve to make more and more people aware of how easily, how very easily it is...to lose your child...Molly, our lead character, had not only found that out, but had been traumatized by what she had seen. Amanda, a little girl had been abducted. Molly had seen her screaming and struggling with a man she thought was the father who had calmly told Molly she was upset about not getting her doll. Molly had driven away but later discovered that the girl had been abducted and later found murdered. Although years had passed, Molly had never forgotten, or forgiven herself. She had sunk so far into depression that her husband decided to relocate the family...But little girls alone are not safe, no matter where you go...Now, in Boyds, a little girl was missing. Her name was Tracey... And Molly was adamant she was going to do everything possible to help find her, even if it meant losing her husband...Besides, she was tortured by visions of little Tracey. "She called the powerful episodes the Knowing, as her mother had. Now, she'd give anything to be able to close her eyes against her ability, wash it away like dirt from a fall. Before Amanda, Molly's visions had been vague and sporadic, sand under a breaking wave, morphing from one second to the next in unclear shapes and patterns. Amanda's death had changed every aspect of her life, including the clarity and frequency of her visions..."While Boyds was a quiet small town where Molly had become involved and gotten to know most of the members of the community, she found that people were not happy that she was diligently working to find Tracey. Asking questions had led to the fact that another little girl had disappeared there 20 years ago and never been found. Secrets of small towns may disrupt an entire community and the person asking questions may be in danger..."No! Not now! She closed her eyes and tried to will away the pressure in her head. There was no escape. She clenched her fists and brought them to her forehead, bracing herself for what she knew was happening. A fog enveloped her mind, and her legs became weak beneath her. A passerby, seeing her body shake and thrust, would have thought Molly was having a seizure. A passerby wouldn't have been able to distinguish between a seizure and the Knowing. Molly could...She felt like a puppet on a string. Visions flashed in her mind: A cavern-like room surrounded by shadowy darkness; a young girl huddled in a corner, scared and shivering; the smell of rancid, wet earth. Molly fell to the ground and cried out in fear and frustration, "No!"The police wouldn't support her; her husband didn't want her to become so involved. The one woman, her pastor, who had helped her through many discussions when she had first arrived, now seemed distant, secretive, and Molly had even seen her out in the night in strange places. But she wasn't the only one--another friend who had been out searching had stopped strangely in the middle of a cornfield and touched the ground, saw Molly and moved on. When Molly reached the spot, she bent down and "felt" that something was there...But time was passing and Tracey had still not been found. Molly was finding clues, but kept them to herself, hoping that they would bring psychic connections...but when they did, nobody would go with her to the place where she knew Tracey was being held... Now she faced Tracey's abductor, and found that Tracey had been so traumatized that she no longer wanted to leave the one who had kidnapped her...You DO NOT want to miss this one! I considered this a must-read...for many reasons! Readers--you know who you are! Melissa Foster is a true storyteller, able to create strong believable characters, provide riveting suspense, and, at the same time, spotlight the major issue of child abduction. Melissa, very well done!Book Received ViaFacebook Reviewers RoundupGABixlerReviews

summary: By far the best description of an NDE than any other on the market
reviewText: This NDE description is outstanding because it describes an NDE extending DAYS, not a minute or two.  What gives this story strength is that it's written by a no-nonsense successful neurosurgeon.

Eben Alexander, M.D., has been an academic neurosurgeon for the last twenty-five years, including fifteen years at the Brigham & Women's and the Children's Hospitals and Harvard Medical School in Boston. Dr. Eben Alexander's near-death experience is the most astounding I have read in my decades of reading and studying this phenomenon.Dr. Alexander brings a very special view to the spiritual realm due to his education and vocation in the medical world.  His combination of science and the spiritual is profound and believable.  Proof of Heaven is a compelling story of our future as we move from this life into the next dimension.  My only fear is that the scientific community will continue to ignore the spiritual element that governs this place we call the universe.  Hopefully, Dr. Alexander's persuasive and undeniable story will convince our skeptics to take a long, serious look at this arena.I also enjoyed the story within the story about his struggles with adoption and the captivating tale of despair and eventually fulfillment.  This story was forceful for me as I have a daughter struggling with the same issues.  I hope she can find peace as Dr. Alexander has done.I highly recommend this book.  I hope you found the review/opinion helpful.Michael L. Gooch, SPHR - Author of Wingtips with Spurs, Lessons from the Ranch and Voodoo Fever.

Great story, reinforces faith and the knowledge that this is not the end of the road, but only a testing ground to grow strong in times of trial and sorrow and ultimately, to return to the arms of our Creator, a better soul for having lived our lives on earth.
Typically I can figure out an ending to a book but this story had so many twist and turns I really was completely in the dark until it was all revealed. Great read

Chasing Amanda is a well-crafted suspense novel. In this page-turner, Melissa Foster brilliantly describes the emotional turmoil resulting from not being able to prevent a child's abduction and death. In Chasing Amanda, Ms. Foster weaves a complex tale by capturing the fragility of several poignant relationships - wife and husband, mother and son, sister and brother, neighbors and friends--into one riveting main theme. Brava Melissa Foster, Chasing Amanda is a superb novel.

This is one of the most fascinating books about out of body experiences as it is told by a guy who knows how the brain works and function. It also took a great amount of courage to stand up and be counted.
Hillarious.  Great adventure and full of off the wall facts. Makes you want to go for a hike.
There has been so much speculation over the years about heaven, and the light at the end of the tunnel, that this gives the reader additional ideas to consider.,

When Bill Bryson returned to the United States after living in Britain for twenty years, he decided to reacquaint himself with his home country in a rather unique way. He would hike the Appalachian Trail. The AT, in hiker lingo, opened in 1937 and snakes 2,100 miles across 14 states, from Georgia to Maine. Nor did he go it alone; Stephen Katz, a colorful childhood friend from Iowa whom he had barely seen in 25 years, joined him. Both hikers were grossly out of shape as they approached their mid-life venture, and neither knew the least thing about hiking and camping. Bryson is a brilliant writer and a comic genius, and in his hands their many AT experiences spring to life--from buying their equipment, to obsessing about bear attacks, through rain and snow, filth and mud, and encounters with oddballs and eccentrics they met along the trail. Interspersed among the comic narrative, Bryson alternates with the history, topography and geography of the AT. As I prepared to hike the comparatively short John Muir Trail in California, a mere 200 miles, a friend who knew that I was a rookie recommended that I read this book. Bryson's Walk enjoyed a run on the bestseller list of the New York Times a few years ago, and I found myself resonating with one reviewer who compared Bryson to a combination of John Muir and Dave Berry. The AT is a hike of five million steps, says Bryson, but you can enjoy this wonderful book without ever leaving the house.
I laughed, I cried and just didn't want to put this book down.Heartwarming, just a great read.

I ordered this book after I heard Madonna Badger say she found it very comforting (she tragically lost her 3 kids and parents in a house fire).  The author writes well, and I love how he goes into detail medically; ie: layperson can easily understand!  I am half way through and plan on finishing up tonight.  It's a fast read.
I love this book.  It's the true story of a man who experienced Heaven and returned to Earth.  It is so well written and wonderful to read.

Liked this book enough that it has me looking for the first two in the series. I think that I may already have them but just haven't taken the time to read them yet, if so they both just jumped to the top of the queue.This story does prove the point that yes there are times when a person needs to panic and run for their life, but afterwards, they need to both ask for help and stand up and fight back. If they don't they will never be safe or happy again.

This is an excellent report of a Doc's personal experience (with a long period of coma) in another world!! As a "non" believer and transformation in the other direction to one convinced of the existence of God and continuing lifetime after death is very compelling and I believe happening to all people.

I ;lved the knowledge behind it and the ability to think outside the box of conventional science. Dr. Alexander was very careful in the documentation of his experience to keep the information as pure as possible.
Yet another book purchased for my husband.  He has probably 20 plus books of this type and has enjoyed reading all of them, though Bill Bryson is his favorite.  Would recommend to everyone.

If you enjoy your chick lit a little more serious, then this is the book for you.  I found this book hard to put down once I started.  The characters are well developed and, best of all, there is a complete plot!  I thought this book would appeal to readers who enjoy Jodi Picoult and Wally Lamb.  It is a very emotional book written with humor and grace.  I don't want to give away the plot, but basically a troubled and abused woman overcomes her abused past and triumphs over tragedy. You have to read it.
this book did not disappoint me.  i would recommend it for those looking for hope or validation.  like any book it's up to you what you take out of it

summary: Classic tale of the Appalachian Trail
reviewText: Bryson hits on all cylinders on this book.  It is informative regarding the trail, throroughly enjoyable and humorous. His hiking companion Katz would be a marvelous character invention if he wasn't actually real.  His depiction of the scenery and characters they meet along the trail are a joy to behold.
I couldn't put this book down.  Incredibly detailed event of life after death.  I would highly recommend this book for anyone that is spiritual.

summary: Scientific Proof of a Near Death Experience
reviewText: Dr Eben's NDE is probably the most compelling evidence so far that these experiences are real and not just phenomena due to lack of oxygen and such. His medical education and experience further support up his claim explained in his book in such vivid detail.

Bill Bryson is a great writer, and of the three books of his that I've read, this is my favorite!  It's a memoir of his experiences hiking on the Appalachian Trail.  The book is hilarious, thoughtful, and a little bit poignant all at the same time.  I wanted to strap on my hiking boots and head out the door.  Highly recommended!  Great one to do on tape or cd too.

summary: gives you insight into hip hop
reviewText: this book defintely gives you insight into the world of what these vidoe girls go through just to be a part of the hip scene. i felt digusted and sadden all at the same time. i can't bash this girl because she has had it rough and seems to have changed for the better. the guys in hip hop we glorify buy their music uphold them even when they treat our women like pieces of meat. even after reading this book 99% of you will still hold her responsible for all she's gone thrugh but none of the men. what does hat say about us as people? we need to wake up and to make matters worse more than most these girls don't even get paid for these videos they are ripped off or paid chump change.i can't wait for the next book to drop!
I liked this book because of the factual medical knowledge the author presents to prove his neath death experience was the real thing.

Quite honestly, I couldn't put this book down. I just loved it! The author, Bill Bryson, does a superb job in describing the Appalachians. Upon finishing reading this book, I ordered books from amazon.com on the Appalachian Trail. You guessed it: my next adventure will be to hike the Trail.Not many books succeed in motivating you to leave your coach and explore the beautiful world around you. If you are a hiker, A Walk in the Woods might just be the best book you will read this year! However, a word of caution: Do not read it at bedtime; your heart will beat so fast from excitement you'll lose sleep.The story is about the author and his friend Stephen Katz, a hilarious character, deciding to hike the whole 2100 miles or so of the Appalachian Trail. They end up hiking half of it (just less than 900 miles), deciding that they are not cut out for this; still, quite an achievement.The author narrates the history of the Appalachian Trail; statistics on how many hikers succeed or fail in hiking the whole trail; bear attack statistics (only 9 bear attacks in the last few decades); fatal and non-fatal diseases one can get hiking the Trail (some are horrific and probably you never heard of them or expected to be present in your backyard); snake bites (apparently none were fatal); murder on the trail (the Trail is not immune from murderers, and there was a murder committed at the time the author was hiking the Trail); and most importantly, loads of laughter!Read this book; you'll be glad you did.

summary: After Reading Master of the Realm, I Believe Proof of Heaven
reviewText: I just finished readingMaster of the Realmby Valentine deFrancis, which not only was an amazing story, but has gotten me to believe in life after death. So when Proof of Heaven came out, I decided to read it, which is something I never would have done. I believe his story and I hope that others will open their minds to the possibility that life after death exists.

very interesting to hear an actual neurosurgeon's perspective about life after death.My aunt, a nurse, told me about this book and I had to get it.I have read many books on stories of life after physical death, and it was extremely interesting to hear the details from a scientist/physician--ESPECIALLY a NEUROSURGEON'S experience.From what I have read, we have much more than just our Faith to support this.

summary: This is an amazing true story.
reviewText: This book is heartfelt, metaphysical, compelling, and a work of art. I think everyone should read it!I too am a physician who had a near death experience. I found a kinship in Dr. Alexander's words.

summary: EXCELLENT BOOK ABOUT LIFE AFTER DEATH
reviewText: I read this book in one sitting. It is 188 pages long. It took me about one hour and 45 minutes. I am a Christian and I have always believed in Life after Death so that was my primary reason for wanting to read this book which has been recommended by so many reviewers and critics. If you are not a person of Faith then this book may not change that because even this book is still Faith based. Dr. Eben Alexander is an accomplished Neurosurgeon who is the author and the subject of this book. The journey recounts the brief After Life journey taken by Dr. Alexander while his mortal body remained on Earth in a hospital attended by family, colleagues and friends struggling to survive. The actual After Life journey by the spirit of Dr. Alexander is something that you will richly enjoy if you are a person of Faith so I will not spoil that here. Buy this book and read about the journey. If you are a person of Faith it will be worth it. The terminology is Medical Level at times because Dr. Alexander is a Neurosurgeon but, it fits well with the book. Since the return of the Spirit of Dr. Alexander to his Earthly body he has chosen a new mission in Life; to spread The Word about The After Life!
Well worth the read. Will keep it to read again since the first time was with my Bible study group. Has a lot of medical terminology.

my own experiences are  very similar.  I was in motor vehicle accident and took a journey into heaven that changed me forever.  my experience is always teaching me new things either as I remember more or encounter situations designed to teach me.  I could write much more.  this book is well written and a good read.
Much of the experience appears to be compatible with Buddhist thought. True truth is in the realization of beliefs, even without a belief in the power of a divinity.
Very good book, especially someone from the medical profession. Puts a different spin on your thinking.

This story is so compelling and expertly told that the book is very difficult to put down. When I was finished, I missed being able to read it. There have been many stories about near death experiences, but this man's qualifications as a neurosurgeon, and his ability to keep close reference to the facts makes the story very beleivable.

summary: Proof? None better that I have read...
reviewText: Dr. Alexander's description of his visit to the afterlife is vivid and colorful.  It makes you almost imagine that you are there as well.  This NDE experience, like many others I have read, has many things in common.  What is most exciting from a clinical perspective, is this writer is in one of the highest regarded medical catagories.  As a neurosurgeon, who beyond this status that can reliable refute what he has written about how this is REAL.  The facts he presents about his medical situation and how each possibility for cause are eliminated, are truly the amazing thing in this book!  Let the medical world be on notice, it is real....and no, it's not all statistics.  Holly Klein MSW, LSCSW

This was a fascinating book. A lot of wise things that rang true to me.I am no longer surprised when after finding a wonderful book, I then see a lot of doubters and haters  of it in the Amazon reviews. Usually, as in the case of this book, they are thankfully in the minority. Just ignore their negativity and close-mindedness and read this book anyway.This book gives every indication to me that the author is sincere and is genuinely trying to share something valuable with the world. I found what he said to be valuable.His explanations about the meaning and purpose of life are pretty closely aligned with what I believe as a Mormon, even though some of the specifics of what he saw sound a bit strange. But I'm prepared to believe it's a big universe to experience and try to comprehend "on the other side."I thank the author for having the courage and honesty to write this book.As with all these NDE books, there is a lot about the illness, the author's background, etc. I always skip over that and just read the actual NDE account. However, this book also includes many chapters where the author analyzes and tries to synthesize what he learned - those chapters were also great.If you liked this book, also check outReturn from Tomorrow.

I command DR. Alexander for his brave decision to come forward with his experience, and his decision to go fare-ward with further research in that field. It is about time! Keeping our eyes closed in-front the truth will not make the truth go away, will it? We are Spiritual Beings having Human experience. Time is NOW that we finally Integrate our Sovereignty with the matter, and therefore, we are acknowledging that we are actually a Sovereign Integral here and now. And with this science, the end to the World trouble to.Perhaps, what happened to him, it was universal orchestrating for that reason? Certainly is unique and medically unexplainable...?Great book!

I love the characters in this series. Easy to get lost on an island with men like the guys in these pages. I also like how the women are strong and sassy, very good characters, great story lines. I guess I read romance novels now too.

summary: The Virgin Queen... In her own words
reviewText: As an passionate reader of royal history (fiction or fact), I found this book extremely detailed and very moving. This masterpiece by Miles takes the reader from an early point in Elizabeth's life and up to her last days. Though the novel cuts short her last thoughts. This story allows the reader to almost become the Queen herself as she struggles to survive her controling father and the manipulative factions that work with in the monarchy. She shares her feelings and deepest desires for self love and independence after being labled a bastard. She lights on her affection for Thomas Seymour and her sister Mary's tumultuous reign. She wows in her love for Lord Robert Dudley and longing for children of her own all the while devoting herself entirely to people and country.I have seen many films, both biographical and hollywood cinema like that portray the Queen as a strong, intellectual, high spirited, passionate woman and leader who still finds time to pursue important matters close to her heart. Miles does a supurb job of showing Elizabeth I's life, loves and struggles of being a queen in a very controversial time in England's history

I really enjoyed reading Chasing Amanda. Melissa Foster dis a great job with this book.It was full of suspense and I did not want to put the book down.The book had an unexpected twists (and secrets) in the end.I would definitely recommend reading this book.

I thought this was a very interesting read. I enjoy reading books written by medical professionals as they always put a little different spin on it. This author obviously had an extremely well described life experience that is thought provoking.

summary: Proof of Heaven:  A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife
reviewText: I chose this rating because I really enjoyed Dr. Alexander's book.  I knew his father from work and appreciated him very much and I'm happy to learn that his son has personally experienced Proof of Heaven.  It is great that some physicians are experiencing what so many of their patients have.

I found Proof of Heaven simply amazing and fascinating.  Although I am Catholic, what I appreciated about his writing is that he makes no mention of "religion" or "what you must believe'... because his approach was scientific, I think that it will reach far more souls than if it was purely "religious."  I also think that it may clear up some of the claims that heaven is only for a select few... or a particular people who believe a certain way. The sheer vastness of the universe and the lack of words to even express it confirms once again my thoughts that God is so far beyond what we know of Him.

Many have probably had a relative or friend who has told of "seeing the light" when a near-death experience occurred. But this writer was a skeptic and a very highly trained neurosurgeon who understood brain function in its entirity.  This is similar to a trusted friend/financial advisor giving you inside information.  You have to take it seriously.We probably all hope that there is something after we die.  Some look to religion, some look to nature.  This writer is convinced that there is an afterlife, as he has been there and seen it personally.  He takes a lot of time to explain why his experience cannot be attributed to brain function or malfunction. He truly became convinced that there is something good waiting for us after we die.The book is easy to read in some parts and quite technical in other parts.  I have a medical background so I understood most of it but some parts were well beyond my understanding.  Also, while he mentions his religious background, he makes his arguments on non-religious basis.It is a good read and provides a lot of hope to his fellow humans.

summary: I've been recommending this book to everyone I know!
reviewText: It's written with great good humor, yet it's very informative (geology, history, land use issues, outdoor activities, and nature). I marked many passages for later reference, including material on Pangaea and continental drift, the Ice Ages, and the decades-long coal fire burning under Centralia, PA. The tone of the book develops with the progress and setbacks of the walk itself, encompassing moments of high hilarity, sudden terror, and somber reflection. It was fun to read a "confrontation with nature" book that wasn't shadowed by the sense of doom that necessarily pervaded "Young Men and Fire," "Into Thin Air," "Into the Wild," and "A Perfect Storm" (all excellent books, of course!)

summary: Casually looking title, you are hard-put to figure out...
reviewText: ...how it could possibly be "a runaway best seller."No less than thirty-three sage reviewers (thirty-six if you count the three reviews no the cover) heap praise and commendation on Bill Bryson's story of his 870 mile trek over the Appalachian Trail (the trail is actually 2,200 miles long). All this, mind you, carrying a forty-pound pack. (Have you hoisted a forty-pound pack lately, let alone try to walk with it?) And all earthly needs, on such a walk, must come from this pack on your back. I daresay few of us have the strength or fortitude to carry out this kind of venture, particularly, as Bryson did, in part, with snow on the ground.In 1996 that's what Bryson and his friend Stephen Katz did and Bryson made it into a 274-page story that is "choke on your coffee funny" as one reviewer put it. For example: "I wanted to get back on the trail, to knock off some miles. It is what we did. Besides, I was bored to the point somewhat beyond being bored out of my mind. I was reading restaurant place mats, then turning them over to see if there was anything on the back. At the lumberyard, I talked to workmen through the fence. Late on the third afternoon, I stood in a Burger King and studied, with absorption, the photographs of the manager and his executive crew (reflecting on the curious fact that people who go into hamburger management always look as if their mother slept with Goofy), then slid one place to the right to examine the Employee of the Month awards. I then realized I had to get out of Franklin."Not only is Mr. Bryson's tale excruciatingly funny, he is an astute observer who lays out powerful insights on how modern mankind is wantonly destroying nature at an alarming pace. He captivates you with penetrating wit, yet at the same time, makes it crystal clear that if we keep tearing nature down at our present frantic pace, there soon won't be any nature with the result that, indeed, there may not be any of "us."

reviewerName: Perry P. Perkins "Author of La Caja China Coo...
reviewText: I picked this book up, along with many others, in preparation for hiking the Pacific Crest Trail."A Walk In The Woods" is, by far, the funniest book on hiking I've ever read. While a contender for funniest book in any genre, it is also laced with biting commentary and deep insights on nature and man's approach to it.Bill Bryson's commentaries on the Parks Department, Bears, Hillbillies, and the genealogy of fast-food management will have you choking on your trail mix on every other page!Thanks for the laughs Mr. Bryson; I plan to put this one on my "read every year" shelf!Please take another long walk, and please, please tell us all about it!-PerryPerry P. PerkinsAuthor"Just Past Oysterville"

Watching TV one evening a sniper was asked what he felt after shooting someone, his reply was recoil. That says a lot. Don't have time to dwell on your actions while it still going on around you. If this is what a college degree accomplish's keep me uneducated. Men who are willing to take the fight to those who want to hide in the shadows & chunk grenades deserve what that get. The Gunny was one of these people & should be honored as one. Doing a job well that no one else wants to do is honorable. Thank you Gunny, I'm sure there are guys that owe you their life that also say thanks.

In American, we don't teach people to "die well."  I've always believed in a life after life and the idea has been debated when the subject of NDE's were introduced into the conversation. Some believe that it's a way for your brain to protect you during death. I choose too believe that it is so much more. I am happy to see a book by a neurosurgeon who experienced it first hand and gives a very cogent and educated analysis of his experience.  The appendixes, written by colleagues who cared for him during his coma, along with his personal research which attempts to prove that NDE's are real,(a concept that he didn't believe in until experiencing it) gives credibility to the many people who have had NDEs.  For me, it was a picture of hope that one day everyone will understand that everything and everyone in our universe is connected. My hope is that as the subject is studied more in depth,we will evolve to a more peaceful, loving, life experience, facing death as the next new adventure rather than just an ending.

The bears out there"Into the Woods" captures perfectly the stupefying/frightening/exhilarating experience of tramping through the forests of the East Coast. Bryson brings his trademark wit and intelligence to bear on his experience of (partly) hiking the Appalachian trail -- the 2500-some-odd mile long footpath from Georgia to Maine. Bryson is accompanied by his friend, Steve Katz, who provides the perfect foil to Bryson's attempts at good trail sense. Bryson is comically unprepared, and foolishly cavalier about trail etiquette. He throws away important items and wanders off without map or compass, not that he could read them anyway. Sometime, I thought that if Katz didn't exist, Bryson would have had to invent him. And perhaps he did. But Bryson's friend provided the drama that a long walk in the woods might not otherwise enjoy.Bryson used the book as an excuse to talk about all sort of subjects related to the great outdoors. He tells of the glaciers, extreme weather and human dreams that shaped the trail. He terrifies us with stories of bear attacks, cougar sightings and hypothermia. He enrages us with tales of the ineptitude of the US Park Service and the US Corps of Engineers. He saddens with stories of Centralia, PA, a town which literally sits above a fire pit. Then there's the disappearance of much of the tree cover that dominated the America forests not so many years ago: so many chestnuts and elms lost to fungi and other diseases. But his stories about fellow hikers are often hilarious - especially one poor, unprepared young lady who spent her time questioning other hikers about their choice of gear - "Big mistake!" has her byword. But Bryson always enchants with his description of the vastness, wildness and ruggedness of the forest. He makes us appreciate its innate loveliness, as well as the people who make it their life's goal to preserve it and make it available to others. His description of the breathtaking beauty and incredible fickleness of my beloved White Mountains had me enthralled."A Walk in the Woods" is not the definitive book on the twists and turns of the Appalachian Trail. For that, refer to one of the many guides about the trail and its topography. But it is a must-read for those who love the outdoors -- and for the occasional hiker, who can stand to be made wary of the perils of tramping unprepared.

summary: I urge you to read this book
reviewText: I believe this account is authentic for Dr Alexander; we all have much to learn from it. I am so glad I read it.

summary: Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife
reviewText: I read this book in 2 days! Very interesting. More proof of what I believe the Bible tells us about heaven.My husband & pastor want to read next before I give to others to read.

This Woman went thru so much crap - and lived to tell about it.  I found this book to be incredibly entertaining.  This book has a few pages of color photos that I enjoyed referring to while I read.  I give this book 5 big stars!

This is a wonderful book about a doctor who truely finds he can rise above his mental mind and that ther is so much more to what we are and why we are here.  People who read this should read some of Harold Klemp's books such as "How to Survive Spiritually in OUr Times" or "A Modern Prophet Answers Your Questions about LIfe" or Paul Twitchell's book - "The Spiritual Notebook"  These books help us understand even further who we are as Soul and what we are doing here on this Earth plane.  Dr. Alexander took a huge leap of conciousness and hopefully helped thousands of others do hte same. I would like to help too! There is SO MUCH MORE.
I have read many books on this subject ,and him being a Doctor telling his story makes me believe even more.

summary: A wondeful book, made me appreciate the subject
reviewText: I read this book to start with mainly because I so enjoy this author's writing style.  However, he is such a masterful writer, he made me also  have an appreciation for the trail and for other subjects I thought I had  no interest in, like the death of the chestnut tree.  I even learned much  about my childhood state of Maine, where his trek ended.  I can't imagine  anyone not liking this book.

I picked this book cause it didn't sound preachy and religious and thank God it wasn't. Although deeply spiritual the author didn't try throwing his own religious nonsense or beliefs in there like so many NDR's seem to do. That is a huge turnoff for me and one that makes me feel that those claiming to have the experience are either coloring it too much with their own beliefs or flat out lying. The author was able to explain much of his experience in a way that I could fully understand and in basic terms. Although he gave us alot of medical background he admits that science alone has no answer for the divine. I highly recommend this book if you aren't looking for someone to shove Jesus or religion or the bible down your throat.
I am really liking this series.  Makes me want to go to the outter banks and find out what island life is really like.

I just have to begin by saying that I loved this book. From the first fifteen pages that I read sitting on a stool in the bookstore, I saw that Bryson was able to write with an astuteness that made me want to never put the book down. He was able to slice through and get to the humor or meaning behind any event. I originally picked up this book because I was interested in the subject and the back cover advertised how funny it was. However, this book is much more than funny. In addition to his wit, Bryson is incredibly thoughtful and well researched. In between descriptions of his own hike, Bryson discusses the history of the trail, and the condition of plants, animals, and anything else he runs into. He was no expert hiker, and his story is relatable. From the beginning, he was able to get himself into ridiculous situations, though perhaps some of this is the fact that Bryson could make the most mundane experience interesting. I normally try to point out some of the weaker points in a book, but I liked this book too much to find anything worth mentioning. Well, I'm off to go hiking.

I had bought this book as a gift for someone who enjoyed it so much I bought a copy for myself.  What a gem!  Other than CONFEDERACY OF DUNCES,  there has been no book which made me laugh out loud, time and again.  Seeking more of Bryson's keen wit, I read (available on Amazon) NOTES FROM  A SMALL ISLAND, a similarly-written account of his sojourn through England.  Not as laugh-out-loud funny, but a funny-bone tickler nonetheless.  If you  liked WALK, you'll like SMALL ISLAND.

A MUST READ!!  Many average every-day people write of this experience.  Thrilled a Neurosurgeon would put himself out to the world to read - there are so many 'non-believers' in this experience.  In his profession he put his patient's perception of him on the line - he spared no detail.  Thanks for opening this amazing happening to us!  Rated it 5 stars due to it's validity, it's personalization, and it reads as if you went thru it w/ him!  I surely recommend it to believers as well as skeptics!!
A new view of unseen spiritual verities coming from a man of science.He is suggesting that the scientific community explore this realm with greater open mindedness.
It is a good read. He tries to help the skeptics understand what he went through. He just reiterated what believers already know. Read it and he describes a place that is truly beyond words.
Probably more convincing to agnostics than hardened skeptics, but should make even the skeptics stop and think. A real comfort to those who have lost  a loved one.

I read a review in my local paper about this book and was motivated to buy it since my Mother is dying and I was reaching out for a better understanding of death. I found this comforting and worth sharing with anyone who is going through this or grieving a passing of a loved one.

summary: Disturbing but I still couldn't put it down
reviewText: Definitely suspenseful, but disturbing.  However, I couldn't get myself to stop reading because I had to make sure everything turned out OK.  I would recommend this book.

New outdoor-enthusiast friends recommended this Bill Bryson audio book to us for our drives to the Oregon Coast. Being a native Pennsylvanian, I thought it good to know more about the eastern US.  The author's writing style is friendly and I was blown away by his lack of planning for a trip of this magnitude on the Appalachian Trail. I fouind his personal insights/opinions about the National Park system as well as  history of native song bird and tree species literally vanishing extremely interesting. We had occassion to both laugh and feel deep dismay at some of the  treatment of the land and people along this trek.

This book was very interesting and well worth the wait. Amazing to see the changes  a man of medicine went through,having changed so many attitudes and survived to share the tale. As always, it took no time for my shipment to arrive.I have always received them when they were expected if not before. I thoroughly enjoyed the reading and look forward to finishing the one I bought from Amazon that I'm reading now. Thank you for your effort.Coralie
I liked the descriptions - the importance of family - the feeling of love.  The honesty of the book and the connection to science and body and soul.  A good read.
I loved this book.  I was abused as a child. I related to Julia on so many levels. I laughed. Andcried  and understood her panic attacks from the beginning. I will read all of this author's books.

summary: Reassuring book about life after death that did seem to offer proof that it does exist.
reviewText: I already believe in life after death but this author presented his experience in a scientific manner that was different from the other books that I had previously read on the subject.  I would recommend this book to anyone, like myself that does not mind the classroom experience while reading this topic of interest.

summary: A Must Read For Anyone Needing Proof of Heaven
reviewText: Dr. Alexander shares certain knowledge of an afterlife we must surely all dream of - an after life of limitless possibilities. The proof is irrefutable if you have an open mind - a Quantum perspective.  This work is both enlightening and entertaining.The story of Dr. Alexander's NDE is amazing itself, but when coupled with a rare proof beyond question it is astounding.I am using Proof of Heaven as a reference to my new e-book: Quantum Moments and Keys to Prosperity due in winter or spring of 3014. Also, consider Dr. Goswami's Quantum Activism as further proof to Dr. Alexanders claim.Boyd K. Smith, Ph.D.CEO - New Ways To Prospernewways2013@wavecable.comfacebook.com/NewWaysToProspernewways2013.com
LOVED this book!  I was hooked from the beginning!!!  A very well written and engaging story...  As a sensitive, I could relate very well to Molly.

I enjoyed this book very much. I appreciated author's candor, and honesty. I even found some of the medical/technical info interesting - even if you skip that part it's still has a lot to offer. It in no way 'sells' religion. Gives you lots of food for thought.
Bill Bryson combines humor and adventure, this book will leave you feeling like the appalachian trial is magnificant and horrible to climb- his experiences are easily read and charming.

summary: Good examination of his own near death experience
reviewText: A neurosurgeon becomes deathly ill, has a near death experience and returns to the physical world to examine his experience and tell others.  I am a believer in the spiritual world, so what he says rings true to me.  If you like this sort of thing, there is a book you may also like - Evidence of the Afterlife - a more scientific examination of NDE throughout all cultures.

summary: Proof of Heaven by Eben Alexander III MD.
reviewText: This was a great read also. I wonder how he has been able to help others prove their experiences also. I am in a Bible Study group and one of the ladies in my class recommended this one and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

This book had some serious laugh out loud sections that make it more than worth the read.  Contains a wealth of random knowledge like his other books.  There were still a few chapters that were drawn out with little value in them but the rest was more than enough to make up for it.

I bought this and put it on my klindel so my son could read it.  I  read it many years ago when I was on our town library board.  Just loved it and have read several other Bill Brysoh books.  Loved them all as his sense of humor appeals to me!

summary: Reading this book was an unusual and rewarding experience
reviewText: I liked Dr Alexander's scientific approach when describing his near death experience. It caused me to begin to believe there is an after life for everyone that is filled with total and unconditional love. When a reader completes this book they will undoubtedly have a stronger sense of spirituality. I know I did!

reviewerName: W. Michael King, Ph.D. "Advisor & Mentor: Aut...
reviewText: As one in science and in psychology, I take delight in learning of (another) SCIENTIST'S CASE FOR THE AFTERLIFE, essentially because this is very similar to what I discovered during my clinical death as I have written in my book "Atheists Can Get To 'Heaven': Perspectives From The Journey Beyond the Tunnel of Light!"In particular, my Journey also took me into what seemed to be inter-stellar space! The wonder, glory, challenge and beauty of my experience aligns very well to Dr. Alexander's because we both moved beyond temporal bounds into the infinity of "Heaven."[...]

summary: Clear explanation of life after death
reviewText: Dr. Eben clearly explains life after death based on his near-death experience. I have discussed this with others who have had NDE and they confirm Dr. Eben's experience.Sweep Away Your Thorny Childhood: Eight Steps to a Life of Well-Being

summary: A Scientists Point of View.  Well worth the read
reviewText: I'm a science/history TV, book sort of guy, not so much a drama or comedy type.  This book made life after death and all those theories by quantum physicists, theoretical physicists, and cosmologists make a lot more sense.  I'm not a scientist.  I have degrees in engineering, theology, and counseling.  I'm glad I read this book as my entry into the Near Death Experience genre.  I have terminal cancer, am not actively religious, and this book kicked me into growing in my perception/understanding of life after death.

This was a good read. Surprising twists and turns kept me reading. The answers to the mystery always seemed right around the corner. Sometimes this author writes in confusing sentences, causing me to reread what written. Even so I liked the story.  This was the second book I have read by this author.

The thing is, you don't need to be in a coma to experience unusual things. You just need to be a medium of some kind. See my own eBook "Visitations from the Other Side" for an unusual take on the medium experience:Visitations from the Other Side

summary: A fun story about a difficult trip
reviewText: For those of us who have always wanted to hike the Appalachian trail, but who just haven't seemed to get around to it, Bill Bryson offers the next best thing, a detailed and amusing rendition of his own journey. The great  strength of this book is Bryson himself--far from being a smooth, skilled  outdoorsman, he seems as lost, as frustrated, and as tired as we ourselves  would be in his situation. This book not only tells you what it's like to  hike the Appalachian trail, but it provides some insight into the human  response to adversity.

A beautiful read. Whatever is true about the afterlife we won't know until we die, but this book makes sense and takes away the fear of not knowing. Thoroughly enjoyed the story, the message, and the fact that it was written by a neurosurgeon who experienced what he did.
been there. did that. had similar experience many years ago. the book tells his story with a touch of reality.

summary: A walk in the woods by Bill Bryson
reviewText: Fast shipping and good quality cassettes. I have enjoyed listening to the book since I don't have much time for reading. Thank you for having cassettes available.

This book is funny for both the young and older. It details a fun experience between two average guys taking on way more than they can handle. Strangely it'll have you wanting to take the same miserable endeavor they do.

Amazing the controversy a book like this stirs up - with friends saying it is not true because it isn't biblical.  This is this man's experience - it was true for him - and it turned him into a believer.  What more do these people want?

summary: No... It's not in your head.
reviewText: The first part of the book is a bit dry and somewhat difficult to stay with, but I'm glad I did. The author did a good job of showing how dry his own spiritual beliefs were prior to his near death experience. Upon his "experience" the book becomes very engaging and easy to follow.Having had an NDE when I was nine (over 50 years ago) and being told many of the same things the author talks about (it's in your head, you were on medication and hallucinated, etc) I found the author explained this aspect very clearly.If you are interested in NDEs, have had a personal experience or just want to see what someone does go through, pick up a copy of the book.
The fact that the author is a brain specialist, and had a medical miracle happen to him, gives his story credibility.

You would think that a story of walking the Appalachian Trail would be pretty boring ... 'we walked up the hill then back down the other side' ... but Bill Bryson's version is anything but.  Yes, he was on the trail, but his story-telling is of the land, the people, the history, and everything in between.  A great book for anyone, highly recommended, now that I think about it, I ought to read it again ...
Another great Anchor Island novel. I love how other characters were developed in this novel. Definitely recommend this one! Very fast read!

summary: Could not wait to get back to this book
reviewText: I thought I knew who it was and I had the wrong person all along and was so surprised when I got to the end of the book and found out I was wrong. Good book and I will look for more of her books.

summary: Like a good meal;life is about enjoyment of the ambience,side dishes and company along with the main course.
reviewText: I don't know if the writer had it in mind at the time;but I found along with his experiences of hiking the Appalachian Trail ,he has a real thoughtful message here about enjoying life;no matter what we choose to do with our all too short time here on earth---at least that part we spend above the ground.I you keep this in mind, you will find this a rewarding read and obtain from it some real insights into what you enjoy in life.Some reviewers have criticized the fact that Bill and Katz didn't complete the Trail from beginning to end.To them ,I can only say,you missed the point...I am 73 now, and have had a string of interests all my life.Was I ever the best ,or did I ever reach the pinacle of any of them? no but I enjoyed each and every one of them and they all enriched my life.In this book ,we see that these two friends got great pleasure from what they did and the writer still dabbles in hiking but his observances of everything else from Katz,historical aspects along the Trail,the people they encounter,nature,hardships,his family,and a raft of other things are much more important than if his mindset had been on, only completing the trail at the exlusion of all else.Therefore; he got great satisfaction from the Trail, where if total completion was the only issue;he would have been disappointed. Isn't that what all life is really about?I have been an avid Birder for many years and have often crossed a somewhat similar trail here in Ontario,and have even walked along some short parts of it while birding .It is called "The Bruce Trail and starts at Niagara Falls and runs to the tip of the Bruce Peninsula,over 200 miles ,as the crow lies,ending in Tobermory at Lake Huron." When I see the markings on the trees and when I come across the record book stands or meet hikers,I feel the "sense" of the trail and even contempleted "giving it a try";but probably never will;and have to be contented with my minimal samplings of it ;not unlike the sampling of birding that the hikers get.After all,nobody can do everything ,that doesn't mean you can't sample everything you come across.I have seen nearly 600 different species of birds in North America and in those travels have encounteres much history,enviroments,weather,and people along the way.There are still more of them to see,but so be it;the real enjoyment is in what I have done;not what I still have to see.I am often reminded of what Roger Tory Peterson,one of America's most famous Birders said ,when asked ;"What was your favorite bird?" His reply was "The one I'm looking at ,at the time."I fully agree with Bryson when he says "We hiked the Appalachian Trail".Some people who enjoy other pursuits can say the same about what they have done,and in whatever manner they did it.Whether it's sports,fishing,mountain climbing,playing poker or pool,those who do those things generally enjoy the experiences and people that surround them as much as the activity itself.That,I believe,is what Bryson has brought out so well in this book.

A neurosurgeon dies.  He has no brain left,  A few days lter he is alive and whole.What happened where did he go and what did he learn.He met God Our brain is a buffer to prevent us from having an OverLoad.God is Love God is Mind.Evil is a byproduct of our free will.the worst evil is a s a speck of dust -- the entire universe--entire Creation is made up of Divine Love.Yes Prayer does work--he moved faster as people prayed for him.  He was stuck in muck with creatures .. then he wanted to get out of that muck and a gate opened..there was heaven--the muck and creatures were shut out.A MUST READ. I can not do it justice.

This book was awesome! There. I just had to get that out of the way ;)I really liked how the book was divided into four parts; each girl had her own section, and that section was only about that particular Liar.Hanna's story, I thought, was very amusing. Her BF leaves her to go on vacay, and she feels all alone, especially since her dad, stepmother, and Kate move into her house. She meets this cute guy who she may or may not be falling for, and, lets just say that Hanna isn't the only one drooling over this dude. Oh, and Kate is a total witch! Can't believe Hanna has to put up with her!I really liked Emily's story too. There have been pranksters in Rosewood causing havoc in the town. And somehow Emily winds up trying to catch these "Merry Elves" in the act to finally stop all the holiday disasters. How is she going to do this? you ask. Easy: by befriending them, duh.Oh my gods, Aria's story was....crazy! Seriously crazy and shocking! That is the only way I can describe it. Aria's was supposed to spend the holidays with her dad and brother, but something totally uncool changed things. Upon arriving home, Aria gets an unexpected visit from her ex-BF from Iceland. And from there things get crazy! I wish I could say, but I don't want to spoil things! Let's just say it involves panthers, weddings, and delinquents! You seriously have got to read this one!Spencer goes on vacation with her family to Florida. Here she meet a really cute guy, he seems to be interested in her. But, again, she might not be the only one. Oddly enough, Melissa helps Spencer get the guy! Oh, the things they do when they work together...that revenge they pulled off at the end, for example. Oh my gods, it was hilarious!This book was seriously awesome, and totally creepy...you know, because of A. Throughout the whole book I kept wondering if A was the same A we discovered on the show in this summer season finally. If it is, then it makes no sense at all!But anyway, I cannot wait for more of this series...both the books AND the show!

LOVED this book! He had me in stitches throughout the story! I highly recommend this to people who wouldn't be caught dead without a flush toilet - but, would like to hear about the adventures of hiking the AT.  Keep in mind this book is tongue in cheek - don't expect survival advice. Do expect a wonderfully light hearted story about a regular guy with high aspirations!

Dr. Eben Alexander is one more intelligent and eloquent voice bridging the scientific and spiritual worlds with his extraordinary book Proof of Heaven. The fact that a neurosurgeon, of finely tuned and solid scientific bent, was the individual who found himself having a NDE (near-death experience) is beyond coincidence. Heaven chose the perfect spokesperson! Dr. Alexander writes from the heart, which makes his book so readable, but he also includes some of his own scientific observations, which may be helpful to those with a more skeptical mindset. I loved reading all of it, and I especially appreciated the way the book was organized, with chapters describing his own other-worldly experience alternating with chapters describing the experiences of his family members who sat by his side while he was in a coma. This is NOT a dry factual narrative--the beauty of his thoughts, feelings, and perceptions brought me to tears at times. A beautiful uplifting book!--Peggy Korneggerauthor of Living with Spirit
The book makes you realize on how much God loves you. The author is a neurosurgeon and have a very scientific mind. This makes you understand the connection between science and spirituality.
It was a page turner and even though I knew the outcome from watching videos of the author, I was captured by his story.  I  recommend it to everyone.

This is a wonderful book, about courage, healing, redemption, faith, hope and love -- the stuff that makes life worth living.  Each of the major characters in the story has enormous challenges to meet, and with each others help they manage to survive, even triumph, in spite of a few truly foolish decisions.  The only criticism I'd make is that the men aren't explored as thoroughly as the women -- their challenges are in the past, referred to but not shown, which makes them more spear-carriers than developing characters -- and they're great guys, and would have been interesting.  The monsters are truly monstrous, also, without any desire or intent to do the right thing, ever.  That said, I loved this book, curled up and read it for hours, finishing it at 2 a.m. And I had to get up at 5:30.  It's that good.

A primary goal of quantum theory is the explanation of reality and the role of human consciousness in bringing it about.  In QM, this is known as "the observables problem"."Proof of Heaven" by Eben Alexander, M.D., is the most scientifically well documented presentation of an NDE (Near Death Experience) I've ever heard of, and there are 10's of thousands of NDE's carefully recorded and itemized in academic compendia.  These include irreproachable reports from young children but which are, perforce, less scientifically well grounded than this one from a noted neurosurgeon.Coming from a standpoint other than quantum theory, viz. from his personal experience,  Alexander's insights into the interrelationships between body, mind, consciousness, and spirit (or soul), and what they tell us about reality, are extremely interesting.Martin Fricke, Ph.D.San Diego

summary: A great read Thank you Jack Coughlin
reviewerName: Beth DeRoos "Beth DeRoos from the California ...
reviewText: Even I cannot explain why I read and even liked this book. Perhaps it is because I grew up around firearms and feel comfortable with them. But something tells me that it was more the need to know what it feels like to know that the firearm you hold in your hand has one job. Kill.To get inside the #1 sniper of the United States and see or learn what it must be like to take aim at someone whom you do not know, someone who has a mother who carried him/her to term, breastfed, laughed and nurtured whom you know seek to put a bullet in that persons heart or head is jaw dropping surreal. And something I think the American citizen needs to know!In my opinion most Americans don't give much thought to what their tax dollars are paying for in the military or sadly, the underpaid, men women we send off to far off lands to do our bidding and sadly killing. But men like Jack Coughlin do what most Americans couldn't do even if threatened face to face.  It sounds so odd calling him a hero, but to me he is. War is hell and good all American men/women are doing the job well.

i am also an MD and trained in the "science" of believe what can be proven. I have seen things that cannot be explained by science happen to children I have cared for. This book reminds us that we cannot explain everything and that we will be "on the other side" someday ourselves. I trust it will be as wonderful as Dr Alexander describes as best he could.

I am a 60 year old woman who has been reading books since the age of 8, and this is one of my all time favorites.  I had never read anything by this author before picking up this book several years ago.  I bought it because of the bear on the front - I love bears - and I just loved it.  I passed it onto my son who is an even more addicted reader than I am and he read this book so many times the pages fell out of it.  I have given this book to friends who loved it.  It surprises me that anyone would rate this book in a negative way.  I did not feel that the humor was at anybody's expense.  I remember a couple of years after reading this book I happened to be in the Blue Ridge mountains.  I had stopped at a ranger station to pick up some maps and information.  I started talking to one of the rangers there and I mentioned this book.  As soon as I said it he started laughing and so did I.  It's a fun book and I would recommend it to anybody.

Thank you Dr. Alexander for sharing your riveting and compelling  experience. Paramount was your NDE, but I also enjoyed your personal journey to find your birth mother. Inspirational on many levels. Thank you!

This wonderfully written book contains one of the most detailed and extraordinary accounts of a near-death experience. It is extremely persuasive of the existence of an afterlife, and contains in depth accounts of the entire event, reading in a very accessible and heart-warming way. Adding even more credibility to this memoir is the fact that the writer is a neurosurgeon.
I am interested in the subject as I have read many accounts of life beyond.  This account is more scientific and credible....

I seldom give 5 stars for anything but this book caused me to sit and wonder if Heaven is real. I think you will feel the same. The author puts it out for us to make the decision. Give it a try...I think you would agree with me.

summary: This is a great story and possibly a life changing book
reviewText: The story itself is great. You might think when you are reading it that there is extraneous information in it, but I found that it was tightly written. The whole story wraps up very nicely and it is one of those "real-life" events. I was very pleased with how easy it was to read and engaging the story was and it has affected my life for the better. I highly recommend that people read this book, especially if they are trying to figure out how God and science can co-exist (or actually be part of the same universe). I really appreciate the fact that the book is written as an interesting story as well as conveying a life-altering event.

This is a very powerful book.  I read it in two days, but it's one of those books that makes me want to read it again.  The author gives credibility to his true story because of his status as a neurosurgeon.  As a doctor, he answers many questions that are raised and sometimes dismissed by other near-death-experience authors.  I highly recommend this book.

This is a very good book about a near death experience by a man who really wasn't very spiritual. He connects us to the other side through his story about the journey. I found the book fascinating. I couldn't put it down.

I do believe this is a very true story and the experience was similar to many other NDE experiences people have.  Gives you some insight into what heaven will FEEL like.  And is a great testimony for those who like to explain NDE's as the brain playing tricks.

Not what I expected but more than what I hope for.  This was a great read.  Really exposing and capturing the honest person in the novel.  Great writing without seedy graphics but just enough so you can understand the pain and self discovery.  Great Job!
What an amazing book about a near-death experience.  For this neurosurgeon and atheist to come to an understanding about God, heaven and his life is really amazing.  It was quite a journey.

A really great read!  I have both the book and the audio.  Have listened to the audio multiple times.  I don't often reread books but this one is a classic.  I'm a hiker but you don't need to be one to enjoy Bill Bryson's unique take on things.  Love it, love it, love it!

summary: My response to Proof of Heaven
reviewText: It' a fascinating book.  I wish I had more knowledge of medical terms, especially neurological ones. I am still reading it.
Great sense of humor, unlikely duo, very thoughtful, allowing for various points of view.  I loved it.  This book demonstrates the need to preserve our wilderness areas.
Should be required reading for all the curious about the after life.It is also a great read on a cool stormy day just get a blanket wrap up and enjoy.

This is one of those books I couldn't put down, and held onto through every free moment I had until it was complete.  It is also one of those books that stays on my shelf instead of being sold back to Amazon, because I know I will want to open it again.  The story is great, and Bill's style of writing really makes you feel like you are tagging along.  He is also a well educated man, and has loads of information about the Appalachians within, but makes sure to keep you on track with the story to prevent you from losing interest.
