The first half of the book is better than the second in my opinion, and apparently in a lot of others opinions also... but overall the entire book is worth checking out.  I picked one up used on Amazon for just a couple bucks!  Get one!

Over the years, there have been many near death and out of body experience books and accounts. But this one is different in that Eban Alexander is highly educated and a trained neurosurgeon rather than a New Age seeker. Eban tells his story from the heart with compassion, sincerity and intelligence and not without professional risk. As someone who has always known that this life is temporary and there is so much that is unknown about consciousness and life itself, this was a genuinely insightful and uplifting read. Enjoy.

The only thing that stopped me reading was the need to wipe my eyes. My tears were blurring my vision. Though--especially if you are in the medical profession--you still might not believe in heaven, I don't think it's possible for anyone to read this book and not believe in love.
This was a good read, written by a man who should know. As a brain surgeon who experienced a life threatening illness it gives us all hope for heaven.

I was a little skeptical when I bought this for my Kindle.I was on a long flight over the Christmas holidays and decided to look at it.I was hooked!Couldn't wait for my connecting flight so I could read again.It's always interesting when a man of science writes a book like this, because they always pooh pooh belief in God, but not this one.I recommend this to all my friends.
Recently lost our son and this book made me feel better.  I have always believed in heaven but Dr Alexander's experience confirms my belief.
I loved this book and have recommended it to so many people already. For a guy who was all about the sciences of stuff to really believe in heaven is quite the amazing testimony.

I've read lots of books from other people on NDE near death experience and books from well known mediums.But to finally hear that Heaven does exit, especially from a nero-surgeon was just mind blowing! I've always believed in Heaven, now maybe the rest of the world will too.  If you are a doughter, read this book.

summary: A Worthy Walk for the Armchair Traveler
reviewText: In the words of Bill Bryson he "happened upon a path that vanished into a wood on the edge of town."  So begins a complex love/hate relationship with the Appalachian Trail that is equal parts hilarious travelogue and cautionary tale.  Tightly written and wonderfully descriptive, A Walk in the Woods is the story of Bill and his sidekick Stephan Katz.  These two are not your typical outdoorsman but two relatively sedentary middle-aged men who undertake one of the most challenging hikes on the continent armed with little more than a backpack full of Little Debbie cakes (soon abandoned)and the vague notion of hiking the two-thousand odd miles of the trail in one season.It's not spoiling the story to tell you they don't even come close to meeting that goal, but the story is so rich and so fun it helps demonstrate that the joy is really in the journey, not the destination.I loved this book for its honest and direct tone and the way Bryson kept me laughing from page one.  A great read for a rainy winter afternoon.

well this book has changed my mind about the hereafter....excellent read with an incredible report about Dr. Alexander's experience in "the life after death".  I love that the author was able to weave the story from his childhood all the way to his current life.

Loved the book.  I live in Tn so, I totally understood their treck through the mountains. I, too would love to do this one day.  The best part was the friend, throwing needful stuff away because it was heavy.  I laughed because I know people like this!  Such a great read.  Informative and real.

The heroine in this book is a strong, capable woman who also can show some vulnerability. I love that realistic element. Home To Stay will tug your heart strings at times, but also make you laugh. The friendships on the island are classic! A wonderful cast of characters will take you on a journey and keep you on your toes!

I enjoyed this book immensely and did not get offended by the comments like many of the reviewers. The information on the trail is great alone, even without the humorous observations. So what if he didn't pan out as a thru-hiker, the book is still a interesting read and inspiring to those who dream of hiking the trail. I think he deserves respect for increasing interest in hiking the trail. Now maybe it won't fall into ruin and be forgotten like other american treasures.
I saw the author interviewed on TV.  It just goes to show that people with lots of education can still experience the same miracles as us "common folk".  A good read by an enthusiastic author.

A very down to earth Experience  explained by one of the last persons one would expect to write of such Happenings ! ..........it is a extremely important Event at this time of our ever growing  need of personal growth in  Consciousness and AwarenessThis is no 'accident' that a man of Dr. Alexander's background/education/status in Science and stellar reputation is being used toheighten and accelerate our consciousness in this age of  very rapid change !

Can read numerous times and receive new information. Reminds us God reaches out to us even when we don't recognize him. We read as a group in Sunday School with great discussion. A different perspective from a doctor/scientist.
well written story.  Willow and Randy make a pretty good team.  sometimes you just half to have a leap of faith.

summary: Secrets, lies & more secrets and lies
reviewText: If you're  a fan of the Pretty Little Liars you will love this book. It focuses on each character separately and goes into their lives and secrets that they have on their own without the others in the group knowing. Some of the secrets will shock you.
This is a very well documented book and is written in an easy to read and understand manner.  If you are interested in life after death info, this is a good book.

A very well written book that is clearly causing some controversy in the medical field.  After all, as a neurosurgeon, Dr. Alexander would have a far better grasp on how the brain works, especially under the dire circumstances that he found himself, than the average lay person and he is not so easily dismissed.My impression is that for all his years of academic research, study and practice, he struggled to describe exactly what he experienced as there are no sufficient words that could do it justice.  The fact that on his return to this life, he looked closely at other possible scenarios as to what could have caused such an experience, shows that he was not quick to jump on the NDE bandwagon as some have asserted, but rather wanted to make sure that there was really no other materialist explanation that made any sense.I've read several of the critics comments who demand that he provide 'proof' that he had this experience while in a deep coma as they insist that he had it while on the road to recovery.  Of course, they cannot prove that either but expect everyone to accept their view without question.My only criticism of the book is the title.  While I believe his account is very strong evidence that something does indeed survive the physical death, it is not 100% proof, at least by human standards.  Other than that, I thoroughly enjoyed it.

I choose this rating because I find the subject very interesting and compelling.. Have always wondered what it would be like to actually have vision.. At times I feel connected to people for know reason ..also in our family we have a true connection to know when one of us is needing a little more love ..I would recommend this book to any of these people and To any of the friends I have found interested in this..And No I am note sure if the punishments were right but It is fiction.;););)Thank you

I've read several of Bryson's travel-oriented books, and this is by far my favorite. Don't expect a detailed guidebook telling you everything you need to know about hiking the Appalachian Trail.  Instead, expect to be hilariously entertained by the experiences of Bryson, his hiking companion, and the people they encounter while venturing out on several sections of the AT.  Be warned however:  as you read, you will probably laugh out loud on a regular basis, and people nearby will certainly give you strange looks!For an inside look at how a not-so-fit person might experience the AT, this is a great book to pick up.
This book puts heaven in the context of science. It is a great read. I just wish it was longer. I will be coming back to this book over and over again!

I downloaded this book on the advise of a friend that said I jsut had to read it.  It was compelling reading, especially since the auther is a neurosurgeon and he is telling of his own personal experience of his near death experience.  It was facscinating reading

A fast paced, although lengthy, first person narrative showcasing the complexities and intrigues surrounding Elizabeth's rise to power. Her loves, her enemies, her triumphs and failures, they are all here. A compelling,"I can't put it down" read. Historical fiction is a  super interesting way to supplement drier biographical approaches. An  enormously fascinating and emotionally evocative drama. Her life was  amazing. I loved this book!
This was a very well written bok and was so inspiring.  It held your interest and I always hated to put it down when I had somethng else to do.  Job well done.
I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Each time I read it, the author makes a point that makes you think. He is the real deal.

summary: I, Elizabeth, a must read for anglophiles
reviewText: The most interesting queen in history. I've read many biographies on her. While this book is fiction, it is based on historical facts. It is a little peep into the Elizabethan age and a brilliant, yet flawed woman. Ms. Miles has written Elizabeth as I would have imagined her to be, warts and all. I quite enjoyed the book, great read!
This was a great third book.  I'm glad I got to read it.  I'm going to miss this series.  Terri Osburn is a great author and I'm looking forward to reading more wrote by her.

summary: Gives you hope and raises your heart to new limits
reviewText: Just when you think all is lost, a simply marvelous depiction of what is yet to come from an unassuming and calm person. Believable beyond the norm was this writer.  Makes so much sense and simplicity out of what is yet to come.  So VERY glad that Eben Alexander came back to impart this wisdom to all of us.

An island, hot guy, mystery women and a touch of suspense. What more could you ask for in a book. Loved the writing, the story had hot, steamy lust and love. Randy was a giant teddy bear who finally found his love. Enjoyable read. I know there is more coming in this series. Can't wait to visit Anchor and its people again.
Bryson is funny and informative...the trail calls out to many who will never touch it; "a walk in the woods" offers the almost experience-

My husband read this book in two days and has a whole new outlook on death and heaven.  As a physician also he has discussed the book and recommended it to several colleagues to see what they think about the book and Dr. Alexander's journey.

summary: One of the best on the subject
reviewText: This book goes where others fear to tread.  Most of the simple living, decluttering books stop short of confronting the main tenet of this book:  how much do we really need to live "rich" lives?  The answer Lawrence gives us with candid examples is, 'very little!'  I love this book because it opens my mind to consider American life in radical ways, and because he gives concrete examples of how to do it.  Yes, the book is short (minimal:proves the point!) and, yes, because it's self-published there might be a few typos and Lawrence doesn't have the advantage of Madison Avenue's best and brightest editors.  Reviewers who focus on this are missing the point: someone has broken ranks with convention to share his insights with us and they're extremely valuable.Mr. Lawrence was born in Singapore and he had a successful career with HP in the states after moving here.  He was able to retire in his 40s due to his frugality.  Lawrence's perspective gives us the insight and impetus to examine our own lives.  This is one of the few books I bought and kept; I refer to it regularly.One reviewer compared Lawrence's lifestyle to living under a bridge.  Far from it!  Lawrence lives in one of the wealthiest communities on the planet with a five-star view from his condo living room.  And he can move easily within the continent in a compact sedan car.  Lawrence eats well, dresses well, gives back through volunteering, has good friends and, as he shares, peace of mind.This is an author I wish I could meet, and I hope he will write more.  I'd love to read about a day in his life, see a video on youtube that shows his home and neighborhood and grocery shopping, hear what he is reading.  Lawrence is a very bright, walks-his-talk, likable, progressive person and I appreciate the opportunity to "meet him" through this great book.

Julia Bennett decides to flee her abusive fiancé Robert before he seriously harms her physically, which he has already done mentally.  She decides the best place to reflect on her life safely is her Aunt Lydia's farm near rural Golden, Oregon where making chocolate has always been a relaxant for her.  She knows an "inconvenienced" Robert eventually will come for her once he obtains Aunt Lydia's address from her mom hidden in Minnesota with her zillionth boyfriend, but Lydia will not go with him.Lydia welcomes her beloved niece and offers sanctuary while Julia tries to recoup her lost optimism.  Lydia's warm friends also greet Julia as one of them.  She and her circle of friends welcome Julia into their lives.  As Julia begins to feel better about herself and her future, she makes friends and chocolate.From the opening line of leaving her wedding dress on a tree in North Dakota to the climax, JULIA'S CHOCOLATES is a strong character study looking deep at a woman trying desperately to regain the hope she once had about life.  The supporting females like Aunt Lydia and her friends add depth to the audience comprehending the demons eroding Julia's dreams.  Contemporary fiction fans will appreciate this fine portrayal just go easy on the chocolates.Harriet Klausner
This book gives courage to those of us who are not "religious".  I like the hope in the message it gives.

I am only a little more than half way through it but it is remarkable how he is able to describe his experiences and bring them to life. He is very believable because of who he is and his knowledge of the brain.

Who among us has not been inspired by some handicapped marathon runner/the theme music to Rocky/some historical epic to feel that we're missing out on life since we are not in the midst of some magnificent physical undertaking?This is the book for anyone who have ever tapped into that vein of sentiment sufficiently to actually do something. Bryson flies down to Georgia, and starts his own Great Trek.And this absolutely hysterical account ensues.I read the book while "waiting" (doctor's office etc), and I've never enjoyed the experience so much.Bryson's gift is that you can easily put yoursel in his shoes; his comedy is of the "ordinary man puts himself in extraordinary situation" genre.This would not be the book that I was suggest for someone who was actually preparing to walk the AT. However, it would be perfect for someone who was contemplating undertaking the endeavor.Its funny, well written, and a good tale well told.

First of all, I can relate to the book because I hiked a part of the AT back when I was a teenager. It's not an easy walk. Bryson writes with a great deal of humor and interesting facts about the trail. If you've never read any of his works, A Walk in the Woods would be a great place to start.

summary: This story kept me glued to my Kiindle
reviewText: Molly, having gone through an emotional roller coaster that almost cost her her sanity and her family, has moved from Philadelphia to a quiet town in Maryland. Her mundane life was about to turn upside down, when her nightmare starts again.A child is missing.  Molly's gift, the Knowing, which can bring her to her knees, gives her vague, horrific visions, that she can't put together.  Will this nightmare end like the other?  Her family and sanity is once again on the line.Melissa Foster has the ability to spin a tale that has her readers feeling all the emotions she is writing about, be it happiness, anger, anxiety, and terror!Chasing Amanda is a well written story that kept me reading and I never lost interest in the story!PS - I never saw the ending coming!  What a surprise!

Great service once again. I have ordered so many books and movies and cd's from Amazon sellers and don't recall ever being disappointed. It could happen some day but my advice is, try it, it's a great place to buy media.

summary: I don't hike alot, but did after I read this book
reviewText: I love this book on tape so much I had to listen to it twice.  I've hiked about three times in the past several years, but after listening to this book, I immediately went hiking, for the day and still laughed about the characters in Bryson's book.  I'm going to the Maui Writer's Conference in August, which Bill Bryson will be speaking at and I can't wait to meet him, hopefully he'll endorse my book.

A very lucid and well-written book. Dr. Eben makes a convincing case for the afterlife and explains, as a scientist, the amazing experience of not only heaven but of returning to life on earth and explaining his experiences to his colleagues and family. A read worth the time and money.

I just loved what Cathy Lamb did with Julia and all the characters.  To be able to take that much abuse and turn it into so much love and laughter.  I cried when Olivia Cutter found her human side.  And Aunt Lydia going through Chemo reminded me of my Mom in so many ways.  Enough said!  Read it.I'm adding to this original review.  I have purchased Julia's Chocolates for dear friends of mine to read, hoping that they would come away with the same good feelings that I did.  They did.  I also purchased the book again for myself and have read all of Cathy Lamb's books.

This is the first time I've read anything by Bill Bryson.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book and his style and now want to read more by him.  Dry humor, interesting historical info about the places he visited, and an unpretentious writing style.  Don't usually go in for travelogues, but this was an A+.
I have always believed that some are to travel to the other side, to let us all know that there is hope for us. There will always be the doubters, and that is ok, but I know what I believe.
Once I started reading this book I couldn't put it down. I hope that agnostics will read it and come to understand the spiritual side of our lives.

I think this book is realy a wonderful addition to the growing library on near death experiences (NDEs), that give us here on the earth plane a better connection with what happens when we leave this physical body. It is very credible, and written by a man who had spent his career aurguing against the case he made in this book. It is a must read for people that still harbor a fear of dying, or hold grief in their hearts - from loosing a loved one.
Was a wonderful book, Loved it.  Enlightening, interesting and thought provoking.Open your mind and you will find another world

For all those who think that YA novels hold no literary importance, credibility or fascination for adults are missing out on a lot. I have read many YA novels that have overwhelmed me with their value as a book to treasure and read over and over again. A Wounded Name is most definitely one of them. Hamlet has long been a favorite of mine. I've seen professional and not-so-professional productions, and each one held a particular fascination for me, especially through the interpretation of the character, Ophelia.A Wounded Name is a retelling of the tragedy, Hamlet, seen primarily through the eyes of Ophelia. The author does not miss a beat with this story -- Ophelia has been brought to life in full bloom, to my delight. If you enjoy excellent writing from an author who thoroughly knows her characters and presents them without fear of violating a politically correct view of a heroine, this book is most definitely one that will satisfy on many levels. Recommended for both adults and older teens.

This book was incredible. The two main characters were incredibly drawn; their stories were heartbreaking, but I couldn't look away. I really enjoy novels that have a historical backdrop and this novel did a good job of using the atmosphere of Sri Lanka's past to add to the stories (did not distract from it). Not only did I get to enjoy a good story (two stories), but also had the opportunity to learn some history of Sri Lanka and how various people lived there. I don't want to get into any more detail for fear of giving something away.This would make a great Book Club selection. When my turn comes to make the next selection in the Book Club I am part of, I'll be choosing it.
It was not written well but what can you expect from a neurosurgeon? It is still incredible and an absolutely amazing true story. A must read.
Could not stop reading until I finished the book in one sitting! What an inspiring story which further confirms my beliefs about our spiritual and physical "self" is one!

A wonderful book written by a doctor who comes to terms with his near death experience. He learns about love and the connections of all living beings to each other. It is a great journey to another reality which not many of us are blessed to take, so we have people like Eben who fortunately take the time to tell us about it.  I would rather believe in an afterlife and be wrong, than to NOT believe. Belief in a place that transcends this earthly realm is what makes the idea of death bearable. He takes us there.

I have read a couple of books similar to this one, but never one written by a doctor.  You can tell he's trying to make scientific sense about what happened to him.  I believe he really did experience what he said he did.  I would highly recomment this book.

The third series to Anchor Island books by Terri Osburn.  AMAZING!  This is Willow and Randy's story.  Will has trust issues because of her past. Randy knows something is going on but doesn't push the issue.  Can they remain friends? Will they become lovers?  Without giving the story away I can't really talk more about it, but it is definitely worth reading.  The friendship between Sid, Beth and Will is also a testament to true friendship.

This is an exceptionally well-written book with a phenomenal story.  I, too, am cynical about religion, an afterlife, etc.  This book gave me pause to rethink my beliefs.  A friend recommended it and now I'm interested in reading more from among the books listed in Dr. Alexander's bibliography.His scientific street cred greatly enhances the believability of his story.  I can't recommend this book enough.

summary: Melissa Foster is a great writer to say the least!!
reviewText: This book was captivating and very intriguing wondering if Molly would be able to solve the missing pieces. Like what happened to Rodney Letts and what secrets the minister held inside her.  What made the Boyd house so secretive that no one was allowed in.  What secrets Hannah held close to her chest.  And who took Tracey and what happened so many years ago with Kate another kidnapped victim and did Rodney hold the secrets or was he to blame.  I applaud how Molly was able to percever when she had doubts when she witnessed a girl go missing and turned up dead.  The woman who took Tracey somewhere deep down thought she was doing what she was taught.  She had very much a Stockholm syndrome going on, which brought her to her own turmoil.  Molly and Cole suffer their own issues wishing they could have done more for Amanda and in some ways I believe that is what made this book so captivating.  Tracey has no connection to Molly but yet Molly is so determined to help her, I think it was in a way someone she could help when she felt her "knowing" failed her when she needed it the most.  Rodney and Molly even have an interesting connection both being born with abilities to know what is happening to someone else.  The two abilities connected together help prove that sometimes psychics know what they are doing.  A great story full of so much love and admiration towards family that I can't wait to read Megan's Way.
Excellent explanation of connectedness of realms. I always believed in God and heaven but not in a fire and brimstone way.
This certainly was a nice read. The drama was enough to put you on edge, but the romance & heat made it all worthwhile. Looking forward to reading the other books in the series.

summary: If you wonder .. could there be ??
reviewText: I avoid religiously driven stories.  Too much desire to preach and convince the reader to believe as they do.  So when I saw this book and that it was written by a physician who was basically a scientist and skeptic , I thought  that I could relate to his point of view.  I considered that the book could be written primarily for financial gain, but then I thought, well, he is a Neurosurgeon and his income has to be in the upper stratosphere, so money would not be a number one reason .  His story is fascinating and his recovery equally fascinating.  I believe that I was just hearing that in August 2013 , a skeptical story is going to be published that questions the good doctor.  That will be interesting to read .  Questioning anything is always good.  But the story is riveting and the circumstances of his health at the time were dire.  He has changed his life to tell his story.  He believes that what happened is true. The reader can decide !
We hear about people having been to Heaven and having been to hell, I do believe Jesus is trying to tell us he is coming and keep the oil in the lamp in case he is delayed.

This book will make a believer of you if you have had any doubt of our continued existence post physical death.  He recounts his miraculous trip to the spiritual world and the gaining of all knowledge and his encounter with GOD/OM.  With his medical training he is able to give credence to the reality of his special message. Read and believe.  Have faith we will continue beyond this existence.

Proof of Heaven is another in a number of books out on "near death" experiences.  I generally love these kinds of books and think they are especially pertinent to this time on earth when there are so many changes and challenges facing humanity.  What is somewhat different about this book is the technical medical information provided by the author, a highly respected neurosurgeon with a wealth of knowledge about the brain and how he discounts any possibility that his near death experience could be anything but real.  This book should be read  especially by scientifically oriented individuals in the medical profession who tend to try to come up with explanations of how such an experience might occur as a sort of hallucination.  It is especially pertinent for people in the medical profession who are around people who are considered to be terminal or who have survived a serious illness and talk about their experiences.

I read a lot about heaven and near death experiences, and this is the real thing! We worship a loving God, and will be in his presences one day! This author tried to describe the experience, but was at a loss for words. The angels that swirled around him were not formed, they were "it's", and the swirling  made music. This is the closes description to the bible description I have ever read. This brilliant surgeon chose to share his experience even though it was totally against all of his beliefs and training. Thank you Dr. Alexander!

summary: One of the funniest laugh out loud books I've ever read
reviewText: I have read this book several times and it is one of the funniest ever. There are scenes in this book I still recount to other people and I will never think about bears in the woods the same way. It bogs down toward the end especially when it veers toward preachiness but all in all it was hilarious. Excellent audio narration too.

summary: Pretty Little Liars: Pretty Little Secrets
reviewText: I got this on my Kindle Fire instead of getting the book. But I'm going to end up buying the book the old fashion way after I read it on the Kindle to add to my Pretty Little Liars collection. I still need to get it. I love the books! I love all the books! Just like I love the show on ABC Family!
I love her writting.  Good story flows so easily..  I have read all of her books and cannot wait for the next one.  Give her a try you will not be disappointed

summary: Third time reading it and still a favorite
reviewText: Read this years ago for the first time and loved it.  Read it again with my high schooler, knowing it'd be a good read for him. Then I read a recent book I bought at Amazon on a man's journey walking the Trail and while it was interesting, it lacked the humor that I so loved about Bryson's books (I've read all of his) so I actually reread the book again and laughed most of the way through. I'd forgotten some of the tales and the humor was just as funny the 3rd time around.  It's one of his best.

summary: I couldn't put this book down
reviewText: I started reading this book the other evening in bed before I went to sleep.  Before I knew it, it was 3 o'clock in the morning. This book kept me spellbound.  I couldn't wait to finish the book in the morning which I promptly did.  This book is not your typical NDE (near death experience).  Although the doctor does speak some medical jargon which some people won't completely understand, it still is easy to get the whole picture.  I am convinced he was on the other side in heaven and paints heaven as a beautiful peaceful place indescribable in human language. He saw "dogs" in heaven.."happy" dogs.  Read the book.  You won't be sorry.  I am in the medical profession also and it really appealed to my emotions.
An excellent book to recommend to all friends of like mind or similar .It is a well detailed account  of a professional .

summary: Proof of Heaven is an interesting book.
reviewText: I really enjoyed the book.  Dr. Alexander had a life changing experience, and he is a  very gifted writer, also.
the book was very good . it is easy to understand, and i recommended to 5 other people that are friends of mine

I love Bill Bryson and I consider this his best book.  Laugh out loud funny.  I couldn't put it down.  You will be entertained for sure, but also enlightened and educated about a few things.  Actually, in the last third of the book, Bryson gets a little too much on his soap box for my taste.  But the book is so great, just skim over that part.

summary: Most Important book of this century
reviewText: By Darrell Stoddard, darrellstoddard@gmail.comWith more than 6,000 reviews of the book "Proof of Heaven" in such a shot time, I don't think it is an exaggeration to say that it is the most desired subject of the century. It is a daunting task for one such as I "of very small brain" as Winnie the Poo put it, to even think of writing a review that anyone would find in an amazon.com search except for those who "See all of my reviews." I therefore differ to Mike Adams review that I think is the best review that has been given. It has value for non-readers because they will get the message of the book without reading it."Proof of Heaven' documents existence of afterlife, multiverse, intelligent life beyond Earth, multidimensional realities" by Mike Adams(NaturalNews) "There's a secret that's much bigger than politics, health freedom, science or even the entire history of the human race. That secret remains entirely unacknowledged -- even condemned -- by the scientific community, and yet it is the single most important secret about everything that is. Yes, everything.That secret is simply this: We all survive the physical death of our bodies. Our consciousness lives on, and upon our death in this Earthly dream, our consciousness transcends this physical reality and experiences an existence so amazing and powerful that the human language cannot even begin to describe it.This is the message from Dr. Eben Alexander, author of the newly-published book, "Proof of Heaven." I recently read the book and found it both fascinating and also confirming of several important theories I've been developing about the nature of life and the Creator. (See below.)A lifelong science skeptic who never believed in God, Heaven or consciousnessLong before this book was ever written, Dr. Alexander was a practicing neurosurgeon and a lifelong "science skeptic." He did not believe in consciousness, free will or the existence of a non-physical spirit. Trained in western medical school and surrounded by medical colleagues who are deeply invested in the materialism view of the universe, Dr. Alexander believed that so-called "consciousness" was only an illusion created by the biochemical functioning of the brain.This is a view held by virtually all of today's mainstream scientists, including physicists like Stephen Hawking who say that human beings are nothing more than "biological robots" with no consciousness and no free will.Dr. Alexander would have held this view to his own death bed had it not been for his experiencing an event so bizarre and miraculous that it defies all conventional scientific explanation: Dr. Alexander "died" for seven days and experienced a vivid journey into the afterlife. He then returned to his physical body, experienced a miraculous healing, and went on to write the book "Proof of Heaven."E.coli infection eats his brainIt all started when e.coli bacteria infected Dr. Alexander's spinal fluid and outer cerebrum. The e.coli began to literally eat his brain away, and he went into an extremely violent fit of seizures, verbal outbursts and muscular spasms before lapsing into a brain-dead coma.In this coma, he showed zero higher brain activity and was only kept alive via a respirator and IV fluids. The attending physicians soon concluded that Dr. Alexander would die within a matter of days, and that even if he lived, he would be a non-functioning "vegetable" with limited brain function. Statistically, the death rate for patients with e.coli infections of the brain is 97%.But here's the real shocker in all this: Rather than experiencing nothingness during these seven earth-days of unconsciousness, Dr. Alexander found himself "awakening" from the dream of his earthly life, suddenly experiencing an incomprehensibly vast expansion of his consciousness in the afterlife.This experience is described in more detail in his book "Proof of Heaven," but here are the highlights:* The experience of the afterlife was so "real" and expansive that the experience of living as a human on Earth seemed like an artificial dream by comparison.* There was no time dimension in the afterlife. Time did not "flow" as it does in our universe. An instant could seem like eternity, and consciousness could move through what we perceive to be time without effort. (This idea that all time exists simultaneously has enormous implications in understanding the nature of free will and the multiverse, along with the apparent flow of time experienced by our consciousness in this realm.)* The fabric of the afterlife was pure LOVE. Love dominated the afterlife to such a huge degree that the overall presence of evil was infinitesimally small.* In the afterlife, all communication was telepathic. There was no need for spoken words, nor even any separation between the self and everything else happening around you.* The moment you asked a question in your mind, the answers were immediately apparent in breathtaking depth and detail. There was no "unknown" and the mere asking of a question was instantly accompanied by the appearance of its answers.* There also exists a literal Hell, which was described by Dr. Alexander as a place buried underground, with gnarled tree roots and demonic faces and never-ending torment. Dr. Alexander was rescued from this place by angelic beings and transported to Heaven.God acknowledges the existence of the multiverseThe passage of "Proof of Heaven" I found most interesting is found on page 48, where Dr. Alexander says:Through the Orb, [God] told me that there is not one universe but many -- in fact, more than I could conceive -- but that love lay at the center of them all. Evil was present in all the other universes as well, but only in the tiniest trace amounts. Evil was necessary because without it free will was impossible, and without free will there could be no growth -- no forward movement, no chance for us to become what God longed for us to be. Horrible and all-powerful as evil sometimes seemed to be in a world like ours, in the larger picture love was overwhelmingly dominant, and it would ultimately be triumphant.This passage struck an important cord with me, as I have long believed our universe was created by the Creator as just one of an infinite number of other universes, each with variations on life and the laws of physics. (Click here to read my writings on the Higgs Boson particle, consciousness and the multiverse.) What Dr. Alexander's quote confirms is that our life on planet Earth is a "test" of personal growth, and that the way to make progress in this test is to overcome evil while spreading love and compassion.Even more, this passage also confirms the existence of free will and even helps answer the question I'm often asking myself: "Why are we placed here in a world of such evil and surrounded by ignorance, darkness and deception?" The answer appears to be that Earth is a testing ground for souls that have been selected by the Creator for the ultimate test of good versus evil.Earth as a testing groundAlthough "Proof of Heaven" doesn't go as far as I'm explaining here, my working theory is that our planet Earth is among the highest evil-infested realms in the grand multiverse. Only the most courageous souls agree to come to Earth by being born into human bodies and stripped of their memories.From there, the challenge of life is multi-faceted:1) Figure out WHO you are and WHY you are here.2) Learn to recognize and overcome EVIL (tyranny, slavery, oppression, Big Government, etc.).3) Learn to spread love, compassion, healing and knowledge.Upon our death, we are judged by a higher power, and that judgment takes into account our performance in these areas. Did we achieve a measure of self-awareness? Did we work to overcome evil? Did we express love and compassion and help uplift others with knowledge and awareness?As you've probably already figured out, the vast majority of humans fail these tests. They die as bitter, selfish, substance-addicted, greed-driven minions of evil who mistakenly thought they were winning the game of life while, in reality, they were losing the far more important test of the Creator.The most important part about living a human life is not acquiring money, or fame, or power over others but rather achieving a high "score" in this simulation known as "life" by resisting evil, spreading love and expanding awareness of that which is true.For those who respect life, who practice humility and self awareness, who seek to spread knowledge and wisdom while resisting tyranny, oppression, ignorance and evil, their souls will, I believe, be selected for special tasks in the greater multiverse. That's the "real" existence. This Earthly life is only a dream-like simulation where your soul interfaces with the crude biology of our planet for a very short time span that's actually the blink of an eye in the larger picture.In reality, you are much more than your body. In fact, your soul is infinitely more aware, intelligent and creative than what can be experienced or expressed through the brain of a human. Trying to experience the full reality of what you are through the limited physical brain matter of a human being is a lot like trying to teach an insect to compose music like Mozart.The multiverse is teeming with intelligent life, including multidimensional beingsDr. Alexander's journey also confirms the existence of intelligent life far beyond Earth. As he explains in Proof of Heaven:I saw the abundance of life throughout the countless universes, including some whose intelligence was advanced far beyond that of humanity. I saw that there are countless higher dimensions, but that the only way to know these dimensions is to enter and experience them directly. They cannot be known, or understood, from lower dimensional space. From those higher worlds one could access any time or place in our world.This not only confirms the existence of other intelligent civilizations throughout our known universe, but more importantly the existence of multidimensional beings who can come and go from our realm as they please.Throughout the cultures of the world, there are countless accounts of advanced beings visiting Earth, transferring technology to ancient Earth civilizations, and possibly even interbreeding with early humans. Even the very basis of Christianity begins with the idea that an omnipresent multidimensional being (God) can intervene at will, and can therefore transcend time and space.Alternative researchers like David Icke also talk about multidimensional beings visiting Earth and infecting the planet with great evil. According to Icke, the globalist controllers of our planet are literally reptilian shape-shifters who have invaded our world for the purpose of controlling and enslaving humanity. Although nothing like this is covered in Dr. Alexander's book, it is not inconsistent with what Dr. Alexander was told by God during his coma... Namely, that there are multidimensional realities, that certain high-vibration beings can traverse those realities at will, and that Earth is infested with a great evil with the specific purpose of testing our character.If all this sounds a little too spooky for you, consider the words of the Bible itself: An upright talking reptilian snake spoke in audible words to Adam and Even in the Garden of Eden, did it not?The science skeptics are wrong (again)Regardless of what you might think about multidimensional beings, intelligent life beyond Earth, and the existence of great evil on our planet, there's one aspect of all this that's crystal clear: The science skeptics are dead wrong.Science "skeptics" are actually misnamed. They aren't skeptical at all. They simply follow their own religion with its own sacred beliefs that cannot be questioned... ever! Those beliefs include the utter worship of the materialistic view of the universe. Simultaneously, so-called "skeptics" do not believe they are conscious beings themselves because they believe consciousness is merely an "artifact" of biochemical brain function.There is no afterlife, they insist. There is no mind-body medicine, the placebo effect is useless, and there's no such thing as premonition, remote viewing or psychic phenomena. Oh yes, and they also insist that injecting yourself with mercury, MSG and formaldehyde via vaccines is actually good for you, that fluoride chemicals are good for the public health and that we should all eat more GMOs, pesticides and synthetic chemicals.It's no surprise these religious cult members of the "scientism" cult don't believe in an afterlife. That's what allows them to commit genocidal crimes against the human race today via GMOs, experimental medicine, toxic vaccines and other deadly pursuits. In their view, humans have no souls so killing them is of no consequence.As Dr. Alexander says,Certain members of the scientific community, who are pledged to the materialistic worldview, have insisted again and again that science and spirituality cannot coexist. They are mistaken.Well of course they are. The "science skeptics" are dead wrong about almost everything they claim to advocate. But their biggest mistake of all is in denying the existence of their own souls. Needless to say, they are all going to fail the human experience simulation once they pass on and face judgment. My, what a surprise that will be for those sad souls when they day arrives...I would hate to face God one day after having lived a life of a science skeptic, and then have God ask the question: "You doubted ME?" How could anyone take a look at the world around them and not see the signs of an intelligent Creator? Even the very laws of physics have been tweaked and fine-tuned in precisely the right balance so that our universe itself can support the formation of stars, and planets, and carbon-based life forms. This is called the "Goldilocks Enigma," and there's a wonderful book by that same name written by Paul Davies.No biochemical explanation for Dr. Alexander's experienceFor those skeptics who may be reading this, Dr. Alexander goes through nine possible biochemical hypotheses for his experiences and then meticulously and scientifically dismisses them all one by one. The result? His experience was REAL. In fact, it was "more real" than life as a human being.Remember, Dr. Alexander is a neurosurgeon. This guy knows the physical brain like no one else. The nine medical explanations he considers and dismisses as possible causes for his experience are:1) Primitive brainstem program.2) Distorted recall of memories from the limbic system.3) Endogenous glutamate blockade with excitotoxicity.4) DMT dump.5) Isolated preservation of cortical regions of the brain.6) Loss of inhibitory neurons leading to highly levels of activity among excitatory neuronal networks to generate an apparent "ultra-reality."7) Activation of thalamus, basal ganglia and brainstorm to create a hyper-reality experience.8) Reboot phenomenon.9) Unusual memory generation through archaic visual pathways.Dr. Alexander may be the most credible afterlife witness in the history of humanityDr. Alexander's experience (and subsequent book) is arguably the best-documented case of the afterlife that exists in western science today. The fact that a vivid, hyper-real afterlife was experienced by a science skeptic materialistic brain surgeon who didn't believe in the afterlife -- and who subsequently found the courage to document his experiences and publish them in a book -- adds irrefutable credibility to the experience.This was not some kook seeking fame on a TV show. In fact, his writing this book earned him endless ridicule from his former "scientific" colleagues. There was every reason to NOT write this book. Only by the grace of God was Dr. Alexander healed of his e.coli infection, restored to normal brain function, and granted the VISION of the afterlife so that he could return to this realm and attempt to put it into words.Personally, I believe Dr. Alexander, and his experience mirrors that of countless others, across every culture, who have reported similar NDEs (Near Death Experiences). There is life after life, and the shift in consciousness of Earthlings that is required to take our species to a higher level of understanding begins, I believe, with embracing the truth of the immortality of our own souls (and the existence of a grand Creator).What does it all mean?Dr. Alexander's spiritual journey gives us a wealth of information that can help provide meaning and purpose in our daily lives.For starters, it means that all our actions are recorded in the cosmos and that there are no secrets in the larger scope of things. You cannot secretly screw somebody over here on Earth and think it won't be recorded on your soul forever. It also means that all our actions will be accounted for in the afterlife. If this message sounds familiar, that's because an identical idea is the pillar of every major world religion, including Christianity.It also means there are people living today on this planet whose souls will literally burn in eternal Hell. There are others whose souls, like Dr. Alexander, will be lifted into Heaven and shown a greater reality. What we choose to do with our lives each and every day determines which path our souls will take after the passing of our physical bodies.What matters, then, is not whether you actually succeed in defeating evil here on Earth, but rather the nature of your character that emerges from all the challenges and tribulations you face. This is all a test, get it? That's why life seems to suck sometimes. It's not a panacea; it's a testing ground for the most courageous souls of all -- those who wish to enter the realm of great evil and hope they can rise above it before the end of their human lifespan." - Mike AdamsSee all of my reviews. I (Darrell Stoddard) write only about books, events, or motion pictures of enduring significance that have changed the course of history or unforgettable books or motion pictures that will totally change peoples lives.Darrell Stoddard, Founder - Pain Research Institute and saveusa.biz
Excellent read, orbiting, if you like suspense this is the book for you!  The eye opening twist at the end fantastic.

summary: Not a guide book - really. Read it anyway.
reviewText: It's a shame how many people seem to have bought this looking for a travel guide and missed the whole point.  This is the book that got me to read the read of Bryson's catologue and I've enjoyed them all. (OK, I only occasionally read parts of a Brief History of Everything) This is one of those books that tells you the truth even though you know he maikg up a good bit of the stuff included.  Bryson and Katz set off on an ill-advised assault of the AT and learn more about themselves in the process.  I've always had a hankering to hike the AT and may never make it, but part of me feels like I've at least been to parts of it because of this book.  There are AT people out there who scoff at this book just as there are marathoners who look down on those take more than 5 hours to finish.  This book is about the road not travelled all the way, but at least attempted and shared.

summary: thank you for writing this book
reviewText: Along with Emmanuels book, this book is a reminder that there is more than meets the eye in taking this journey on the Earth. I for one need this reminder and am grateful when I find it. Irrefutable evidence of the existance of the soul and its purpose. Thank you for writing.

Since the book was written by a Neurologist, it give extra credibility to the near death experiences of the author.  The book does a good job of integrating the scientific method of deduction with the metaphysical method.

My hat is off to Jack.  It was a tough job, but he managed to save countless of our boys, and the story was wonderfully written.I could not put this one down and went another sleepless night reading it.It was a tough job, and Jack did it well.  I rank him with Carlos and others as doing a job that needed to be done.Another fine Marine.

This was my first introduction to Bill Bryson's writing. Afterwards I bought everything else he wrote, but this is my favorite. Though I enjoyed ALL the book jackets. Really fun. Whoever designs his book covers has a great sense of humor.All of Bill Bryson's writing is funny, but this is his best. I think his traveling companion, the crazy Katz, made the book. He played the Gracie Allen role to Bryson's George Burns style of dry commentary.This book is hilarious. Even though I read the book the day my house sold to pay off a landfill-sized pile of debt I laughed until my stomach ached from gasping for air. Bill Bryson could make me laugh out loud even as I sat reading on a bare hardwood floor in an empty room as movers hauled away my life, piece by piece. (The movers thought I was nuts.) What a talent, what a gift--to be able to make someone laugh during a personal disaster.  I love this book, especially the sarcasm.

reviewerName: Robin G. Soletzky "addiction to L.J. Smith"
reviewText: I am loving this book. Whether you believe in Heaven or the afterlife, I think Mr. Alexander takes you on a beautiful journey.

summary: Love Anchor Island and all the people on it!!!
reviewText: I was able to get this book early with my prime membership which was exciting since I read the other two Anchor Island novels and had been waiting for a new one. I absolutely love the series. Terri Osburn is a wonderful writer and storyteller!! If you haven't read her you need to do so right now! The characters seem so real and after reading you will want to visit a place like Anchor Island! I love the humor mixed with the steamy romance in her books. This books tells the story of Will who we met in the previous novels of this series. This one has an added mysterious element as you unfold Will's story along with the romance and humor. I highly recommend it!
So glad I believe in Heaven.  Just need to know: is there chocolate there? Wonderful first person description of a near death experience.
Christina Dodd has written a delightfully clever and charming novel.  It was a light, humorous reading experience.  In the world in which we live we need more laughs.  I highly recommend this book.
I loved this book. It was very eye-opening and entertaining. The entire book was very interesting, not a boring page in it at all.

I don't need to add to the vast number of reviews of this book.  I just want to say how much I enjoyed the scientific side of this.  If a successful neurosurgeon is prepared to put his career on the line by writing a book of this sort, there has to be something we need to know in the subject. I found it reassuring.

This puts a wonderful light on our purpose here and what we can have on the other side making our inevitable death a blessing reading the poem at the end makes it all fit along with his account of his journey there and back.  I will definitely recommend this book and it has changed how I look at the world and the energy I project

Written by a scientist, who was somewhat skeptical, but has become a believer due to his personal experience.  Well written, in a logical, the way it happened, format.  Hard to argue with his conclusions.  An important book, and a strong Near Death Experience report.  Highly recommended for people pursuing the truth about what happens when your body dies.

Completed reading this book, and have ordered another copy.  I've experienced a number of NDE's, and finding the words to describe is nearly impossible.  Analyzing the experience, as the author has done, is really the only way to approach the life changing event.

convincing, scientific yet anecdotal. Helped me be less fearful of death and death has been a lifelong phobia of mine.  I have read some quantum physics that align with some spiritual concepts and Dr. Eben supports this marriage of the two.  I like his humanity and sincerity as well as the scientific base from where he writes.
I have no trouble believing this amazing, wonderful story.  And it helps me tremendously to live successfully in this challenging and limited world.

summary: Suggest the Kindle Version for non-Medical Folk
reviewText: I read the Kindle version....AND I'd advise this version (explained at end of review)It is interesting to hear adults and children have similar coma experiences. And maybe that's the point....we're all children when it comes to the Creator. It is also interesting as he was going through the exhausting process of re-entering the conscious world (I did it as a child, and it is exhausting), he had a strong sense that there was a little person for whom he was still responsible: his devastated 10 year old son. It is not the first time that Love has proven powerful enough to wake the dead. Helps me understand God's willingness to redeem...that while we are yet a long way off, God sees us and looks upon us with compassion.Alexander is clear that there will be naysayers and those who will disparage his experience...and I am glad he realized that up front...the reviews already show that; however, he has crafted a beautiful experience for all, and a carrot to entice the medical community to rethink their explanations of NDE's. Another doctor, writing almost 2,000 years ago recorded, "Even if one rises from the dead [to detail the afterlife], they will not believe him." Oh well. It did not bother Dr Luke to tell the truth, so I hope it won't bother Dr Eben.If there is any criticism, it would be that the clinical descriptions are a little medical-terminology-heavy. I still had to look up a few terms, despite medical training. My suggestion (unless you're a medical professional) is to buy the Kindle version so that you can instantly look up the jargon by simply pressing the word. But even if you don't have a Kindle or IPad, you'll "get" what is most important: Love.

summary: I once was blind but now I see
reviewText: I purchased both the Audio CD's and Book about a month after my husband passed away from battling heart disease for over 30 years. I wanted the family to be introduced to a more substantial look at the near death experience and since Eben Alexander was a neurosurgeon, from a scientist's background, I found that his views might be the best of the best.In 1974, I myself had a near death experience which was very powerful and very spiritual, which I have detailed in my personal website.[...]Like Eben Alexander, following my own NDE, I started reading everything I could find on this very mystical experience.  In 1975 our family purchased an already existing Christian Book Shop which was in the Catholic tradition.  Our clientele was very progressive and I was introduced to many authors and was able to search out and get more comfortable with my own experiences.  I will give you a listing at the end of my review.Dr. Alexander early in his book gives us the most important message of his experience.  That we are all loved unconditionally.  This is very hard for him to put into words and also very hard for most of us to accept.  Not many of us have had the opportunity to experience this overwhelming love that seeps deeply into one's soul.  This is why it is almost impossible to put into words, it loses it's potency.  Thomas Aquinas on his death bed experienced the beatific vision (God/Om).  He told his contemporaries that all that he had written before this vision was all straw. (Summa Theologiae).Dr. Alexander, being a scientist and trying to meld the spiritual in his life was very difficult for him before he experienced his NDE.  After his NDE, trying to explain this to his colleagues.His son Eben IV, suggested that he not read any books until he wrote his own observations.  This was very wise advice.  One does not want to mix other people's, thoughts, beliefs,  experiences with his/hers.  I myself, did the same.But reading we must because this confirms and explains the phenomenon of the experience(s).  From Buddha to Jesus to our contemporaries, we find meaning and the reason for our being,Other books for your consideration:The Other Side of Silence: A Guide to Christian Meditationby Morton KelseyThe Way of the Explorer: An Apollo Astronaut's Journey Through the Material and Mystical Worlds, Revised Editionby Edgar D. MitchellReaching Out: The Three Movements of the Spiritual Lifeby Henri J. M. Seraphim RoseSWEDENBORG'S JOURNAL OF DREAMS: THE EXTRAORDINARY RECORD OF THE TRANSFORMATION OF A SCIENTIST INTO A SEER by Emmanuel SwedenborgWe Don't Die: George Anderson's Conversations with the Other Side by Joel MartinA Parenthesis in Eternity: Living the Mystical Life Joel S GoldsmithWitness from Beyond: New cosmic concepts on death and survival received from the late A.
