(Pere Marquette Theology Lecture) by Jorgman Moltman

Home To Stay is a Heartwarming touching story. Love, and Lasting Friendships, True Home.Maybe Willow Parsons was running away from her past that's until she came to Anchor Island. She may not know too many people but she makes friends and is welcomed. Then Randy tells her that people from a magazine are doing a feature article about Anchor Island and all the business's..she is a little nervous about that, because it could dredge up her past,.She never let's on why. When these people come onto the island, and start shaking things up making Willow nervous. It especially get's interesting when they walk into Dempsey's Bar and Grill. When the reporter says she looks familiar that sets Willow into panic mode..That's were she is working now as the bartender helping the Dempsey's out. She acts calm and does what she has to do.Randy Navarro is the owner of the fitness club and a great guy, but he's confused that Willow Parsons keeps him at a great arms length and only him. He plans on finding out why that is. After she tells him why he gets a better understanding.Will and Randy start becoming friends which becomes more then friendship. It's hard for Willow but she takes a leap of faith. The attraction between them is there for awhile but it's just recently it's somewhat becomes more,When something happens and she's backed into a corner she runs. She's terrified. What sets are off is a phone call? What was the call all about?If you have not read the Anchor Series you should. It's a great series..A town who takes care of it's own. Will go to great lengths to do so.One of my favorite lines..."My best todays will always be the the ones I spent with you."

If curiosity about what exists after death haunts or piques the imagination, Dr Alexander's personal journey into the afterlife may well answer some questions if not present a worthy challenge to accepted beliefs.  Whether one is religious or not, the experience of neurosurgeon Eben Alexander, demonstrates there are some definitions of brain-death that are not clear cut.Dr. Alexander tries to define the gateways of death in scientific terms and he is convinced his experience took him to another sphere, a reality that did not match the customary description of a christian heaven but certainly had the all consuming sense of peace and acceptance that many religions grant exists in an afterlife.It goes without saying that his survival of this near death experience changed his life.  Dr Alexander doesn't claim to have all the answers, however.  He concedes there are many people who have different experiences.  His personal journey is offered as another glimpse through the fog that surrounds the question where do we go when we die?Whether or not the reader agrees with all of Dr Alexander's conclusions is not important.  That this story was shared gives opportunity for deeper consideration that each of us can give the concepts.

In today's world of electronic interconnectedness, it's amazing how some ideas seem to go `Viral' and others don't. I kept hearing about this book from several avenues.  It was as if the Universe were saying, pay close attention, just as it did years ago when I kept hearing `A Course in Miracles-Original Edition' mentioned over and over or last year when I learned ofDying To Be Me: My Journey from Cancer, to Near Death, to True Healing. It appears that this is another one of those `wake up calls' from [y/our] BEING.  And so it is!The most significant facets of this Near Death Experience [NDE] are:*  The person who experienced it was a skeptical neurosurgeon scientist.*  The CORTEX of his brain was not functioning yet he experienced crystal clear clarity.*  He had a complete and total recovery from E. coli meningitis, which is a medical miracle.We may have seen television shows regarding NDE's which often begin with phenomenal claims of other worldly experiences and end with a scientific de-bunking using medical science of the brain to prove it was `all in their head.' The evidence the scientists present is offered in an effort to show that there IS no `scientific proof' that these experiences were anywhere but in the physical brain. This is exactly how Eben [Dr. Alexander] thought until his own first-hand experience of an NDE.Dr. Alexander writes: "The more I read of the "scientific" explanations of what NDE's are, the more I was shocked by their transparent flimsiness. And yet I also knew with chagrin that they were exactly the ones that the old "me" would have pointed to vaguely if someone had asked me to "explain" what an NDE is."You may have see Dr. Alexander on Oprah, NBC, ABC, Fox, Cover of Newsweek etc. Why is he out there is such a big way? He answers that question himself:"Without recovering that memory of our larger connectedness, and of the unconditional love of our Creator, we will always feel lost here on earth." P.171Dr. Eben Alexander, husband, father, neurosurgeon  contracted the extremely rare condition of E. coli meningitis completely out of the blue. Only 1 in 10 Million people will do the same. He made a full recovery one month after lying in a coma, near death, for seven days. This book is his best attempt at trying to share an experience which was truly beyond words.As the book progresses, his story becomes an exquisite tapestry.  The experiences of his family and friends and doctors in the hospital, dealing with this grave E coli infection, are interwoven with a recounting of Eden's experience as a consciousness, with no connection to the past, in a `place' where words could never do it justice.Even though it kept the attention of the reader by the vacillating between the solid world that we know and the ephemeral albeit Real world that Eben was experiencing, it wasn't until toward the end of the book that I found myself grabbing for the tissues.There is a part of Eben's life that I have not mentioned and it has everything to do with the message he received and more importantly the Being who brought the message to him. Now I leave that mystery of WHO that was for you to discover, dear reader, although the message itself is for all to know and to remember."You are loved and cherished, dearly, forever.""You have nothing to fear.""There is nothing you can do wrong."~ Reja Janaki Joy GreenOmaha, NE

summary: Ho ho ho Ha ha ha!
reviewText: Simply put - what a delightful read! I laughed so hard at times I needed to go "potty".  What a great light-hearted book! This goes on my "keeper" pile for a future re-read for sure!

I bought this book after reading the prelude on my kindle because it was so intriguing having been written by a renowned neurosurgeon.  His story is fascinating and totally believable mainly because of his status in life.  After all someone in his profession who has had so much experience with life and death and who did not really believe in life after death until it happened to him.  His impressive background of science alone made me want to hear what he had to say.  The book gives us hope to believe in God and his promise of life everlasting more than any sermon I have ever heard in the religious sector. Once I started reading I could not put it down.

I love Bill Bryon's writing but this made me burst outloud laughing several times. I so enjoyed the balance of information (sounds dull, doesn't it?). I liked the conversations he shared, the thoughts (some very un-p.c., thank you!), and the information about the AT's formation. Oh yes, I agreed 100% with his thoughts on the environmental damage we've done and the horrific permission of murdering animals. I too had a close encounter with a moose while at Portage Glacier in Alaska and his account vividly refreshed that memory including the goose bumps and spiritual wonder of it all. Any murdering of animals should be outlawed rather than encouraged! Thank you, Bill, for an enjoyable weekend of reading. My son-in-law walked the full AT and I have so admired him for doing so, but I now hold him in awe for that incredible accomplishment.

summary: Another Great Book by Bill Bryson
reviewText: Bill Bryson is by far one of my favorite authors and he does not dissapoint with this book.  I absolutely love his honest and detailed account of hiking the A.T.  His hiking companion is an absolute riot!  I would definitely recomend this book to one and all.

summary: Didn't want this one to end...
reviewText: If you can't get out to do such an adventure yourself...it sure is fun to read about one, such as this!  Bill B. is one of the funniest, cleverest writers I can remember.His account of his traveling buddy is just so heartwarming...it all made for a wonderful summer read.The factual and historical backgrounds of the AMT were fascinating.  The philosophical wonderings of where we could do better for preserving our national treasures: important and compelling.Gotta read more of this sort of nature adventure...or get out into it myself!
I'm developing an interest in near death experiences, and I appreciate Dr. Alexander's candid testimony. Well written and edited. A blessing indeed!

summary: Best Bryson book I ever read
reviewText: I've always wanted to walk the AT.  Yeah, twiddly things like work and perhaps a bad knee (for the last part up in Maine) is a good reason I should refrain the whole distance thing.Bryson sets out at the south end of the thing with a semi-dysfunctional (physically-speaking) friend named Katz, and they get started.Humor can age, but even on a second reading of this book, I was right in on it.  I admit I like my humor interspersed with some aspects of reality -- you get the real impression that neither of these guys was truly prepared for the trip, and thus what happened was all the more real for it.  Bryson brings in serious moments, too, but in ways that do not remotely detract from the book.  It's not supposed to be a slap-happy humor book after all, but better for it not being so.If you are considering a seriously major hiking event, I'd recommend this for things NOT to do, as well as a good broad perspective.  Also, yes, for some good fulsome belly-laughs.(I've hiked about 20 miles of the Trail, total.)

Will.is holding a deadly secret near her heart, read as she also finds herself holding love near to her heart. It takes love for  Will to find herself. Love this small island and her occupants! Fantastic read! Found myself holding my breath as the reporter did her  sleuthing.

summary: First hand report from a neuro scientist MD
reviewText: Dr Alexander has written a wonderful book about his life/near death experience.I bought this when it first came out and have given several to grieving friends.It is a must read, has been on NYT top sellers for about a year

This book is an account of a neurosurgeon's near death experience. Dr. Eben Alexander, the author, survived a severe illness and this story tells his experience during the severity of his illness whilst he was unconscious, in a coma, in an intensive care unit. I declare that I am a nurse and I have experienced an out of body experience during a meditation session, albeit many years ago, and it has never happened since.This story was well written because it held my interest. I could not put it down, therefore it warranted 5 stars. However in his attempt to analyse or make sense of his experience from a scientific point of view, at times this book became a little too technical for me. Whether or not you believe that Dr. Alexander did reach heaven, is for the reader to judge and in my opinion irrelevant. This is an account of one man's experience during a severe illness, which almost ended in mortality, and this man for his reasons has felt a compulsion to tell his story.

Willow is a private person who has made wonderful friends on Anchor Island.  She enjoys her job and her friends love her for who she is.  Her hidden past is haunting but a secret .  She doesn't want to get involved with a romantic relationship.  But her friends have a different opinion.  Much is revealed and friends are forever.
This guy is a great writer and VERY funny.  I love him and this book made me laugh out loud.

reviewerName: John Eric Jacobsen, Author of The Jesus Lecture
reviewText: How many of us secretly hope and pray that there is something on the other-side?  This book is a wonderful book because it offers hope.  And hope is a very necessary commodity in this day & age.  I thought the research and information was very compelling, and to hear it from the point of view of a neurosurgeon helped me to enjoy it even more.  Most of all because the book was so well written, it helped me to remain open-minded and enthused thoughout!

summary: A new type of book for me
reviewText: Eben has captured my attention into the life beyond with his book.  The way he wrote it with so much clarity of the excursion into the beyond, I truly hated for the book to end.

summary: Mind, body and soul speaking in unison
reviewText: The author felt strongly enough about his message to the reader that even knowing the possible negative feedback from his contemporaries, the felt obligated to write it.  That speaks volumes for the accuracy he worked very hard to present.  This was truly in my mind his soul speaking to mine.

summary: Great book from a science based  view to prove the  existance of God
reviewText: Love the way this book was so easy to read. I finished it in one day because I just could not put it down.
Once again, Terri Osburn wrote another heartwarming, romantic novel! She described the characters so well, I felt they were real! This is a definite great read for all!

reviewerName: Lisa Harris-Markle "life as I know it"
reviewText: Cathy Lamb kept me entertained with her writing. Julia is my hero. And everyone should have an Aunt Lydia. Looking forward to reading more of her work.

People who have a difficult time believing in Christ and a life beyond this earthly one would benefit greatly by reading this book.  Even better, it is written from the experience of a neurosurgen who has devoted his life to continued and advanced studies of the brain.  Only someone like this could write this book.  And I'm glad he did!

Even though I need no convincing for myself of the existence of heaven I enjoyed reading this book from the experience of the medical professional. We are so dependent on the empirical method that reading of the mystical experience of a well trained medical doctor was refreshing. It all adds to my own dialogue!

I adored the first book. I loved the second book. This book blew the first two out of the water. Suspense, romance, mystery, this book had it all! I will be recommending this book to everyone I know :)
I ordered this book for my husband and he enjoyed it very much.  He learned about it from his brother who has also read the book and they hope to get together soon to discuss it.
This is a very comforting book for anyone who has lost someeone dear, whether one is a believer or notVery touching!
I saw the interview of Dr. Alexander with Oprah and decided I wanted to read it. It is an eye opener and a faith restorer. Loved it

First, let me say this: Melissa Foster is an AMAZING author. She really blew me away with this novel. I don't know how to explain it, but she has got phenomenally seasoned skills. I enjoyed this book from beginning to end, and read it in one night, I was THAT hooked. The characters, the plot, the wording....it all really wrapped itself around me and left me in awe.With a character by the name of Molly (ahem...cough*cough*....it's a VERY good name, if I might say so), you can't go wrong. Well, you COULD go wrong, but Melissa Foster did NOT go wrong. I loved the characters, the little lost girls were my favorite and my heart truly went out to them. And the plot line....well, if you engross yourself into the story the way I did, the story becomes reality. I found myself feeling as though I was Molly Tanner, seeing the visions and the emotions of trying to salvage my marriage. It was all quite an experience. Vanishings, mystery, drama, family, and secrets. The key elements that make up this INCREDIBLE novel!I highly, without doubt, recommend this to every reader. There is something in this novel that will hook everyone. With twists and turns that don't leave you hanging, and an ending that will leave you hungry for more Melissa Foster work, this 5 star book is worth the read! Great job, Melissa- you have a new fan in this reader!*This review is based on a complimentary copy which was provided for an honest review*
Really enjoyed this book But was disappointed to see it was part of a trilogy and that you don't have the other books, why is that ? I would really like to read the other two books.

summary: A Most Enjoyable Book, Backed by Great Research
reviewText: This book did not become a bestseller by accident.  It is one of the most enjoyable and well-researched books I could name.  You needn't give a rip about the Appalachian Trail to have fun reading A Walk in the Woods, but chances are you'll have grown an interest in this amazing recreational facility by the time you finish.Since I read A Walk in the Woods a few months ago, I've bought more Bill Bryson books.  His combination of subtle comedy, extremely thorough research and great writing talent is hard to beat.
This is a true story of a doctor who takes seriously ill and literally dies. His journey in to the afterlife makes for a great read!

summary: What you will and won't get & the problem with skeptical arguments.
reviewText: What you won't get:1.) A loving and detailed description of streets paved with gold and dancing angels.2.) Proof.What you *will* get:A narrative that is divided into two alternating parts: One part is what others are doing (mostly family members) while Alexander is in a coma. The other part is what Alexander is experiencing during the Coma. His description is undoubtedly thinner than what most would probably like but narrative description doesn't seem to be one of Alexander's gifts. We can't all be poets. Alexander dedicated his life to being a highly trained and accomplished neurologist, not a John Steinbeck. (What Alexander *does* spend considerable time describing is the emotional impact the experience was having on him.) More to the point: Once one reads enough NDEs, one realizes that NDEs are highly subjective experiences filled with symbolism and archetype. Was the butterfly Alexander rode during his NDE "real"? Yes and no. Yes, it was real in a subjective and symbolic sense. The butterfly was obviously a potent symbol and it doesn't take much insight to guess its meaning. Will the next person, during their NDE, ride or see a butterfly? No, but they may experience something "like" the butterfly, and something just as powerfully meaningful. Reading NDEs for what heaven "looks like" may be gratifying (like eating popcorn) but that's not what NDEs are about. The NDE landscape is different for each person because what matters isn't what's *seen*, but what's *meaningful*. To one person what's meaningful is an angel with wings. To another, that "angel" will be a child, on orb or a beautiful sphere of light. Judge Alexander's NDE not for what he did or didn't see, but for what he learned concerning life, our place in it, and Love. These are universal lessons common to nearly all NDEs. The only difference is in the symbolism used to express and communicate these ideas:"You are loved and cherished, dearly forever.""You have nothing to fear.""There is nothing you can do wrong."What is a tour of heaven going to add to these sentiments?*Proof*First thing to be said is that Alexander initially opposed the title of the book. The title was given by the publisher, Simon & Schuster."I didn't really consider this book to be scientific proof of anything," he said.Alexander's book, as he himself states, is written for the "second camp" of readers "who have heard about NDEs, either by reading about them or--because they're extraordinarily common--by having a friend or relative who had undergone one. These people in the middle were the ones my story could really help." It's not written to persuade the atheist or the devout skeptic. He's spent his life comforting and healing, and this book (in his view) is an extension of that. If you're looking for proof, you're not going to find it in this book at least (which makes the title unfortunate). Alexander intimates that he will write another book (or "paper" perhaps) intended for the more scientifically and skeptically oriented. With that in mind, and despite the claims of many critics (and reviewers here at Amazon) Alexander *does* address the issue of *when* his NDE may have occurred. He is inclined to eliminate the possibility that the entirety of the NDE occurred during the brief hours (or less) when his neocortex presumably began to recover. He writes:8. A "reboot phenomenon" -- a random dump of bizarre disjointed memories due to old memories in the damaged neocortex, which might occur on restarting the cortex into consciousness after a prolonged system-wide failure, as in my diffuse meningitis. Especially given the intricacies of my elaborate recollections, this seems most unlikely.So, this would be Alexander's response to critics like Sam Harris, Richard Carrier and numerous armchair atheists and self-styled philosophers. Here's one typical response by someone named PZ Myers://"Notice that key phrase: "words registered later". He was not writing this stuff down while he was in a brain-dead state; I would argue that he was also not experiencing them at that time. These were stories that he built later, as he was coming to grips with that past trauma, and they were a means of coping with a huge painful gap in his memory. We know that this is what our brains do; it fills gaps in our knowledge with imaginary events to maintain continuity, a process called confabulation."//This "dismissal by confabulation" is a current favorite among skeptics, and simply in terms of evidence there *is* none. Skeptics, when offering "confabulation", are indulging in a mechanism which actually has less to support it than non-local consciousness. There is no evidence that "confabulation" can create a lucid, meaningful narrative and experience on par with the NDE. It's a leap, an assumption that skeptics are willing to make, but there is (as of yet) *no* evidence to support that leap. If you read any skeptic who says otherwise, ask them to provide the evidence, the study, or the link to the paper that backs up their assertion. They can't. All they can point you to (which they somehow can't be bothered to defend) is research that does *not*, in fact, suggest the brain is capable of creating the lucid narrative of an NDE. Alexendar is also aware of this, being a neurosurgeon. If confabulation were remotely capable of producing an NDE I trust that Alexander would be the first to suggest it (and most likely accept it). More importantly, many, many NDEs occur when the brain is *not* recovering from the type of trauma that would induce confabulation. This also indicates that confabulation is not a reliable or likely explanation for NDEs. It is, however, sufficient for skeptics who, when a lack of evidence works in their favor, are hypocritically willing to accept that insufficiency.And this raises another issue. I have yet to read a response, from a skeptic, that was remotely convincing. All the skeptics I have read fall back on discredited explanations (explanations discredited by other skeptics, mind you), and offer no supporting evidence that backs up their assertions. This is skepticism turned Scientism. Skepticism requires knowledge concerning the subject being investigated; but all the dismissive skeptics I have read display little knowledge of the NDE. They end up expressing a priori opinions based on a reductionist or materialist belief system that is, at root, no different than any religious belief system.Another avenue which critics take is to ridicule the content or the message expressed in Alexander's NDE://"But of course not. He returns from his mind-expanding experience and does not sit down to write a revolutionary new paper on the science of the mind, but instead, as usual, writes a bunch of banal drivel about angels. This is the deep message that he shares with us that would have taken years to fully grasp..." ~ PZ Myers//Whether one thinks the NDE was banal is as red as the red herring can get. Who cares whether Myers thinks Alexander's NDE was banal? (I personally find Myers' article to be pompous and banal - especially when he can't come up with anything better than to write "bullshit"). The issue isn't whether the NDE was transcendent (how can one communicate such an experience - real or not?), but that it occurred at all. According to every current model of the brain, Alexander's brain shouldn't have been able to produce a lucid experience.Don't believe skeptics who write that there's no evidence to support non-local consciousness. That's complete rubbish. There is a mountain of evidence suggesting that consciousness is non-local. The only issue is in how one *interprets* that evidence. To date, skeptics have singularly and indisputably failed to provide a brain-based explanation for the NDE. This does not mean they won't. What it means is that any assertion that consciousness is purely the product of the brain is a statement of belief -- of a reductionist belief system. Period.For example, here's Victor Stenger://This is nothing more than the classic argument from ignorance," wrote physicist Victor Stenger, the author of the best-selling book "God: The Failed Hypothesis: How Science Shows that God Does Not Exist.""The flaw in the argument should be obvious. Just because someone -- or even all of science -- currently cannot provide a natural explanation for something, it does not follow that a natural explanation does not exist or will never be found," he wrote.//The fundamental flaw in Stenger's argument should be obvious. He thinks he knows what "natural" is. He believes (operative word being "believes") that what is natural entails a fairly circumscribed reductionist or materialist belief system. Here is Wikipedia://"Metaphysical naturalism is a philosophy which maintains that nature encompasses all that exists throughout space and time. Nature (the universe or cosmos) consists only of natural elements, that is, of spatiotemporal physical substance--mass-energy. For example, astronomer Carl Sagan, an agnostic, described the cosmos as "all that is or ever was or ever will be."[1] Non-physical or quasi-physical substance, such as information, ideas, values, logic, mathematics, intellect, and other emergent phenomena, either supervene upon the physical or can be reduced to a physical account. The supernatural does not exist, which is to say, only nature is real[2], i.e. Atheism."//Stenger, like Richard Carrier and other skeptics, is a Metaphysical Naturalist. Metaphysical Naturalism, it needs to be pointed out, *is a belief system*. Science does not support metaphysical naturalism (or Stenger or Harris or any of the other self-styled "skeptics"). Science is a methodology, not a belief system.The methodology of science is best expressed, not by the Metaphysical Naturalist, but by the *Methodological* Naturalist://"Methodological naturalism is concerned not with claims about what exists but with methods of learning what is nature. It is strictly the idea that all scientific endeavors--all hypotheses and events--are to be explained and tested by reference to natural causes and events. The genesis of nature, e.g., by an act of God, is not addressed. This second sense of naturalism seeks only to provide a framework within which to conduct the scientific study of the laws of nature. Methodological naturalism is a way of acquiring knowledge."//The methodological naturalist does not make proclamations concerning the nature of NDEs, consciousness, reality or God. *Science* properly recognizes that the jury is still out. Again, there is mounting evidence that allows for the interpretation that consciousness is non-local. If that offends the belief systems of individuals like Carrier, Myers, Harris or Stenger, then they'll just have to suck it up (just like their religious brethren, who still refuse to belief in evolution or a 4.6 billion year old earth). Nobody should treat their pronouncements any differently than the pronouncements made by adherents of any other threatened belief system.Parting thought: I hope Alexander follows up this book with something more scientifically minded. As far as skeptics go, this book is low hanging fruit. The real test for Alexander will be in confronting the belief systems of his colleagues. He has the knowledge to make the argument and I look forward to hearing it.At the close of the book, Alexander writes:"I know there will be people who will seek to invalidate my experience anyhow, and many who will discount it out of court, because of a refusal to believe that what I underwent could possibly be "scientific" -- could possibly be anything more than a crazy, feverish dream.... [But] here I am. I'm still a scientist, I'm still a doctor, and as such I have two essential duties: to honor the truth and to help heal. That means telling my story."One stylistic observation:What's with the incomplete sentences Mr. Alexander? They're not necessary and they *do* tend to confuse.

I found this book very honest and enlightening. As a Christian, there was nothing I found offensive or inconsistent with my faith. God reveals Himself in any way He chooses. Thank you, Dr. Alexander, for sharing your journey.
Well written, very interesting journey this neurosurgeon experienced. Would recommend for any one to read. I plan to read it again.

summary: RICK SHAQ GOLDSTEIN SAYS: "SUPERSTAR OF SNIPERS!"
reviewText: I would first, like to make a point about the title, that I picked for my review. Some people, might possibly find it offensive. But if you were watching a motion picture, or a TV program, that had Jack as one of the main characters, and his comrades referred to him in that exalted way, you would take it in stride. Imagine Jack, as the young sniper in "Saving Private Ryan". With that being said, let's continue with the review. I felt this was an excellent book, and one of the things that appealed to me, as a U.S. Veteran, is that Jack and his co-writers, wrote in the "language", that is truly spoken between men, not only in war, but in training for war. Another thing that I really liked, was the fact, that as bad as Jack wanted to be a sniper, he then had even higher goals. He had the desire, to not just be the best sniper, but he had the drive and vision, to try to improve the entire operating procedure of snipers. The battlefield, was not the same as in World War II. A couple of earlier Marine marksmen, Hathcock and Mawhinney, showed in Viet Nam, "that snipers could be much more aggressive and effective by getting out of their holes and going on the hunt." I know what Jack meant, when he describes the anguish, of not only keeping classified missions to yourself, but also, dealing with the uncontrollable memories of death you've created, that reverberate in your dreams, that you can't discuss with anyone, including your wife. Jack says: "If I awoke suddenly in the middle of the night, with a start so violent, that it shook the bed, Kim knew not to question why or what was going on in my head. She was careful not to startle me with a sudden touch." This passage, sent chills up and down my spine, since in my own life, twenty years after I was out of the service, I was a single father, who always wanted my young son to wake me, before he left for school, and give me a kiss. He got scared, at the way I would wake up, swinging and yelling, about things I never told anyone. We then used a procedure, where he would come into my bedroom, tap my shoulder, and then run to the doorway, and after I got back to normal, I would give him a hug and kiss goodbye. I would like to give one last comparison of Jack's stature, especially, for the benefit of people that weren't in the military. I was awarded the "Small Arms Expert Marksmanship Ribbon, (SAEMR) with an M-16. Comparing that, to what Jack did, is like you comparing your two-year-old son's, hitting a wiffle ball, off a plastic tee, to the accomplishments of Babe Ruth. There are three things I'm happy for, after reading this book: 1) That Jack was on our side. 2) That Jack got home alive. 3) That Jack and his cohorts wrote this book. God Bless America!P.S. The 2007 movie with the same name, has absolutely nothing to do with this book.

A Walk in the Woods is a wonderful book about two men's adventures on the Appalachian Trail. I found myself laughing out loud at their misadventures, and the best part of the story is that it's all true! I hated to come to the end.  Buy this book, it is great!

Was he internally hallucinating because his brain was 'floating in pus', or was his experience a miracle designed to show us that consciousness continues after death? You decide. Pretty incredible story, even if just from a medical perspective, and the author has the credentials to tell it.

This book was chosen as my book clubs January selection.  To say I was dubious, skeptical, and underwhelmed by this choice would be an understatement.  However, I decided to open it and at least I could say I 'tried' to read it.  Wow!  The first thing that struck me was the passion and honesty that translated through the words of Dr. Alexander... then when I saw he had practiced at Brigham & Women's Hospital, in Boston... I quickly contacted a trusted, longtime friend who also worked there at the same time.  I told her what I was  reading and that it sat open on my desk... she used 3 words... "I believe him".  That's all I needed... because it was exactly what I was thinking, too.  After chatting for a bit, I hung up and turned the page, I finished this book excited to share it with every one!  Thank-you, thank-you, thank-you!

reviewText: Proof of Heaven by Dr. Even Alexander.I liked this very much.It reconfirms a lot of what I already knew!
I really, really enjoyed this book, and actually read it again a month after getting it. Couldn't put it down.
Poor Katz.  This book was so much fun, I had to send it to my hiking-happy husband.  Every single situation and page in this book is beyond hilarious.

This is another great Anchor Island read... I am interested in how all of their lives move on; Beth's baby and becoming a parent, Sid and Lucas continuing on and now Will and Randy getting married. Great easy reads, entertaining

summary: Loved the book, even better on tape
reviewText: My flight had been delayed for hours and I was going to be in bad traffic and late for a meeting at the other end once I finally boarded.  I bought this book in the terminal and was soon laughing out loud, embarassed but helpless.  Months later I got the tape as a gift.  At first I was taken back by Bryson's whiny voice, but then it became perfect.  My wife and I drove around listening to this and laughing like idiots.  "What did she say about us? Come on, tell us."  I am laughing as I write this years later.  We will never forget Katz, his hiking partner.March 2010 update:  Still laughing.  Bryson's Best.

A friend told me that this book was a good read. I decided to try it, but did not know why. Well, from the beginning of the book, I have had such a feeling of peace. Normally, I read so quickly through book, but not this one. I have been savoring every single word of it so that I gain the true understanding of Dr. Alexander's words and feelings. I loved this book.
all six of us loved the book, can you imagine six women all liking something?  I would highly recommend, in fact I sent to a friend and her mother read it and really liked it too.

To have such an account from a very credible doctor, verifying what many believe to be, regarding those "near death" experiences is heart warming.  What I was taught as a child and have always believed the reasons I strive to live a good and moral life are not just theory or speculation.  This Doctors personal story certainly indicates that those scientist and doctors excuses for why people have these experiences are not just scientific theory but reality.
An amazing story well told.  Medical issues explained well and easy to understand in laymans language. Entirely believable. A very worthwhile read.

this is another wonderful true story verifying that their is a heaven and we are all goingthere eventually.  coming thru the mouth of a little boy that should have not known all thesedetails proves that it is true.  it trully is PROOF.

It's wonderful that it comes so quickly. I'm enjoying the book very much. We're very fortunate to have the ability to be able to purchase new, recently published books so easily and at such good prices.

I Read "A Walk In the Woods" with my non fiction book club.I thoroughly enjoyed the book and wanted to immediately go to Massachusetts, closest place to me, to see the trail first hand.  Bill Bryson has an engaging and entertaining style of writing that makes for quick reading.  I particularly liked the background information he interspersed within his narrative and the characters and adventures he encountered.  I had very little knowledge of the trail before reading this.This is not the type of book I would normally read on my own and I am glad the club selected it to read.

This book is an instant classic. For those of us who consider "roughing it" not having room service, Bryson and his hilarious pal Katz have balls, my friends. And they have blisters. And bears. And bravery. Bryson hikes like a trooper, writes like an angel, and can be so funny so suddenly that you find it hard to breathe you're laughing so hard.

I have been doing out-of-body experience for long time now and some of the thoughts or writings in this book has very similar aspects as when I am in the state of OBE. As it confirms more to me that these experiences that I am having are truly happening. This book does not only tell you about NDE but can help people who are trouble confirming OBE.Good book must read for all those who are interested in the afterlife.
This was a mind altering read. It did my soul good. It was well written and easy to follow. I enjoyed it very much. Thank you.
I've read several other NDE related books and can say that this is a very interesting and thought provoking story.

summary: One of My All Time Favorites
reviewText: I do not generally like historical fiction but I just loved this book (as did my husband). I had a hard time putting it down.
I thought Dr. Alexander really explained what many of us believe, that there is life after death on another plane, and that people have experienced dying and coming back to life as we know it.

summary: Proof of Heaven:  A neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife.
reviewText: I really enjoyed this book and have recommended it to quite a few people.  Dr. Eben tell his story in a way i really enjoyed.
Have read most Bryson books, and with few exceptions, love them all.  He's just got a rhythm that comes through every paragraph that makes the reading a genuinely positive experience.
It was great to read about someone who is a Neurosurgeon who believes!! Was an awesome account of what happened to him that even he can't explain except to say this life isn't the end!

summary: a refreshing take amongst all the other "heaven" type books.
reviewText: As a theologian I found the skepticism of the afterlife in the book good and necessary. After all, as Paul Tillich said, "Doubt and faith are not antithetical to one another but necessary to one another." This book will appeal to those who can embrace paradox, ambiguity, mystery and yes, doubt. I "devoured" the book in 2 days.

WELL WORTH YOUR TIME. YOU WILL SHARE THIS WITH MANY OTHERS. THE ONE PERSON THAT PROFESSIONALLY KNOWS HOW A BRAIN WORKS SHARES WHAT HAPPED TO HIM WHEN HE WAS "DEAD". IT'S INTERESDTING TO EXPERIENCE HIS SURPRISE TO THIS EXPERIENCE AND WHAT HE CONCLUDES HAPPENED.

Me being me, I started on this - the third book - before I read the others.  But, I loved it all the same.  Made me smile and laugh and cry.Was a great book and I plan on reading the first two straight away.

This is truly an awesome book, in the true sense of "awesome".Simply and elegantly written, it makes the most profound and strange experience of this man completely accessible and moving. This is a book to share with people you hold dear and one to read and re-read over and over. I'm grateful to Dr. Alexander for sharing his insight and to whatever forces brought the book into my life.
Convincing intimate sharing which gives any believer confirmation of hope and trust.Should read, and be lifted in spirit towards truth.

The authors scientific nature and thoroughness make this a great read. Sone people will hold beliefs above evidence, yet this book should make any open minded atheist reconsider the nature of our journey. It should provide comfort to many. For those who know, it is well written and an exciting read.

A book for everyone, male, female, young and old. Particularly a good book for those who enjoy the outdoors and like to hike. I found myself laughing out loud after I was irritated when my husband was reading it and laughing. I could not concentrate on the book I was reading. Totally get why he was laughing. Bryson has a humorous way of telling this true story with some very interesting true facts and some that are very scary. A must read!  I just heard they are making a movie and Robert Redford will be Bill Bryson. Cannot wait to see this film. I hope they do this book justice.
Outstanding!
Another excellent book written by Cathy Lamb! Loved the story and characters. Didn't want to put the book down or wanted to end. Would highly recommend reading this book.

This was a good story it plled you in to se what would happen next. You became part of the story. Its a good book to read on a cold night so you can curl up in the bed and go to another place in your head.
LOVE Dr. Alelxander!  This book is a must read for serious seekers of Truth...

I love all Bill's books, this was no different.  Living less than 20 miles from Centralia, PA which is mentioned in book, I can attest he gives very accurate info on the history of the mining town, as well as, a very vivid and detailed description of its current appearance.  This alone made me aware of the accuracy of his writing(s) on the places he visits and experiences.  The negative comments(reviews) towards his "hiking experience" confuse me, he does attest(to his credit) as being an expert on the subject of hiking must less walking, this is HIS EXPERIENCE as HE EXPERIENCED IT....great read, funny, real, light, entertaining...

summary: Psychic seeker's guilt helps in "Chasing Amanda"
reviewText: Without cracking open a page, I knew "Chasing Amanda" was going to be a great book.  I had recently read Melissa Foster's "Megan's Way" and was so wrapped up in her writing style, that I knew she wouldn't disappoint.  She didn't, in fact, I found it difficult to decide which book I loved more!"Chasing Amanda" is a book about regret, redemption, "gifts", the balancing of family and doing what's right, and so much more.  Melissa is a master storyteller who can lead us masterfully from the horrors of a child's abduction to the resolution of another's with the finesse of a writer whose work is far beyond her years.  She will have you drawn in like a lamb and have your emotions twisting inside of you before you know what's hit you!Characterization is key in this novel and it is achieved to such a fine point that each person is "living" and breathing in our minds.  My favorite, of course, is Molly who has to live with seeing and not helping with a child's abduction.  Molly's paranormal gift of "seeing and knowing" help her in her journey to understand many things, but it also makes some things in life more complex.  As we are drawn into the complexities, and we're given different perspectives through the stories of different people that Melissa sets up, we struggle to sort out who the real villain is!Ms Foster's ability to keep the ending a secret from the reader is a lot of the powerfulness of her novel.  The suspense will kill you!  In a good way...  One of the fascinating elements of the novel is Molly's relationship to the small town she finds herself in.  We can understand this small town mentality...the secretive ways that so many townspeople hold dear...and the barriers to newcomers they put up.  To live with the resistance of these people lends a tension to the story that works.Melissa is at the top of her game in writing this suspense thriller.  It's great fun to read, engrossing and exciting with many characters that will grab you and claim your attention.  The element of not knowing who the "bad guy" is until Molly finds out in the end, is wonderful because it keeps us working on the mystery.There are lots of women mystery/suspense writers, not so many with the element of paranormal...and not so many who come close to writing as well as Melissa Foster.  "Chasing Amanda" has already won several awards for best women's novel, suspense/thriller, paranormal. You better check it out, soon!5 stars for a great book and an author with a great future!Deborah/TheBookishDame

summary: wonderful!  one of the most awesome person experiences I have ever heard of.
reviewText: This is an amazing story of a journey into heart of our existence.  I could not put this book down and thank the author for sharing his journey with us.

summary: An extraordinary tale about the beauty of the female spirit! by Sherry Gorman, MD (former pen name Kate O'Reilley)
reviewText: "I left my wedding dress hanging on a tree somewhere in North Dakota."These are the captivating words Cathy Lamb selected to begin her wonderfully crafted novel, Julia's Chocolates.  The mental image of a pristine wedding dress hanging limply from a lonely tree in the middle of nowhere is nothing short of genius.  From that sentence on, I had to know what one has to do with the other.Julia Bennett is no stranger to abuse.  Growing up neglected by her mother and abused at the hands of her mother's train of boyfriends, Julia finds herself trapped in a repeat the cycle with her fiancée, Robert.  After years of enduring physical, sexual, and verbal insults at the hands of the man she is about to marry, Julia has a moment of clarity on the day of her wedding.  She reacts by fleeing to the sanctity of her beloved Aunt Lydia's farm in a small Oregon town.  On her way across the country, Julia stops in North Dakota and heaves her wedding gown over a roadside tree.At Aunt Lydia's eccentric farm, the story unfolds when five flawed women come together to offer one another love and support.  Each character is delightfully unique and colorful.  Julia, who is overweight, cursed with massive breasts, and afraid to love another man uses the creation of chocolate masterpieces as an escape.  Aunt Lydia grows her own marijuana, keeps the love of her life at arms length, and embraces the female spirit in a host of hilarious scenes.  Katie works herself ragged to support her children and her alcoholic husband.  At the same time, she does her best to shield her kids from their cruel and selfish father. Lara, a prim and proper closet alcoholic, grew up brainwashed and intimidated by the constant barrage of Christianity forcefully imposed upon her by her father.  She frees herself from her father's control only to marry the town pastor.  Attempting to be the perfect wife, Lara is slowly dying inside.  Caroline is the quirky town psychic with an uncontrollable twitchy eye.Through their weekly rendezvous referred to as "psychic nights" the women develop deep bonds with one another.  They also begin individual journeys of self-discovery and tackle the demons that have held them hostage for so much of their lives.Julia's Chocolates is a novel that addresses a host of serious issues: body image, sexual, physical and emotional abuse, alcoholism, homosexuality, domination through religion, and stalking.  Yet the real story is the beauty of the female spirit.  The characters aren't perfect, each of their lives messed up to varying degrees, and they all must sort through the issues that haunt them.  But they do it together.  With the support of one another, each woman emerges stronger as they venture down the road of self-discovery.  In a world where women seldom unite to display solidarity and pride in the female sex, this book is an inspiration.  Through the most unlikely cast of characters, Lamb shows the reader the power and resilience of the female spirit and the pure beauty of the bond of womanhood.After reading this novel, I am in awe of Cathy Lamb.  The woman has an incredible gift - the uncanny ability to bring the most bizarre characters and imagery together and create a masterpiece.  Lamb combines an eclectic mix of humor, tragedy, abuse, victimization, and outrageous scenarios to create a story that on the surface is pure entertainment, but woven into all of this is a much deeper message.Cathy Lamb has a style all her own, and her writing skills are superb.  Beyond that, it's the uninhibited craziness that she's not afraid to introduce into the story that makes me love her work.  It wasn't until after I completed the book and started looking into Cathy's blog that I learned that Julia's Chocolate was her debut novel.  If Julia's Chocolates was her starting point, I can only imagine where she has gone from there.  I am a true fan, and will continue to read her other books.  Thank you, Cathy, for being you and for allowing the rest of us to share in your feisty spirit.Julia's Chocolates, ★★★★★Disclaimer: I purchased Julia's Chocolates from Amazon.  I did not receive any compensation or endorsement for my review.  It is an honest, unbiased assessment of the author's work.

Bill Bryson captured my attention by making me laugh.  There were many moments in the first few chapters were I found myself laughing outloud while fellow train passengers or coffee shop customers strained their necks to see first who was making such a racket and then what, exactly, I was reading.  I was happy to oblige them by flashing the cover because I think pretty much anyone would enjoy this book.Bill Bryson is funny because he doesn't take himself too seriously.  He knows he doesn't know much about camping in general and the Appalachian Trail specifically.  He knows he's overweight and out of shape and his partner on this adventure is even more so.  Unfortunately, he initially doesn't know enough to take the trail too seriously either...he's mentally prepared for the extremes of bears and snakebite, but not the tedium of 16 hours of daily hiking with no stunning view to keep himself going. But, his awakening experiences lead to more humor as he and Katz quickly succumb to, but then triumph over the difficulty and repetition of life on the AT.  Their conversations are hilarious.  The bizarre people they meet are fully entertaining.  Simultaneously I wished I was along for the trip, but also glad I was comfortably seated without a sixty pound pack weighing me down.As the story of Bryson's adventures continue, he masterfully interweaves environmental and historical lessons about the trail itself and the many towns and regions he visits along the way.  As Bryson walks, we learn bits of American history that are fascinating, but have managed to be overlooked by many others. Bryson's observations are engaging and contagious.  At many points I found myself putting the book down and drifting off into  my own memories of hiking through the mountains on a crip autumn day or of shivering in a rainsoaked sleeping bag in a pile of mud.  His writing made me get outside, go for a walk at the woods, and just stare at the trees.  And then I actually went and bought a book on tree identification so I could learn even more!This book made me laugh, inspired me to reconnect with the outdoors, and gave me a whole lot of respect for those who attempt to hike the AT.
This book satisfied something I have been longing to read about. Well written and full of love , this book is worth reading.

summary: This book will change your life
reviewText: I saw an interview on Varney & Company (Fox Business) with the author, Dr. Alexander and it sounded interesting.  Read the book in one day and it will change your life.  I feel at peace and comforted, a must read.

I have always been a spiritually minded person, but I never considered how important it is to see consciousness and brain function as completely separate entities.  This book has opened my eyes to why I have always struggled to reconcile the two.  They can never be completely reconciled, as they 're different as night and day.  Thanks for telling. Your story.

This book covered a very intellectual analysis from the author based on his medically technical experiences and overall life  story as an impartial and thought provoking view of his coma and out-of-body journey into the spiritual realm.  His accounting gave so much "Food for Thought" on the body's consciousness, spirit and soul and how it functions. Many who have related their near-death experiences were met with skepticism by medical professionals, and scientist who rely on facts versus unexplained spiritual encounters with little evidence to substantiate their occurrences. Proof of Heaven puts the author's account of his out-of-body experiences and contacts on a spiritual level as much more credible.

Great read for anyone who believes in and also for who doesn't believes in after-life after death. Dr. Alexander is a neurosurgeon who strongly didn't believe in such thing until he was 7 days in a coma and had the most profound experience. It's a very good read and everybody should read it.

This book is so well written, and touched my heart so many times, and felt so true, I do not have enough words to tell you how much it moved me!I had the unabbriged audio version and it was amazing! Some books are better to be read, some to be listened to, and I reccomend you lisen to the authors narration. I truly belive in what the author is saying, and it made me feel more full of life, loved, and knowing that all is well.

summary: What a wnderful and comforting book  !!!
reviewText: This book tells of a journey taken by a man in a coma, and it is not the usual near death experience (NDE) we all have come to know of people seeing the bright light and all of their passed family there to greet them.  This journey is layered and fascinating to go on with the author.  I am amazed he was able to reconstruct his memories in such a lucid way, but I believe what he says here is true -- maybe not believable for everyone, but definitely for many.  A fabulous read.
This book answered a lot of old questions about death. I hope others who have that same type of question would read this amazing book.
It re-confirmed what I already believe - it was the greatest comfort since my son and his fiances passing a year ago.
This book arrived quite quickly. I enjoy the colors on the cover- they are very eye catching. It's a quick and easy read and I'm ready to find out more!!
This book was recommended to me and at first it was a little hard to get into, but then once I was able to get into it,, I fell in love with the characters and made me want to read he other books!

summary: Wonderful, Engrossing Book, Best I've Read in a Long Time!
reviewText: The book by Ru Freemen is a novel which takes place in Sri Lanka.  A young woman in the capital city of Colombo, is raised from a young child by a wealthy family.  The couple's own child is her age and she becomes a "friend" to the child until she grows up and it becomes apparent that she was to serve them without pay and without any prospects.  She attends school up to the 8th grade but the mother puts a stop to it and insists she stay a servant.  There is a second story, less intriguing and less well developed about a woman named Biso who was loved by a married man, had children and is now barely able to care for herself.  This story is very confusing and less interesting that you wonder why the author included it until the story converges near the end of the book.  Latha is a woman I found very interesting and loved her story.  She is the young girl raised to be a servant.  Jealous of her friend's marriage prospects, she seduces the girl's fiance with disastrous consequences for all concerned, even herself, though she doesn't fully understand what she has done.  I really enjoyed this book and was engrossed in my reading all the way through.  The author did not make this story a fairy tale and did not provide unrealistic situations.  All the situations ring true in Sri Lankan society.  Ru Freeman really wrote a wonderful novel and I look forward to reading more novels and books by her.

This is the third of a series for those new to Anchor Island and the stories are just getting stronger.--- A friend to all on the island but running from her past Willow finally loses the fight on her slide in to the best thing that has happened to her, a home with family and friends if she is willing to trust in them and herself.

Melissa Foster has truly done it again. Weaving the reader through the intricate dealings with relationships, but also bringing twists and turns to the plot to keep you from putting the book down! Foster does a fantastic job making the reader feel the emotions and urgency the characters feel. It is like you are along for the journey. Put simply....A MUST READ! Wonderful follow-up to Megan's Way! Absolutely cannot wait for her next book!

summary: Truly Proof of Heaven as good as Proof can get
reviewText: This book is a mind blower. I have read a number of NDA books but this doctor spent a "week" out of body and describes the experience from a scientific standpoint.

summary: I'm a fan of Jack Coughlin
reviewText: I have read several stories by Jack Coughlin and loved each one.  This gave me insight on the brave men who stormed thru Iraq.
It was very nice to see a different side to things than what you are used to. It's a great supplement to the novels.
Wonderful story, true story, difficult to put into words, I have been there.. A feel good book, read it soon! :)
I bought this book after seeing Dr. Alexander in an interview and found it fascinating. I recommend it to everyone.

This book took me by surprise! My mom passed it to me and said that I had to read it and she thought that I would absolutely love it. I wasn't so sure because I have strongly disliked almost every other book she has passed to me but I took it and started it that night. I read this book in 3 days and am absolutely in love with it and all of the characters! It has become my new favorite go to book! I have read it 7 times since and I always enjoy it every time! I hope you all enjoy this book as much as I do! (PS: I the only other books that I have ever re-read are the Harry Potters and The Great Gatsby ... That's how enjoyable reading this book is!)

summary: Scientific review of a NDE of a doctor, by a doctor
reviewText: Amazing on many levels. The author was the patient and is the neurosurgeon. He is board certified and eminently well qualified. This is a scientific approach to a NDE by a doctor who did not believe that they were possible. Skeptics read this. From the mouth a unbelieving doctor comes the report. A must read if you are looking for truth.

summary: A must read for medical professionals and an interesting read for others.
reviewText: This book is well written with just the right amount of science and personal emotions  to keep the reader interested.  I am very glad the author penned it.

Awesome book. Very well written. This is a no-nonsense account of one man's journey into the afterlife. The best part is that his story is not filtered through "religious" glasses because he was an agnostic when he journeyed. You will not be disappointed if you are searching to find the "truth".

SO amazing!  Very interesting.  Not sure if I believe 100% of what was written in here, but Dr. Alexander is very convincing either way and it definitely gives you hope for some sort of afterlife if you don't really believe in that sort of thing.  Read this!  You'll probably cry.

summary: Hysterical, laugh out loud, funniest book I ever read.
reviewText: This was hands-down the best humorous memoir I have ever read. After listening to my wife howl with laughter every night as she read this book, I was driven to read a page or two, then three, then a chapter...finally, she bought me a copy! I am not someone who is especially comfortable in the woods, and the scene in LL Bean where they attempt to purchase equipment for their upcoming adventure is comedic genius. If you have read any of Bryson's other efforts, you know what to expect.Interspersed with the misadventures of this unlikely duo, we are treated to interesting asides on the history and development of the Appalachian trail, and some of the historical figures prominent in it's history. This was the best beach/fireside read I have ever come across; give it a try when you need something that is light, fun, yet informative at the same time.If you like this, the athor also has a few others that are a hoot. TryNotes from a Small Island, andI'm a Stranger Here Myself: Notes on Returning to America After 20 Years Away

summary: An intricately woven tapestry of lies, love, hope and page-turning suspense.
reviewText: Author Melissa Foster is a rising star! Soon her name will be mentioned in the same breath as all the other talented and prolific women authors of our day. An inspiration, she has done it again. Chasing Amanda, her second novel, hooked me right from the start. I didn't want this book to end.The characters were more than just descriptions on a page. They jumped out and pulled me, willingly, hungrily, into their lives.  I resisted putting this book down, night after night. I not only wanted to find out what would happen next--I needed to. Thank you, Melissa, for inducing so many late nights and tired mornings in search of coffee! Starbucks thanks you as well.A parent's worst nightmare--the disappearance of their child--leads Molly Tanner into a spinning web of intricate secrets kept by the people in this otherwise quiet town. Having lived, thankfully very briefly, through the feelings one gets when told their child is missing, I was drawn into the emotional story of the people of this town--most especially, Molly Tanner. She must fight against her husband's resistance, the resistance of the townspeople to talk about the past and her own personal demons. I spent night after night fully engaged in this story, trying to figure out the complex interactions and connections.Her relationship with her husband and son were genuine and the emotions were raw and authentic. Chasing Amanda is frightening and heart-warming, sad and inspirational. I loved every minute of it. I am so thrilled to have found this author at the start of her burgeoning career. It is going to be a real pleasure watching her writing get better with each subsequent book.This was a well-written and suspenseful story that you won't regret reading--at any price!

This book shows a different look at the subject of life after death. This book is not the same stories that usually go along eith this subject. I would this book to anyone interested in the subject of this book.

This book is so very different from the previous books about visiting Heaven, yet everyone"s experience seems to be different and yet similar in some small aspects.  Coming from a physician, it gives more information about the physical issues and in the light of being away from his earthly body, it gives credence to the powerful and awesomeness of how God works in His wondrous ways.

summary: Great book on an interesting topic.
reviewText: I really enjoyed reading this book.  My dad had an afterlife experience and this went along with what he reported about it.  Well documented and written.

summary: Finally, a doctor, scientist, neurosurgeon gets it. We are more than a body.  A book that will expand your consciousness!
reviewText: This is truly a wonderful book. It is the story of certain death and then resurrection. Written by an MD neurosurgeon, it is his  personal experience with certain death, and then his physical and spiritual resurrection. His healing did not come through medical science but by a visit to the hereafter. Upon his return he came with an new insight into the meaning of life and how it should be lived and what science must eventually learn to be truly helpful. Well written both from a scientific and spiritual point of view, you will both be amazed and be inspired to see your life in a wholistic new way. Don't miss this real life drama and the inner knowledge it brings to the reader. It is a gripping story.
I enjoyed the story.  Sometimes it just seemed to drag because he had to keep explaining everything all the time.  I did like it !!
If you have ever considered hiking the AT this is a very entertaining book also filled with  historical tid bits and facts. I couldn't help laughing out loud during some portions, highly recommend!

reviewerName: D. Shank "everything you know is wrong"
reviewText: I am stunned at the number of people who want to believe so badly that they will ignore anything and everything to get and keep their toe in the door of this most absurd idea.I wonder how many have read the book?I wonder how many have bothered to even think hard and critically about the very idea?I wonder how many truly understand that an "eternity" of anything could be the best definition of hell ever conceived.I wonder how many understand that if there were such a thing as a heaven as most people want it to be - how it would ruin, better destroy, the enjoyment of the life we actually do get to have right here and right now.

More of a recount of an experience then a scientific analysis, Proof of Heaven is an engaging read that gave me a greater understanding of our existence.The book is an account of Dr. Eben Alexander's near death experience.  He contracts a severe form of E. Coli meningitis and quickly falls into a coma.  During the coma he experiences a journey to a place of peace. It starts as cloudy place, which he calls the worm's eye view.  He then journeys to a sunny pasture land where he meets a lovely women who becomes his guide.  Finally he finds himself in a place that he describes as being in the middle of God himself.  After seven days in coma, Dr. Eben miraculously wakes up from his coma and fully recovers.Even though this book is not empirical scientific proof of the existence of heaven, his neurological explanations of the impossibility of his experience gives me hope that there really is more to this existence that our short time here on earth.  I would recommend this to anybody with an openness to the possibility of an existence of life after death.  If you completely don't believe in an afterlife, this book will most likely not help.

summary: A Hilarious Series of Misadventures, History Lesson, and Buddy Tale All in One
reviewText: I'm rereading this one for maybe the twelfth time--absolutely classic. First book I remember that made me laugh out loud until I cried. Lewis and Clark meet Laurel and Hardy, by way of Mark Twain. Bryson is the best travel writer, period. Five stars.

There have been thousands of near death experiences recorded but this is the first one by a neurosurgeon and skeptic. A doctor who regularly surgically invades brains developed a bacterial infection of the lining of his own brain and "died" for seven days.  Virtually flat lining, he made a miraculous recovery to return with the story of his experiences while "dead". A wonderful hopeful experience.I remember hearing that Steve Jobs last words as he was dying were "Oh, Wow!" He must have been seeing the same view as Doctor Alexander.

This guy could read the NEWSPAPER and it would be funny - perfect timing, he's hilarious.  And here he's reading his own great material, for a delightful, side-splitting romp.  No one could do droll Bryson like Bryson (even his accent is funny).  My husband and I took this tape on a car trip, and were actually sorry to have the trip end - sat (after 6 hours of driving) in the car in our garage to hear the end of a particularly good bit.  We're not hikers, but after this account ... well ... let's just say we're tempted.
Great reading. Could not stop reading until I was finished. Have not read other books in this series but I will now. Look forward to reading the any others that follow this one too.

Before I started this review I read a few comments from folks who felt Mr. Bryson deserved much less than five stars.  My goodness, we humans are a diverse group of Homo sapiens. There was this one 1-star review from an anal person who surely read a different book than I. Actually, I felt sorry for him because if he lets this lightweight, humorous book get his briefs all tangled up in his...well...you know...then real life must be hell.  Anyway, I see I'm digressing here. Who cares if he walked the entire AT; it was the adventure and the excellent way in which he told his story--spinning interesting factoids, humor and honest yet not-so-flattering (but funny) observations--that made this book so wonderful. I loved it so much in fact it has inspired me to walk the AT too. I'm in training now.  Yesterday I walked to the mailbox and back.  AT, here I come.

After reading the first two books, I just had to read this one. Terri Osburn did an excellent job with this story. I really hated for the story to end. I definitely would recommend this series to everyone.

summary: Near Death Experiences comfort some people.
reviewerName: Fred W. Hallberg "A Retired Humanities Prof."
reviewText: A close acquaintance of mine is into New Age spirituality. This book on near death experiences is a gift for her. It is appropriate for anyone who relies on stories of soul-travel immortality to reconcile them to the unpleasant facts of death.

summary: An easy read and total soul journey.
reviewText: as a metaphysical-mystical life student it verified for me what I already know. it was a truth writing and totally believable. and it was simply and clearly written.

summary: It's a vast universe out there
reviewText: Very insightful.  Having had some experience with Hemi-sync I was pleased to see it mentioned by Dr. Alexander in his book.  There are some powerful tools out there at our disposal with which we can explore our spirituality if only we open our minds and hearts to them.  Mountain Quest in West VA is a wonderful place to visit to learn more about Hemi-sync.

This doctor's experience is easy and fascinating to read. Whether you believe or not, his story is really interesting and his arguments comforting. Thought provoking and quick read.  I hope it's all true!

summary: A must read if you have ever been near the Appalachian Trail
reviewText: Bryson's dry sense of humor makes you laugh out loud as he describes his adventure on the Appalachian Trail.  Although I have only walked about 100 yards on the trail, Bryson's description of his trek enable me to visualize it perfectly.  Reading about the trail is enough for me.
Wonderful read, enjoyed reading about the subject.  The doctor suffered a terrible ailment that brought him to the brink.  His faith is what we should all strive for.

I can't tell you the number of people that I have run into that have read this book and been enthralled by it. He takes information that's hard to visualize and does just that. He walks you through his experience and you feel as if you are either there, or as if you can clearly see it. A must read in my opinion.

Eben Alexander, M.D.: pristine medical and scientific credentials; experience in the top Boston hospitals, a sought-after neurosurgeon.  Suddenly he contracts E-coli bacterial meningitis and is comatose.  The disease is eating his brain and the prognosis is grim.  Eben is dying.Well, not quite.  Eben is very ill but his spirit is conscious and it has passed through a dull, flat space which offers a worm's eye view of experience (limbo cum purgatory?) and into the light, where he tastes the heavenly afterlife--not a place in the clouds but an all-encompassing spiritual plane in which understanding occurs instantaneously, love is omnipresent, there are guardian angels, figures floating in orbs, the Creator Himself and (thank you, Lord), dogs.The author examines all of the alternative, physiological explanations for his experience and realizes that they are all inadequate.  The scientist/sceptic by training becomes an intense believer.  The empiricist sees the experience for what it must be (assuming that there is no chemical delusion occurring here): the first stage of scientific proof.The author's heaven is so overwhelming that descriptions are, perforce, vague and inadequate.  The experience is not exactly ineffable or inexpressible, but it is so vast and so heightened that describing it is a struggle.  Fortunately, he writes well and we have a reasonably clear sense of the experience that he is laboring to describe.What is particularly interesting is the fact that his experience corresponds, in many ways, to what we have hoped to believe.  There are people there; there are angels there and there is contact with God there.  There are fields and skies, not so much an enclosed realistic, Edenic garden, but more like a beautifully-colored Rainbow-britelike space, a heightened, purified earthly landscape.Eben Alexander's heaven is one which particularly focuses on consciousness and understanding, spiritual learning at an unanticipated, nearly unimaginable level, a kind of infused knowledge.  Do we each have the kind of heaven that we would desire or is this the universal article?  The orbs suggest something out of Leibniz's Monadology and the author learns the reason for evil in the world: so that we might have authentic free will.  That's what Milton said, so perhaps he was right.Like the proofs for God's existence, near death experiences are more aids to piety than apodictic proofs, compelling belief.  Given the stakes, however, they certainly compel our attention and the author here is the perfect intermediary--the last person who would believe what he actually experienced, now with the faith of a convert.This is a lovely little book that all should read--believers, sceptics, searchers.  At the very least, the stakes involved put all of our daily travails in context and may serve to ameliorate them.Someone once said that it's not going to be heaven if there's no Ray Charles and others have said that hell is a place without Mozart.  There are sounds there as well, but mostly unconditional love and learning, people, angels, God . . . and dogs.

Dr. Alexander's experience confirmed what I long suspected about our consciousness and what is beyond this world and out there in the Universe.  I love that this happened to a man of science who wasn't afraid to tell the world about what happened to him.  The medical community can't brush it aside as easily as they do when your average person has a NDE.I also love that he doesn't have a religious agenda (he isn't trying to convert anyone).  A lot of other NDE accounts seem aimed at making you find religion OR ELSE.  I was only 1/3 of the book and was in tears.  What he experienced feels very right and very real and I am grateful he had the courage to write this book.  It is a MUST read!
Since most men and women of science don't believe much in the spiritial realm, this NDE might be a bit of an eye opener for them since this happened to a neuroscientist.

This book gave a renew hope for life and for accepting death.  I had a certain difficulties at times with the lack of flow, but I undertand that the author is not a writer by choice.  Very illustrative.  Peaceful.
I love Bryson's wry self-depricating humor, his perspecacious wit, and amazing ability to bring me into his experience. This is a great summer read.

Molly witnesses a child being abducted and doesn't realize until days later when the child's  face flashes across the tv.  Dead.  Murdered.  Her motherly guilt turns into torment and grows to the point of agonizing.  She almost loses her husband, her family and herself.A move seemed just the thing to help rebuild her families lives, and it does, but then another little girl goes missing.  Molly sees visions, has nightmares.  She can't let it happen again.  This time she refuses to sit back and watch.  She struggles to get her husband to believe in her.  But with or without him, she refuses to give up until she finds the little girl.But will she be too late?The twist at the end is sure to get you spinning!!An outstanding read by an author with a real flare for characterization.  Writing in the mind of a little girl isn't an easy thing to do, but Melissa Foster does it brilliantly, showing how easily a child could become reliant on an adult who stole her away.  Scary, believable and true.A wonderful summer read!!
My daughter got this for Christmas and I really liked it as well. We both read the book and recommended it to my youngest daughter .

This story is well worth reading, if like me you are interested in the Age old questions of life beyond the physical one we are living.,  So many report these experience or ones like this , the very convincing part comes this time by someone who is a very science minded dotor, it took a very severe experience to show him the that there could indeed be more to our Spiritual existance than many believe.
My first novel by this author, certainly not my last. I'm looking forward to more Anchor Island romance and fun.

summary: Compare this book with Scout's Honor
reviewText: This is actually a review of two books, one old and one new.  Both are nonfiction, and both are intended for grown-ups.  There's nothing in them that kids will find objectionable, but they may find them boring.  I found them to be funny, poignant at times, and thought-provoking.The first is called A Walk in the Woods, by Bill Bryson, published in 1997.  The second is called Scout's Honor, by Peter Applebome, published in 2003.  Bryson is a writer and journalist who decided to walk the Appalachian Trail at around age 50, and Walk is the story of his adventures on the AT.  Applebome is a writer and a journalist who decided to become a Boy Scout dad at around age 50, and Honor is the story of his adventures with his son's Boy Scout troop and with Scouting in general.I read Walk several years ago, and just discovered Honor last week.  Reading Honor reminded me of Walk, so much so that I couldn't review the former without talking about the latter.Bryson and a friend decided, almost on a lark, to hike the AT which they had heard so much about, but Bryson was so inexperienced a hiker that he couldn't tell a Nalgene from a North Face.  In fact, his introduction to backpacking and hiking occurred in a sporting goods store.  He and his friend started at the southern end of the AT, in Georgia, on a snowy autumn day, and ended, with a few breaks, at the northern end in Maine several years later.Bryson's writing is self-deprecating and intentionally funny.  He plays for laughs, and he gets them.  By poking fun at himself, he gives himself license to give all the other characters on the trail the same treatment he gives himself in his writing.  The book is funny throughout.
