But just as Mark Twain and Will Rogers gave us lots of food for thought in the middle of their humor, so Bryson writes a series of thoughtful essays between the lines of his funny stories:  lessons about people's character and behavior, about greed and status, about environmental awareness and social responsibility, and about what Thoreau called "the need for wilderness" or something like that.  (Yes, Thoreau talked about it before John Muir did.)When you finish Bryson's book, you will be as satisfied with the conclusion as he was with the end of the hike.  You may also come away with a renewed appreciation for wild places and with an awareness of the personality flaws that make you similar to the characters Bryson writes about.  It's definitely a book I would read again.Applebome, like Bryson, knew nothing about hiking, camping and backpacking, until he moved his family from Atlanta to Chappaqua, New York, and his son wanted to join the Boy Scouts.  He was reluctant to get into the hiking and the canoeing, the knot-tying and the sleeping outside on the hard ground surrounded by rain, snow, wind and critters.  He had hoped that his son would express an interest in Little League baseball instead, but, wishing to score some Good Dad points with his son, he went along with him to the Boy Scout meetings and outings.Even before he started, Applebome had anti-Boy-Scout leanings -- but as he became more involved with his son's troop, that changed.  Interweaved with the funny and poignant story of his own adventures with his son's troop, Applebome tells a balanced, thoughtful, well-researched and honest story about the history of Scouting and its founders, its awkward attempts to adapt to social change, and the recent controversies surrounding it.  The book isn't all narrative -- it includes a lot of reporting, exposition and editorializing -- but it's definitely worth reading.Applebome comes the end of his book grateful for having been able to share the experience with his son, the troop leaders, and the other Scouts and their dads.  He himself grows considerably through his experiences, and he faces a huge crisis of conscience when the Boy Scouts win the Supreme Court judgement in their favor with respect to gays in Scouting.  The crisis of conscience occurs because he feels that the corporate organization that is the Boy Scouts of America is dead wrong on at least one of the "three G" issues (gays, God, and girls) and not faithful to the wishes of Scouting's founders, and yet he sees that the local organizations of Scouting, the councils and troops, are a powerful force for good in their communities and are getting a raw deal by both BSA headquarters and the left-wing liberals who get all over Scouting's case because of the three Gs.Being a reporter and a problem-solver at heart, he takes a long, hard look at what Scouting could be (and should be), compares it to what it is, and makes several really good recommendations for fixing Scouting.  One of the most interesting things he says is that the Scout Oath and the Scout Law, the moral foundations for Scouting (in the U.S.A.), are rock-solid and it woud be a very good thing if all boys (and men!) lived by those tenets.  He also says (either himself, or quoting someone) that the Boy Scout Handbook, any edition, is just the kind of "advice to boys" that people have been longing to give to boys today.Unfortunately, Scouting is increasingly irrelevant in a society which competes so heavily (and so much more effectively) for boys' attention with sports, video games, and so on.  Applebome laments this turn of events, and yet he asserts, with his primary evidence being the members of his own son, that Scouting appeals to a certain group of boys who really don't care if other people think it's uncool, and that Scouting (practiced the way it should be) really is a Good Thing in the boys' lives and is a major influence in turning them into the kind of men this world needs.  (Those are my words, not his.  He said it differently.)Scout's Honor is written to and for three groups of people:  former Boy Scouts who are now adults; current and former Boy Scouts; and current and former Boy Scout leaders.  It's high-energy food for thought for all three groups.A Walk in the Woods is written for everyone, and will be especially enjoyed by those who love or hate hiking, backpacking, camping, wilderness and the fools they find there.  Although it contains more mental junk food than food for thought, it will open your mind and is definitely worth reading.

A Review by Anthony T. Riggio of "Proof of Heaven" (A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife)by Eben Alexander, MD, September 21, 2013My wife recommended this book that she purchased from Amazon and thought I would enjoy it.  I was skeptical about reading a book on this subject primarily because everything I heard about Near Death Experiences (NDE) have pointed to chemical or neurological events in the affected person's brain.  While I believe that there is an existence after death and a part of me agrees that "we are spiritual beings living a human existence", I still have some doubts because the evidence is not completely provable, i.e., as in a Court of Law.  Paradoxically, as a believer, I have faith that God loves me and will embrace me after I die but still in one little corner of my thinking, I harbor doubts that I hope God will forgive me for when I meet Him.I read this book with a very open mind and the credentials of the author are not one bit in doubt.  I believe he is a most rational person who had the same questions, before his experience, we all share.When I read some of the reviews on both Amazon and Goodreads, I was surprised how many negative ones there were, but out of almost 6,500  reviews almost 5,000 were positive, i.e., 4 stars or better and less than 1,500 were 3stars or less.  I am not sure what this spread of reviews points out but I do believe that every reader must make up his own mind based on his experiences.  I believe that this book presentation outlines, unabashedly, his firm belief. The authors medical arguments seem plausible and certainly by writing this book he leaves his self open to greater scrutiny from his peers in the medical profession.I do believe that anything we say or write is open for all to take their pot shots.  I have to say, I believe his writing style was very readable and enjoyable and I did not sense condescension from him one iota.  I did not sense a self loving narcissism as one critic did.  On the contrary, I found the author to be a very humble man who knew he was going to go out on a limb both professionally and socially.  His life's experiences, being adopted and then much later in life seeking answers, did not warp his sense of being.  I truly believe he was and is a dedicated scientist/physician and has undertaken a field of study in the medical profession that is not for the timid and yes if that requires a big ego, so be it.In reading this short, informative as well as entertaining book, I believe that he experienced something like a NDE, though not typical of other NDE reports, and I will not take issue either way.  After all, these were his experiences and he was willing to share it with all who will read his book; the reader believing it, was not his intent but rather that he believes it.  I do believe we will never have all the answers and that is the reason we have belief systems.  I can tell you, I do feel better about the unknown because I do believe in a "Loving" God.I highly recommend this book and give it, unhesitatingly, five stars.

The truth is that I never had known that there was this whole group of people who tried to thru-hike the entire trail in one year. It sounded immediately cool to me. Better yet, I never had hiked before. But when I read what these two cripples had at least attempted this forbidding journey, I thought, "Why not me?"Many, many other readers have had that same thought. The trail population actually increased significantly upon the book's publication. By my lights, the more people who get outside and into the wilderness, the better off we will be as a country. So thank you Bill Bryson and thank you Stephen Katz for being the amiable foil.Hiking the Appalachian Trail and writing my own narrative, Skywalker--Close Encounters on the Appalachian Trail, (modeled on Bryson's irreverent narrative, if not quite as dashing!), have been two of the highlights of my life.Skywalker

Chasing Amanda grabbed me from the beginning and never let go. Foster weaves an intricate tale around one woman's courage and perserverance even at the risk of losing everything she holds most dear. A gripping story of deceit,secrecy, horror, and finally triumph. I will definitely search out more of this author's work.

I really liked this book.  Granted it's a romance but that's okay, right?  Light reading, good new characters, good old characters, a mystery from the past now haunting the present.  I didn't pay much attention to the character of Willow in the previous books so it's wonderful that her character and her history are developed in this book.  And, of course, a happy ending is a bonus!
I have read many books on the subject of grief and with this book, although long, gave me hope for my son and friends who have gone to be with the LORD before me.  Beautiful imagery.
All Bill Bryson's books that I've read have been 5-star reads, and this is no exception.I laughed all the way through. I love his writing.

We all vacillate on the belief monitor in our lives from one to ten. At least I think that is for most of us. It's always based on our human life experiences. I listened to Dr. Alexander being interviewed by Dennis Prager on the radio. I had read the article he wrote in Newsweek. Because of his background as a neuro Surgeon at Harvard I had to figure a 2nd generation surgeon was dead solid serious in his perception of what happened to him in the 'brain dead' state of his coma. This was not a fundementalist layman who attributed God to making every discision in his life. Had he fell off a tractor while farming I doubt (no reflection on farmers) that his story would have reached Newsweek. As he said he doubted he would have believed a colleague with the same story.I don't know that he offers proof of heaven but he offers up the possibility of a heaven that I like to believe in. He tells you over and over that he doesn't have the vocabulary to even describe his experience but he does it in grand detail in my opinion. I had trouble putting in down. The book is written with a lot of medical reasons 'why' and why not these experiences could not just 'happen'.  I'm sure this will not give many skeptics a reason to do anymore that claim him crazy or at best delusional from the illness. For those of us that live with doubt and are open minded I think the book does offer you an explanation on why he now believes, even if it's just in the idea that belief is possible. Faith seems to be a gift that some have and some don't. Short of a personal experience, I get the idea that Dr. Alexander was not on the fast track to become a believer! Unfortunately most of us will not experience that type of conversion but it's a nice way to spend a few hours with someone who has had a life changing experience that we may never have. It filled in a few blanks for me.
Great story kept you guessing to the very end. I didn't want to put it down. It had a plot with a bit of everything.

This was  a really good book. It was very relatable due to the fact that I knew most of the men she spoke of. Before reading I never knew her story and labelled her as an industry whore. After reading I must say that I have a new respect for her

summary: Proof of Heaven is a Story One Wants to Believe
reviewText: One starts out hoping the author can describe his experience well enough to convince the reader of the reality of Heaven.  It would be nice for once and for all to be absolutely convinced that it is true.  The story is supported by medical terminology so convincingly by the neurosurgeon author that a non-medical person cannot disprove it.  One wants to believe but feels in the end that the story can neither completely prove nor disprove the afterlife.  In the end the story, though fascinating, raises a lot of questions one perhaps cannot have answered in this life.  Persons who have experienced near death experiences cannnot be denied their belief in the afterlife.  I just wish their conviction could be so clearly easily expressed that it would be acceptable to the rest of us.
No other word for it!  This intelligent medical doctor is completely swept off his laurels by the supernatural event that he experienced.

summary: Finally.  An NDE subject with scientific credibiliy.
reviewText: A brain surgeon collapses from a rare illness, goes into coma and is pronounced brain dead yet finds himself alive and completely congnizant on "the other side".  His journey to the next world and back reads better than the best fiction; I literally could not put it down.  I had seen Eben Alexander's story on the TV series "Beyond and Back" and was thrilled when I heard he'd written a book about it.  That book turned out to be well-written and detailed, laying to rest the medical establishment's denial about the reality of near-death as a true account of continuing consciousness and not a fake euphoria driven by excess serotonin.  Dr. Alexander brings back confirmation that love is the causal center and meaning of life and that consciousness is everlasting.  For those who need a biblical-sized miracle (as if this weren't enough) the account of his spontaneous, and eventually complete, recovery ought to satisfy the toughest skeptic.  An important book that anyone of any faith (or of no faith, for that matter) should read.
the author described what it means to be a shooter and a sniper. a marine sniper is one of the most formidable assets on a battlefield
If you have ever had doubts about the afterlife, this book will help you understand better.It's a great story and and easy read. It helps to put your mind at ease.
It's just an all around fascinating book written with such wit and wisdom.  I highly recommend it, and great price.

This bonus book comes betweenUnbelievable (Pretty Little Liars #4)andPretty Little Liars #5: Wickedand readers gain whole new insights into this quartet of Pretty Little Liars!The people the girls thought were A are dead; Ian Thomas, one suspect is in jail and perhaps the girls can go on to a routine life in Rosewood, PA if such a thing is even possible.Dramatis Personae:Aria, my favorite PLL. An attractive, blue-eyed brunette with athletic prowess, she is not happy about her dad being involved with a local art teacher named Meredith.  Meredith is pregnant and this is one major reason Aria does not want to spend the winter holidays with her dad, brother Mike, who is 2 years her junior and Meredith.  Instead of traditional winter holidays, Aria Montgomery's family celebrates Winter Solstice.  Aria and Mike spent 3 years in Iceland and while there, Aria acquires a yak-fur bag which becomes her security blanket.  I admit I was sick of that damn yak-fur bag which is featured in every book.  In this book, Aria surprises readers - there was NO WAY I saw THAT coming!Spencer is a grind.  She has an older sister named Melissa who has recently graduated from college and is viewed as the epitome of success.  Spencer sputters more than an old fuse and sooner or later you can count on her to keep on doing this.  The girls' mother decides what the family needs is a beach vacation and so they go to beach country where Spencer's volatile grandmother lives.  Fortunately the old bag is on her own trip, so the family can stay in her house free without her kid-unfriendly presence there to spoil things.  What DOES spoil things is the strife between the girls' parents; the way Spencer is treated like an unloved outcast by her own family and the cat fight she has over a tennis pro she meets.  There is a funny revenge scene which is just delightful!Emily, the swimmer who has been ostracized by others for being bisexual has been given a weird assignment.  Emily's mother gets her a job playing Santa in a local mall to infiltrate a clique of girls who are allegedly stealing Christmas decorations.  Her objective in getting Emily to do this - she wants the Baby Jesus that was stolen from her Nativity scene back.  The kicker is she wants to sell the Baby Jesus so as to buy more gifts for Emily, her 2 older sisters and brother.  This assignment puts Emily in a bad position, but the resolution is also delicious and quite unexpected!  As it turns out, it is Emily who has shown true holiday spirit!Hanna, who bears a strong resemblance to Cinderella is coping with her indifferent father and stepmother and beyotch of a stepsister, Kate, who is the same age as Hanna.  Hanna's mother took a job in Singapore and Hanna feels abandoned and Kate is always finding ways to get her into trouble.  Hanna's father appears to have replaced Hanna with Kate for a daughter and Kate has fangs and claws she will use at the drop of a hat.  You just want to kick Hanna's dad in the shins as he puts his own daughter down to Kate and sings Kate's praises to Hanna every chance possible.  Hanna's boyfriend is a nice guy (you'll have to read the book to know who it is in THIS installment).  However, she meets someone new who gets her involved in a worthwhile activity.  Hanna has an eating disorder and it resurfaces in this book.  However, with friendships shifting and changing, Hanna comes up with a very resourceful revenge scheme that is deliciously wicked!Each Liar has to deal with the havoc this mysterious A has wreaked.  The Liars try to think of ways to stay steps ahead of A.  Only Aria appears to take A in stride, despite her shocking secrets.  I admit that I never saw THAT one coming and it bowled me over!This book is a wonderful filler and is so refreshingly different in that there is nothing extraneous or predictable about it.  Readers learn a lot more about each Liar and gain new insights as to what makes these characters "tick." The book is divided into 4 parts, with each Liar being given 15 chapters for readers to learn her story.It's best if you've read all the books in the series before you get to this one (at the time of this review, "Ruthless #10" being the most current).  You see the shadows that loom large in the girls' legends and you will feel the same hair raising, skin-prickly sensation of their encounters with the person or persons they think is A.Be sure to read the dust jacket as well so you will be updated on the latest message from A.  I love the PLL series and Sara Shepherd is a genius.  I can't wait to read the one following "Ruthless!"Kind of makes you hope A would stAy.

Well, I cannot compare this book to Hamlet, like some of the other reviewers, because I've never read it. Instead, I'll just tell you this.. I loved it. I loved the setting, the eerie Elsinore Academy. I loved the idea that the main character had to take a medication to keep her gift of seeing spirits at bay. And  Ophelia's mother, the siren in the lake.... wow. This book is magical. Don't get me wrong though, it's darkly magical. This is the story of a girl fighting madness, in simple terms. But this book is anything but simple. I loved every page!

Regardless what your spiritual leanings, this book is an amazing admission for someone who had no such beliefs beforehand. I give the author credit for honestly relating his miraculous experience as he himself was able to interpret it. As far as the "you can do nothing wrong" bit - I would think twice about anything that meets you in the clouds and tells you something like that. If nothing we can do is "wrong" someone please explain the evil done by humans in this world. Perhaps this doctor had some type of experience and perhaps he believes he visited heaven, but being told that nothing you can do is wrong is a stretch for anyone who has ever experienced the thing called conscience. No matter what your beliefs, we all need to contemplate and pray about such things. I recommend Lin Tomasso's book Prayer Warrior: How to Get Your Prayers Answered to help do this correctly. Prayer is a formula, and this book shows how to do it correctly to achieve results. I downloaded it to my laptop (you can download it to any device) for $2.99 at smashwords.com. Tomasso is funny and down to earth, a great read. Apply the basic principles no matter what your belief system. I loved it.

summary: An awesome peek into another realm beyond physical reality
reviewText: I found this book to be well worth the investment of both money and time to read. I won't write more about what is in the book but remark upon one thing; the truth is we can do no wrong, but some of us shouldn't know that here as it gives license to create unnecessary pain when we should do the opposite, remove as much unnecessary pain in life as we can, give as much love as we can, help where we can.We can do no wrong but do as much good as you can.Christopher

summary: Amazing book that should be required reading in high school
reviewText: Dr.Alexander is an amazing man with an amazing experience to share.  A thought provoking book for anyone who has an open mind to post death existence.

I recently re-read this hilarious, lyric,  fact-tilled book, and Bill Bryson remains one of my two or three favorite, reliable, go-to authors for serious reading thoroughly leavened with laughter.  I think I own all his books, in hardback, because they are so worthy of re-reading.  Bryson has a knack for injecting fascinating bits of earth sciences, history, and social evolution into all his books - a trait he shares with another of my favorites, John McPhee.  Any book by Bill Bryson repays reading, over and over.

I find myself speaking of this book all the time and buying copies to give away. The is nothing more real than what is beyond the very limited reality we humans construct and enforce every day. Dr. Alexander shares a glimpse into a reality that challenges all assumptions and pulls us toward wholeness and love. What a blessing to know what he shares and to realize that our loved ones who go before us are very near to us.There are several reviews that rate this book as poor but in most of the ones I read, they did not understand that Dr. Alexander gives words to the ineffable. They fault him for not going into more depth about his NDE. The fact that he even tried to describe it is an accomplishment and a gift. Some critics also dislike him writing about his life but I don't understand why. What he experienced is deeply inter-related to life now and life to come. It's about relationships and how they affect us now and in what will be.

Have recommended this book to many for the presentation of a picture of a possible afterlife. The author's standing as a professional and scientist lends more credence to his story and, while not proving anything, still raises the level of hope among those who are hopeful yet skeptical about such things.
I had a similar expirience and I love how he explained it, I never find words to express what I felt in that moment, was peace, love and I do not have enough words por that.

I loved this book.  I saw Eben on Oprah's Super Soul Sunday and immediately got online and ordered the book.  I enjoyed reading every page and found the medical journey mixed with the spiritual journey to be compelling.  Buy it, read it and enjoy!!

I have read this book through SEVEN times and I still laugh my head off at the antics of Bill and his friend as they hike the trail.It is a excellent book that I plan to carry and read again on the trail when I hike it in 2004. VERY HIGHLY RECOMMEND this book to everyone. Whether planning to hike the trail or not. I would not recommend it as reading for young children as there is some cussing in it.

summary: A true piece of American Pie
reviewText: What I enjoyed most about this book was the writing style of it's author, Bill Bryson.  He is witty, intelligent, knowlegdeable, and easily read, all at the same time.The book (non-fiction and usually found in a travel section of a book store) centers around the existence of the appalachian trail in the eastern U.S..  After spending years away from America, in the boorish land of the Brits, Bill discovers the trail and decides to hike it from end to end.  Initially he has trouble finding someone willing to go on this extended hike with him, but then an old school chum, Steven Katz, calls up and decides to join him.  The two are a rumbling, bumbling, out of shape and disjointed pair that have you chuckling many times as you read on.  Hiking the trail isn't an easy thing to do with your life on your back, or so they soon discover.  But they plod along and along the way the reader gets some interesting history behind the trails establishment, the people they meet along it's course, the states that they amble through, and the general decay of their minds as they begin to see nothing but mile upon mile upon mile upon mile of trail ahead of them.Did they hike the appalachian trail though?  That is a question that each reader will have to answer for themselves.  I think they did.  I've hiked many miles in Alaska and I know what it's like to be on trails like that.  They hiked it!  Trust me!
What happens to the patient when one is in a coma for a week?  This is the framework within much of this book's action happens.

This was a really good book.  The suspense is well spaced to keep you going wanting g to read more.  You are not left disappointed at the end of the story.  I have read two of fosters books and enjoyed both.  I recommend her to anyone who enjoys suspense.

This book will delight and challenge you.  Even putting aside the lead story, the medical narrative is as suspenseful as any thriller.  The detail of Alexander's journey to heaven is astounding and hope-giving.  I will say that the ending doesn't hold up to the rest of the book.  It just kind of ends...like the plug was pulled or something.  Even so, this is one of the best reads in a long time.  Read it!

summary: A must read to get a glimpse of the other side
reviewText: This book is great proof that awareness is beyond our physiology. As a neuro-surgeon, Eben Alexander, gives an objective view of the near death experience providing for those who believe the evidence to confirm it. There are a few near death books that I would recommend and this is one of them.
I loved how this man of science came around to believing and even being compelled to share his story of the truth of Heaven. It will definitely touch your heart!!!!

reviewerName: W. Paul Blakey "of Twin Eagles Publishing"
reviewText: The title is a bit misleading, but the author's experience and his consequent paradigm shift regarding the role of consciousness in the universe (and it's non-locality) is delicious.I certainly applaud Dr. Alexander for having the courage and the will to stand in the face of the scientism that insists that consciousness is an artifact of brain function.Highly recommended.
I found this to be the best and most informative book on nde's I have ever read. Very descriptive and clear.
You have to read it; maybe not just once. This is so well-developed it truly whets the appetite. I consider no one can doubt its veracity.

summary: If Laughter is the Best Medicine, than this is the cure for everything
reviewText: I majored in Environmental Science many years ago. One of my professors had hiked a southern section of the Appalachian trail for his honeymoon in spring when the whole trail was in glorious bloom. It had been a spectacular experience which I had always envied, but never gotten the chance to copy. I'm afraid my Environmental Science Professor and his wife were ten times the outdoor people I would ever be. So this book was perhaps my vicarious trip on the Appalachian trail. I'm sure my adventures would have been similarly hilariously disastrous. I laughed so hard at almost every page of this book, that I probably got as much exercise as I would have had I hiked the trail. If you've ever harbored the seductive notion that getting back to nature is an easy trip, this book will riotously disabuse you of that misconception. If you like to laugh, get this book and read it often. And be sure to keep for those days when laughter is hard to come by.

summary: And death is not the final chapter.
reviewText: For anyone who is curious about what happens to us when we die (and that would include most of us), this is a fascinating and provocative read. Granted, it is nonfiction, and I will take the author at his word on this but, to his credit, the story unfolds like literary fiction. Meaning, it's riveting.What came to mind was a movie-length adaptation of an episode from the television series House: A healthy neurosurgeon is suddenly stuck down by a severe and puzzling form of meningitis and slips into a coma, resulting in a near-death experience (NDE), a preview of heaven, then a miraculous recovery with no brain damage, and the doctor returns to life to tell the tale.I appreciated the medical details the author brings to this memoir - which is not surprising since Alexander is a neurosurgeon who knows the ins-and-outs of this life-and-death business. So the fact that he is the one who becomes trapped on the other side of the glass, or mirror, metaphorically speaking - the doctor now the patient facing death - is a key factor in making this story resonate. If told by a car salesman or motivational speaker (no disrespect to these professions) - it just would not have the same impact.Proof of Heaven? I can practically hear the atheists screaming no! The believers shouting yes! And the agnostics shaking their heads every which way. Why? Because no one truly knows. That is the human condition: to wonder. As for me, the book helps confirm what I have felt most of my life. We have a soul. And death is not the final chapter.Also worth reading:heretofore.
This author is a surgeon.  If heaven is as he describes it, it must be a truly wondrous place. A great read.

summary: A Fast Paced Read Through The Eyes of A Sniper
reviewText: I heard about the book on cspan network.  Once I picked up the book and started reading I was hooked.  I quickly became intrigued with the history of sniping.  The reader is introduced to a Russian sniper who has more than three hundred kills and I will leave it at that.  The book is serious in nature, but also shows us that humor can be found just about anywhere; even on a battlefield.  Coughlin and Kuhlman lead us down some harrowing paths that leave the reader pondering about the brutal nature of war.Shooter is a great read for readers that want to see firsthand what being a sniper is all about.  The book is graphic at times but then so is life.  I would like to say thanks to Coughlin and Kuhlman for the service that they have done for our country and for sharing their experiences.  Great job gentlemen!
This is an amazing story and leaves one with no doubt about heaven being real. This book confirms what I have always believed.

summary: This would make a Great Christmas gift!
reviewText: Very convincing true story of an man of faith and his journey to heaven, I could not put the book down, I wish I could share it with everyone, non believers might have their eyes opened!

summary: I ordered this for my Mother for Christmas
reviewText: I ordered this as a gift. I began reading it, and realized that I wanted to keep the copy. SO - I ordered 8 more copies and gave them to family for Christmas. Pretty neat to be able to contract and compare a scientist's view of NDEs.  THANKS Eben!!

This books provides an interesting insight to life after death and had me wondering why we don't celebrate not only a person's life, but what they have to look forward to.  It would be wonderful if Funeral Homes would offer something more than just the sadness of a life, but based on what people have experienced, offer reflections of another element of life.  As the book reflects, life doesn't end when one dies.  One can get bogged down in the book with some uninteresting facts, but beyond that is a wonderful insight to a credible person's experience.

This is a wonderful "autobiographical" novel by Rosalind Miles and probably the book that got me hooked on British historical fiction and history. I have read this tome several times (and it is pretty big) and have loved it each time. It is still at the top of my favorites list (though it has been joined by SKP's Sunne!)It is wonderfully (and very believably) written in Elizabeth's "voice" and as a reader I could honestly see Elizabeth acting, thinking, and talking like that. Miles really makes her come alive in this telling that covers Elizabeth's earliest memories as a child, her precarious position during her brother and sister's reigns, the tumultuous early years of her own reign, and the numerous issues she had to deal with during her life (from about age 4 up until 2 years before her death). Elizabeth is portrayed in many different ways (flirty, vain, silly, brilliant, cunning, clever, stubborn, manipulative, caring) but they all fit together wonderfully and these different attributes are what made her an amazing queen. I think one of my favorite things about the novel is the humor you see from Elizabeth. I really enjoyed some of her "one liners" and her sense of humor. It really makes her seem human.Through Elizabeth's eyes you get a very interesting perspective on her father Henry VIII, her brother Edward, and her older sister Mary. Her feelings concerning her father change over the course of her lifetime and you really see the different events (and her maturing) that help bring about that change. She moves from loving and adoring him to fearing him and eventually hating him (quite a bit of that is due to what he did to her mother). You also see that she very much takes to heart the lessons to be learned when a woman marries and gives all the power to her husband. She has her mother's example always looming over her, she saw what happened to her stepmother Catherine Parr, and she also sees what happens to her sister Mary after she marries King Phillip. She also sees what befalls her cousin Mary, Queen of Scots, in her disastrous marriages. Who can blame her for not wanting to stumble into the same trap?There is a lot of time devoted to Elizabeth's male favorites, Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, and the Earl of Essex, throughout the course of this novel. These two men played a large roll in her life and I did not mind reading about her feeling and interactions with them, especially Dudley. Elizabeth really does seem to have loved him and wanted to marry him but she knew she couldn't (and wouldn't want to) give up any power to a husband. In her mind she was married to England and England came first in her heart. As to the Earl of Essex, I never liked him and I wanted to shake Elizabeth a few times for letting him get away with some of the stunts he pulled. She even said many times that she knew what he was doing, that her feelings for him had died, that she realized he was a traitor, but she always forgave him. It took a very drastic act for her to finally have him arrested and sign the warrant for his execution.You can't talk about Elizabeth without mentioning her cousin Mary and Miles does a wonderful job of showing how torn Elizabeth was on this subject. She knew that Mary was a huge and dangerous threat to her and was well aware of her plotting to take the English throne. As a queen she knew that she should let Mary have the justice she deserved for plotting against her (many times) so as to secure the safety of her realm. However, Mary is after all an anointed queen (and her cousin) and she sees the danger in setting a precedent in which the Lords of a land can put a queen on trial and condemn her to death. She tells her councilmen many times that what they do to Mary could easily be done to her. Elizabeth really struggles with this for twenty years until she finally makes that ultimate decision. During all that time you can really sympathize with her and feel how hard she struggles with this.This is a wonderful book and I would recommend it to anyone interested in the Tudors. It is a well written novel and you really get a glimpse into what Elizabeth was really like (perhaps) and the sacrifices she(maybe) made to keep England safe.

Great read!  I firmly believe that God allowed this doctor to experience and reveal his findings to others.  I loved how he discovered how science and faith go hand in hand!  There is no conflict betweent the two.  Very encouraging and enjoyable read.

Having read dozens of books about near-death experiences (NDEs) and other phenomena strongly suggesting the survival of consciousness after death, I didn't read this book in search of "proof" of "heaven."  I had already come to the conclusion that the evidence for survival, if not providing absolute proof, at least meets the "beyond a reasonable doubt" standard of our legal system.  However, just as the orthodox religious person needs to renew his or her faith by reading his/her "good book" over and over again and then attending weekly services to hear someone discuss the teachings of the book - discussions probably heard dozens of times before - I find a certain renewal and revitalization in reading newer accounts of NDEs.  Yes, the stories are often similar, as one might expect them to be if they are to be considered evidential, but there is usually enough variety to make the stories interesting, informative, intriguing, and inspirational, what I call the "four I's."  This book exceeded my expectations, for each of those four I's.Because Dr. Eben Alexander, the author and experiencer, is a neurosurgeon who was for the most part a materialist with little interest in the subject of NDEs before his own NDE, this story has even more credibility than most, although the pseudoskeptics, in all their wisdom, were attempting to discredit the author as delusional and the victim of wishful thinking even before the book was released.  "Like many other scientific skeptics, I refused to even review the data relevant to the questions concerning these phenomena," Alexander tells of his own pre-NDE mindset. "I prejudged the data, and those providing it, because my limited perspective failed to provide the foggiest notion of how such things might actually happen."  He now sees such people "who know the truth without needing to look at the facts" as willfully ignorant."Brilliant, vibrant, ecstatic, stunning," Alexander describes the "new world" he found himself in after his physical body and brain completely shut down, admitting, as so many others have, that  human language and ideas fail when one attempts to translate celestial visions and experiences into terrestrial imagery and verbiage.  "We taint, with out insufficient descriptions, their truly awesome nature," he offers, stressing his belief that what he experienced was "more real than the house I sat in, more real than the logs burning in the fireplace."Alexander examines the usual NDE debunking theories, including endogenous glutamate blockade, REM intrusion, "DMT dump," the "reboot phenomenon," and "feigned-death" strategies, dismissing them one by one.  Everything he experienced suggested higher, not lower, brain functioning.  "The more I read of the `scientific' explanations of what NDEs are, the more I was shocked by their transparent flimsiness," he states, going on to say that after studying the subject matter following his NDE, he began to realize his was "a technically near-impeccable near-death experience."In one of the final chapters, Alexander tells of stories he had heard from patients before his experience - stories which he wrote off as fantasy, but which he now saw very possibly real.  He also mentions a very interesting story related to him by one of his colleagues involving "terminal lucidity," in which the colleague's dying father, who had been demented, became lucid and in last moments alive.In his 1974 Pulitzer prize-winning book, "The Denial of Death," anthropologist Ernest Becker stated that the fear of death haunts the human mind like nothing else. Most people deal with this fear by repressing it - burying it deep in the subconscious and busying themselves with mundane activities. And then, one day, perhaps when it becomes apparent that their days are numbered, those repressed anxieties relating to death begin welling up into the consciousness.  They proceed to live their final years under a dark and increasingly foreboding shadow.  For the most part, the muddled information provided by orthodox religion offers little relief, little comfort.  But books like this one serve to erase that fear and allow the person to embrace death, living his or her final years with a certain optimism.  I am grateful to Dr. Alexander for writing it and intend to buy a few extra copies to give as Christmas presents.

summary: A wondrous spiritual universe which can’t be easily dismissed
reviewText: This book should be of interest to anyone who has ever pondered the true nature of the universe, and, in particular, the relationship between the physical world --- the world in which we live --- and the so-called spiritual world about which we know so little of substance.  For, it describes a universe which few ‘living men’ have ever visited: a spiritual realm which differs markedly from that described by any of our world’s great religions.This may present a problem for some readers.  For, while this ‘heaven’ provides possible answers to some otherwise perplexing questions, it also challenges many long-standing and deep-seated beliefs.  What makes it so compelling, however, is that this book was written by a nationally renowned neurosurgeon who was once a staunch skeptic of ‘Near-Death Experiences’ as reported to him over a period of some twenty-five years, but who was forced to reconsider when he, himself, experienced just such a revelation.The author’s life, and life view, changed suddenly and dramatically when he contracted an extremely rare form of what neurosurgeons term a ‘spontaneous E. coli bacterial meningitis infection,’ an infection which few survive, and from which those who do survive generally require constant care for the remainder of their lives.  He lay dying in a coma for seven days while his doctors struggled vainly to diagnose and treat his illness, while, at the same time, the E. coli bacteria was destroying the outer cortex of his brain.  Then, when he was all but given up for dead, he miraculously recovered.  During his seven days in the coma, the author fell into a deep state of unconsciousness, closer to actual death than any other known patient.  In that state, he lost all sense of personal identity and entered into the spiritual realm which he discusses in this book.  He describes it as seemingly existing in three distinct states: a dark and foreboding “worm’s eye view’ region, a ‘gateway’ to an inner ‘core,’ and a ‘core’ --- that being the broader, glorious, all encompassing, universe of God in which he became immersed and of which our physical universe was seen as just a trivial part.The author acknowledges that his description of this spiritual universe is woefully deficient: due, as he says, to the fact that we are so limited here in our physical world that it is impossible to describe it with any degree of clarity, especially when constrained by the limited vocabulary we must use to do so.  But, what struck me most forcefully about his attempted description was the stark contrast between the universal reality which he describes and ‘God,’ as we envision him in more personal terms.  But, as the author makes clear: in our limited physical world, we are forced to envision ‘God’ in ‘our’ own terms.  I was also struck by the fact that the author’s vision of heaven and the soul also coincides remarkably well with that described by the ‘sleeping prophet,’ Edgar Cayce, as discussed in the book, ‘The Story of Edgar Cayce: There is a River,’ by Thomas Sugrue.  It also goes a long way toward explaining how Cayce was able to do the incredible things he did.Bottom line: Although ‘heaven,’ as described herein, runs counter to much of what we think we know, it offers a fresh view of a wondrous spiritual universe far beyond our wildest imaginings --- one which can’t be easily dismissed.

I saw Dr. Alexander on the news shortly after the Connecticut school shootings. He was talking about his experiences, which were comforting after a horrible situation. The book was interesting coming from a doctor dealing with science.  I totally would recommend "Proof of Heaven".
This is a terrific book.  I have never been a believer in life ever after, but this book really makes you think about it.
Enjoyed this book.  Likely a great read for anyone who has lost a loved one or possibly struggling with their own possible death due to age or illness

summary: Affirmation for everything I ever intuited about death; from a man of Science.
reviewText: Beautifully written accounting of one man's NDE, from the viewpoint of the Neurosurgeon to whom this happened.  Such validation of what many people have come to believe about what happens to us after our physical body stops.
I wasn't quite expecting for the story to turn out like it has but as I started reading, I had a hard time putting my kindle down. This book is just super good and very inspirational.
Cathy Lamb has a unique gift for tackling a dark subject like spousal and child abuse with truth, grace, and humor.  And everyone needs a champion like Aunt Lydia in their life!  Good read!
this book captivates your attention from page 1, it lets you live the lives of the characters & all the while your wishing the heroine ends up with her hero.

This was my first attempt to reading Amanda Ashley. When I first bought it I was thinking vampire novel but as it turns out its nothing like I expected. The book pulls you in from the start and holds you there to the very end. Its a page turner and a really great romance. The love shared between the two main characters is breathtaking...ooooh to have a man like that. Anyway, read this book you won't be disappointed.
Was an excellent book holding my interest the entire time and I would highly recommend to anyone who is interested in this present life and the one to come.

summary: One  M.D. that does not rely on Science alone!
reviewText: Excellent book to read. Many medical professionals are so science based that religious experiences are difficult for them to grasp but this book, this book blew me away. Read it and you will agree! Well done

Chasing Amanda is a riveting story. Molly Tanner, unknowingly witnesses the kidnapping of a young girl who is later found dead. The horrid tragedy haunts her nine years later, as her mind is flooded with memories and regrets when another young girl is missing.Molly experiences the knowing, a form of ESP that gives her clues as to the condition and whereabouts of this little girl. She risks everything--her marriage, credibility, and even her life--to rescue her alive.Pros: This book is very well written. The characters are developed nicely, the storyline is consistent and the pacing is fast and mesmeric. The imagery is fabulous. I could picture the scenes quite clearly. It has been quite some time since I've enjoyed a book this much.Cons: Can't think of a single one.Overall: Highly recommended. I was totally captivated by this story and its characters. I also have Melissa Foster's novel, Megan's Way, in my TBR stack. I look forward to reading it!Disclosure of Material Connection: I received this book free from the author/Goodreads. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission's 16 CFR, Part 255 <> : "Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising."

Dr. Alexander tells in such detail what we all know in that deep part of us we often ignore.  The medical terminology is sometimes over the layman's head, but does not detract from a message that needs to be heard.  Wonderful, rich read.  Very thought provoking.

summary: It is a little technical, but it answered questions.
reviewText: Very interesting with proof of heaven. He reports it from an experience with medical evidence. He truly was chosen with a purpose.
This is a must read for everyone.  I found it captivating and the author quite believable.  I would purchase this with the Life After Life book.

This is the funniest hiking book ever. Full of twists and turns, A Walk in the Woods keeps readers captivated and intrigued. Bill Bryson is a great author, but I'd be curious to hear Katz's (his hiking partner) side of the story as well...

summary: Strong proof from a scientific perspective
reviewText: Loved this book and bought one for my best friend.  I found it to be a page-turner with a surprise ending regarding the heavenly guide. More importantly, Alexander's scientific rebuttals of responses the medical community makes to reports of after-life experience were satisfactorily compelling.(On another note: I found some experiential support of chakra energy theory in his ascent from the brown underworld through the yellow spinning place and upward to the vaulted highest center. An imperfect mapping of the 6 chakras but a pitch-perfect rendition of the 3 he recalled.)

summary: A Scientist's Response to Proof of Heaven
reviewerName: Charles T. T a r t
reviewText: As a researcher who has been studying the nature of consciousness and trying to build bridges between the best of science and the best of spirituality for more than 50 years, I was fascinated by Eben Alexander's Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Near-Death Experience and Journey Into the Afterlife.One of the ways we get new knowledge and refine our knowledge about the spiritual is by listening closely to and working with the accounts of people who have what I will loosely call "spiritual experiences."  In recent decades our culture, e.g., has been strongly affected by previously unheard of familiarity with Near-Death Experiences, NDEs.  When I first began working in psychology 50 years ago, I knew about NDEs because I had read a lot of very esoteric psychical research literature, but aside from knowing that NDEs happened and a few of their characteristics, very little was known by anyone, and the average person had never heard of them.  When Raymond Moody published his Life After Life book on NDEs in 1976 and it hit the bestseller lists (more than 13 million copies sold to 2012!), it resonated with people's spiritual needs, and now there is widespread knowledge about qualities of NDEs.One of the things that most impressed me about people's accounts of their NDEs back then was that people with very different backgrounds and religious beliefs, including people with no formal religious beliefs to speak of, described the qualities of NDEs in a similar way.  But if NDEs were nothing but the distorted functioning of a distressed brain, you would think that, like most hallucinations resulting from brain malfunctions, the content of those hallucinations would be very much affected by a person's life experiences, cultural background, and individual beliefs.  That there was so much commonality immediately made a case that people were telling you about something that might be real in some sense.  By analogy, I have never been to Rome, but accounts I have heard of what Rome looks like by people who claim to have been there show so much commonality that I have high confidence that there really is a place called Rome.From my perspective as a researcher, however, there is a major drawback to collecting more accounts of NDEs today that didn't apply when they were first collected.  Back then, almost everyone who finally came forth with an account noted that they had never heard of such things before they had their own NDE.  Indeed they usually had never talked to anyone about what they had experienced, or had tried to talk to others and been so severely rejected (you must have been hallucinating, that's crazy, the work of the devil, etc., etc.) that they remained silent about it, and so there was very little obvious influence from cultural background or others' opinions creating the similarity in their accounts.  Now there have been so many articles, books, TV specials, etc., about NDEs that when you hear about someone's recent NDE, you have to wonder how much is this an accurate report of something that is "real" and how much their experience has been colored by all their previous knowledge about what NDEs are supposed to be about.I am particularly concerned with the potentially biasing effects of previous knowledge because a lot of my early research was on hypnosis, and I had it constantly demonstrated in my research that about a quarter or so of the population could have profoundly real-seeming experiences of any arbitrary nature whatsoever suggested to them by a hypnotist.  I doubt that most NDEs are in this category of the purely arbitrary, all a product of suggestion, even the ones occurring today, but even if a major part of what a person experiences is "real" in the sense of belonging to some reality external to their belief system, still the way they perceive it may be influenced to some unknown degree by the now widespread cultural knowledge of what NDEs are supposed to be about.  This doesn't mean there's no point in studying most people's NDEs, just that we have to be careful about this possible biasing factor.  There's nothing particularly novel about this, of course, people's descriptions of ordinary reality are often biased by what they believe, emotions of the moment, etc.So one way of getting a less biased picture of what NDEs are like might be to simply give more weight to experiences collected in the early days of research, when most accounts were from people who had never heard anything about what NDEs were supposed to be about.  Another way of trying to get beyond such a biasing factor is to study more extreme types of NDEs, NDEs with characteristics that are not all that common or known in our culture, and this is a major reason why I find Doctor Eben Alexander's Proof of Heaven  book of great value.  One of the most common features of NDEs established in the early research, for example, was that at some point the person having the NDE, the NDEr, reaches some kind of "border," or "barrier," or "bridge" or "gateway," and although they want to go on to what seem even more wonderful heavenly reaches of the experience, they are not allowed to go cross this border or go through this gateway, because if they did, there would be no chance of them returning to physical life.  Sometimes, knowing this, the NDEr chooses to come back to physical life, sometimes he or she is forced to come back to physical life even though they desperately want to go on.What lies beyond this gateway?Doctor Alexander is a neurosurgeon, and he describes a seven days long NDE caused by a usually fatal brain infection that, given our current medical knowledge, we would say totally knocks out all the higher functioning of the brain, everything that makes us conscious human beings.  From the outside medical perspective, he's in a totally unresponsive coma.  Inside, at first he experiences his NDE almost like a vegetative state, with no real thoughts occurring in it, and going on "forever," although no ordinary concept of time or duration meant anything to him in that condition.  And yet eventually he rose above this, with assistance that he perceived in a most interesting way  - -  I won't give away this very thought-provoking aspect of the book  - -  and eventually went through a gateway, and reported  an exceptionally profound experience.Because his experience was exceptionally "positive," a word that hardly begin to convey its power, as a human being I want to believe that his was a true glimpse of the reality of the universe, that we're all under the care of a loving, alive, intelligent universe, like physician Richard M. Bucke reported in his Cosmic Consciousness experience, described in my The End of Materialism: How Evidence of the Paranormal is Bringing Science and Spirit Together.That's my personal reaction, but as a scientist, I have to bracket that reaction.  That is I don't deny it or suppress it, but I recognize that this is something with strong emotions underlying it and it has a possibility of biasing an otherwise relatively objective attempt of mine to understand the experience.  So as a scholar and scientific investigator of NDEs, I look at the content of Doctor Alexander's experience, in so far as he can convey it, note the similarities and differences between some other reports of profound experiences by different people in different times and places (like the Bucke Cosmic Consciousness experience mentioned above, or the Darkness of God experience reported by John Wren-Lewis reported on my TASTE (The Archives of Scientists' Transcendent Experiences) site (go to [...] Collected Archives, and select account number 0051, The Darkness of God), and  - - -  Here's where I'd like to say I understand it's clearly connected to such-and-such phenomena in ways that are very interesting - - -  but I can't yet say much more than that this is really interesting, and I want us to learn a lot more about this kind of thing!  I know, this is the traditional scientific conclusion to almost all reports, "More research is needed," but it's true!  Indeed I would say the implications of NDEs are infinitely more important than 99 percent of what we study in science, so research on NDEs should have an enormous priority in life, but that's not the political reality we live in.  ;-(I also give some extra credence to Doctor Alexander's account because he wasn't a "believer," he wasn't heavily invested in some religious belief system that he had a desperate need to prove.  He had a certain, shallow, conventional religiosity from his family background: going to church on Christmas and Easter, otherwise not really giving religion and spirituality any thought.  He had heard of reports of NDEs, but, like too many physicians, who are closed minded rather than scientific about this area, he dismissed them as nothing but the  hallucinations of a malfunctioning brain.  He wouldn't tell a patient they were crazy if they reported unusual experiences to him: in his role as a doctor, as a healer, he would always be nice to them.  But accounts of NDEs were just noise to him, damaged brain hallucinations.  When he had his own NDE, though, that was something else again!So, moving into book review mode, am I recommending Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife?  Absolutely!  Who am I recommending it to?  Anyone seriously interested in the meaning of life, and anyone willing to try to bracket their own previous beliefs and preconceptions and be very, very stimulated...

summary: Fascinating Insight into Life After Life
reviewText: Having read a number of "life after life" books on near death experiences, I enjoyed the perspective this author brings to the subject as a brain surgeon.  I've had a number of friends and colleagues--a boss, co-worker, mother of a close friend, parent at my school where I worked--have a life after life experience so have heard these accounts in person by people whom I trust.If you are intrigued by how physics, metaphysics, and brain science relates to this experience, this author, as a doctor and scientist who isn't very religious, explains how they related to his 'life after life' episode. It is the first book of this type I have read which connects how quantum physics, science and spirituality mesh in this kind of experience.  I read a lot of metaphysics and some physics and always saw their significance in these near death experiences.  The experience supports quantum physics and spirituality.It's helpful to have the author, as a medical doctor, describe his experience and explain why, in clear scientific and medical language, he believes what he experienced can't be explained merely by neurology or medical science.  His experience gives credibility, to those with an open mind, that there is life after life.If you are looking for long descriptions of what happens in the after-life, you might want more.  There's enough in this book to give you glimpses of it.  There were some original insights in this book I hadn't read elsewhere.  I found this book fascinating, and especially appreciated how a scientific and medical mind reviewed the experience and the conclusions the doctor arrived at in retrospect.  It is a valuable addition to the body of work on this topic.

I took on this book as part of a blog tour project, thinking I could squeeze it in between books that I really wanted to read this summer. As it turns out, I was so completely engrossed in this book that I literally read it in a day, taking breaks only when absolutely necessary. Chasing Amanda caught my attention and didn't let go for 377 pages.Chasing Amanda is the story of Molly Tanner, wife and mom, still trying to stitch her life back together after enduring years of guilt over the abduction of a child named Amanda. Molly witnessed Amanda's abduction, and has spent years beating herself up for not doing more to help the girl. She and her family have since moved to the small town of Boyds, Maryland, to get away from the past and start over. Now, nine years later, another young girl, Tracey, goes missing- and this time, Molly is determined not to let anything get in the way of her helping to find the child- alive.I found myself deeply engrossed in Molly's narrative, and related to the character on an intuitive level. Her concern for this latest lost child goes beyond that of your average neighbor; she is driven to see that she is safe, risking her own safety on several occasions in pursuit of information on the child's whereabouts. The character feels like an old friend early on in the reading.The description of the small town of Boyds is stunningly picturesque. The ambling back roads lined with gorgeous forests are lovely to behold, and easy to hide within. There is so much beauty to distract a person from what is right under her nose.Amazingly, this small town holds several secrets that tie into the disappearance of little Tracey- and it seems that Molly Tanner is the only one willing to connect all the dots.This is a truly entertaining mystery, with a good measure of surprise in store for the patient reader. Don't let yourself get too caught up in trying to figure it all out, though, lest you miss some of the fun of the chase.

reviewerName: Donna McBroom-Theriot "My Life. One Story at ...
reviewText: It has been a long time since I have read a book that truly held me captive. Chasing Amanda is a very well written book. The story line continuously delves deeper and deeper into a community of people and takes one surprising turn after another. Just when you think you have it figured out, wham! Another twist is revealed. It is not until the end of the book that the entire plot and cast of characters and their hidden secrets are exposed.The book begins with child abduction, one that Molly has had visions of happening. Unable to hone in on the specifics of her vision, she is unable to help the child. Years later, the past seems to be unfolding before her eyes when another child disappears. Even with the risk of destroying her marriage, she is drawn into her visions and her quest to help find the missing child.I began reading the book anticipating a simple storyline - child abducted, woman finds child through visions - but was pleasantly surprised as the story unfolded. The only analogy I can think of to describe Chasing Amanda is to picture the story line as a maze of intertwining vines leading downward to one stalk. There were a lot of surprises and twists and turns and entanglements with one discovery leading to another, each one more surprising than the last.Being quiet in tuned with my own sixth sense (in my own life) I have always been intrigued with books involving the sixth sense. Molly and her son, Eric, share this trait. While sometimes tugging at them, it proves to be a bond between them in the end. It is Eric, who finally convinces Cole, Molly's husband and Eric's father, that the visions are real and that Molly was in need of help.The use of Molly's visions does not consume the book. The book also depicts the difficulties of having special abilities on a family, especially when family members do not want to believe or acknowledge the gift. Molly's marriage is repeatedly pushed to the brink of collapse because of her gift.The loyalty displayed between some of the characters was impressive. It is very hard to find such loyalty and as a person who values loyalty, I appreciated this part of the story line. Chasing Amanda was also a story of understanding our human traits and idiosyncrasies, and learning to respect our differences.I could tell you a lot more about the actual story - but that would spoil the reading of the book. The book blurb tells you enough about the story, I hope my review seals the deal and makes you want to read the book.
These were wonderful stories.  I wish there was someone else to write another story about.  Maybe a lost brother will show up and we will learn about him.

The sub-title of this book is Redicovering America, and that is what this book is really about. It is also an excellent guidebook to the Appalachian Trail. Since both Bryson and, the by now infamous Katz, are middle-aged and out of shape, it gives the reader a good sense of what it really is like to hike it.Bryson does not do anything half-hearted; he has read up extensively on all kinds of facts surrounding the trail - nature, about hiking, the politics of the trail, cultural history, the US as a whole. All journeys have an inner and outer aspect. The outer aspect here is how it is walking the trail and what you expect to encounter along the route. The inner aspect is that he uses the all the facts he has found out about the trail to make it a journey through the US of today. Just this worry that there have been three murders (five when the book is over) along the trail, and they worry about their safety when Katz observes that you can draw a random line through the US and there have been at least three murders along that line!The first part of the book reads like a triumph - they manage to walk and experience nature in all its glory. The second part is more like a descent into hell: Katz deteriorates, and Bryson continues part of the trail on his own. The trail cuts through more "civilized" areas up in the north, and there he encounters all the follies of modern man: civil war battlefields, hikers with more gadgets than sense, hikers that defy all description, senseless murders, derelict hotels and resorts, and Centralia. Centralia is something you would expect coming out of the pens of King or Lovecraft, not something that actually exists!Bryson can be very sarcastic and cynical at times. I think that that is the curse of the very kind and intelligent man he is (I have met him) - he is very distraught by the idiocy of his fellow men.

summary: Compelling evidence of consciousness continuation after death!
reviewText: I have had several NDEs and all though I am a believer, I found the experiences Dr Eben Alexander had were accurate descriptions of what I have experienced on the other side and were compelling evidence for those scientifically inclined to give reports of continuation of consciousness after brain death another look!
Love, love, love this book! The author has done an exceptional job in relating his experience back to the reader. This is a must read for anyone who needs PROOF!

This should be read by everyone! It touches your heart ,fills your mind. everyone knows of or about NDE (near death experiences) the stories are always profound  this  one is that and so much more. Dr. Eben Alexander lll  writes his experience in a way that those that believe in Heaven will be comforted, but more that the unbeliever  will as well. Perhaps to their surprise.It is all wonderful, and thank you D. Eben for giving this wonderful book to everyone.

And, the reason it is so amazing, it is unlike any other NDE experience that you have ever read before.  The fact that the Scientist/Doctor who experienced this event is the most amazing.  I read it twice on my Kindle and then purchased books for gifts, also.  The first time i read it was for the experience information.  The 2nd time was for the  science part.  I just would like to know, is this man, Eben Alexander still operationg on other's brains?The surprise at the end was quite lovely, also so do order and enjoy this book!
great read could not put it down would recommend to anyone  easy read book was priced well good value buy it

summary: Very suspenseful. Kept me reading clear to the wee hours of the night/morning.
reviewText: Very good read.  Full of suspense. I couldnt put the book down. I read the entire book in a day.

Chasing Amanda by Melissa Foster is a five star story. It is an emotional read, and has a very clear message- get involved when something seems out of place. The protagonist Molly tries to undue a wrong she thought she had made years prior. The abduction of a small child-would haunt her and her family for years. She believes what the man has told her; that his daughter was screaming and flailing around in his car because she `didn't get the doll she wanted', but that wasn't the case. Molly is racked with guilt and turns her attention into high gear when another little girl goes missing in their new town.  She's clairvoyant, but gets very little help from the authorities, and she's shrouded in doubt. The characters are memorable, and some are very rare and uniquely odd to say the least.  The story was chilling at times, and made you grasp onto your own feelings on crimes against children. How easy it is to brainwash a child into trusting a stranger. It also contains a mystery that isn't solved until the end. Very well written and my mind was full of ideas on how it would end. I almost wanted to read the last chapter, which is rare for me, just to find out the ending. It was a touching and sensitive tale that had me on an emotional roller-coaster. Melissa does an excellent job of bringing out the personalities, temperaments and qualities of each character in the book. I would definitely recommend, Chasing Amanda. Laura Helland/Stolmeier
I found Proof of Heaven to be well written and Dr. Alexander's reason valid.  It was comforting to me and uplifting.

The other reviews tell you all about the richness of characters and the fabulous story that revolves around them -- and they are spot on. I will only say that it will be one of the best books you ever read. It now ranks among my favorite books of all time. I can't recommend this book enough. You really do laugh out loud and sob out loud throughout the book.
i love this book. it encourages us to keep reading and not to put the book down.i cannot wait to read the next book in this enchanting series.it is the best book that i have read.
Understandable writing of his neuro problems and his story of afterlife.He was very believable and very wonderful in his understanding of life.

This is the first Near Death Experience retelling that I found credible.  It's heady reading but well worth it.  The appendix which explains the neuroscientific hypotheses he considered to explain his experience but found them lacking lends credibility.

I thought it was amazing how well he bounced back after being so ill.  I was a clinical nurse specialist and worked 45 years mainly in psychiatry.  I am a spiritual person and also have read "Heaven is for Real"

In his book Dr. Alexander's describes the experiences of, and surrounding, his Near Death Experience (NDE). His audience from the Prologue:"I am especially eager to tell my story to the people who might have heard stories similar to mine before and wanted to believe them, but had not been able to fully do so."I am not one of his intended audience since I'm very familiar with NDEs from Moody and others and belong to the scientific/mystic group. Scientific and Religious dogmatists (skeptics) will find no solace in his wonderful story.He tells his story simply and eloquently. I particularly enjoyed his observations about the difference between having/being an experience and being able to explain that experience to others. Kinda like stuffing a million pounds of sugar into a teaspoon. Or as a friend put: "You can know what you think, but you can't think what you know." Thought as a symbolic representation in language is an experience, yet not the same as the originating experience.Additionally, at the end of Ch 28 Dr. Alexander writes:"...I had been alive, and aware, truly aware, in a universe characterized above all by love, consciousness, and reality."This "love, consciousness, and reality" is a restatement in his words of his experience of the ancient Sanskrit concept/experience of "Sat-Chit-Ananda": Existence-Consciousness-Bliss.Dr. Alexander, with his story, adds himself to a growing list of scientists who propound the truth of Science and Spirituality as two non-dichotomous aspects of the same reality.I do differ from him wrt "Evil", in the sense of my experience of: "All there is, is Love. If you are not experiencing Love, you are deluded." Thus I see "Evil" merely as "Delusion", and, still another aspect of Love.For me, the last chapter held a special joy and beauty.Finally, thank you Dr. Alexander for sharing your magnificent story with the world. You, we, are the reason.Om Prema, Mahalo Nui Loa, and Aloha.. Al

summary: Everyone should read this excellent book.
reviewText: Well worth reading. I finished this book in one afternoon as I couldn't put it down. Its basically a story of a physician's journey into the spiritual plane of the otherworld and back while near death in a septic coma and how that experience has changed his worldview.  I've never had an NDE but I've had mystical experiences and it gives me joy to have more evidence that our consciousness continues after death. This book doesn't conform to the biblical description of what heaven is like, so the title may be misleading for Christians. This book is well suited for people interested in consciousness subjects {e.g. NDEs, astral projection, sensory deprivation...) and transpersonal experiences and may help people see above materialism and scientific reductionism. Hopefully it will help alter our collective behavior as a society for the better if more people realize that there is more to our life that this short time on earth.

I was a bit leery at first...missing child stories are generally hard for me to read. Melissa Foster handled a storyline that kept you intrigued and interested all long the way. The characters were interesting, and I loved the spirituality aspect she created without being overly religious or new-agey.Regarding the reviews that noted errors on e-books...I would assume these are errors with the technology, not the editing.
The writing is complicated in his explanations.  Requires some background in science.  I don't think the skeptics will accept his explanation either, but I find it very deep.

This is the incredible story of Dr. Alexander's journey during the 7 days he spent in a coma.  Because he is a neurosurgeon, he explains the science behind his disease process along with what happens to the brain in its comatose state.  His is an fascinating story & it's a mircle that he was able to share it with us!

I absolutely loved this book!  I had zero expectations when I started and it ended up being one of my top 10 books I have ever read.  It was fascinating. It was really funny and I learned a lot of history about the trail, nature etc...Highly recommend!

summary: Not near death Dead and back
reviewText: This man died with having lost his faith years before, but comes back knowing of God and His goodness.  He is a neurosurgeon and dispels the scientific reasoning on brain death and the light.  Among other theories they might have.
Having hiked other trails, this story brought back experiences in a very real way and made me long to do it again. If you read this Bob, let's make plans.

Overheard  people talking about it in the airport.  When they told me it was available on Kindle, I opened mine up and bought it right away.  ...had most of it read by the end of my trip.  Thought provoking.
According to Esquire magazine, this guy is a flat out liar.  Be warned, investigate before giving your hard earned cash to this guy.  $15 million in book sales, there's motive for ya.

reviewerName: Lexxa ""A friend in need is a friend inde...
reviewText: I'm a huge Laymon fan...I've read many of his books over the years...but this one just didn't do it for me. I actually don't know if I can write a true review; I didn't even finish the book. I just couldn't. I was so bored and I found the characters annoying. The story concept seemed interesting, but it just wasn't. I had started reading this maybe about...6 years ago? It's sitting on my bookshelf. I did try picking it up again and starting over, but I only ended up with the same result. I will finish it one day, really only to get another Laymon book under my belt. If you are a Laymon fan, you will be disappointed. For someone who hasn't read anything by this author, don't start with this.

The first few pages of the book start out well and I expected a gripping read. Instead it quickly unraveled into possibly the worst book I have ever read. Poorly developed characters, poorly developed story with completely amateurish, laugh out loud writing. I am quite frankly amazed that the author got a publisher for this book. A complete waste of time and money.

Arrogant, overweight, middle-aged guy attempts hike of Appalachian Trail, quits after only a few days, then spends 200 pages making up for his short-comings in a story that goes absolutely nowhere.  My first Bryson book I ever read, and certainly my last.

summary: Please - what a bunch of hooey
reviewText: I died and was revived.  You don't see anything except a lot of panicked hospital workers when they shock (defib) you and you "come back to life."  I was "dead" for four minutes.  There is no heaven/hell/jesus - just darkness.  People - we are organic matter with a psyche that thrives on our ego.  When you die, you die.UPDATED:  wow - all your vitrol surprised me - but that's okay - I think I might write a book full of a bunch of malarkey so you can buy it and make me rich!"I saw and angel""I cried with my dead grandma"wait - I'm developing it now - keep an eye on Amazon - have your wallet ready!

summary: Falls Short of Its Full Potential
reviewText: I have to admit when I began to read this story I had high expectations. The author had received many favorable reviews, awards, and was heavily marketing the book through various social media. I don't recall whether I actually purchased the book or got it free through a promotion but because it was a fellow twitter user and author, I committed myself, without telling the author, to reviewing it when I finished.I am a big believer in supporting other writers and this is one way I try to show my support.
